#2015-10-31Â 13:17:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ For anyone else who is curious, clara-tools is an experimental UI to visualize rule logic and sessions. (It's what I used in the Strangeloop 2014 talk.) It's not as battle hardened as clara-rules itself but has drawn some interest.

#2015-11-01Â 23:30:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Heya @ryanbrush -- Is there a reason why there isn't a group-by-esque built-in accumulator?
#2015-11-01Â 23:52:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn No reason besides the fact that we just hadn't needed it yet. I think it makes sense and would be happy to include it if someone wants to take a stab at it.
#2015-11-01Â 23:54:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: cool, was seeing max/sum/all/min/average and such, which made me wonder if group-by would somehow be problematic for automatic retraction
#2015-11-02Â 00:02:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Retraction presents some edge cases that aren't trivial but it's solvable in group-by similar to how we do it in other accumulators. Notice the all accumulator takes care to only remove what is retracted, for instance. Group-by is more complicated but I think a suitable approach would work.
#2015-11-02Â 00:03:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Gotcha. Thanks.
#2015-11-02Â 00:04:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: as long as I've got you here: something that's been on my mind that I think I remember reading something on the ML about is: How much can I rely on storing rules in a database, what about sessions? We've been toying with the idea of exposing some level of rule authorship at some point in the future, but either way, we are going to have differing sets of rules, some of which will be generated based on configuration data.
#2015-11-02Â 00:11:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Other random things on my mind: 1.) I've been reading about Jess and Drools, and they have a collect or collectBy IIRC. Since map can be written in terms of reduce, is it reasonable to say that Clara has collect by way of its accumulate? Is all basically collect? 2.) Do you have any suggested reading? I am occasionally flop-sweating a bit over whether or not I should reach for an accumulator, for instance. This is my first time working with a rules engine, and so I am still sort of in the hunting and pecking phase. Not entirely confident.
#2015-11-02Â 00:15:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I don't see any problem with storing rules or externally or generating them, and mixing those rules with hand-written rules. mk-session supports multiple inputs that can pull rules in from multiple heterogenous sources. Note that to load new rules you need to create a new session...you can't add or update rules to a session that has already been created.
#2015-11-02Â 00:16:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for collect and collectBy, it's been a while since I've used Drools but I believe they are basically just the all accumulator (or some other special accumulator case).
#2015-11-02Â 00:18:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for recommended reading, most of what I've found lately subscribes to the approach of rules-for-business-users rather than directed at engineers, so there's not much out there. I think designing rules just follows the best practices for designing code: take the simplest, most clear, and least surprising approach possible...and iterate to improve it.
#2015-11-02Â 00:18:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: yeah, we're pulling from multiple sources right now. I guess the big question was: as of right now, do you foresee any future compatibility issues with storing the value of a defrule. Like, if 1.0 changed to having :lhs {:different [] :stuff []}
#2015-11-02Â 00:20:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ No, I think the schema for the defrule and defquery value is pretty much locked down.
#2015-11-02Â 00:21:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Any changes there would be non-breaking (like we might add properties for activation groups or things like that). But that basic structure of a rule is pretty fundamental to the system, so I don't see it changing.
#2015-11-02Â 00:21:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: good common sense advice. i would hope we're meeting our obligation to keep things clean, but in some cases I question whether I'm taking the "easy" route over the "simple" route, simply because I don't know what I don't know.

#2015-11-13Â 21:04:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ @ryanbrush: this appears to be invalid is there a way to express this?:
#2015-11-13Â 21:04:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ 
[?it <- accumulator
   [:or
    [X1 (= ?v x)]
    [X2 (= ?v x)]
    [X3 (= ?v x)]]]
#2015-11-13Â 21:07:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ the error we receive 
{:type java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
   :message "Only one argument can be passed to a condition."
   :at [clara.rules.dsl$construct_condition invoke "dsl.clj" 53]}
#2015-11-13Â 21:08:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ maybe it's worth a PR but i think it'd be helpful to use ex-info here providing the offending form. we had to do a bit of binary chop to find the problem.
#2015-11-13Â 21:15:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @noprompt: Yeah, that error message is pretty bad; we need to share something better there. As for the problem itself, accumulators can only accumulate over simple fact-based expressions rather than everything in a complex expression. So rather than having the [:or ] "inside" the accumulator, you'd need to accumulate over each of X1, X2, and X3 independently.
#2015-11-13Â 21:20:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ There might be other ways to break down the problem depending on what you're trying to accomplish. For instance, if X1, X2, and X3 are children of a super type, you can match on the super type. Clara just uses Clojure's type system by default, which also works with Java's type hierarchy and obeys clojure.core/derive if you want to use that to logically derive new types.
#2015-11-13Â 21:25:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ here's what we came up with:
#2015-11-13Â 21:25:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ 
[?it <-
 [:or
  [?x1 <- accumulator :from
   [X1 (= ?v x)]]

  [?x2 <- accumulator :from
   [X2 (= ?v x)]]

  [?x3 <- accumulator :from
   [X3 (= ?v x)]]]]
#2015-11-13Â 21:26:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ @ryanbrush: you mentioned derive can you explain how that would work? afaik it only works with namespaced keywords.
#2015-11-13Â 21:30:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Sure. Some users are just using Clojure maps as their fact types and tagging type metadata to them in the form of namespaced keywords, where derive will work.
#2015-11-13Â 21:31:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I think the child in derive can also be an arbitrary record type...it's the parent that needs to be a namespaced keyword. This might be an abuse of the intent of derive, though.
#2015-11-13Â 21:32:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for the model you came up with: I'm actually not sure that will work...or at least I don't have a test covering binding to the result of an :or expression and that isn't something we've done in production.
#2015-11-13Â 21:33:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ right. we're using records and unfortunately that does not work with derive (e.g. (derive Square Shape)).
#2015-11-13Â 21:33:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Another approach would be to break up the accumulators into separate rules, each of which insert some "GroupOfX" type that can be joined to in another rule that combines them all.
#2015-11-13Â 21:34:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ oh i see what you're saying wrt derive.
#2015-11-13Â 21:34:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ re: your uncertainty. well we'll kick the tires for you and let you know if it does work. ðŸ˜„
#2015-11-13Â 21:38:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I know the above approach will work.
#2015-11-13Â 21:38:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ okay, we'll do that if this turns up dry.
#2015-11-13Â 21:41:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I'm almost certain that you won't be able to bind the result of an ":or", so I think the post above is your best bet. The Rete algorithm splits up the or's into separate rule invocations, and there aren't well-defined semantics for binding the result of other boolean operators in general. But merging the results of separate accumulators will work and is something we do frequently.
#2015-11-13Â 21:43:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ By the way, please do report bad or misleading error messages, here or on the github project. I think this is a weak point in Clara right now, especially for new users, so we want to make that better.
#2015-11-13Â 22:35:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ @ryanbrush: re: error messages, we're investing in clara so hopefully you can expect more than just an experience report. simple_smile
#2015-11-13Â 22:36:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nopromptÂ we focus a lot on producing good error messages at work and use ex-info to not only provide a description but, where possible, provide a prescription to solve the problem.
#2015-11-13Â 22:50:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Sounds great! And I definitely agree with the idea of good, prescriptive error messages. This can be challenging when dealing with the kind of deep macros, like what Clara does when building the Rete network, but is an important step forward.
#2015-11-13Â 22:53:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ By the way, I'm planning on moving Clara to its own GitHub project organization and add at least one more committer soon, a colleague who has made some nice pull requests. It shouldn't be too disruptive, but I'll be sure to share here when that happens.
#2015-11-14Â 17:05:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I had some fun playing with Instaparse and Clara recently, so I blogged about it: http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/

#2015-11-15Â 19:17:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: very cool
#2015-11-16Â 11:40:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thomasÂ @ryanbrush: read your blog post. really good. thank you.
#2015-11-16Â 14:18:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas Thanks! It was a lot of fun to write. I appreciate the kind words!
#2015-11-24Â 13:33:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raggeÂ hello
#2015-11-24Â 13:34:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raggeÂ @ryanbrush: are there any guidelines/limits for the number of facts?
#2015-11-24Â 14:40:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @ragge Not really, besides the limits of the JVM. We frequently have 100,000+ facts in our sessions, and I've tested into the millions (although for a limited scenario). Most of the work is done in Clojure group-by and reducer functions, which scale well.
#2015-11-24Â 14:43:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @ragge The only thing to keep in mind is doing a non-equality cartesian join over lots of facts. Rule constraints that join on equals use hash-based joins, which scale well. This constraint applies pretty commonly to rule engines.
#2015-11-24Â 16:21:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raggeÂ @ryanbrush: thanks for your reply, will definitely give it a go for our use case (which is currently around 50k facts)
#2015-11-24Â 16:52:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @ragge Sounds good. Clara's performance should at least be competitive with other JVM-based rule engines and is working well with a large number of facts for us. If you do run into a workload that isn't doing well, please let me know.
#2015-11-24Â 17:23:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â albakerÂ is there a performance measurement of Clara?
#2015-11-24Â 17:24:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â albakerÂ or guidelines, like how much memory you should budget for number of facts/rules?
#2015-11-24Â 21:15:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @albaker I use Criterium (https://github.com/hugoduncan/criterium) against a function that loads and exercises our Clara rulesets to measure performance. I did post the program I wrote some time ago to benchmark Clara itself at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-benchmark, but generally its easier just to write your own test function and use Criterium to measure.
#2015-11-24Â 21:18:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @albaker Some considerations for a memory budget: each condition on a rule will compile into its own function, and identical conditions between rules are reused, reducing the overall size. The facts are mostly just stored in Clojure sequences, or maps grouped by fact type. In general, the memory footprint will be dominated by the size of the facts you have.
#2015-11-24Â 21:20:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I think the best way to think of it as you're just writing Clojure functions and creating Clojure structures. Clara will wire things together, but the footprint is generally a function of the size of your data.
#2015-11-24Â 23:28:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â albakerÂ Cool, thanks!
#2015-11-25Â 16:11:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ FYI, I just pushed Clara 0.9.1 to Clojars. It's a fix release for a specific scenario, but worth the upgrade. https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/dWLm9veo-dA
#2015-11-30Â 17:55:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: Is it possible to use [:or [?foo <- my/accumulator [X (= a 1)]] [?bar <- my/accumulator [Y (= b 2)]]]
#2015-11-30Â 18:04:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: here's a sketch of what we imagine: 
(defrule thing-a
  [?foo <- [:or
            [my/accumulator [Foo (= a 1)]]
            [:not [Foo (= a 1)]]]]
  =>
  (when-not (nil? ?foo)
    (insert! (map->Bar ?foo))))
#2015-11-30Â 18:04:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ We want Foo to be optional, but when it exists, we'd like to accumulate over matching Foo facts.
#2015-11-30Â 18:06:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The best way to solve this problem is to have my/accumulator provide a default value. That way if there are no Foo records, the default value will be returned from the accumulator and propagate down.
#2015-11-30Â 18:07:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ For instance, the provided sum accumulator will return a sum of zero if there are no items to sum.
#2015-11-30Â 18:07:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Funnily enough, we talked about that a bit.
#2015-11-30Â 18:09:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As a side note, you can't quite think of [:or]'s in rules quite like you'd think of or expressions in Clojure. [:or ..] doesn't "return" a value that can be bound to. (In fact, in the Rete algorithm [:or] actually causes two separate rules to be generated for each branch.)
#2015-11-30Â 18:11:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: thanks!
#2015-11-30Â 18:15:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn By the way, when fiddling with this I noticed Clara isn't reporting an error if a user attempts to bind a variable in an unsupported location. This is a bug, so I logged it here https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/144
#2015-11-30Â 19:29:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: that is good to know, indeed
#2015-11-30Â 19:30:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: trying to be respectful of your time here, but another question: with accumulators, can I make a function which produces an accumulator and use that in the LHS?
#2015-11-30Â 19:32:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ like 
[Bar (= ?x x)]
[?foo <- (make-accumulator ?x) :from [Foo (= ?y y]]
#2015-11-30Â 19:32:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ this basically comes down to wanting to tweak the initial value to the accumulator
#2015-11-30Â 19:37:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn Definitely! The accumulators in clara.rules.accumulators are all just functions that return accumulators and should be a good reference. They use constants for the initial value but you can easily pass it as a param.
#2015-11-30Â 19:37:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ asking because all of the examples i've seen are def'd and only took the field to compare on
#2015-11-30Â 19:38:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ cool, guess I could have tried it, but didn't know calling a function in place of a def'd accumulator had any edges i needed to be aware of
#2015-11-30Â 19:38:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Any function that returns an accumulator will work. The provided ones just happen to use fields.
#2015-11-30Â 19:47:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: a couple other small bits - Any reason that things like min/max couldn't optionally take a function to coerce the value of a field to be comparable? For instance, dates. - Using reduce-to-accum seems to imply :supports-retract given that min, max etc. call comparison-based, which in turn calls reduce-to-accum with an initial value of nil. Is that true? I remember reading the pull request a couple of times, but are there any good rules of thumb to use when building accumulators to know that you've supported retraction? Now that I write that out, my other question is: When retract is mentioned, is it talking about automatic retraction, explicit retraction, or both?
#2015-11-30Â 19:55:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As long as your accumulator has a retract-fn, it supports retraction. reduce-to-accum is a convenience function that makes it easier to turn general reduce functions into accumulators by (by default) creating a retract-fn that removes the retracted item from the accumulator and re-runs the reduce. In some cases you can create more efficient retract-fn implementations. See, for instance, sum...to retract a value from a sum you can just subtract the value, which is of course more efficient than re-running the entire sum with the value removed.
#2015-11-30Â 19:55:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ This applies to both automatic and explicit retraction.
#2015-11-30Â 19:57:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Really the retract-fn is just to "undo" the presence of an item in the accumulated value, like subtraction undoes the value in a sum. the reduce-to-accum just offers a "brute force" way to do this for all reduce functions by re-running them. In some very performance-sensitive cases where you don't care about retraction you can skip supporting it, but I wouldn't do so unless you have a special need.
#2015-11-30Â 19:59:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ FWIW, Clara accumulators work pretty much exactly like the same concept in Jess and Drools. You just write the functions in Clojure. ðŸ˜‰
#2015-11-30Â 20:00:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ (Also, I need to drop offline for a bit but will be back on later today.)

    (insert-all facts)
    (fire-rules))

(watch/browse!)
#2015-12-10Â 10:42:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thomasÂ Hi, just a quick question... are rules written in Clara Clojure functions? just a thought that crossed my mind.
#2015-12-11Â 01:44:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas Sort of. To elaborate a bit: The rules are forms, and the rule constraints and actions are just Clojure expressions. All of these get compiled down into Clojure functions in the end, which are executed as part of a Rete-style rule network. I have no idea if that's what you're looking for or not. ðŸ˜‰
#2015-12-11Â 01:46:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn Not sure why that use wouldn't work. Facts that aren't in the session should be seen in the UI. I almost certainly have a bug in there somewhere. clara-tools will harden over the next few weeks but the current draft is very much use at your own risk (although bug reports and patches are of course welcome.)
#2015-12-11Â 01:47:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ By the way: Clara 0.9.2 is out: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/kuy-XPUKzLU. It fixes an ugly edge case of truth maintenance and hopefully does a better job reporting errors in a number of scenarios.
#2015-12-11Â 08:48:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thomasÂ @ryanbrush: reason for me asking is that I was wondering if Clara could be combined with Onyx and make it some sort of Rule/Event processing engine.
#2015-12-11Â 15:06:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas I don't know much about Onyx, but I'm sure you could invoke Clara rules and queries from with in a function running within Onyx. The rule engine working memory would be local to that node, which in many cases is fine.
#2015-12-11Â 15:08:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas Ultimately I'd like to have an implementation of Clara's working memory that is distributed across a processing cluster, so you could just write rules to deal with input and emit outcomes. This is significantly more challenging. I had an experimental extension of Clara where the memory was distributed across a Storm cluster, but this effort was dropped due to other needs. The big challenge is fault tolerance of a distributed working memory. If a node becomes unavailable, how do we recover its part of the Rete network? I've been toying with some solutions to this by mapping Clara's working memory onto existing fault tolerant processing patterns but this is little more than an idea right now.
#2015-12-11Â 15:08:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thomasÂ @ryanbrush: ok thank you, this is something I would like to look into at some stage
#2015-12-11Â 15:09:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thomasÂ ie. read one day
#2015-12-11Â 15:12:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas Yes, me too!
#2015-12-11Â 15:13:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas Poking around Onyx a bit I think you could use Clara as a stateful aggregator of previously grouped data pretty easily, using Onyx's state management/windowing capabilities. So you could have a stream of data, inserting updates into a Clara working memory, and computing results like that. Could be useful to solve a number of problems.
#2015-12-11Â 15:14:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thomasÂ I was wondering if something like that could be done... would be very cool.
#2015-12-11Â 15:18:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @thomas Yeah, I haven't used Onyx but it seems doable from what I can see.
#2015-12-14Â 02:05:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: so, i suspect this might be considered out of scope for clara, but all the same: any thoughts on rule persistence/versioning? for instance, i might receive rules over the wire.
#2015-12-14Â 02:05:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ if this is the case, I may need to for instance, make a function registry so functions within the LHS or RHS are resolvable when I read them in
#2015-12-14Â 02:07:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ is this something you or anyone else following along has dealt with? what'd you choose as a method of versioning and mapping rule logic?
#2015-12-14Â 15:14:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn We just keep rules in source control and it let it handle versioning. I'd imagine a variety of content management systems would be up to the task. As for a function registry, I just use fully-qualified function names from a library, and just have rules depend on a specific library version to use those functions. So not so much as a "function registry" as just using a versioned dependency JAR and qualified function names.
#2015-12-14Â 15:15:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn Of course, a more sophisticated solution could be built, but I've found just using source control and dependency management sufficient for our needs. And, as you know, Clara rules are just data structures that could be stored wherever convenient.
#2015-12-14Â 20:37:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â xandrewsÂ any recommended reading on the subject of rules systems design?
#2015-12-14Â 22:43:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @xandrews: I'm going old school in my reading list

#2015-12-15Â 01:11:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn It's not in the public API, but the clara.rules.engine/rule-context dynamic var is populated when a rule is firing. So you could do something like (get-in clara.rules.engine/rule-context [:node :production]) , which would have :name and :doc properties.
#2015-12-15Â 01:11:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: ah perfect

#2015-12-15Â 01:15:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ It doesn't use meta (but that would be add-able). This might be a good case for rule properties. You could do (defrule my-rule {:cool true} "doc here" ... => ...) This is how rule salience is set but you can put arbitrary properties there.

#2016-12-30Â 23:02:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ just curious what you thought -- took a bit of tinkering to figure it out
#2016-12-30Â 23:02:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ and I guess I don't see why it couldn't be a set
#2016-12-30Â 23:02:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ or coerced into one
#2016-12-30Â 23:02:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ the generated source rules, i mean
#2016-12-30Â 23:05:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn I'm open to the idea of using a set to improve cache hits. Come to think of it, if the code that generates rules produces a set (rather than a list) that is passed to mk-session, then that might actually trigger a cache hit by itself. We should be able to think of mk-session as a memoized function. If passing a set of rules into mk-session doesn't hit the cache then we could probably change that.
#2016-12-30Â 23:06:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ yes, making it a set makes it a cache hit
#2016-12-30Â 23:06:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn However, managing your own cache might be a better idea, anyway, since putting all rules into a set (or doing a deep comparison in a sequence) could get expensive for a lot of rules. You could probably do something more efficient in user code if you know that things changed or didn't.
#2016-12-30Â 23:08:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ i guess my thinking was that it was a little subtle why at first. i opened up yourkit to figure out what was slow, found myself in mk-session, beta and alpha creation, yadda yadda, noticed a lot of DynamicClassLoader business, saw a bunch of eval's which i believe are the generate LHS and RHS fns
#2016-12-30Â 23:09:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ finally noticed we were just getting cache misses, diff'd the generated rules, noticed the order issue, yadda yadda

#2016-12-30Â 23:12:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, that's fair. Just want to understand any performance implications there might be but I think we can do that.

#2016-01-11Â 01:23:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â datajohnnyÂ how can I make this just return the string to the caller? https://gist.github.com/datajohnny/a927c54a56f00035676e
#2016-01-11Â 12:53:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jthomsonÂ @datajohnny: my understanding is that the RHS of a clara rule should be side-effecting. Sometimes, the side effect will be updating the Clara session itself, via insert! and retract!. A common pattern for what you are trying to do would be to insert! a new fact on the RHS of your rule, then query the session for those facts after fire-rules.
#2016-01-11Â 12:54:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jthomsonÂ you could follow one of the examples in the clara-examples project
#2016-01-11Â 12:54:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jthomsonÂ https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/shopping.clj

#2016-01-13Â 15:15:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â datajohnnyÂ @ragge: what I want is to add that record when the rule is true

#2016-01-13Â 15:17:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â datajohnnyÂ another thing is that for some reason age the (>= 21 age) is not working if I set the age on the session to 21
#2016-01-13Â 16:00:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @datajohnny That test rule matches a person when the age is >= 21, so it is only true if such a person has already been inserted. The right-hand side of the rule is just a Clojure s-expression that can insert additional facts derived from what matched. So typically you would insert the person (as that example does), match on age >=21, and insert a new fact if that's the case (like a PersonIsAdult fact).
#2016-01-13Â 16:01:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @datajohnny: If you want to get an idea of general usage patterns, I'd check out the examples at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/tree/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples
#2016-01-13Â 16:04:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â datajohnnyÂ @ryanbrush: thanks
#2016-01-13Â 16:06:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @datajohnny: You bet!
#2016-01-13Â 16:49:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â datajohnnyÂ @ryanbrush: can the rules work with just maps instead of records, I am trying to build kinda like the same thing you had in your latest blog post but instead of grammar I am getting a json payload
#2016-01-13Â 16:56:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @datajohnny: It can use records. You'll need to provide a function that returns a "type" for map you use, which will match the type of the rule. See the fact-type-fn at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/#fact-expressions. There's also a unit test that shows some usage of it at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1977. The test generates rules in place but you can see a provided fact-type-fn that just reads a field from a record in action.
#2016-01-21Â 19:15:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ Hello
#2016-01-21Â 19:16:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ Iâ€™m new to clara-rules and trying to model a rule with a â€œmust notâ€ condition
#2016-01-21Â 19:16:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ like â€œdo not trigger if there is this object present"
#2016-01-21Â 19:16:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ is it doable ?
#2016-01-21Â 21:17:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @pguillebert: sure, totally doable.
#2016-01-21Â 21:24:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @pguillebert: 
(defrecord Foo [a])
(defrecord Bar [b])
(defrecord Baz [b])

(defrule foo
  [:not [Foo]]
  [Bar (= ?b b 3)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Baz ?b)))

(defquery q:baz []
  [?baz <- Baz])

(-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
    (insert-all [;; (->Foo 1)
                  (->Bar 3)])
    (fire-rules)
    (query q:baz))

;; => ({:?baz #crede.rules.examples.Baz{:b 3}})
#2016-01-21Â 21:25:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ With the same setup, but including a Foo: 
(-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
    (insert-all [(->Foo 1)
                 (->Bar 3)])
    (fire-rules)
    (query q:baz))

;; => ()
#2016-01-21Â 21:27:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ There is also [:exists [Foo]], but I am not sure I understand the nuance there, though:
#2016-01-21Â 21:27:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ ok, with :not
#2016-01-21Â 21:28:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ 
(defrule foo
  [:exists [Foo]]
  [Bar (= ?b b 3)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Baz ?b)))

(defquery q:baz []
  [?baz <- Baz])

(-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
    (insert-all [(->Foo 1)
                 (->Bar 3)])
    (fire-rules)
    (query q:baz))

;; => ({:?baz #crede.rules.examples.Baz{:b 3}})
#2016-01-21Â 21:28:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ I just have to trust the magic
#2016-01-21Â 21:28:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @pguillebert: it's definitely taken me some getting used to
#2016-01-21Â 21:29:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ it's happened more than once now where we wrote some rules, had some initial facts, and then a week or two later realize: "oh, this could be simplified a whole lot"
#2016-01-21Â 21:29:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ or "hmm, this record type is too general, we should fan out to multiple types of records in this rule"
#2016-01-21Â 21:40:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ ok thanks
#2016-01-21Â 21:40:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @pguillebert: it really helps to keep an up-to-date graph of the logic, how rules are connected
#2016-01-21Â 21:41:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ this is really a different way of expressing what I want
#2016-01-21Â 21:41:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pguillebertÂ yeah ok
#2016-01-21Â 21:42:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: do you have any thoughts on the following: 
(defn group
  "Return a generic grouping accumulator. It behaves like
  clojure.core/group-by with the exception of specifying the grouping
  step.

  Parameters:

  value-fn - unary function which returns the grouping key.
  grouping-fn - binary function which recieves the current key
    value the current reduce value and returns a new key value.
  combine-fn - function for clara.rules/accumulator :combine-fn.
  convert-return-fn - function for clara.rules/accumulator :convert-return-fn."
  [{:keys [value-fn grouping-fn combine-fn convert-return-fn]
    :or {value-fn identity
         combine-fn merge
         convert-return-fn identity}}]
  {:pre [(ifn? grouping-fn)]}
  (clara.acc/accum
   {:initial-value {}
    :reduce-fn
    (fn [m x]
      (let [v (value-fn x)]
        (update m v grouping-fn x)))
    :combine-fn combine-fn
    :retract-fn #(throw (RuntimeException. "group retract-fn triggered"))
    :convert-return-fn convert-return-fn}))

(defn group-by
  "Return an accumulator which behaves like clojure.core/group-by."
  [f]
  (group
   {:value-fn f
    :grouping-fn (fnil conj [])
    :combine-fn (fn [a b]
                  (merge-with (comp vec into) a b))}))
#2016-01-21Â 21:42:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ What should retract-fn be here? /me puzzles
#2016-01-21Â 21:44:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ perhaps I should be using reduce-to-accum here instead
#2016-01-21Â 22:00:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ 
(defn group-by
  [f]
  (clara.acc/reduce-to-accum
   (fn [m x]
     (let [v (f x)]
       (update m v (fnil conj []) x)))
   {}
   identity
   (fn [a b]
     (merge-with (comp vec into) a b))))
#2016-01-21Â 22:06:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn retract-fn should "undo" the effect of adding an element to the accumulated result. In this case, I think it's the opposite of a group-by step for a single value...which presumably would be finding that value in its underlying group and removing it. Probably not trivial to implement but seems doable.
#2016-01-21Â 22:07:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: the behavior of group-by with reduce-to-accum seems to be doing what i'm looking for by default. am i crazy?
#2016-01-21Â 22:09:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ 
(defrule foo
  [?foo <- (my-group-by :a)
   :from [Foo]]
  [Bar (= ?b b 3)]
  [:test (do (println ?foo)
             ?foo)]
  =>
  (println ?foo)
  (insert! (->Baz ?foo)))

(defquery q:baz []
  [?Qux <- Baz])

(let [f (->Foo 3)]
  (-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
      (insert-all [(->Foo 1)
                   (->Foo 1)
                   (->Foo 2)
                   f
                   (->Bar 3)])
      (retract f)
      (fire-rules)
      (query q:baz)))
#2016-01-21Â 22:09:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ prints: 
{1 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1} #myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1}], 2 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 2}], 3 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 3}]}
{1 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1} #myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1}], 2 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 2}]}
{1 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1} #myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1}], 2 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 2}]}
#2016-01-21Â 22:10:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @devn, no that makes sense. It's probably not the most efficient implementation if you have lots of retracts since it will redo the entire computation. The retract optimization could do something more efficient by removing a single value rather than re-reducing.
#2016-01-21Â 22:10:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ ahhh, i see what you're getting at

#2016-01-21Â 22:11:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, I wouldn't worry about it unless you have lots of retracts and data, and you can always optimize it later without changing visible behavior.

#2016-02-18Â 21:00:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ 
session (-> (mk-session [grouping-query
                                 grouping-convert-query])
                    (insert-all [(->Temperature 30 "MCI")
                                 (->Temperature 10 "MCI")
                                 (->Temperature 80 "MCI")
                                 (->Temperature 80 "MCI")]))

        retracted-session (-> session
                              (retract (->Temperature 80 "MCI")
                                       (->Temperature 80 "MCI")))

#2016-02-18Â 21:12:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @wparker: reading through the issue you filed, and thinking "boy, generative tests in this case would make a lot of sense."
#2016-02-18Â 21:20:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Iâ€™m not super familiar with how accumulators work in the engine, but one thing to keep in mind there is that reduce-to-accum creates a retraction function
#2016-02-18Â 21:20:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/accumulators.cljc#L91
#2016-02-18Â 21:24:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Regarding generative tests: that could be helpful, but I havenâ€™t come up with any good ideas on how to make them (I havenâ€™t thought about it that deeply though).
#2016-02-18Â 22:34:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @wparker @devn A good suite of generative tests would be great, and may have found a number of issues in logical edge cases. This would require generating rules with different criteria and ensuring consistency to really do well, and how to do so doesn't seem obvious. But I like the thought if anyone wants to play with it.
#2016-02-18Â 22:36:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for retraction, Clara used Clojure equality semantics by design. This seems like the least surprising behavior to treat facts as values....just like the number 1 is 1 no matter what its "identity". Seems like the Clojure way to me, and is analogous to removing an item from a map or set.
#2016-03-04Â 17:05:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ Iâ€™m running into some behavior that I donâ€™t understand. I have a fact type of which I only ever expect 1 or 0 instances. If the session has 0 instances, Iâ€™d like to make a rule which inserts an instance with some reasonable default values. Right now I have this rule: 
(defrule default-event-date
  "If there is no EventDate, create one far in the future."
  [:not [EventDate]]
  =>
  (clara.rules/insert!
   (r/map->EventDate {:date (time.coerce/to-date-time "30000")})))
This correctly does not fire if I start the session with an EventDate fact. If I donâ€™t, however, run-rules never returns. It seems to just keep firing. I would expect it to fire once.
#2016-03-04Â 17:07:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ Ah, just found the mailing list thread about this. I guess that the fact gets retracted when the LHS stops being true, which causes it to get re-inserted, which causes the LHS to stop being true, which causes it to get retracted, etc. ad infinitum
#2016-03-04Â 17:17:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ The suggestion is to use insert-unconditional!, but that seems to never fire, even when there are no facts
#2016-03-04Â 17:23:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @enn Hmm, insert-unconditional! should fire in example above if no EventDate facts are in the working memory when fire-rules is called. It might be worth restarting the REPL in case fact types got reloaded (and rules are looking at a different type). If things are still failing and can be narrowed down to a reproducible test I can take a look.
#2016-03-04Â 17:24:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ @ryanbrush I was mistakenâ€”it does fire, it just doesnâ€™t show up in explain-activations. Is that expected?
#2016-03-04Â 17:32:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @enn So explain-activations uses the truth maintenance facility to figure out what is supporting the fact, which wouldn't be used in an unconditional insert. I think one could argue the fact that unconditional inserts aren't seen here is a bug, but there are tradeoffs there. Another use case for unconditional insert is for performance-critical edge cases where users don't want to pay the accounting cost of tracking truth and activation explanation...which we couldn't offer if we tracked truth maintenance/explain-activations for unconditional inserts.
#2016-03-04Â 17:34:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @enn In short, I'd be open to adding unconditional activations to explain-activations, but I'd want to consider the tradeoffs and make sure our performance-critical use cases (some inserting more then 100,000 facts) have a path forward as well.
#2016-03-04Â 17:36:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @enn As for the original problem of an infinite looping rule, this comes up enough that I think we need a better way to expose and explain it to the user. I've seen other engines limit the number of recursive activations to a few thousand and throw an exception with context to explain where the failure is coming from. Tempted to add that to Clara as well.
#2016-03-04Â 17:42:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ @ryanbrush: thanks for the explanation. That makes sense. I was just using explain-activations as a debugging tool, so now that I know it has that limitation, itâ€™s not a problem that itâ€™s not showing up.
#2016-03-04Â 17:48:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @enn Fair enough. I mostly want to extinguish any sort of surprising behavior, even if it is for debugging purposes. I'll think about it some more but won't make any immediate changes here.

#2016-03-22Â 17:03:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ We don't need to retract here. I pushed back against the use of it, but it worked, until we bumped to 0.11.0 of course simple_smile
#2016-03-22Â 20:21:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ devn: yeah, in that particular scenario the previous behavior was questionable
#2016-03-22Â 20:21:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The RHS is retracting the facts that are supporting the truth of the rule in general
#2016-03-22Â 20:22:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This goes against the concept of logical truth maintenance of inserted facts. Retracts will often lead you into bad situations when it comes to truth maintenance. In this particular scenario, the rule shouldn't insert anything because anything it inserts loses its logical support immediately, due to the retract of all the recommendations.
#2016-03-22Â 20:23:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Looks like Will put more details on the Google groups though.
#2016-03-22Â 20:24:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In our use-cases, we avoid retracts pretty much completely. We like to rely on the logical truth maintenance of inserts to do any "retracts" for us. It does involve adding new fact types occasionally, which Clara's default is via :type metadata or the Java class hierarchy (on Java side) or JS hierarchy (on JS side)
#2016-03-23Â 14:01:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Hey all, still out of town but I think @mikerod's answer here and @wparker's answer in the forum are on target. I kind of regret adding retract! at all since it's such an easy way to shoot oneself in the foot. (This isn't the first time it has caused confusion.) I'm tempted to deprecate it, or move it into a specialized package to make it clear. I don't think there is a great way to "fix" retract! when interacting with truth maintenance, since it's semantics conflict with what the engine does. Looking back on it, it feels like it's the equivalent of a GOTO statement for expert systems.
#2016-03-23Â 15:41:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ ðŸ‘
#2016-03-23Â 19:54:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so it is "retract! considered harmful"
#2016-03-23Â 19:55:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ maybe just a part of Clara docs that gives that big warning
#2016-04-08Â 19:58:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @mikerod I am behind on the ML discussion, but I think there was some discussion of removing it altogether. Frankly, I'm really happy to hear that.
#2016-04-08Â 21:58:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @devn perhaps. I think there may be valid usages, but they need to be constrained and perhaps we could see about reporting errors on the cases that have vague or ambiguous semantics
#2016-04-14Â 14:56:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saicheongÂ I have just started learning clara. In clara-examples, the facts that are inserted into working memory are typically record type.
#2016-04-14Â 14:57:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saicheongÂ I wonder if 'primitive' data can also be inserted - like Strings or Keywords.
#2016-04-14Â 15:00:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saicheongÂ How do we write the condition expression to match a keyword or a string?
#2016-04-14Â 16:04:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @saicheong: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/wiki/Guide#fact-types
#2016-04-14Â 18:35:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @saicheong: By default you can any type known to Clojure's type function, which includes the Java class hierarchy (including Strings, or clojure.lang.Keyword, but that's not something I've done.) If you need something more sophisticated, the link @devn posted is a good reference.
#2016-04-14Â 23:24:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saicheongÂ Say I have a rule that inserts a keyword :exceed-cap. Now I need to this keyword to match other rules. Will this expression in a rule match the keyword?: [clojure.lang.Keyword (= :exceed-cap)]
#2016-04-15Â 00:38:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @saicheong: I haven't done what you're describing. You could try it but something tells me that won't work.
#2016-04-15Â 00:39:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ I am heading out otherwise I'd help you out.
#2016-04-15Â 02:51:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @saicheong: I believe the problem with the constraint you have there is that youâ€™re calling = with one argument, which always returns false. The symbol â€œthisâ€ in rule constraints is bound to the fact under consideration; I believe you need to test that â€œthisâ€ is equal to :exceed-cap. Example gist: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/9cafbe73b2c3b99153fd3fcfc8daa4c3
#2016-04-15Â 03:00:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ One thing to keep in mind (without knowing anything about your use-case of course) is that one of the major optimizations of Clara (and the Rete algorithm it is based on more generally) is only testing facts against conditions that their type allows them to match. That is, if you inserted something that isnâ€™t a Keyword into the example in the gist above, that equality check wouldnâ€™t ever be tried. Checking equality against a keyword should be very, very fast though, just something to be aware of more generally. Of course, if your use case is small enough even thinking about that could be premature optimization.
#2016-04-15Â 03:00:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saicheongÂ @devn: Thanks. I'll try it out when I get some time.
#2016-04-15Â 03:06:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â saicheongÂ @wparker: thanks for the tip on using 'this' in the expression. I'll try that out too.
#2016-04-25Â 15:43:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ clara-rules 0.11.1 is up on Clojars. It's a fix release with some nice performance optimizations from @mikerod. Details in the change log: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0111

#2016-04-27Â 20:01:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ No big deal. We are getting a lot of good use out of Clara so far and it is fun to work on.
#2016-04-27Â 20:02:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thanks for your feedback and contributions to it too!
#2016-06-06Â 16:38:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Hello friends
#2016-06-06Â 16:40:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Question for you... Provided: 
(defrecord DatedFact [date whatever])
(defrecord LatestFact [date whatever])

(def latest
  "Accumulator for finding the maximum value of a :date field."
  (clara.acc/max (comp time.coerce/to-long :date)
                 :returns-fact true))

(clara/defrule simple-latest-rule
  [?result <- latest :from [DatedFact (= ?date date)]]
  =>
  (clara.rules/insert! (map->LatestFact ?result)))

(clara/defquery query-latest [] [?latest <- LatestFact])
#2016-06-06Â 16:40:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ This will insert! for all DatedFacts.
#2016-06-06Â 16:42:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Without the constraint on (= ?date date), it will fire only once.
#2016-06-06Â 16:43:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ I understand why this is so, but I guess I'm interested to know what you think about how you'd prevent this sort of thing from happening by rule authors.
#2016-06-06Â 17:05:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ On second thought, I could use a good plain english explanation of why this is the case.
#2016-06-07Â 17:17:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Hey @devn, a good rule of thumb is that Clara will have one activation for each unique combination of bound variables. So when you remove the ?date binding in that accumulator, it just grabs the latest for all records and fires once. If you add a binding in an accumulator, it accumulates separately for each binding (?date in this case) and fires once per unique binding.
#2016-06-07Â 17:20:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Thanks for that explanation. I was thinking about the binding on ?date being a sort of bucketing/grouping operation, so for each bucket of unique ?date values, capture the greatest date.
#2016-06-07Â 17:22:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ using ?date there doesn't make much sense from a practical standpoint, since the accumulator pulls :date anyhow
#2016-06-07Â 17:22:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, that's he idea.
#2016-06-07Â 17:23:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush: a loaded question: any thoughts on multiple sessions vs a single, shared session?
#2016-06-07Â 17:23:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ If you need richer semantics, you can always access any fields in the resulting accumulated value in the RHS, or even use a custom accumulator. But that depends on the use case
#2016-06-07Â 17:23:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ my question is sort of intentionally vague
#2016-06-07Â 17:24:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ the big question is: are there common triggers in your mind for when to split out a new session using the results of queries on another session?
#2016-06-07Â 17:25:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for a single vs multiple sessions, just depends on what's easier to work with. We tend to use multiple sessions since there is very little overlap between them so it makes sense to keep separate. But YMMV.
#2016-06-07Â 17:26:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ But big sessions should perform pretty well, so whatever is simpler seems like a good starting point. We have sessions with 100k records and thousands of rules easily.
#2016-06-07Â 17:27:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ thinking out loud: i guess it's like namespacing or anything else, it's just that there is a pretty pipeline-ish feel to what we've built, and with the number of facts that are inserted for specific rule firings, it seems like there might be some valuable in splitting things out a bit more to make inspection easier
#2016-06-07Â 17:27:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ then again, from the standpoint of providing explanations, there's some overhead associated with passing those facts through to another session
#2016-06-07Â 17:28:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ since, for the purposes of a UI for instance, you need to capture the explanations from different sessions and cobble them together
#2016-06-07Â 17:28:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ not hard, really
#2016-06-07Â 17:28:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ just easier to have the single session
#2016-06-07Â 17:29:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah. The old loose coupling/high cohesion design trade offs never really go away.
#2016-06-07Â 17:29:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Speaking of UIs... ðŸ˜‰

#2016-06-07Â 17:32:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ (Oops....Need to drop offline for a bit here, but will be back on later in the day.)
#2016-06-07Â 17:34:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ It hasn't been a big need for us either, but generally speaking, onboarding people who haven't worked with a rules engine could be easier. I've been thinking about whether it's a UI that I want, or if it's just better editor tooling to bring "focus" to specific rules, or parts of rules.
#2016-06-07Â 17:42:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ clara provides an opportunity to deliver good explanations. so, i wonder about a sort of meta-explain that could provide a more readable version of why a rule fired. I imagine in the above case seeing something like: For each DatedFact (of which there were 10), retrieve the latest fact for each unique ?foo value grouping. There were 3 unique ?foo values (`"A", "B", "C"`). As a result, 3 LatestFact facts were inserted into the session. Since you've requested I focus my attention on the date field of LatestFact in my summaries, these are the date values on LatestFact which were inserted: 2016-05-10, ...
#2016-06-07Â 17:47:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ I would of course settle for: "Me take DatedFact, put unique ?foo in many bucket, put LatestFact with date of 2016-05-10." ðŸ™‚
#2016-06-07Â 17:49:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ BTW, @mikerod && @ryanbrush -- Excited to see the work and thought going into session durability. Thank you.
#2016-06-07Â 18:10:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ devn: I'd echo sort of what Ryan said that smaller sessions can work alright. If you have heavy-weight logic in rules though, it is good to share that if it applies to many other sessions. One idea would be to just derive facts for the common logic in one session, and then insert those facts into another new session later. That isn't too expensive if the hard-work is in the rules that make those derived facts.
#2016-06-07Â 18:11:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ devn: And yes, the durability stuff will be coming along hopefully in a timely manner. I'm working on a prototype for it still currently and will keep design thoughts and discussions posted on the https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198 issue
#2016-06-07Â 18:12:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you have any input there on how you'd want it to work, I'd be interested to hear that too. I have a use-case in mind, but it is good to know if there are any differing needs. I had a really rough demo of some thoughts @ https://github.com/mrrodriguez/clara-durability-demo but that would not be the expected way everyone would need to interface. I was just toying with an idea of being able to use an extension point like clojure.core/print-dup to give hooks for serialization.
#2016-06-07Â 18:13:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In our case, our working memory of the rules session will actually have different types of objects in them, like Java Serializable, Avro, Clojure records
#2016-06-07Â 18:13:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So I am messing around with ideas on how to efficiently provide capabilities to serialize this data when the serialization formats of groups of the data points actually, likely needs to vary..

#2016-06-11Â 00:38:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @devn: There isnâ€™t any barrier to having non-Clojure types in a session. For fields, Clara will just fall back to using JavaBean properties if it can. https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.11.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L165 You might get into trouble using things like Java primitives or maybe a falsey value, but Iâ€™d expect normal Java objects to work. As far as why, I work with @mikerod so I can speak to that; the short answer without saying too much is that while our group
#2016-06-11Â 00:39:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ groupâ€™s code is mostly in Clojure, weâ€™re part of a larger Java system, and our external interaction points involve Avro records.

#2016-06-13Â 03:09:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ http://docs.jboss.org/drools/release/6.4.0.Final/drools-docs/html_single/#DroolsComplexEventProcessingChapter
#2016-06-13Â 03:09:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ 
"Complex Event Processing, or CEP, is primarily an event processing concept that deals with the task of processing multiple events with the goal of identifying the meaningful events within the event cloud. CEP employs techniques such as detection of complex patterns of many events, event correlation and abstraction, event hierarchies, and relationships between events such as causality, membership, and timing, and event-driven processes."
#2016-06-13Â 03:10:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ yeah, that may be the sort of thought you're thinking about

#2016-06-13Â 21:59:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @devn: FWIW, I agree with Mike that the engine and (Iâ€™ll add) the memory are probably the best places to start. When I was first getting familiar with the internals of Clara I found it useful, and still do if Iâ€™m unsure of what some rule will look like in the network, to just create a session from that rule and look at the rulebase generated. That is, something like (-> (mk-session [rule-in-question] :cache false) .rulebase :alpha-roots) and just poke around the rules network generated.
#2016-06-13Â 22:00:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Iâ€™ve found that if Iâ€™m not dealing with the compiler, it is very possible to just deal with the rules network and forget where it came from. The memory is even more isolated in some ways in that it mostly is just a composite data structure, albeit one very much tailored to the needs of the engine.
#2016-06-13Â 22:02:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The reason I put the :alpha-roots in the call above is that facts inserted start there and propagate downward to the children of those alpha-roots
#2016-07-07Â 07:57:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ anyone using the durability feature? want to try it out on heroku with redis as a backend, wondering if there are any experience reports out there
#2016-07-07Â 07:58:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ also @ryanbrush I note that the durability feature is experimental
#2016-07-07Â 07:59:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ what is your thinking about what extra work needs doing there to conclude the experiment?
#2016-07-07Â 17:08:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @raymcdermott: The current durability implementation has some significant problems that are described at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198 . Please feel free to ask questions here or there if anything is unclear. @mikerod is working on a more robust durability implementation that will be targeted at speed of rule execution after deserialization; Iâ€™ll let him speak to the current state of that. Do you mind elaborating a bit on your use-case for durability? For less taxing use cases performance-wise just re-executing the rules from your serialized facts might well be a good approach.
#2016-07-07Â 17:54:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ raymcdermott: Iâ€™d definitely say to suspect the durability of Clara to get a full overhaul. What is there right now hasnâ€™t really been maintained and probably will fail or produce incorrect results for modern-day Clara sessions.
#2016-07-07Â 17:54:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™d definitely recommend reading through https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198 and Iâ€™d really like to know if these goals align with what youâ€™d want out of it

#2016-07-07Â 20:05:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ Serialising facts using transit out to REDIS would be enough in my case. I can imagine that vast rulesets would benefits but its not the case for my first set of use cases.
#2016-07-07Â 20:07:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ I want to make a simple way to check a web user's disposition based on a small number of rules
#2016-07-07Â 20:08:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ with Heroku any dyno should be able to answer any query and obtaining the facts from the back-end should be kept to a minimum, hence REDIS

#2016-07-07Â 20:12:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ so itâ€™s good to understand where the work is happening ðŸ™‚
#2016-07-07Â 22:31:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Yeah, if youâ€™re OK with just running everything again to retrieve your state performance-wise that would probably be easiest. Youâ€™d want to just use your top-level input of course or account for the use of generated facts in your rules of course; inserting logically generated facts by Clara back into a session that then generates facts not in the original session is a problem with the current durability implementation as Mike mentions in that issue. Regarding the number of user sessions, just in case you donâ€™t know, Clara sessions are immutable so you can just have a single base session without user-session-specific facts that you then add things into.
#2016-07-08Â 06:49:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ To play that back my understanding is that I create an empty session (as in (def empty-session (mk-session))) and insert facts on a per customer basis and fire the rules per customer - I hope thatâ€™s what you mean. If not, I would like to understand more!
#2016-07-08Â 06:51:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ the issue seems to revolve around cases where side effects or where establishing truth is expensive in complex sessions but I donâ€™t have that issue - my case is very much operating like a pure function where Clara is simply used to improve expressivity
#2016-07-08Â 07:12:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ dumb question - are the facts from previous sessions GCd? If not, must I retract them? It would be simpler to take the hit on running mksession every time and TBH I have not profiled that so maybe itâ€™s also not such a biggie!
#2016-07-08Â 14:18:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @raymcdermott: Clara sessions are intended to be data structures that obey Clojure idioms, that is, they are value-based and immutable. When you insert a fact into a session, a new session is returned that is independent of the previous session. So, for example, if you create an empty session and insert a fact into it, the original empty session still exists and can be reused. I created a quick demo of this at https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/c6be14cb249d55b6d2e3ff42500a9334
#2016-07-08Â 14:20:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The â€œcom/clear-session-cache!â€ clears a cache of created sessions that Clara automatically creates unless it is explicitly turned off. The sessions without facts are cached by Clara on the set of rules, queries, and session options to save compilation time. However, this cache should never contain sessions with facts. The relevant code for that cache is at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.11.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L1530
#2016-07-08Â 14:21:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara should only maintain references to facts through sessions. Once all sessions containing a given fact are GCâ€™able then that fact itself should be GCâ€™able as far as Clara is concerned.
#2016-07-08Â 14:23:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ To clarify too, Clara doesnâ€™t copy the facts between sessions that contain them; if you have a session that contains FactA and then you insert FactB in it youâ€™ll have two sessions that both contain a reference to the same FactA object. Clara expects that facts wonâ€™t be mutated after insertion.
#2016-07-08Â 18:05:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â raymcdermottÂ thanks - I appreciate the effort put into your answer

#2016-07-14Â 23:20:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Anyone have thoughts on clojure.spec and clara? Also, I was wondering: If I I decided to move to using :fact-type-fn on plain old maps to determine type, would it be possible to automatically bind the syms the same way they're bound for Java beans and Clojure Records?
#2016-07-14Â 23:24:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Mainly, I'm interested in preserving provenance of the data that is being used to create the records. Given what's showing up in alpha10: user> #:person{:age 42, :name "Fred"} => {:person/age 42 :person/age "Fred"}, and the fact that destructuring is going to work with namespaced keys, I wondered what y'all would think about automatically binding from namespaced keys in maps.
#2016-07-18Â 14:06:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Regarding using the fact-type-fn, the automatic field lookup is determined by the type; see https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.11.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L152 So right now the auto field access will just be by the record or bean properties. I could conceivably see this is an extension point if there were use-cases for it. However, I donâ€™t see any reason why you canâ€™t use hash bindings for other types. So, for example, something like
#2016-07-18Â 14:06:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ [FactClass (= ?fieldA (.someNonBeanAccessorMethod this))]
#2016-07-18Â 14:06:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @devn:
#2016-07-18Â 15:10:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mattdarlingÂ I'm actually interested in achieving something similar, is there any kind of field access aside from "auto field access"?
#2016-07-18Â 17:35:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @mattdarling: The fact itself is bound to â€œthisâ€ in the constraints on the RHS (right-hand side) so you can do arbitrary things with it there. So
#2016-07-18Â 17:35:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule some-rule
#2016-07-18Â 17:35:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ [FactClass (= ?fieldA (some-arbitrary-operation this))]
#2016-07-18Â 17:36:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ => ;; whatever RHS
#2016-07-18Â 17:36:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Note: I meant constraints on the LHS above, not RHS ðŸ˜›
#2016-07-18Â 17:36:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ so left-hand-side
#2016-07-18Â 17:36:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So the lack of automatic field access shouldnâ€™t prevent you from doing anything functionality, it is purely a bit of syntax sugar
#2016-07-18Â 17:36:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ *functionally
#2016-07-18Â 17:42:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ That said, no, I donâ€™t believe anything other than records or beans is supported for that syntax sugar now. I donâ€™t think it would be terribly difficult to change the compiler to make that an extension point, perhaps making clara.rules.compiler/get-fields a multifunction (http://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/defmulti) if someone was interested in doing so and Ryan agreed (I havenâ€™t thought deeply on the issue though, it is possible there would be a complication Iâ€™m not seeing immediately).
#2016-07-18Â 18:17:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mattdarlingÂ Got it working as I wanted with "this", thank you! I thought that was just example syntax, not an existing feature
#2016-07-18Â 18:47:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Ah no, the â€œthisâ€ binding and field bindings for Clojure records and JavaBeans exist already and have for some time; they arenâ€™t an experimental feature or anything like that
#2016-07-18Â 18:55:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mattdarlingÂ I had used the bindings for Clojure records initially, but wanted to introduce a bit of polymorphism, so I switched to maps with a key to indicate their type + made that the fact-type-fn
#2016-07-22Â 11:17:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ mattdarling in case you like the â€œsyntax sugarâ€ of it you can also use destructuring in rule conditions the same way youâ€™d use it in the arglist of a fn
#2016-07-22Â 11:18:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ [:my-type-thing [{:keys [x y z]}] (< x 10) (= ?y y)]
#2016-07-22Â 11:18:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so that just destructures the map as normal in clj and then you have â€œdirect accessâ€ to â€œfieldsâ€ x y z
#2016-07-22Â 11:18:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s just syntax sugar though really. performs the same as destructuring
#2016-08-09Â 06:07:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ramkumarkbÂ Hi, I am new to Clara and trying it in one the projects. Has anyone tried to use Clara with Hazelcast as its working memory? #2016-08-09Â 06:08:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ramkumarkbÂ Btw, I hope this is the right forum to ask Clara related questions.
#2016-08-09Â 08:09:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @ramkumarkb: This is indeed the correct place to ask questions about Clara. ðŸ™‚ Weâ€™ve used Clara in some heavy-hitting scenarios, although perhaps not quite as many as 5 million total objects, at least intentionally. In general, my instinct is that bad scenarios would probably be a combination of both the number of facts, the rules, and the data scenarios, rather than just the number of facts though. Thatâ€™s generally what weâ€™ve seen, except in some cases where weâ€™ve had bad rules create a number of facts that was a problem for the heap. Iâ€™m not sure what you mean by using Hazelcast as the memory - are you implementing your own memory as a replacement for the Clara defaults, considering using it in combination with the persistence stuff @mikerod is working on with https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198, or something else? Iâ€™m not an expert on Hazelcast, this is the first time Iâ€™ve heard of it. It would certainly be interesting to me to hear about other perf-intensive use-cases.
#2016-08-18Â 02:01:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ Hello, I'm new to Clara and Clojure and stumbled upon a case, which is expected behaviour but I am not sure what to do with it, so maybe you can enlighten me: I have a rule with an or condition on two boolean member variables of a Java object passed into the Clojure namespace. The rule is if either of the booleans is true, then fire. Now I have a case where both variables are true and it seems that the same rule fires twice, which seems expected behaviour. I do not understand how to proceed as I do not need it to fire twice... Thanks for any input.
#2016-08-18Â 03:34:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ramkumarkbÂ @wparker: Thank you for the reply and suggestions. Will get back after we run some tests and see if we indeed have trouble fitting into a single JVM.
#2016-08-19Â 08:12:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @flavio : So the or is on two different conditions on the same fact? It sounds like this need not fire twice. Or conditions in the constraints on a single fact condition donâ€™t produce multiple firings, that is only for :or conditions that are actually part of the Rete network. I think of something like [:or B C] as firing for all elements of the union of B and C, to put it differently, whereas conditions like [B (or pred1 pred2)] are still one set that just calls clojure.core/or to determine what facts of type B should be members of that set. A concrete example might help; https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/booleans.clj#L41 will fire once per matching Order, while https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/booleans.clj#L19 will fire once per matching NewCustomer or ValuedCustomer. If you have a single fact that youâ€™re trying to test it sounds like you want something more like new-or-valued-customer-basic-coupons in that examples page; the :or condition functionality is really just shorthand for writing multiple rules in a single defrule in the code. Does this help? It is a bit confusing because weâ€™re using the same word â€œorâ€ to mean fundamentally different things.
#2016-08-19Â 08:14:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Also, you may have seen http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/booleans, but if you havenâ€™t that could be helpful. The key point though is that that only addresses booleans created like https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/booleans.clj#L19 ; the way to distinguish the cases visibly is what is a clojure keyword (:or :and) versus a normal Clojure function call like (orâ€¦ or (and...
#2016-08-21Â 12:40:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ @wparker: thanks for your explanation. It is as you say: [:or B C ] is firing as an union, whereas what I am looking for is [B (or pred1 pred2)]
#2016-08-22Â 13:26:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ramji013Â Hi All, I have posted my query in different group instead Clara. Anyone in the group please help to look into this. regarding 2nd question, we have found the answer. response type of queryString() from QueryResult is Object type, that can be typecasted to respective object. https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/clojurescript/p1471836222005217
#2016-08-22Â 15:20:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Hi @ramji013, if you're having a specific issue the best way to troubleshoot is to post a minimal runnable example that shows the problem you're having, possibly as a gist or issue on github. def'd variables should be visible from within rules; we do it frequently. If you're doing something in ClojureScript I'm less sure, since I haven't used that in earnest.
#2016-08-22Â 15:21:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for getting to nested fields, you can use Clojure's destructuring to get to the top-level field (or fact itself), and then access nested fields just using Clojure expressions as part of the rule left-hand side. Some details on restructuring are here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/
#2016-08-22Â 15:27:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ An announcement: Clara 0.12.0 has been released!
