#2016-08-29Â 15:38:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ramji013Â Hi All, I am new to Clara rules. One of my usecase I supposed to iterate list of object and perform validations in clojure. Anyone could you please suggest an approach, how it can be done?
#2016-08-30Â 08:49:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @ramji013 : It seems like something like (filter valid-object? object) if you just want the collection of invalid objects or something like (when (some invalid-object? objects) (throw code-to-create-exception-here)) if you want to fail on an invalid object would work if you have a simple predicate. From your comment Iâ€™m not sure why Clara would be helpful. Perhaps there is some other complication to your use-case though.
#2016-08-31Â 13:17:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ ramji013 without a little more context, it is hard to assist much, as wparker pointed out. I will also add that if you have large collections of objects though, it is often better to insert them all into the Clara session separately or â€œextractâ€ them in a rule and perform the inserts in the RHS (right-hand side) of the rule. From there you can assert the validity of objects in a object-at-a-time sort of pattern matching. This can be helpful if you wish to then perform joins to/assertions with types of objects in the sessionâ€™s working memory with these objects that you have decided were â€œvalid".
#2016-09-03Â 07:59:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ hello all, I am experimenting with accumulators and face following problem where I would need your expertise. I have following rule: (def oldest-person (acc/max :age :returns-fact true)) (defrule get-oldest-person [?senile-person <- oldest-person :from [Person (= ?name name)]] => (println (str "The oldest person is aged " (.getAge ?senile-person) ". The person's name is " ?name)) ) The Person fact is a java bean. The accumulator doesn't seem to do anything with the :age variable, as the output is not accumulated: The oldest person is aged 50. The person's name is Person 3 The oldest person is aged 150. The person's name is Person 4 The oldest person is aged 200. The person's name is Person 1 The oldest person is aged 100. The person's name is Person 2 I suspect I am not passing the right variable binding to the accumulator, but I am not sure what to change. (.getAge) instead of :age throws an exception when compiling. Thanks for any pointers.
#2016-09-04Â 00:54:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @flavio Do you mean that you were trying to do something like (def oldest-person (acc/max (.getAge) :returns-fact true)) ? (.getAge) isnâ€™t a valid Clojure expression; an interop form needs a target to invoke on. http://clojure.org/reference/java_interop might be helpful if youâ€™re unfamiliar. Introducing the ?name binding in the accumulator will cause you to accumulate once per name, which doesnâ€™t seem like what you would want in this example case. As chance would have it, I have a PR open to clara-site that discusses the subject. https://github.com/rbrush/clara-site/pull/8
#2016-09-04Â 00:57:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ That grouping behavior isnâ€™t new to 0.12, but there were some bugs around it before that were fixed in 0.12
#2016-09-04Â 15:30:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ @wparker , thanks for the updated documentation on the accumulators. This explains the constraint part of the accumulator. I have now successfully run following example: (defrule get-old-person-count [?old-person-count <- (acc/count) :from [Person]] => (println (str "The number of elderly persons is " ?old-person-count)) ) Which returns the number of Person facts as expected. However, I am still struggling with accumulators expecting a field to work with: (defrule get-old-person-max-age [?oldest-age <- (acc/max :age ) :from [Person]] => (println (str "The oldest person is aged: " ?oldest-age)) ) Above rule throws a null pointer exception as it doesn't know what :age is. My question is how can I pass a field name to an accumulator where the field name comes from a Java Bean. I went through the Interop documentation multiple times but I can't seem to get it right. Thanks
#2016-09-05Â 08:38:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Iâ€™d surmise that youâ€™re doing numeric comparisons on nil, though I canâ€™t be sure without a stack trace. You probably need something like (def oldest-person (acc/max #(.getAge %) :returns-fact true)). In your original you use :age as a function, but when you look a keyword up on something that is not a Clojure map you just get nil. You can refer to fields by name in Clara rules and queries due to some special handling by Claraâ€™s compiler, but that isnâ€™t the case when you define accumulators, which are really just maps of keywords to Clojure functions if you take a look at what the value of oldest-person ends up being in a REPL.
#2016-09-05Â 08:38:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @flavio
#2016-09-05Â 08:56:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ @wparker: thanks a lot for the response, this was the syntax I was looking for. I couldn't find it on the Java interop page.
#2016-09-07Â 14:12:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ flavio is you want to avoid reflection, youâ€™ll have to type-hint the .getAge call too
#2016-09-07Â 14:13:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Same as any other Clojure expression and Java interop
#2016-09-08Â 12:31:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ @mikerod, is it generally good practise to type-hint for perfomance reasons? Are you guys recommending it? or, why should I not do it?
#2016-09-08Â 20:59:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I suggest reading https://kotka.de/blog/2012/06/Did_you_know_IX.html . A very short explanation is that the JVM can compile something like (.someMethod x) to run faster if the type of x is known at compile time. In absolute terms, though, even without type hints the calls are still fast. In our codebase we make a point of avoiding reflection since 1. We work at a very large scale that makes such bottlenecks matter. 2. It is easier to avoid reflection entirely than to have to release our code again when it turns out there is a major perf problem. What you should do depends on your use-case and the attendant tradeoffs; some people donâ€™t (and shouldnâ€™t for their use-cases) care about reflection
#2016-09-14Â 15:57:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @flavio yeah, I would say that reflection does have a significant performance penalty, but all of what Will had to say about it is probably the standard advice there.
#2016-09-14Â 15:58:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, see the official Clojure stance http://clojure.org/reference/java_interop#typehints which I believe is written by Rich himself
#2016-09-14Â 15:59:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In our applications, we donâ€™t want to risk/spend the performance penalty though, so we aggressively eliminate reflection warnings. The Clara compiler does give some effort in ensuring type hints are automatically added where the Clara compiler can effectively infer the types. However, that only goes so far.
#2016-09-17Â 06:36:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flavioÂ Thanks for the advice. Will definitely try to avoid reflection.

#2016-09-20Â 09:03:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @ramkumarkb : If you mean that the facts are Java objects, I donâ€™t see any barrier to that; JavaBeans are a very normal Clara fact. If you mean working in Clojure with a Java session of the sort in the docs you linked, you can interact with it via Clojureâ€™s Java interop; see https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_java.clj#L42 for an example
#2016-09-20Â 16:05:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @devn I think https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/inspect.clj#L67 has the info youâ€™d need for truth maintenance governed facts anyway, clara-tools builds on this https://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/impl/facts.clj
#2016-09-20Â 16:06:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ My understanding is that this ultimately works because Clara stores logical insertions in the activation-memory

#2016-09-23Â 20:08:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @wparker you specifically said in the above "the info you'd need for truth maintenance governed facts"
#2016-09-23Â 20:09:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ it got me wondering about some of our logic. there are places in our rules where im thinking unconditional insertion would improve our ability to reason about the rules
#2016-09-23Â 20:09:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ it's kind of a place to hang your hat: "You can always rely on me being there. Nothing can undo this."
#2016-09-23Â 20:10:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ It strikes me a bit like the convention of using do--- on functions which have side effects
#2016-09-23Â 20:11:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ in the same way, im thinking about unconditional insertion to mark the territory of where branching will never happen, or ought to be expected not to happen
#2016-09-27Â 10:45:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @devn the reason for truth maintenance governed facts to have more information available is that when facts are inserted using truth maintenance, the memory stores information to the effective of â€œthis fact was inserted from this rule based on X other factsâ€. The code in the memory is at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.12.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/memory.cljc#L685 This is only called if truth maintenance is used; if you use unconditional insertions it wonâ€™t be. You can see the conditional on that at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.12.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L228 It is a little confusing because the ProductionNode will add â€œactivationsâ€ in any case, but Clara batches insertions from them in the activation-memory as a sort of queue, then pops them off when you call fire-rules https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.12.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1483 As far as the reasoning behind this, truth maintenance does have some performance cost. If you do want to keep track of unconditional assertions, I suspect a way to do it with listeners could be found.
#2016-09-27Â 10:52:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ As far as simplicity, Iâ€™d suggest keeping in mind that rules can fire based on intermediate state in the rules engine that wonâ€™t be reflected in the final state after the fire-rules loop finishes, and unconditional insertions can thus reflect such intermediate state. In our case, we have a mostly stark dividing line between â€œtypes of facts that can be inserted from outside the sessionâ€ and â€œfacts that can be created by rulesâ€; our unconditional insertions tend to be from rules whose LHS looks for things of the former types. Thinking through how the intermediate state of the rules engine will play out can get pretty tricky and may be non-guaranteed behavior depending on the use case. There are certainly many legitimate use cases for unconditional insertions though.
#2016-10-18Â 13:00:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tbrookeÂ I started playing with the protege IDE associated with Rete4frames https://github.com/rururu/rete4frames and wondered about using protege with Clara -I am not sure how it is integrated but it might be a nice way to build up an ontology for use in a Clara rules system
#2016-10-19Â 15:40:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @tbrooke I haven't used Protege, so it's not obvious to me how this would plug in. Clara's core Rete implementation could be invoked by external tools that generate rules. Most of our usage of Clara is based around rules working with arbitrary Clojure records rather than specialized templates or RDF-style tuples, so we typically use a more conventional development environment.
#2016-10-19Â 15:42:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ That said, a template-style approach could certainly use Clara's rete implementation. To illustrate this, rules could be generated from an external structure like how I describe here: http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ So some front end tool could produce the rule structure that is then converted to Clara rules using a pattern similar to that post.
#2016-10-23Â 02:27:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Anyone made a clara app with reagent yet? ðŸ˜„
#2016-10-25Â 08:18:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The (experimental) clara-tools project uses Reagent https://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools, but it is focused on displaying the logic from a JVM rules session, not using rules in cljs to drive an application. Iâ€™d be curious too if there is any such usage.
#2016-10-28Â 03:12:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ramkumarkbÂ @wparker: Hi William, With reference to your discussion thread on conditional activation: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/clara-rules/conditional$20activation%7Csort:relevance/clara-rules/w_Iq7zom2bU/OFcbeFZlCwAJ We have a similar requirement when we want to fire rule-3, when either rule-1 or rule-2 does not fire for a fact of TypeA We find that the [:not [Logicamarker ]] approach is not working as it appears that RETE engine fires the rule bcos before the rule-1 or rule-2 creates the LogicalMarker, rule-3 LHS seems to be satisfied. Any tips would be really helpful. (defrecord LogicalMarker [marker prop1 prop2] (defrule rule-1 [?a <- TypeA (= ?prop1 prop1) (= ?prop2 prop2)] [?x <- TypeX] => (insert! (map->LogicalMarker {:marker "1" :prop1 ?prop1 :prop2 ?prop2})) (defrule rule-2 [?a <- TypeA (= ?prop1 prop1) (= ?prop2 prop2)] [?y <- TypeY] => (insert! (map->LogicalMarker {:marker "2" :prop1 ?prop1 :prop2 ?prop2})) (defrule rule-3 [?a <- TypeA (= ?prop1 prop1) (= ?prop2 prop2)] [:not [LogicalMarker (= ?prop1 :prop1) (= ?prop2 :prop2)]] => (println "Conditional Rule executed successfully!")
#2016-10-28Â 18:59:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Hey @ramkumarkb, I posted a response on the Google Group thread. Hopefully that helps.
#2016-11-11Â 14:47:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Hey everyone, a quick announcement regarding Clara: we've been using it heavily in production at Cerner for some time, so we're making it official an open source project sponsored by Cerner.
#2016-11-11Â 14:48:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ You can see the announcement here: http://engineering.cerner.com/blog/clara-rules-joins-cerner-open-source/
#2016-11-11Â 14:49:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ This is a good thing for Clara. It reflects its importance to our production systems, and shows this project will be maintained far into the future. Otherwise, not much else will change from the users' perspective; it's the same code in a new location, with all future releases in the com.cerner group on Clojars.
#2016-11-16Â 22:21:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ I think Iâ€™m missing something with accumulators - Iâ€™d like to have some sort of collection of reasons that something failed
#2016-11-16Â 22:21:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ Originally I thought the best way to do that would be to have rules for each mode of failure
#2016-11-16Â 22:21:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ And those rules would add a fact with a reason
#2016-11-16Â 22:22:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ Test code here: 
(defrecord DomainObject [name1 name2])
(defrecord Invalid [reason])

(defrule name1-not-test
  [DomainObject (not= name1 "test")]
  =>
  (insert! (->Invalid "test")))

(defrule name2-is-test
  [DomainObject (= name2 "test")]
  =>
  (insert! (->Invalid "name2 test")))

(defrule collect-invalids
  [?reasons <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]]
  =>
  (prn "Invalid for: " (map :reason ?reasons)))
#2016-11-16Â 22:22:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ When run with: 
(-> (mk-session 'clara-playground.core)
                           (insert (->DomainObject "nottest" "test"))
                           (fire-rules))
#2016-11-16Â 22:22:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ The output is 
"Invalid for: " ()
"Invalid for: " ("test" "name2 test")
#2016-11-16Â 22:22:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ After reading more on the accumulator side, I added a restriction
#2016-11-16Â 22:22:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ And rewrote collect-invalids as 
(defrule collect-invalids
  [?reasons <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid (= ?reason reason)]]
  =>
  (prn "Invalid for: " (map :reason ?reasons)))
#2016-11-16Â 22:23:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ But that output is 
"Invalid for: " ("test")
"Invalid for: " ("name2 test")
#2016-11-16Â 22:23:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ Any suggestions on what Iâ€™m missing?
#2016-11-16Â 22:24:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ If itâ€™s unclear, I want collect-invalids to fire a single time, with all the reasons
#2016-11-16Â 22:29:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â surreal.analysisÂ Or is this something thatâ€™s better left to queries?
#2016-11-17Â 09:31:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @surreal.analysis I think this is expected behavior. The contract from Clara is that the state after all rules finish firing will be consistent with the rules, but the steps Clara takes to get there inside fire-rules are undefined except if you provide salience. Your print statements are reflecting intermediate state in the rules engine that is eliminated before fire-rules returns. So in your first example, collect-invalids fired with no Invalid facts because none had been created yet; once Invalid facts were created it fired with them. If collect-invalids had inserted other fact(s) the facts inserted by the firing with no Invalid facts yet would be removed before fire-rules returned to the caller. For something like this Iâ€™d suggest using queries or inserting another fact using insert! since these will be adjusted by the truth maintenance system when Invalid facts are added to the session.
#2016-11-17Â 09:32:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So something like (defquery invalid-query â€œquery for Invalidâ€ [Invalid (= reason ?reason)])
#2016-11-17Â 09:32:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Or (defrecord CollectedInvalid [all-invalid-reasons])
#2016-11-17Â 09:33:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule get-all-invalid [?invalids <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]] => ;; for exame
#2016-11-17Â 09:33:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ ``
#2016-11-17Â 09:33:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule get-all-invalid [?invalids <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]] =>
#2016-11-17Â 09:34:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ => ;; do something here that doesnâ€™t depend on intermediate state
#2016-11-17Â 09:34:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Ignore "(defrule get-all-invalid [?invalids <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid]] => ;; for exame [9:33] ``â€ please, I was trying to set up a code block but apparently donâ€™t know how to do so in Slack ðŸ˜›
#2016-11-17Â 09:35:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ When you did
#2016-11-17Â 09:35:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule collect-invalids [?reasons <- (acc/all) :from [Invalid (= ?reason reason)]] => (prn "Invalid for: " (map :reason ?reasons)))
#2016-11-17Â 09:37:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ You donâ€™t fire when there are no Invalid facts since ?reason is not bound elsewhere (this is the behavior as of 0.12.0 at least, we fixed some bugs around accumulators that release). However, the effect of adding the ?reason binding in the accumulator condition is that you collect all Invalid facts for each reason and fire once per distinct reason.
#2016-11-17Â 09:38:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So something like (defrule get-windspeeds-at-location [?wind <- (acc/all) :from [WindSpeed (= ?location location)]] => ;; do something )
#2016-11-17Â 09:39:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ given four windspeeds, where two come from LocationA and two come from LocationB, would fire twice, once with ?wind bound to the WindSpeed from LocationA and once with ?wind bound to the WindSpeed facts from LocationB
#2016-11-17Â 09:41:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Hopefully this clears things up, please ask if it doesnâ€™t and if anyone has thoughts on things at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/ that could be cleared up to reduce confusion Iâ€™d be interested
#2016-11-23Â 21:41:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Query on queries: Iâ€™d like to find all the facts in the session of type MyFact, where myfact looks like this: #MyFact{:stuff #{{:a 1} {:b #AnotherFact{:c true}}}
#2016-11-23Â 21:42:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Iâ€™d only like to find MyFact where #AnotherFact{:c true}
#2016-11-23Â 22:20:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ Itâ€™s unclear to me how parameterization of queries works. I have an arg :?foo to the query which is a keyword, but it does not correspond to a field on the fact.
#2016-11-23Â 22:30:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Query parameters just check for equality on a bound variable. So to query on a value in a nested structure, you'll need to bind that value itself to a variable. You can do this by just having an expression on the left-hand side that gets the nested field, e.g. (= ?foo (some-expr-to-get-a-value this).
#2016-11-23Â 22:37:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush ok that makes sense, but what if I need the parameter as an argument to the expr that retrieves a value?
#2016-11-23Â 22:37:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ (= ?foo (get-in [:a ?foo :b] some-declared-field-on-the-toplevel-record))
#2016-11-23Â 22:38:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ where ?foo is the parameter (defquery myquery [:?foo] â€¦)
#2016-11-23Â 22:41:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, queries only do equality checks on bound variables. You could either bind all combinations of the nested path if it's small enough, or have your query return more than you need and filter it out afterwards, or consider other ways to model the data. Not sure what would work best for your model.
#2016-11-23Â 22:43:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush ok, thatâ€™s kind of where i guessed we were heading. though i dont totally grok the binding of all combinations of the nested path.
#2016-11-23Â 22:46:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ the use case is that thereâ€™s a blob of :contributing-facts that gets populated by a big collection of prior rules firing, and i want to write a query that finds all of the facts where the thing that contributed is :x. short of writing a ton of queries, or generating them dynamically, iâ€™m not sure that changing the model will help much. this is the typical â€œletâ€™s have one place where we can dump a grab bag of metadataâ€
#2016-11-23Â 22:57:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, I suspect having a function that scans query results, or finding another way to bind your additional criteria, would be your best bet.
#2016-11-23Â 22:58:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ @ryanbrush thanks for the help
#2016-11-23Â 22:58:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Sure thing!
#2016-11-25Â 00:39:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nlessaÂ Hi, is there any way to set an observable to a clara session to get any new insertion/rectraction fo facts? (I am wondering if it would be possible to use a clara session as a source of a stream of facts).
#2016-11-25Â 11:58:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @nlessa Clara only returns new sessions in response to external calls to insert, retract, fire-rules etc. so if youâ€™re looking to listen for changes in response to those actions Iâ€™d suggest just querying the session after those calls. It is also possible to add arbitrary listeners to a session - you can see the protocol at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/listener.cljc and an example that simply records all operations listened upon at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.clj - but keep in mind that listeners often take you into internal implementation details that could change. Also Clara sessions are immutable, in keeping with typical Clojure data structure semantics. Inserting/retracting facts and firing rules returns a new session with the relevant operation applied but leaves the original unchanged. It might be possible to give a better answer if we had a better idea what youâ€™re trying to accomplish.
#2016-11-29Â 20:05:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nlessaÂ Hi @wparker, thanks for your explanation. What I had thought was to try to treat a session as a source of streaming data. As soon as a new fact is inserted/retracted another job would examine it and take another necessary actions. I see that I can easily obtain a similar effect composing the insert! with sending the fact to a Kafka cluster (for example) but not sure how to deal with the retracts that happens automatically in a clara session.
#2016-11-30Â 13:41:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I think comparing the result of queries, which will reflect the state of the session before and after you fire rules, is what youâ€™re looking for. So if you have something like
#2016-11-30Â 13:42:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule lousy-weather-rule [?c <- Cold] => (insert! (->LousyWeather)))
#2016-11-30Â 13:42:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defquery lousy-weather-query â€œâ€ [] [LousyWeather])
#2016-11-30Â 13:42:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Then (def empty-session (mk-session [lousy-weather-rule lousy-weather-query]))
#2016-11-30Â 13:43:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (query empty-session lousy-weather-query) will return nothing
#2016-11-30Â 13:43:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ However, (def not-empty-session (-> empty-session (insert (->Cold)) fire-rules))
#2016-11-30Â 13:43:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (query not-empty-session lousy-weather-query) would find a LousyWeather fact
#2016-11-30Â 13:44:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ You could query both before and after inserting/retracting + firing rules afterward and see what changed, then dispatch on that
#2016-11-30Â 13:48:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ One perhaps non-obvious part of this is when you query the session, youâ€™re not actually performing much work since Clara basically computes the results for queries after fire-rules. When you run a query youâ€™re really basically retrieving the results already computed with a little data manipulation to get just the bindings you use in your query. You can see that implementation at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.13.0-RC4/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1605
#2016-11-30Â 13:50:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Basically a query and a rule look the same to the rules engine mostly when you look at determine what facts match, a rule just does more things (i.e. it is activated and can insert more facts) once you find matches
#2016-11-30Â 13:54:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ You can think of it as large trees of the different node types in engine.cljc where ProductionNode corresponds to rules, QueryNode corresponds to queries, facts are given to the root nodes of these trees and passed down to the leaf nodes, which are ProductionNodes and QueryNodes
#2016-11-30Â 13:57:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Just comparing the results before and after for the queries would work, albeit somewhat inefficiently since youâ€™d be performing work even when nothing at all changed. I think there are ways Clara could return changes in queries more efficiently than that if you were interested in contributing an enhancement like that though.
#2016-11-30Â 13:57:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @nlessa

(deffact FooFact
  â€œBlah blah"
  (alias foo-fact

  (field some_id :spec string? :doc â€œblah blahâ€)

  (variant InterestingFooFact
    (field additional_field :spec number? :doc â€œâ€¦â€)))

#2017-01-14Â 13:34:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â skuroÂ in my model, some of the facts have a timestamp property, which can be used to let facts expire when they become too old
#2017-01-14Â 13:37:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â skuroÂ so far I have this in my little experiment: 
(defrecord Fact [timestamp ...])

(defn too-old [t]
  (< max-age (- (now) t)))

(defrule ignore-old-facts
  [?fact <- Fact (too-old timestamp)]
  =>
  (retract! ?fact))
#2017-01-14Â 13:39:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â skuroÂ is it the right strategy? I guess facts wonâ€™t be re-evaluated over time in a given session, so if I go for this I would have to recreate it periodically
#2017-01-14Â 13:39:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â skuroÂ but maybe Iâ€™m not understanding clara yet ðŸ™‚
#2017-01-16Â 15:01:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @skuro Youâ€™re correct that facts wonâ€™t be re-evaluated in this case. My suggestion would be to write something like
#2017-01-16Â 15:02:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule ignore-old-facts [TimeFact (= ?time time)] [?fact <- Fact (too-old timestamp ?time)] => (retract! ?fact))
#2017-01-16Â 15:03:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If you retract an old TimeFact and then insert with a newer TimeFact this will force re-evaluation of the join
#2017-01-16Â 15:05:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Thereâ€™s been some discussion on the mailing list of providing support for this sort of use case (events that expire with reference to them in Clara removed) but at this time there isnâ€™t anything in Clara to directly support it.
#2017-01-16Â 16:06:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â skuroÂ ok, thanks
#2017-01-16Â 17:03:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ youâ€™re welcome
#2017-01-19Â 14:00:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â do I understand correctly that a rule like the one in https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/sensors.clj#L48: 
(defrule get-current-temperature
  "Get the current temperature at a location by simply looking at the newest reading."
  [?current-temp <- newest-temp :from [TemperatureReading (= ?location location)]]
  =>
  (insert! (->CurrentTemperature (:value ?current-temp) ?location)))
will accumulate CurrentTemperature facts, never retracting them?
#2017-01-19Â 16:52:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â seems the above is retracted on every new TemperatureReading. Is my intuition right in this case - the retraction happens because when the new TemperatureReading (t+1) arrives, the condition under which the previous CurrentTemperature became true (t+0) is now false?
#2017-01-19Â 17:36:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dm3 that is correct
#2017-01-19Â 17:37:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ When the conditions that caused a logical fact insertion to occur Clara will adjust the session to reflect the new status of those conditions
#2017-01-19Â 17:37:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Logical insertions are those done with insert!
#2017-01-19Â 17:38:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If you used insert-unconditional! youâ€™d end up with multiple CurrentTemperature facts potentially depending on your rules firing pattern
#2017-01-19Â 17:39:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ But as long as you stay away from uncondition insertions and manual fact retractions inside rules you can just think of the rules as pure logical relationships that â€œif as session has these things in it it will also have these other things in it"
#2017-01-19Â 17:39:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ â€œa sessionâ€ not â€œas session"
#2017-01-19Â 17:42:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ After you call fire-rules at least, i.e. (-> your-session (insert your-facts-here) ;;no-contract-about-status-now fire-rules ;; now-there-is-a-contract-about-the-status)
#2017-01-19Â 17:42:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Also note that youâ€™ll group on the location of the TemperatureReading in the above
#2017-01-19Â 17:43:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So if you have TemperatureReading facts with different locations you can have a CurrentTemperature fact for each distinct location
#2017-01-19Â 17:43:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Does that make sense?
#2017-01-19Â 17:48:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â yeah
#2017-01-19Â 17:48:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â running into some other issues now
#2017-01-19Â 17:50:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â what if I have facts that change with time and do an insert CurrentTimestamp -> fire-rules -> retract CurrentTimestamp periodically? Are there any obvious issues I'll run into?
#2017-01-19Â 18:44:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dm3 As long as you use truth maintenance Clara will resolve all transitive impacts on rules
#2017-01-19Â 18:45:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ i.e. if you insert Fact1 which causes RuleA to insert fact2, and fact2 causes ruleB to insert fact3
#2017-01-19Â 18:45:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ a retraction of fact1 will cause fact3 to be removed from the session if appropriate based on the rules
#2017-01-19Â 18:47:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Regarding â€œfacts that change with timeâ€:
#2017-01-19Â 18:47:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara assumes that facts are immutable
#2017-01-19Â 18:48:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If you do something like (insert JavaBeanFact) fire-rules (.setSomeFieldUsedInRules JavaBeanFact newValue)
#2017-01-19Â 18:48:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ the behavior will be undefined
#2017-01-19Â 18:49:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ if you want to change fields youâ€™ll need to retract the fact and then insert a new one with the modifications you want
#2017-01-19Â 18:50:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Actually Iâ€™d consider mutation of facts after insertion to result in undefined behavior in general, apart from whether the field is used
#2017-01-19Â 18:51:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Mutating fields after insertion used in rules would definitely cause problems with the current implementation, would need to think about mutations not impacting rule bindings but either way the behavior isnâ€™t guaranteed and I wouldnâ€™t advise doing it
#2017-01-19Â 18:52:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â thx
#2017-01-19Â 18:52:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â I wasn't considering mutations
#2017-01-19Â 18:52:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ :+1:
#2017-01-19Â 18:53:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â I'm thinking of batching the input stream of events and reducing the batch with (fn [sess batch] (-> (insert sess timestamp) (insert-all batch) (fire-rules) (retract timestamp)))
#2017-01-19Â 18:54:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ yeah obviously the existence of problems depends on the specific use-case but I donâ€™t see problems in general with inserting and then retracting a timestamp fact that would have downstream impact through various rules
#2017-01-19Â 18:55:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ truth maintenance will sort out all the impacts to downstream rules
#2017-01-19Â 18:56:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ also remember Clara sessions are immutable
#2017-01-19Â 18:56:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ so you could do something like this as well
#2017-01-19Â 18:56:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (def session-with-facts-no-timestamp)
#2017-01-19Â 18:57:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (def time1-session (-> session-with-facts-no-timestamp (insert time1) fire-rules))
#2017-01-19Â 18:57:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (def time2-session (-> session-with-facts-no-timestamp (insert time2) fire-rules))
#2017-01-19Â 19:21:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â I'm now trying to do the following: 
(ns rulebot.test
  (:require [clara.rules :as clara]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
            [clara.tools.tracing :as tt]))

(defrecord Value [value instant])
(defrecord Step [step instant])
(defrecord CurrentValue [value])
(defrecord CurrentStep [step])
(defrecord CurrentTimestamp [instant])

(clara/defrule current-value
  [?e <- (acc/max :instant :returns-fact true) :from [Value]]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->CurrentValue (:value ?e))))

(clara/defrule current-step
  [?e <- (acc/max :instant :returns-fact true) :from [Step]]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->CurrentStep (:step ?e))))

(clara/defrule step
  [CurrentValue (= ?value value)]
  [CurrentStep (= ?prev-step step)
               (= ?curr-step (int (/ ?value 10)))]
  [CurrentTimestamp (= ?instant instant)]
  [:test (> ?curr-step ?prev-step)]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->Step ?curr-step ?instant)))

(defn go []
  (let [session (-> (clara/mk-session 'rulebot.test)
                    (tt/with-tracing))]
    (-> session
        (clara/insert (->CurrentTimestamp 0))
        (clara/insert (->Value 1 0))
        (clara/insert (->Step 0 0))
        (clara/fire-rules)
        (clara/retract (->CurrentTimestamp 0))

        (clara/insert (->CurrentTimestamp 1))
        (clara/insert (->Value 11 1))
        (clara/fire-rules)
        (tt/get-trace))))
which fails on the step rule because ?prev-step gets bound to an {:ns-name .., :lhs ..., :rhs ...} map for some reason...
#2017-01-19Â 19:31:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â @wparker can you see anything obviously wrong with that?
#2017-01-19Â 20:40:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ {:ns-name .., :lhs ..., :rhs â€¦} is what the internal representation of a rule looks like; its the map structure that defrule stores in a var
#2017-01-19Â 20:41:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I donâ€™t have time to look into it in detail at the moment but Iâ€™d guess that the â€œstepâ€ field is being resolved to the â€œstepâ€ var instead
#2017-01-19Â 20:41:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If you type â€œstepâ€ in a REPL in that namespace you should see the same value

#2017-01-19Â 22:53:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â the step rule does insert a new Step, which should then retract the old CurrentStep and insert a new one, unless I'm misunderstanding something
#2017-01-19Â 22:56:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â however, after the step rule runs, the current-step rule is still executed with the previous Step fact
#2017-01-19Â 23:00:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â it's probably the truth maintenance screwing with me - Step (t0) is inserted outside the rules, Step (t1) is inserted by the next-step rule with CurrentStep (t0). #2017-01-19Â 23:34:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â I'm trying to capture increases in Value as Steps. #2017-01-19Â 23:37:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â tried reformulating the next-step rule as follows (becuase the CurrentStep is just the MAX of all steps): 
(clara/defrule next-step
  [CurrentValue (= ?value value)]
  [?s <- (acc/max :step :returns-fact true) :from [Step (= ?prev-step step)]]
  [CurrentTimestamp (= ?instant instant)]
  [:test (> (int (/ ?value 10)) ?prev-step)]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->Step (int (/ ?value 10)) ?instant)))
#2017-01-19Â 23:38:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dm3Â the above works, except I couldn't figure out how to bind the ?curr-step = (int (/ ?value 10)) inside the condition

#2017-01-26Â 16:36:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ hi, there! Question about types. Does it necessary to use defrecord in order to declare fact? Can I use ordinary clojure maps to derive a fact and validate them by clojre.spec?
#2017-01-26Â 17:39:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @mike1452 Clara will use the fact-type-fn to determine what type a fact is for matching against conditions. The docs/examples can probably be improved in this regard but it is alluded to in the generated API docs at http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.13.0-RC4/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-mk-session
#2017-01-26Â 17:40:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Defrecord is just convenient for some peopleâ€™s use-cases because it creates a type to match against out of the box
#2017-01-26Â 17:40:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ when you use clojureâ€™s type function as the fact-type-fn (which is the default)
#2017-01-26Â 17:46:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ also because it allows you to use field names in a rule condition directly i.e.
#2017-01-26Â 17:46:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrecord Cold [temperature])
#2017-01-26Â 17:46:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (< temperature 0)
#2017-01-26Â 17:46:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ rather than (< (:temperature this) 0))

#2017-01-26Â 18:56:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @mike1452 this has come up several times. Claraâ€™s architecture would likely facilitate an enhancement to distribute it and if someone were interested in driving that it could be discussed.
#2017-01-31Â 19:57:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ Looking for options for debugging rules. Would have saved some time discovering typos etc today if I could have switched on debug logging evaluating every condition of a given rule say. Or even had "explain-non-activations". Any tips?

#2017-01-31Â 23:45:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ Also - looking at source of load-rules in clara/rules.cljc you can just supply a list of symbols resolving to individual rules, not just namespaces - is that correct? #2017-01-31Â 23:59:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I think a call to mk-session like the one at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/fact_type_options.clj#L20 is what youâ€™re talking about, ignoring the :fact-type-fn and :ancestors-fn options
#2017-02-01Â 15:16:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @apbleonard Think of it as clara.rules/mk-session accepts any number of â€œrule sourcesâ€. This can be anything that implements the clara.rules.compiler/IRuleSource protocol or just a collection of rule/query structures.
#2017-02-01Â 15:17:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clojureâ€™s Symbol implements the clara.rules.compiler/IRuleSource protocol. The function to implement is clara.rules.compiler/load-rules which must return a collection of rule/query structures.
#2017-02-01Â 15:18:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, Will had a good example if all you want to do is something simple like pass rules in
#2017-02-01Â 15:18:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule one-rule <etc>)
(defrule another-rule <etc>)
(defquery some-query <etc>)

;;;; Make session
(mk-session [one-rule another-rule some-query])
#2017-02-01Â 15:19:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can also mix and match. Symbol implements IRuleSource by expecting the symbol to resolve to a namespace name. It scans the whole namespace and finds all rules/queries in vars of that namespace.
#2017-02-01Â 15:20:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (mk-session [one-rule another-rule some-query] 'some.ns.with.rules)
#2017-02-01Â 15:23:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mike1452 Will mentioned that records allow you to refer to record fields directly in the rule. For non-records, you can use destructuring though. Just so you kmow 
(defrule my-rule [:my-type-thing [{:keys [x y]}] (= x â€œhelloâ€)] 
<etc>)
#2017-02-01Â 15:23:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There should probably be documented examples of that sort of destructuring.
#2017-02-01Â 15:27:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ thanks
#2017-02-02Â 22:00:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ @wparker @mikerod Thanks so much - that's exactly the examples I was looking for. Assembling rules dynamically will help us handle our mostly similar (but slightly different) rule-sets for different products. Btw destructuring maps also good to know, as records are not often used in our Clojure codebase.
#2017-02-02Â 22:02:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s probably good to be aware that if you can order rules in a meaningful order of precedence, Clara will attempt to use that as a heuristic during conflict resolution (picking which rule to fire first, when multiple are eligible).
#2017-02-02Â 22:03:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So if you have rules or sets of rules that naturally depend on other rules/sets of rules, you want to put the dependents after the dependencies. This may not matter to you and may not be worth worrying about until you have a concrete performance concern.
#2017-02-02Â 22:06:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ We have relatively low numbers of rules (no more than 100s depending on how granular we make them), but enough for Clara to really help sort out the complexity. ðŸ™‚
#2017-02-02Â 22:06:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If I had rules like: 
(defrule a [(acc/all) :from [A]] => (insert! (->B)))
(defrule b [(acc/all) :from [B]] => (insert! (->C)))
(defrule c [(acc/all) :from [C]] => (insert! (->D)))
All three rules would be â€œeligibleâ€ to be fired immediately, since the acc/all accumulator is always considered â€œtrueâ€. It will just fire with an empty collection if it has no matches, yet. If I mk-session like 
(mk-session [c b a])
This would cause Clara to choose to fire the rules in the opposite order that you would want. The Truth Maintenance System will be sure that your rules logically are correct after firing the rules, however, it will waste cycles firing rules too soon and having to retract and re-fire them later as their dependencies in their LHS change. So you want mk-session like 
(mk-session [a b c])
#2017-02-02Â 22:07:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @apbleonard Yeah, it likely isnâ€™t something to concern yourself with now. Iâ€™m just brining it to your attention since when you start to consider generating rules, etc, it may be something to consider later on if performance becomes and sort of concern.
#2017-02-09Â 21:36:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ Hello. Clojurescript doesnâ€™t seem to be supported at this time. Bummer. Was just what I needed for a project at work.
#2017-02-09Â 22:37:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @gamecubate ClojureScript is definitely intended to be supported, although it isnâ€™t used as much as the Clojure version as far as I can tell and not at all at Cerner.
#2017-02-09Â 22:37:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Those donâ€™t look like fatal warnings to me, did you run into further problems?
#2017-02-10Â 03:50:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ @wparker I didnâ€™t want to spend too much time digging into this. So, Iâ€™ve switched over to core.logic but I have to say progress is glacial (this said less than 2 hours after the switch). Claraâ€™s eloquent DSL I miss already.
#2017-02-10Â 15:20:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ To elaborate a bit, those are basically linter warnings that seem related to the rebinding, in a particular namespace, of core Clojure library definitions to new values. You can look at the source in both cases for whatever version of ClojureScript and Plumatic Schema youâ€™re using to see those redefinitions happening. Whether that is good style in any particular case is a matter of opinion, but I donâ€™t think the linter warnings are actually errors. Obviously your choice to use Clara in any project or not, but nothing I see here makes me think there is a bug with Claraâ€™s ClojureScript support. That said, Claraâ€™s ClojureScript certainly isnâ€™t as hardened as the JVM version and bug reports are welcome.
#2017-02-10Â 15:21:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Against master: https://github.com/plumatic/schema/blob/master/src/cljx/schema/core.cljx#L402 and https://github.com/clojure/clojurescript/blob/master/src/main/cljs/clojure/reflect.cljs#L33
#2017-02-10Â 16:04:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ @wparker End of day when I wrote this. I wasnâ€™t thinking. Of course they were warnings! #2017-02-10Â 16:49:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ Macrosâ€¦ Checking Clara docs, I see mk-session is a macro indeed. I need to probably add a

#2017-02-10Â 16:51:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @gamecubate I'd check out the ClojureScript examples, like the one at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojurescript/clara/examples/shopping.cljs.
#2017-02-10Â 16:52:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Note that mk-session doesn't exist and isn't support in ClojureScript, since it dynamically compiles rules. You'll need to use defsession (which compiles them upfront), as seen in that example. In fact, starting with that example, running it, and experimenting with changes to it is probably a pretty good way to get started with the ClojureScript flow.
#2017-02-10Â 16:53:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ @ryanbrush Thanks. Going through the example now.
#2017-02-10Â 16:55:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @gamecubate Sure thing! If you find problems, please log bugs or let us know. Just to warn you, we've used only the Clojure version in production and therefore haven't deeply optimized the CLJS flow so you might run into more issues there. But bug reports, and especially help tuning or optimizing the CLJS flow against real workloads, would be welcome.
#2017-02-10Â 16:55:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @gamecubate I think we're also behind on the version of ClojureScript we've tested against, so validating against newer versions is welcome as well.

#2017-02-10Â 18:56:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @gamecubate Glad it works! Note that defsession will create the initial, empty session as a static var, but that can be referenced and manipulated like any other Clojure data structure. I haven't thought a ton of good design patterns with Reagent...but just thinking of the session as any other complex, immutable structure is probably a good start.
#2017-02-10Â 18:57:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @gamecubate if you do come up with good patterns for using this with Reagent and are interested in sharing examples of doing so, we could look at including them in the examples project (possibly replacing the dommy example that exists today).
#2017-02-10Â 19:03:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ So far still exploring. What I have done thus far is for my event handlers (someone enters data in a field and clicks on add button -> triggers handler) to insert new session data:

#2017-02-10Â 21:14:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ So, this works. #2017-02-10Â 21:51:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Cool, glad it's working. No rush in adding something to the examples...it's just nice to see a pattern that works with Reagent.
#2017-02-10Â 21:53:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ One thing to note: the session itself is immutable, so you'll probably want to keep it in atom itself and swap out when you make changes. The rules you have above will work because they are just appending state, but you're actually resetting back to an old session state every time.
#2017-02-10Â 22:03:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ There are probably other interesting variations on this. For instance, we could have reactions that fire on a swap of an atom containing the session, and those reactions would query the session and update other state. This could be a little closer to the purely "reactive" ideals of Reagent, rather than having rules that actively update state.
#2017-02-10Â 22:08:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â gamecubateÂ I see. Changes needed then; will think about it to see where and how. Thanks! Gotta go pick up kid @ daycare (immutable task for me :). Cheers.
#2017-02-12Â 18:42:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ Hi! Can Clara detect a rule collisions? If rule C contradicts to rule A ?
#2017-02-12Â 20:59:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ Fairly new to Clara but ... it probably depends slightly what you mean. If you have a rules like "if A then B = 1" and "if A then B = 2", then when you query the session for values of B (assuming A is true) you'll find two values in the lazy sequence returned by the query function.
#2017-02-12Â 21:01:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ If you have rules like "if A then B" and "if B then retract A" ... well, I haven't got that far yet!
#2017-02-12Â 22:17:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ @apbleonard yeah, first variant with two answers is correct, i think. second variant is not, cause "if A then B" will insert fact B, but if retract A then B will be retracted automatically. my question about contradiction was about case if some big organization issues new policy about smth, i want to check that rules in new policy are not contradict to older policies. so i want to find collisions before new policy is issued.
#2017-02-13Â 21:22:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mike1452 @apbleonard the 2nd variant could actually cause an infinite loop since Claraâ€™s insert! will do some automatic truth-maintenance which can hang indefinitely if you have a â€œlogical loop"
#2017-02-13Â 21:24:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, the 1st variant sounds to be more of what you were asking. You have to deal with duplicated inserts yourself. You could have rules all insert some fact like B there, then have some â€œfinalâ€/â€outcome" rule(s) or query(s) that use an accumulator that you can make decide which facts are the most relevant or correct when you get into a situation of â€œcontradictions"
#2017-02-13Â 21:27:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, I think you were also wanting the engine to tell you about these rules so you could remove them perhaps? That would be something youâ€™d probably have to workout yourself. Sounds domain-specific.
#2017-02-13Â 21:27:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It isnâ€™t really clear what a â€œcontradictingâ€ rule means from the rules engineâ€™s perspective. With the exception of logical contradictions, but those also arenâ€™t even clear in the engine right now since the RHS can insert basically anthing
#2017-02-13Â 21:28:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and the LHS can test constraints that arenâ€™t simple to statically analyze.
#2017-02-14Â 16:30:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @mike1452 @apbleonard If you use manual retractions in the RHS you become responsible for ensuring that the rule execution order works out so that you get your desired results. It is basically the same idea as with logical vs unconditional insertions discussed at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ This can be done with salience and/or strategic structuring of your rules, but in my experience adds significant complication and room for error
#2017-02-14Â 16:31:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ My suggestion would be to use accumulators or negation conditions as Mike alluded to above. If you have a priority order of different logical states it wouldnâ€™t be too hard to get the state with the highest priority in an accumulator and use that state in a rule RHS. Alternatively, you can write rules like
#2017-02-14Â 16:34:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ (defrule negation-rule-1 [?a <- A (some-predicate-here)] [:not [B (other-predicate-here)]] => (insert something))
#2017-02-14Â 16:37:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ manual RHS retractions can be useful for getting things out of memory or for performance, in general wouldnâ€™t be my first resort though
#2017-02-14Â 16:47:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ @wparker thanks for suggestions! btw, what is most biggest rules database you've ever seen in production memory that Clara worked with? 10,100, 500?
#2017-02-14Â 16:47:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ do you mean the number of rules?
#2017-02-14Â 16:47:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ yeah
#2017-02-14Â 16:55:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I think we have some rulesets with at least 10K rules now, canâ€™t say exactly off the top of my head since we autogenerate a lot of rules with some internal framework code
#2017-02-14Â 16:58:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ thereâ€™s a reason weâ€™ve spent a lot of effort optimizing performance ðŸ˜›
#2017-02-14Â 18:04:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mike_ananevÂ wow, cool!
#2017-02-14Â 19:19:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ @mike1452 FWIW I have exactly the same challenges. We handle complex government policies introduced atop of older policies, and half the battle is understanding pathways through the logic, and the total space of inputs and the variety of resulting outputs. I'd love to implement the rules trivially enough to give fast feedback to policy makers on what their new policy just did to the complexity of the problem. I feel like clojure's core.logic should be able to help with this...? If that makes sense, anyone know of people using core.logic with Clara?
#2017-02-14Â 20:49:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @apbleonard I'm a fan of core.logic, but am unaware of anyone using it tightly with Clara. I think core.logic works great for problems that can be described as a set of constraints, and core.logic will search that constraint space for a solution. Clara is more centered around encoding business rules or domain expertise. It's not always obvious which tool is best for a given job, so I always think it's a good idea to experiment with both in your problem space before choosing a direction.
#2017-02-14Â 21:10:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara-rules 0.13.0 is released. - The replacement of the previous durability API with a more robust and performant one. This is discussed at issue 198. Note that this is experimental and is subject to further change; that said we're successfully using it in production at Cerner. - Improvements in error reporting in rule and query conditions, discussed at issue 255. Thanks to Carlos Phillips for this one. - Various performance improvements and bug fixes discussed on the changelog.
#2017-02-14Â 21:11:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I meant to say â€œhighlights includeâ€ before my bullets.. I fail at Slack formatting ðŸ˜›
#2017-02-14Â 21:11:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Anyway, basically a cross-post from https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/Q2p7l-Vmcr0
#2017-02-16Â 21:52:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jarrodctaylorÂ Could anyone be so kind as to help me understand how variable definition works? This is the most concise example I have to illustrate my confusion. 
(require '[clara.rules :as rule])

(rule/defrule wat
  [1 (= ?a "a")]
  [1 (= ?b "b")
   (nil? (println ?a))    ;; => "a"
   (nil? (println ?b))    ;; => "b"
   (nil? (println ?a ?b)) ;; => "a nil"
   ] => nil)

(-> (rule/mk-session [wat] :fact-type-fn (constantly 1))
    (rule/insert 1)
    (rule/fire-rules))
#2017-02-16Â 21:53:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jarrodctaylorÂ Why does ?b disappear when printed together with ?a?
#2017-02-16Â 22:41:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I wouldnâ€™t expect that to happen, but I can see the behavior you describe when I drop your example in a REPL
#2017-02-16Â 22:44:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ It is a weird case in that youâ€™d normally expect the bindings to come off the actual fact in some way, but it still seems like incorrect behavior at first glance, probably merits a GitHub issue
#2017-02-16Â 22:45:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @jarrodctaylor
#2017-02-16Â 22:52:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jarrodctaylorÂ I was experiencing the behavior with a more traditional rule in my application. This above was as too the point of an example to demonstrate it as possible. I will open a issue on GitHub.
#2017-02-16Â 22:52:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ i know ive had issues when i try to refer to a binding in the same condition (might be the wrong term) where it was bound.
#2017-02-16Â 22:53:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ but if i used the raw field version it worked fine
#2017-02-16Â 23:10:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I suspect that the reason adding ?a causes ?b to be different is that if you have ?a in the constraint it will become a join with the previous fact, and if it is absent it is a condition on a single fact
#2017-02-16Â 23:10:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Those are different paths in the compiler so one could have a bug the other doesn't
#2017-02-16Â 23:11:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Doing a quick test like
#2017-02-16Â 23:11:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ 
` (rule/defrule wat
  [1 (= ?a "a")]
  [1 (= ?b "b")
   (and (nil? (println ?a))
         (nil? (println ?b))) 
   ] => nil)
`
#2017-02-16Â 23:11:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ makes b be nil as well
#2017-02-16Â 23:12:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ with ?a and ?b in the same constraint
#2017-02-16Â 23:12:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @zylox : a â€œconditionâ€ contains constraints, that is you can have a condition like [FactType constraint1 constraint2]
#2017-02-26Â 03:21:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ https://leanpub.com/readevalprintlove004/read I don't recall if this was shared in this channel yet. It is an interesting read on rules engines by Fogus. I particularly like the simplified implementation of a (naive and simplistic) rules system. The "fruit fly" system. Hah. It does shed some light on some ideas at a high level. There is a little mention of Clara in the end "credits" too. So there is that. ðŸ˜œ
#2017-03-02Â 10:57:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ I have a question about using guards on rules in Clara. I am aiming to create rules that can never insert a fact that already exist. The guard statement works fine if I am manually inserting the fact that the guard stops, but if the rule itself is creating this statement the guard does not stop the rule from triggering again and I get an infinite loop.
#2017-03-02Â 16:05:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ ya thats a tricky one ive dealt with too. i'm not sure what the solution is either.
#2017-03-02Â 16:19:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ with a naive implementation of rules where each rule is checked separately I can see this not being an issue as after each insertion the guard would be checked and with the new fact that guard would be passed. Could this be a bug in the implementation, where somehow not the full condition of the rule is checked for it to fire again?
#2017-03-02Â 16:34:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ maybe i didnt understand what you meant by gaurds, but if a rule inserts something that that same rule looks at, its pretty much always going to cause another firing
#2017-03-02Â 16:34:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ is my understanding

#2017-04-12Â 22:50:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ Hi. How to make an "or" in "match" part of rule. Example: 
;; There is 2 types: groups and items
;; Example:
;; :group [1 false 2]
;; :group [1 false 3]
;; :item [2 true]
;; :item [3 false]
;; :group [4 true 5]
;; :item [5 false]
;; Group '1' contains items '2' and '3'
;; Group '4' contains item '5'
;; My `select` query shoud find [[4][1]]
;; because they are groups and they are selected
;; or contains a selected item
(defrule selected-groups
         ;; Or this
         [:group [[id selected _]] (= ?id group) (= selected true)]

         ;; Or this
         [:group [[id _ item-id]] (= ?id id) (= item-id ?item-id)]
         [:item [[item-id selected]] (= ?item-id item-id) (= selected true)]
         =>
         (insert! ^{:type :select} [?id]))
(sorry for big example) (yes, I know how to do it with 2 rules.) (I dont care with duplicate entries)
#2017-04-13Â 22:29:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @souenzzo Would something like [:or [:group â€¦] [:and {:group ..] [:item]] meet your needs? There are some docs at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/booleans

#2017-04-21Â 21:14:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ for instance, there is a big fan out and fan in between A and C, like A->[B1, B2, B3, B4, B5, BN]->C If C is a specific fact like: MoreThanThreeBs, then who really cares what those Bs were? all I really care about is that by virtue of A, I have the possibility of many Bs, and all I care to know is if I get to state C from A
#2017-04-21Â 21:21:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ We have a lot of scenarios where we need to look at hundreds of thousands of facts on our way to a state, but in the end all we really care about is that given a Lab, we determine whether it is normal or abnormal according to a massive set of facts, and then produce an AbnormalLabResult or NormalLabResult. Labl->AbnormalLab/NormalLab is how I'd prefer to view it in a UI rather than render the 500k+ nodes and corresponding edges in between

#2017-04-21Â 21:55:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Iâ€™m guessing the types of transforms needed will depend heavily on the domain. (The RHS is too late as the accumulators are used only in LHSs.)
#2017-05-01Â 16:13:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ do you have an example stack trace?
#2017-05-01Â 16:17:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ yes:
#2017-05-01Â 16:19:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ @zylox http://paste.lisp.org/display/345606
#2017-05-01Â 16:47:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ ya i got nothing unfortunately. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.clj might be of some help
#2017-05-01Â 17:28:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @enn unfortunately errors during accumulation arenâ€™t handled as well as errors in non-accumulator conditions; https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/265 is logged to improve that (non-accumulator conditions were improved in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/255 )
#2017-05-01Â 17:29:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ In the meantime your best option is probably to wrap the accumulator in question in a way that indicates what rules youâ€™re in when it throw an exception
#2017-05-01Â 17:30:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara accumulators are just maps containing functions, and the accumulator can be modified by adding a new value onto one of the keys
#2017-05-01Â 17:31:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Your stacktrace tells me youâ€™re throwing in the reduce-fn
#2017-05-01Â 17:33:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So you could do something like (defn ->wrapped-reduce-fn [original-reduce-fn rule-name] (fn [& args] (try (apply original-reduce-fn args) (catch Exception e (throw (ex-info (str â€œThrew exception in accumulation in â€ rule-name) {} e))))
#2017-05-01Â 17:34:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ and (defrule [?result-binding <- (update (acc/min :field) :reduce-fn ->wrapped-reduce-fn rule-name) â€¦
#2017-05-01Â 17:35:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ actually to work with the update youâ€™d need to reverse the args order of ->wrapped-reduce-fn, but that is the basic idea
#2017-05-01Â 17:37:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The problem with tracing is that when you throw an exception and exit the rules firing loop youâ€™ll lose the transient listener that has the info you want
#2017-05-01Â 17:37:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ When a RHS exception is thrown we call to-persistent on the listeners but that wonâ€™t happen in an exception during accumulation https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1787
#2017-05-01Â 17:38:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ You could write your own listener that had global side effects or some such to get around that if you wanted though
#2017-05-01Â 17:41:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ There are some docs on what the different accum function fields do at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/, you can also look at the structures created at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/accumulators.cljc
#2017-05-01Â 17:50:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ Thank you, the wrapping idea makes sense
#2017-05-01Â 17:52:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ though a little clunky as we are not specifying the reduce-fn directly (itâ€™s created via acc/max and comparison-based)
#2017-05-01Â 18:03:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Yeah, it is clunky, but hopefully if you have just a handful of rules and a particular exception it wonâ€™t be too bad. Obviously not as nice as having built-in error handling i.e. issue 265 but hopefully solves your immediate need
#2017-05-18Â 19:42:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara-rules 0.15.0 is released and available on Clojars. Highlights include a variety of improvements to session inspection, including functionality to create a graph data structure of facts to facts they caused to be logically inserted, and a fix to a memory leak that caused the memory to retain references to bindings from retracted facts in some cases.
#2017-05-18Â 19:43:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ ðŸŽŠ
