#2017-05-26Â 09:18:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â puzzlerÂ Can someone point me to documentation about how to construct clara rules dynamically?
#2017-05-26Â 11:02:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nkabrichÂ AFAIK defrule just generates a data structure so you can either build that by hand dynamically or check out clara.rules.dsl/parse-rule
#2017-05-26Â 14:13:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @puzzler There are a number of examples of dynamic rule creation in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj You can also just build the rule data structures yourself if that is more convenient for your use-case; see the schema at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/schema.clj#L62
#2017-05-26Â 14:16:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Youâ€™ll need to fully qualify reference in your LHS (left-hand side) code if you use that approach, although in the RHS code it will evaluated in the ns you give if you give one as noted in the comment on the schema; that would be good to do in the LHS too, it just hasnâ€™t been implemented yet
#2017-05-26Â 14:40:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ There is also an example of generating rules from an external DSL on this blog post. Towards the bottom you'll see the Clojure data structure that defines the rules themselves. http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/
#2017-05-26Â 14:41:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ But often just writing defrule for your rules, then looking at the data structure it creates can give you a good idea of what you need, as @nkabrich suggests.
#2017-05-27Â 18:55:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ oh wow I was just about to ask about dynamic rule creation
#2017-05-27Â 18:57:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ The issue I have would be that the list of conditions in the lhs (and some part of the rhs) would be based on the elements of a list that is bound with a condition
#2017-05-27Â 18:58:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ The problem is I can not seem to express it right with defrule nor the underlying code datastructure
#2017-05-27Â 19:03:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ I might be stepping too much over what the rete network does so it might be slow, but if nothing else there should be a way to look into the underying knowledge base for a set of checks the very least based on which I could bind a variable on the right hand side
#2017-05-27Â 19:04:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ but this seems like internal stuff to clara the very least
#2017-05-27Â 19:29:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ was thinking maybe having a test expression that uses a functon and perhaps some internal way of peering into the current knowledge base, based on which it would return variables
#2017-05-27Â 19:43:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @newres I'm not sure I entirely follow your use case, but it seems possible in principle with some of the rule generation patterns described above. However, I'm not sure I'd suggest that approach if you can avoid it. It might be better to, for example, put the needed data in some structure on the left-hand side, and bind the entire structure to a variable...and then de-structure that variable on the right-hand side to get the nested structure out.
#2017-05-27Â 19:52:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ @ryanbrush The problem I would have in binding everything and move it to the right hand side is that in the current implementation I need to use the conclusion in the guard.
#2017-05-27Â 19:56:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ @ryanbrush is there a way on the lhs to reach into the current knowledge base with an expression, without resorting to unification and bindings? Basically with regular programming with some datastructure as a knowledge base the problem is pretty easily solvable, I would not mind skipping any optimizations clara provides just in a few cases.
#2017-05-27Â 20:00:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ @ryanbrush to describe the problem I have a bit better, suppose I have bound a list to the variable ?L. Based on this list I need to check x number of conditions where x is the length of that list and the conditions vary based the the list elements.
#2017-05-27Â 20:07:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The left hand side can only see the fact it is analyzing, and previously bound variables. Unfortunately there isn't a way to dynamically peek into the memory more than that...and there isn't a way to really make that visible that will be stable, either, since the order of evaluation of each rule constraint isn't defined, and we use a mutable structure underneath that can change at any time.
#2017-05-27Â 20:08:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Generating rules ahead of creating the session can be done, but it's not clear whether that helps much. The visibility of the LHS to the fact its evaluating and previous, explicitly bound variables in earlier constraints on the LHS is a pretty firmly build in.
#2017-05-27Â 20:09:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ But you can still bind a list or other structure in one LHS constraint, and then analyze it in a subsequent LHS constraint, if that helps.
#2017-05-27Â 20:09:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ ...which includes test guards
#2017-05-27Â 20:14:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ The problem there is I do not know how I would express the fact that for all elements in that list I need a new slightly different constrained. For example suppose I have in the list 3 variables ?p1, ?p2, ?p3 I would need 3 conditions that check like [T (= ?a s) (= ?p1 p) (= b o)] [T (= ?b s) (= ?p2 p) (= c o)] [T (= ?c s) (= ?p3 p) (= d o)]
#2017-05-27Â 20:16:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ I can probably generate or write up such rules for the length of x manually if writing it for arbitary lengths is not possible
#2017-05-27Â 20:17:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Another simpler option (which may or may not work for your needs) is to use an accumulator to match a list of all items of type T, and then analyze that list in your guard.
#2017-05-27Â 20:18:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The accumulator might not bind anything but the result, so it just passes a list down, and you can call an arbitrarily sophisticated function in the guard to sort it out. Some documentation here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/
#2017-05-27Â 20:22:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ so I could get all the values of T where the middle variable is a member of the list (In my implementation nearly everything is T, so I need to narrow some things down), than have test as a guard that pretty much checks what the conditions would do in a normal case
#2017-05-27Â 20:22:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, that should work.
#2017-05-27Â 20:23:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ It's probably not the most idiomatic way to structure rules, but we've done things like this as well.
#2017-05-27Â 20:24:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ If you really want to get fancy you can write your own accumulator...but just grabbing everything (or just using simple filters if that works) can get you there.
#2017-05-27Â 20:26:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ is there a simple way to say that i want [T (= ?b s) (= ?pl p) (= c o)] where ?pl is a member of a list l
#2017-05-27Â 20:26:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, you can pass ?pl to any function on the LHS after it is declared, including checks for inclusion in a list.
#2017-05-27Â 20:27:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ aha yes that would work, not sure about the efficiency but right now getting it working would be a good step
#2017-05-27Â 20:28:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ Thanks for the help! i am probably pushing clara in some really weird and unexpected ways but the docs really help
#2017-05-27Â 20:29:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Cool. Glad I could help and good luck with your system!
#2017-05-27Â 20:29:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â newresÂ and the board and the slack, thanks !
#2017-05-29Â 14:44:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nkabrichÂ Why is this rule creating an infinite loop? I'm trying to insert a "default fact" if no other rule has yet inserted that fact. Or is there a better pattern for this? 
(defrule infinite-loop
  [:not [SomeFact]]
  =>
  (rules/insert! (map->SomeFact {:a 1})))
Also if I add {:salience -1} to this rule, it seems to hang in the LHS? I'm not exactly sure but in any case when I set the salience a (println "looping") in the RHS fails to print and thread hangs.
#2017-05-29Â 14:48:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ not sure but, i think you can: first accumulate some fact, if it's equal zero, then insert the default.
#2017-05-29Â 15:20:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @ryanbrush Would it be ok to add a Clara channel here? https://discord.gg/v9QMy9D
#2017-05-29Â 15:23:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nkabrichÂ @souenzzo hmm thanks, but I'm still running into an infinite loop using an accumulator and :test to insert a default
#2017-05-29Â 15:31:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @nkabrich Are you using (acc/count)?
#2017-05-29Â 15:33:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ 
[?nfacts <- (acc/count) :from SomeFact]
[:test (= 0 ?nfacts)]
#2017-05-29Â 15:33:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ ?
#2017-05-29Â 15:34:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nkabrichÂ @alex-dixon nope, ill give that a whirl
#2017-05-29Â 15:36:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ If an insert on the RHS causes the LHS to become false, the insert is retracted since it is no longer supported...causing the LHS to become true again and an infinite loop occurs.
#2017-05-29Â 15:37:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The key is for the RHS insert to not match the LHS. Like check in the LHS for not a default value that the RHS could insert, so it doesn't retract the RHS inserted fact.
#2017-05-29Â 15:38:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ You can also use insert-unconditional to avoid this truth maintenance loop outright, but that can cause other headaches that depend on the order of facts inserted.
#2017-05-29Â 15:38:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nkabrichÂ ahh, makes total sense thanks for the explanation.
#2017-05-29Â 15:39:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Sure thing. It's probably the biggest pitfall of rules engines like this....but can be overcome with some care
#2017-05-29Â 15:41:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @alex-dixon I'm not familiar with that service. Let me take a look at it later today
#2017-05-29Â 15:45:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @ryanbrush Thanks. Thereâ€™s some discussion within the community to converting from Slack to it. Seems like weâ€™re in a trial period right now. I know from the JS community that Slackâ€™s message limit is a problem and Discord is generally looked to as the solution (they keep unlimited message history) https://github.com/reactjs/redux for example is a popular JS library that has moved to Discord
#2017-05-30Â 15:02:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ As for the Discord conversation, if the bulk of the Clojure community goes over there then we should go along. That said, I feel like I already have too many collaboration tools I use...so I'll probably only be active on the forums where most of Clojure is. I have no objections if users want to create a Clara channel there...I just won't promise to frequent all of these.
#2017-06-08Â 13:35:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jfntnÂ Iâ€™m not familiar with clara but Iâ€™ve been wondering if it could be used to model a HFSM/Statechart by defining a hierarchy of rules?
#2017-06-08Â 13:42:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jfntnÂ I.e. in any given state, only a subset of the engines rules are loaded, and generally youâ€™d want children states to activate their parentâ€™s rules
#2017-06-08Â 13:44:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jfntnÂ The OOP like mechanics can easily be achieved with a custom hierarchy in clojure, but Iâ€™m wondering if scoping rules to their respective state in clara would involve instantiating different rulesets, or dynamically mutating a global rules registry
#2017-06-09Â 13:35:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fabraoÂ Well @jfntn , I used to classify I kind of link status to avoid chains of ifs, but my experience is that it was more complex than I thougth, so I changed to datascript to be more clear and simple
#2017-06-09Â 13:36:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fabraoÂ here is an example what I did 
(defn limite [chave]
  (read-string (chave (:referencia (:config sistema)))))

(defrecord IcmpLocalizacao [nome-link localidade jitter latencia perda])
(defrecord Problema [mensagem nome-link localidade])

(defrule ligacao-fragmentada
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :fragmentada ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule telefonia-degradada
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> jitter (limite :jitter)) (> latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :degradada ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule perda-qualidade
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> jitter (limite :jitter)) (<= latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :qualidade ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule atraso-telefonia
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (<= jitter (limite :jitter)) (> latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :atraso ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule sem-comunicacao
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (= jitter -1) (= latencia -1) (= perda -1)]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :comunicacao_locais ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defquery problemas-comunicacao []
          [Problema (= ?mensagem mensagem) (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade)])

(defn gerar-fatos [fatos]
  (let [regras (atom #{})]
    (doseq [fato fatos]
    (let [link (first (first fato))
          valor (second (first fato))
          localidade (:localidade valor)
          icmp (:icmp valor)
          jitter (:jitter icmp)
          perda (:perda icmp)
          latencia (:latencia icmp)]
    (swap! regras conj (->IcmpLocalizacao link localidade jitter latencia perda))))
    @regras))

(defn compilar-regras [fatos]
  (into #{}
        (-> (mk-session 'correlacao.item.regraslink)
            (insert-all (gerar-fatos fatos))
            (fire-rules)
            (query problemas-comunicacao))))
#2017-06-09Â 13:38:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fabraoÂ in datascript 
(defn- classificar-elemento [conn tipo op-jitter op-perda op-latencia jitter perda latencia]
  (let [resultado (d/q '[:find ?localidade ?link
                         :in $ ?op-jitter ?op-perda ?op-latencia ?ref-jitter ?ref-perda ?ref-latencia
                         :where 
                         [?e :link ?link]
                         [?e :localidade ?localidade]
                         [?e :jitter ?jitter]
                         [?e :perda ?perda]
                         [?e :latencia ?latencia]
                         [(?op-jitter ?jitter ?ref-jitter)]
                         [(?op-perda ?perda ?ref-perda)]
                         [(?op-latencia ?latencia ?ref-latencia)]
                         ]
                       conn op-jitter op-perda op-latencia jitter perda latencia)]
    (if (= #{} resultado)
      []
      (resultado->set resultado tipo)
      )))
#2017-06-09Â 13:39:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fabraoÂ (classificar-elemento @conn :fragmentada nevermind > nevermind jitter perda latencia)
#2017-06-09Â 13:43:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fabraoÂ I see that datascript was more flexible, but you can use any other ways to define rules for your job, like in https://github.com/threatgrid/naga or even clojure.logic

#2017-06-09Â 18:00:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, Clara has certainly been used in a way that creates logical â€œgroupsâ€ and/or â€œhierarchiesâ€ of rules
#2017-06-09Â 18:00:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can have intermediary facts inserted that act as â€œblockersâ€ for some rules, or have some rules not be able to be satisfied until certain facts are present
#2017-06-09Â 18:01:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, this isnâ€™t done by â€œturning offâ€ rules or by excluding rules from the rulebase/session created, instead it is done purely through logical relationships the rules express
#2017-06-09Â 18:02:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, the â€œtypeâ€ dispatch function used by Clara rules LHS conditions is pluggable. So you could do things with ad hoc hierarchies of Clojure

#2017-06-09Â 18:06:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you flip from session to session, they will not share any of this state with one another. there is a chance that that is suitable for your needs. Iâ€™m just calling it out.
#2017-06-09Â 18:08:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, the time to create a session is typically non-trivial if you have a fair number of rules involved. So often the pattern is to keep the sessions in memory. There will be limitations to how many rule sessions you can store in memory at a time. The size of them is mostly dependent on the number or rules and conditions involved

(def fsm {'Start          {:init             'Ready}
          'Ready          {:missing-password 'Password-Error
                           :missing-email    'Email-Error
                           :submit           'Submitting}
          'Password-Error {:change-password  'Ready}
          'Email-Error    {:change-email     'Ready}
          'Submitting     {:receive-success  'Success}})

(def app-statechart
  {'Visitor
   {:login
    {'LoginForm
     {'Start          {:init 'Ready}
      'Ready          {:missing-password 'Password-Error
                       :missing-email    'Email-Error
                       :submit           'Submitting}
      'Password-Error {:change-password 'Ready}
      'Email-Error    {:change-email 'Ready}
      'Submitting     {:receive-success 'Success}}}
    :signup {... }}
   'User  {...}
   'Admin {...}})
#2017-06-09Â 18:40:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jfntnÂ The key distinction is that for a given node in the tree, valid transitions at that state are the union of its and its parentsâ€™ transitions (or rules in our case), so rules that are not in this set are illegal

(def-tuple-rule ready-exit-missing-password
  [[:app :state :login]]
  [[:login :state :ready]]
  [[_ :missing-email]]
  =>
  (insert-unconditional! [[:login :state :password-error]]))

#2017-06-26Â 15:25:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The space/time complexity of Clara is going to be reliant on the number of rules, complexity of the join conditions within the rules, and the size of facts in working memory.
#2017-06-26Â 15:25:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So you can get a pretty large range of performance characteristics depending on your use-case
#2017-06-26Â 15:26:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The tendency of the rules network is to favor time over space. e.g. intermediate match state is saved to avoid recomputing values later. So a space vs time tradeoff.
#2017-06-26Â 15:26:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If your working memory state isnâ€™t prohibitively large though, the space may still be reasonable

#2017-06-29Â 01:18:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ One thing Iâ€™m interested in is being able to add support using grammars migrated from specs for macros, since I expect there will be more of them in the future.

#2017-06-29Â 01:19:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ As well as selfishly meaning that I can actually try to migrate some macro specs to Cursive - I havenâ€™t seen any in the wild yet.
#2017-06-29Â 01:20:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ Since the macro forms also seem quite complex, it seems like having specs for them would also be generally useful to developers using Clara.
#2017-06-29Â 02:11:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @cfleming Hey, cool idea. I haven't really used specs for macros yet, but I think it would be straightforward to do so for Clara's macros. The structure is pretty well defined (the defrule and defquery macros already have a schema defining their return values) and has been stable for some time.
#2017-06-29Â 02:12:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ @ryanbrush Nice. So is there actually a grammar for the macros themselves anywhere? I see some railroad docs, but they seem incomplete.
#2017-06-29Â 02:12:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ The schema I guess is for the returned data, right? Not the actual macros?
#2017-06-29Â 02:13:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ We had written quite a bit of error handling code for malformed defrule macros to make it easier to debug, but we don't have a formal grammer besides the (incomplete) EBNF we used for the railroad docs.)
#2017-06-29Â 02:13:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Right, the schema is for the returned data.
#2017-06-29Â 02:13:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I agree this could be helpful for rule authors.

#2017-06-29Â 09:45:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ Hi, I'd like to use Clara in my app which uses Component. #2017-06-30Â 10:10:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ Hopefully a quick one, I'm using clara with :fact-type-fn (fn [[e a _]] a). I'm inserting a bunch of facts e.g. 
(rules/insert-all session [[1 :event/eventTypeId 1]
                                          [1 :state/timeElapsed 19]
                                          [2 :event/eventTypeId 1]
                                          [2 :state/timeElapsed 23]])
to match with an example rule of 
(def football-over-20-mins-rule
  (clara-dsl/parse-rule
   [[:event/eventTypeId [[e a v]] (= 1 v) (= ?e e)]
    [:state/timeElapsed [[e a v]] (> v 20) (= ?time v) (= ?e e)]]
   (println "Event " ?e " has gone over 20 mins with " ?time)))
At some point I want to retract all facts for a given 'e', as the event might have finished and I want to keep my facts lean. What is the best way of collecting all facts for matching 'e' so that I can retract them all?
#2017-06-30Â 12:42:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @flipmokid Your best bet is probably to write a query (via defquery) to get all facts for a given e, and then use retract to remove them. There isn't a retract-all (yet), but since it's a multi-arity function you can call it arbitrarily like (apply retract session [my-facts])
#2017-06-30Â 12:46:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ Sorry, it's probably my bad understanding of rules but for my [e a v] fact type how would I get all e's out. As far as I understand the first part of a rule is the type (which is a) and so I'm not sure how I would specify how to pull all entities of a particular number. I'm currently inserting a fact [e :event/retract true] and then trying to find these [:event/retract [[e a v]] (= v true) (= ?e e)] but not sure how to get all matching facts that have the same e
#2017-06-30Â 12:58:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ I guess I just need someone to help me understand how to write a rule/query that can pull the e's (it's having to write the type at the start that is throwing me). I'm not sure if I can check for the :event/retract fact and then have an accumulator to get all e's for it
#2017-06-30Â 13:08:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ I think I see the sticking point here. You'll probably want to match a query on a special "parent" type of all (you can use clojure.core/derive to declare a parent type, which Clara will honor if it's done before the session is created.) Then the query can have a predicate to match on whatever subset you want.
#2017-06-30Â 13:09:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ ...or I suppose you could just have your fact match on java.lang.Object (assuming your running the Clojure rather than the ClojureScript version) and have your predicate check that.
#2017-06-30Â 13:31:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ I'm not sure derive will be of much help. For a fact [e a v] e will always be a number (the id of the sporting event) which is not known in advance, a will be the attribute and v can be anything e.g. [1 :state/timeElapsed 19] So do you think if I wanted to stick with my tuple-shaped facts it would be difficult to extract all es of the same value if my fact-type-fn is (fn [[e a v]] a)? Out of interest do you know how Precept handles retractions of its tupled shaped facts?
#2017-06-30Â 13:36:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ If you know the values of a ahead of time then it derive could work, but might be painful to derive all of that. But a defquery approach might work like:
#2017-06-30Â 13:37:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ `(defquery [:e-to-remove] [Object [my-tuple] (= ?e-to-remove (first my-tuple))])
#2017-06-30Â 13:37:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Haven't actually tried that, but it's an idea to try with. I'm not familiar with how Precept handles this sort of thing.
#2017-06-30Â 13:38:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ That looks interesting, let me give it a go
#2017-06-30Â 13:41:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Sounds good. There are some steps I left out...you'll want to return the full tuples from the query, for instance, so they can be retracted.
#2017-06-30Â 13:58:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ Actually, I'm not sure the Object part will match as I'm not using the type function (please let me know if I'm being stupid though, I often am!) (defquery [:e-to-remove] [Object [my-tuple] (= ?e-to-remove (first my-tuple))])
#2017-06-30Â 14:10:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Ah, of course. You'll need a custom ancestors function to complement the custom type function. There is an example here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/
#2017-06-30Â 14:10:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ So your custom ancestor could just return :all-facts if you wanted to match everything. ðŸ˜‰
#2017-06-30Â 14:11:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ (:all-facts is just an arbitrary keyword here that could be returned by the ancestors function.)
#2017-06-30Â 14:48:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ Ah okay. I'll try that. Thanks for your help so far, I really appreciate it
#2017-06-30Â 15:22:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â flipmokidÂ Brilliant that worked! 
(def retractions-rule
  (clara-dsl/parse-rule
   [[:event/retract [[e a v]] (= v true) (= e ?e)]
    [?elems <- (acc/all) :from [::all [[e _ _]] (= e ?e)]]]
   (println "RETRACTION MATCHED " ?elems)))
Many thanks for your help
#2017-06-30Â 15:33:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Nice!
#2017-07-02Â 13:06:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Just released clara-rules 0.15.1! Details in the change log: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0151

#2017-07-08Â 01:28:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ mk-session should pick up new rules in the REPL. It will only look in the current namespace, though, unless you are explicitly passing namespaces.
#2017-07-08Â 06:34:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dragoncubeÂ @ryanbrush so I need to call mk-session again? if so, is there any way to transfer facts from one session to another? or maybe fire-rules would be enough?
#2017-07-08Â 14:55:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ You'll need to pass in your facts into the new session again. Clara won't do this automatically, but I usually reload the facts or keep them in a list.

#2017-07-13Â 17:35:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickowsyÂ ahh, that could be. A very simple example 
(defquery get-promotions
  "Query to find promotions for the purchase."
  [:?type]
  [?promotion <- Promotion (= ?type type)])
#2017-07-13Â 17:35:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickowsyÂ 
(query session get-promotions :?type :lunch)

#2017-07-13Â 19:09:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fmjreyÂ Basically this does not work: 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?type :?name :?data]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor [?type ?name ?data])])
#2017-07-13Â 19:09:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fmjreyÂ But this does: 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?d]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor ?d)])
#2017-07-13Â 19:10:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fmjreyÂ Thanks @nickowsy for trying ðŸ™‚
#2017-07-13Â 19:13:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickowsyÂ :+1:
#2017-07-13Â 21:53:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @fmjrey the params have to be in the query conditions 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?type :?name :?data]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor [?type ?name ?data])])
is trying to use bindings in the Feature condition without creating them
#2017-07-13Â 21:53:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ the use in the params doesnâ€™t create them, that is for indexing into the query results later
#2017-07-13Â 21:55:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Basically the query params wonâ€™t make an otherwise-invalid query valid, they just control how youâ€™ll view the data later when using the query results
#2017-07-13Â 21:57:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So in the â€œpromotion typeâ€ example in the doc, youâ€™ll provide a type to query for, and youâ€™ll only get results back of that type; without the param youâ€™d get back other types as well
#2017-07-13Â 21:57:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ This is the key line of code: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1960

#2017-07-14Â 00:50:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ Sorry I should add that these are automatic retractions of derived/sourced facts
#2017-07-14Â 14:54:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dadair it sounds like youâ€™re describing truth maintenance so perhaps that will meet your needs http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/
#2017-07-17Â 19:31:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ clara-rules 0.15.2 is released and on Clojars. This was a fix release for a bug in the distinct accumulator.
#2017-07-20Â 16:10:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ greetings! What can I read on combining event sourcing with rule engines? Or about any rules<-> (finite) state machines transitions.
#2017-07-24Â 22:55:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @misha you might try the Google Groups mailing list as well, I know some people have considered using Clara for event processing before. Regarding finite state machines, keep in mind that Clara supports arbitrary code, notably in the RHS (consequences) of rules, so the ability to introspect is limited if your application doesnâ€™t add further restrictions.
#2017-07-25Â 08:16:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ @wparker thanks, will check it out. to have a real life value, FSMs need to support arbitrary code (i/o) execution as part (or as a consequence) of the state's transitions as well, so that comes down to a design decisions in both cases. In the exercise app I am (re)writing now - html5 video/audio tags are basically i/o, as far as the rest of the buttons in UI are concerned, despite those tags being their own FSMs.
#2017-07-26Â 21:27:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @U051HUZLD I was thinking of mainly what types the rules could insert; given an arbitrary set of rules one canâ€™t infer which other rules a given rule could trigger. It is possible to add metadata of some kind specifying this or to parse it if you restrict the RHS code you write to something you can reliably parse. This seemed possibly relevant if you were trying to translate rules to a FSM, specifically w.r.t. the allowed state transitions.
#2017-07-25Â 16:08:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Is it possible to use protocol methods in the left hand side of rules?
#2017-07-25Â 16:09:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â I have a vague feeling it would violate clara's design but cannot articulate why ðŸ™‚
#2017-07-25Â 16:12:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yes, the LHS supports arbitrary Clojure expressions, including protocol methods.
#2017-07-25Â 16:20:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Would you be kind to give an example?
#2017-07-25Â 16:21:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Having trouble wrapping my head around how to refer to the instance showing up in the LHS
#2017-07-25Â 16:22:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â 
(defprotocol IFoo
  (test-foo [this]))

(defrule is-foo
  [IFoo (test-foo ?not sure how to express?)]
  =>...)
#2017-07-25Â 16:23:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â @ryanbrush Thanks for the help in advance ðŸ™‚
#2017-07-25Â 16:24:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @iku000888 Ahh, I thought you meant calling protocol-based methods on the LHS. The type the rules matches needs to be an actual type, either a Java type or a Clojure type via deftype.
#2017-07-25Â 16:25:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ (The one exception is customized "types" discussed here, but this probably isn't applicable to your discussion: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/)
#2017-07-25Â 16:26:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ One correction: I meant clojure.core/derive rather than deftype above.
#2017-07-25Â 16:26:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â I think I understand
#2017-07-25Â 16:27:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Just thought at first glance I could reify a bunch of stuff and passing it through rules would be a usecase
#2017-07-25Â 16:28:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Thanks for clarifying! Much appreciate your time.
#2017-07-25Â 16:28:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â ðŸ™‡
#2017-07-25Â 16:33:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â 
(defprotocol IFoo
  (test-foo [this]))

(deftype Foo []
  IFoo
  (test-foo [this] true))

(defrule is-foo
  [Foo (test-foo ?not sure how to express?)]
  => (println "is a foo"))
#2017-07-25Â 16:33:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Wait, so if it is an actual type I can invoke protocol methods?
#2017-07-26Â 21:39:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Heads up about something potentially tricky: If youâ€™re on the JVM when you create a protocol, behind the scenes Clojure creates a corresponding Java interface of the same name. An interface is a type that you can write rules against, but it might not do what you expect. Only types that Clojure knows satisfy the protocol at the time of their creation will implement the interface. For example:
#2017-07-26Â 21:40:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ 
` user=> (defprotocol MyProtocol (proto-method [_]))
MyProtocol
user=> (defrecord MyRecord1 [] MyProtocol (proto-method [_] "Hello World"))
user.MyRecord1
user=> (defrecord MyRecord2 [])
user.MyRecord2
user=> (extend-type MyRecord2 MyProtocol (proto-method [_] "Hi World"))
nil
user=> (proto-method (->MyRecord1))
"Hello World"
user=> (proto-method (->MyRecord2))
"Hi World"
user=> (instance? user.MyProtocol (->MyRecord1))
true
user=> (instance? user.MyProtocol (->MyRecord2))
false
`
#2017-07-26Â 21:42:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ In another ns you could potentially import the interface rather than the protocol depending on how you set up your ns header i.e. import vs require on it
#2017-07-26Â 21:43:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @iku000888
#2017-07-27Â 02:07:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â @wparker thanks! Did not know about that.
#2017-07-25Â 16:33:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â @ryanbrush
#2017-07-25Â 16:35:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yes, if Foo is a type, you should be able to invoke the test-foo protocol method on it like you show.
#2017-07-25Â 16:35:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â (defrule is-foo [Foo (test-foo this)] => (println "is a foo"))
#2017-07-25Â 16:36:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Works!
#2017-07-25Â 16:37:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Thanks again and sorry for the noob noise ðŸ™‡
#2017-07-25Â 16:37:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Sure thing! I'm glad it works for you.
#2017-07-25Â 16:38:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Just be aware you might have to reload your rules if you redefine the types in a REPL, since the type will change when you do that. ðŸ˜‰

#2017-07-28Â 18:50:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickowsyÂ hi, I'm new to clara and I'm having a bit of trouble understanding clara's durability. I'm serialize the data, storing the rule base separately. When I restore everything, insert new facts, and fire-rules...my rules are not running again. Rules fire great if I use the original session. i.e. not the one that was restored. I have been looking at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_durability.clj and my broken test is at https://github.com/nfox2004/clara-durability/blob/master/test/clara_durability_help/core_test.clj. Any suggestions would be awesome! thanks
#2017-07-28Â 19:38:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @nickowsy from a quick glance over your test I see your original session has a custom :fact-type-fn. Youâ€™ll need to supply the same :fact-type-fn that the original function had when deserializing the rulebase. See the 2-argument version of deserialize-rulebase: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/durability.clj#L653
#2017-07-28Â 19:38:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So something like (deserialize-rulebase session-serializer {:fact-type-fn your-fact-type-function})
#2017-07-28Â 19:41:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The reason it is that way is that arbitrary Clojure function objects arenâ€™t serializable, so you have to either impose some kind of restriction on the functions used that gives you serializability or require the user to handle it; we went with the latter
#2017-07-28Â 20:11:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickowsyÂ @wparker thanks a ton! makes total sense ðŸ™‚
#2017-07-28Â 23:01:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ Not sure if this question goes against the design of fact-based systems, but is there a way to "update" a fact? That is, say we insert ->Fact x, and then we insert ->Fact y, is it possible to only get a single Fact with updated value y in a query?
#2017-07-28Â 23:05:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ concrete example: 
(-> (handle test-file test-action) (r/query fields-for :?formRef "/forms/aae-form"))
=>
({:?formRef "/forms/aae-form",
  :?fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
  :?field #{#justice.rules.forms.FormField{:formRef "/forms/aae-form",
                                           :fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
                                           :descriptor {:type "VALUE",
                                                        :valueType "STRING",
                                                        :value "foo",
                                                        :constraints {:minLength 1, :required true}}}
            #justice.rules.forms.FormField{:formRef "/forms/aae-form",
                                           :fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
                                           :descriptor {:type "VALUE",
                                                        :valueType "STRING",
                                                        :value "",
                                                        :constraints {:minLength 1, :required true}}}}})
I'd like the query to return all FormField's with unique :fieldRef; so in the above example if I update the :descriptor :value from "" to "foo", I only want the single fact returned
#2017-07-29Â 16:09:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ Generational data is kind of tricky. I think you could do what you want though (assuming im understanding) if, externally, you have some way to track "newest", having some sort of version field (whether this is datetime or incremented or whatever). Then, in the rules network, have an accumulator for the "newest" value of that field, and insert ->NewestFact and then depend on that instead. Logical retractions should take care of the rest. @dadair
#2017-07-29Â 16:11:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ i just realized you probably meant internal insertions not external.
#2017-07-29Â 16:14:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ if its internal (so inserting on the rhs), thats trickier because in my experience execution order dependent rules get you in trouble real quick, and without that i'm not sure how you would know what fact is "newer". If your goal is actually whatever fact has the most fields populated, you could still do a check on that in the accumulator, or probably better with rules with checks on the fields you care about.
#2017-08-05Â 00:24:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mrchanceÂ Hi! Is it possible to cause side effects when a fact gets retracted by the truth maintenance mechanism? #2017-08-06Â 00:43:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ demo:
#2017-08-06Â 00:45:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule makes-chan
  [?a <- A]
  [?b <- B]
  =>
  (let [chan (somehow-make it)]
    ;; Not sure what you do with `chan` here
    (r/insert! (->LogicalThing ?a ?b))
    (r/insert-unconditional! (->OpenedChan chan))))

(defrule closes-chan
  [:not [LogicalThing]]
  [?oc <- OpenedChan (= ?chan chan)]
  =>
  (r/retract! ?oc)
  (close-the ?chan))
#2017-08-06Â 00:46:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think it just gets sort of dirty when you are managing your own unconditional facts and retracts - typically a pattern to avoid

#2017-08-06Â 01:05:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ yeah, Iâ€™ve wanted to look at that codebase sometime soon
#2017-08-06Â 01:05:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ seems like some interesting stuff
#2017-08-06Â 05:18:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Several people have had use cases that sounded like what they were looking for was the ability to get the changes in query results relative to an earlier state, and it sounds like that sort of functionality might be what youâ€™re looking for as well @mrchance . That could be done with some wrappers in your code around the session along the lines of â€œQuery the session, store the results, insert/retract facts, fire the rules, then query again and diff the resultsâ€. It could be done as a Clara listener too by tracking on the listening calls in QueryNode: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.15.2/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L430
#2017-08-06Â 05:22:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ It is functionality that I think would be useful for Clara itself to provide at some point, a listener to do that would probably get into Claraâ€™s internal impl details somewhat e.g. â€œis this node a QueryNode?â€ logic. Wouldnâ€™t matter if it was part of Clara and tested there though.
#2017-08-06Â 13:10:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mrchanceÂ @wparker True, that's another way to look at it. This might work too. Your answer also makes me wonder if Datascript would be the better choice for this usecase though, since there you get the transaction logs anyway
#2017-08-07Â 14:03:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I havenâ€™t had occasion to use DataScript, but it also seems like something that could be useful for a use-case like what you describe @mrchance . #2017-08-13Â 19:51:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hagmonkÂ Can anyone explain why the following case doesn't do what I expect?
#2017-08-13Â 19:52:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hagmonkÂ 
(let [matched    (dsl/parse-rule
                   [[:eav
                     (= ?attribute (:attribute this))
                     (= ?attribute_value (:attribute_value this))
                     (= ?id (:id this))]]
                   (insert! {:type ?attribute :id ?id :value ?attribute_value}))

      unscreened (dsl/parse-rule
                   [[:state
                     (= (:value this) 2)
                     (= ?id (:id this))]
                    [:milestone
                     (= (:value this) -1)
                     (= ?id (:id this))]]
                   (insert! {:type :unscreened :id ?id}))

      type-query (dsl/parse-query [] [[?unscreened <- :unscreened]])

      session    (mk-session [matched unscreened type-query] :fact-type-fn :type :cache false)]
  (time (-> session
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :state :attribute_value 2 :id 33695360})
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :milestone :attribute_value -1 :id 33695360})
            fire-rules
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :milestone :attribute_value 123456 :id 33695360})
            fire-rules
            (query type-query))))
#2017-08-13Â 19:52:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hagmonkÂ I insert two facts which cause a third fact of type :unscreened to be inserted
#2017-08-13Â 19:53:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hagmonkÂ I then fire the rules, and insert another fact which should negate the earlier fact
#2017-08-13Â 19:53:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hagmonkÂ Instead, when I query the session for :unscreened, I see that fact still present
#2017-08-14Â 15:18:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â curtis.shafferÂ @olivergeorge authorization on the database is something that can be done; certain databases (Oracle is the one that comes to mind) support triggers which you could use to detect changes
#2017-08-14Â 15:22:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â curtis.shafferÂ @hagmonk as far as I can tell, all three of those facts will still be in the session; the 3rd fact insertion does not negate the 2nd fact insertion. the :id field makes me think that you want it to be an update, which is not what is done
#2017-08-14Â 15:38:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ @hagmonk What Curtis said. You could use an accumlator to grab the highest valued :milestone fact. or if you are looking for all non negative, you could add a :not constraint. Depends on what you are looking for.
#2017-08-14Â 17:50:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @olivergeorge it might help if you can clarify your question. From Claraâ€™s point of view, it doesnâ€™t matter what the ultimate source of the data it processes is. Note though that if rules do things that depend on ordering you have to be careful since Clara can fire and then retract a rule; the contract when using truth maintenance is that the state of the rules engine works out before fire-rules returns. But if you, say, performed operations on a database in a rule RHS youâ€™d have to be careful about controlling rule ordering with salience etc. Our workflows typically involve something retrieving data, providing the data to Clara, firing the rules, querying the resulting session, and then saving the query results - does that help?
#2017-08-15Â 04:38:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Yes thanks. That makes sense.

#2017-08-17Â 22:20:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @enn Strictly speaking no, but with a custom ancestors fn you can create a new type that is the parent of multiple types for whatever fact types youâ€™re working with
#2017-08-17Â 22:21:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Same goes for other condition types as well
#2017-08-17Â 22:21:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ e.g. if you have FactTypeA and FactTypeB, you can make FactTypeC a parent of both
#2017-08-17Â 22:22:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ then [?facts <- (acc/all) :from [FactTypeC (â€¦)]] would accumulate on both FactTypeA and FactTypeC
#2017-08-17Â 22:22:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ see http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ for more info

#2017-08-18Â 20:52:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @enn Iâ€™ll add on more possibility to this: > Can an accumulator accumulate across more than one fact type (joined on some field)? All of the examples show only a single fact type in the :from clause. You can also â€œwrapâ€ multiple types of facts in a common fact type and accumulate instead on that.
#2017-08-18Â 20:52:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ without a need of actually creating a real ancestor, hierarchical change
#2017-08-18Â 20:55:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrecord CommonWrap [wrapped])

(r/defrule wrap-fact-a
[?a <- FactA]
=>
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?a)))

(r/defrule wrap-fact-b
[?b <- FactB]
=>
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?b)))


(r/defrule accum-them
[?acc <- my-accumulator :from [CommonWrap]]
<etc>
=>
<rhs>)
#2017-08-18Â 20:56:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the accumulator could just access the original, field â€œxâ€, like (-> w :wrapped :x)
#2017-08-18Â 20:56:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ or you could make it have the same fields as the original even with 
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?a))
#2017-08-18Â 20:58:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > There would need to be some changes to Clara as well for this, not just Schema. Yeah, I think clara.rules.compiler would probably require the most work on self-hosting

#2017-08-22Â 16:11:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I donâ€™t understand your question - could you clarify?

#2017-08-22Â 19:51:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ I'm having trouble with: lein test - pass all my tests *on repl* - I can test multiple times and get ok, but when I reload the rules namespace, all rules behavior change (my test fail) How to debug?
#2017-08-23Â 13:38:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @souenzzo There are a couple pitfalls on the that can happen. One is that the rule session is being cached, so you're re-running previous rules. This can be turned off by passing :cache false to mk-session as described at http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.15.2/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-mk-session
#2017-08-23Â 13:39:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The other pitfall that can happen is if you're reloading your fact types, the reloaded types may be a different class than what Clara was compiled against, so the facts won't match.
#2017-08-23Â 13:39:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ This can also be addressed by not caching the rules session as described above, or by placing the fact types in a namespace that isn't reloaded in your REPL.
#2017-08-23Â 13:40:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Of course, this only applies if you're using the Java or Clojure type system for your facts (which is the default) rather than using a custom fact type.
#2017-08-23Â 14:12:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ Already tryied with :cache false, :cache true...
#2017-08-23Â 14:12:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ I will try to move defrecord to another ns
#2017-08-23Â 14:29:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ Oh. I noticed that my problems started when I started importing records in different namespaces. (still moving to test if records in a "standalone" ns will solve)
#2017-08-23Â 14:46:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ fixed. @ryanbrush clara docs should contains this info.
#2017-08-23Â 19:25:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @souenzzo Just to add to this conversation: This does sound like something that may be a good idea to point out in some sort of Clara docs, especially concerning development time. However, records getting redefined I think is often at odds with a dynamic repl reloading workflow. I donâ€™t think Clara is the only place affected.
#2017-08-23Â 19:27:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not to suggest to use this lib or not, just to point out Iâ€™ve seen the same concern addressed before https://github.com/ztellman/potemkin/blob/0.4.4/src/potemkin/types.clj#L326
#2017-08-23Â 19:28:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ At one point Plumatic (formerly prismatic) Schema actually defaulted to using potemkins defrecord+ to avoid recreated classes with the same name, that have no impl change, in a new dynamic classloader during (probably repl) reloads
#2017-08-23Â 19:29:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (still exists in schema now, but as an â€œoptionalâ€ dependency https://github.com/plumatic/schema/blob/schema-1.1.6/src/clj/schema/potemkin.clj)
#2017-08-23Â 19:30:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m just pointing this out because in the past I used this â€œnon reloadingâ€ style of defrecord to avoid weird issues with a record class getting reloading, with references still around to the old version of the class
#2017-08-23Â 19:30:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can get away with moving record definitions into some namespace you are careful to not :reload though
#2017-08-23Â 19:31:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ as long as you donâ€™t want to do something like :reload-all

#2017-08-25Â 13:44:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @iku000888 Iâ€™m thinking youâ€™d probably write 2 rules in that case
#2017-08-25Â 13:44:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ or do some of the joining on the RHS - which I often hesitate to think is a good idea
#2017-08-25Â 13:45:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))

(r/defrule nil-joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))
#2017-08-25Â 13:45:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ is that the â€œleft joinâ€ sort of thing?
#2017-08-25Â 13:46:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ A always produce a C, just sometimes there is no B to go with an A
#2017-08-25Â 13:46:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ C can hold whatever info you wanted out of the join
#2017-08-28Â 00:26:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â @mikerod Thanks! I was struggling because for this specific problem coming up it was not clear how to create facts that are [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
#2017-08-28Â 00:27:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â (I would only have facts that are [B (= ?id id)])
#2017-08-28Â 00:28:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â But over the weekend I thought of retracting A's that do have a matching B
#2017-08-28Â 00:28:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â Seems it should do the job
#2017-08-28Â 00:28:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â iku000888Â ðŸ™‚
#2017-08-29Â 17:20:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ I have a shared entry point into a rule session where a namespace associated with specific rules/queries can be applied: 
(defn run-rules
  "Runs a rule session given a rule namespace, a root state tree node, and a performed action."
  [ns root action]
  (let [session (-> (r/mk-session 'justice.rules.shared ns)
                    (r/insert (->Tree (walk/prewalk tree/augment-if-node root))
                              (->Action action))
                    (r/fire-rules))]
  ...
However, I get a No namespace exception when I pass a namespace in eg. (run-rules 'justice.rules.x ..). I've "fixed" the issue by adding (require ns) inside run-rules, but is there a better way to accomplish this? I could for example just require the namespaces in the ns declaration, or I could have a whitelist of namespaces to require, but I'd like to keep adding new namespaces to be as simple as creating a new namespace and passing it in to the generic shared entrypoint.
#2017-08-29Â 19:21:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > Thanks! I was struggling because for this specific problem coming up it was not clear how to create facts that are [:not [B (= ?id id)]] @iku000888 sorry for long delay, just saw your response. Iâ€™m not sure what you mean to create a fact to match a negation (ie condition with a :not). The negation condition is used in conjuction with the [A (= ?id id)] in my example. This together forms a â€œjoinâ€ sort of query for all A that do not have a matching B. So back to that example, repeating for clarity: 
(r/defrule joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))

(r/defrule nil-joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))
The rule names may not be the best, but sticking with them: * The rule joins is for the typical â€œinner joinâ€ matches - it matches A with Bs they go with * The rule nil-joins is for the â€œouter leftâ€ part of the join - it keeps the A results that do not have any actual join with a B This may not be the specific issue you had, but that was my interpretation of your â€œleft-joinâ€ type of rule question. Given that you have something with retraction working, Iâ€™m thinking this is a different problem you are wanting to solve.
#2017-08-29Â 19:22:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair Clojure or ClojureScript?
#2017-08-29Â 19:25:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Either way though, r/mk-session doesnâ€™t attempt to require namespace for you.
#2017-08-29Â 19:25:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m not positive that would be a great idea either. Best practice in clj would be to be sure to appropriately declare the namespace you want to have compiled - most preferably in the ns header :requires
#2017-08-29Â 19:26:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You could get away with a dynamic require call in your run-rules though. Iâ€™ve had use-cases doing that before to load rules from arbitrary namespaces
#2017-08-29Â 19:26:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t think there is a â€œbetter way to accomplish itâ€ though in terms of what Clara currently offers.
#2017-08-29Â 19:26:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It expects things to already be compiled
#2017-08-29Â 19:40:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ @mikerod thanks, this would be regular clojure. I've moved away from dynamic require, as it was adding unnecessary compilation overhead (in terms of performance). I'm still using a ns-whitelist var though rather than using the (ns .. (:require ..)) form as I've had some formatters remove the references as they are "unused".
#2017-08-29Â 19:41:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah, if you wait to do a require in the fn, it could be a pretty big slowdown depending on the size of it
#2017-08-29Â 19:42:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and perhaps could be better suited at â€œcompilation timeâ€ with whatever else you have to start up the app
#2017-08-29Â 19:42:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not to get too lost in the weeds, but Clara does have a few other alternatives instead of loading whole nsâ€™s of rules
#2017-08-29Â 19:45:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For example, you can provide collections of rules to r/mk-session 
(defrule r1 <etc>)
(defrule r2 <etc>)
(defrule r3 <etc>)

(def rule-group1 [r1 r2 r3])

(defrule r4 <etc>)
(defrule r5 <etc>)
(defquery q1 <etc>)

(def rule-group2 [r4 r5 q1])

(defrule r6 <etc>)


<....>

(r/mk-session rule-group1 rule-group2 [r6])
#2017-08-30Â 18:24:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dadair Agreed with @mikerod â€˜s previous comments. I wanted to add that namespace compilation can have arbitrary effects in Clojure; one notable one is protocol extensions. That is, a linter removing namespace whose vars you arenâ€™t directly using from your requires could be dangerous to things other than Clara. Also, note that require will short-circuits if the namespace already exists unless you specifically request reloading, so the performance question is really whether you pay the cost at initialization of your Clojure environment or the first time you build the relevant session.
#2017-08-29Â 19:46:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so you can pick in choose at different granularities is my point
#2017-08-30Â 17:38:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Hi I am a newbie who is looking to use clara to help understand large nested maps. Is there an easy way to turn a large nested map into a series of facts?

Perhaps just a recursive function that concatenates the facts at each nested level of the map/level of recursion?
#2017-08-31Â 16:22:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ is it safe to call insert! from different threads? e.g., within a future? I have a way to not need this (e.g., gather data with the future and then insert! from the main thread), I'm more just curious.
#2017-08-31Â 17:42:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair I think that is a sort of tough question
#2017-08-31Â 17:42:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It seems dangerous to assume semantically
#2017-08-31Â 17:43:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I do think that implementation-wise, as long as every thread has fully completed their r/insert! prior to r/fire-rules it may work
#2017-08-31Â 17:43:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ That isnâ€™t to say I think it is a supported use-case
#2017-08-31Â 17:43:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So in general, during the â€œfire rules loopâ€ cycle of the rules engine, the memory is in a mutable state
#2017-08-31Â 17:44:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This is done primarily for performance. The caller perceives the working memory to be a persistent, immutable data structure that is returned after each call to r/fire-rules on a given sesion
#2017-08-31Â 17:45:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, r/insert! (and a few other similar ones) is called from rule RHSâ€™s. That means it is sort of in that â€œfire rules loopâ€ part of the lifecycle
#2017-08-31Â 17:50:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ yeah that makes sense, I thought as much
#2017-08-31Â 21:07:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ accumulators respect saliency?
#2017-08-31Â 23:00:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @souenzzo salience controls when a rule RHS (right-hand side, or consequence in other terms) fires; whether an accumulator is in the rule doesnâ€™t impact it either way. It wonâ€™t control the time you actually run the accumulator, though Iâ€™m not sure why youâ€™d want to do that.
#2017-09-01Â 14:31:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Well, I know Drools (popular Java-based rules engine)(prior to v6) used to have a good amount of performance issues around accumulators.
#2017-09-01Â 14:31:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Especially several in a rule
#2017-09-01Â 14:31:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so people used to wish that salience would â€œdelayâ€ their evaluation
#2017-09-01Â 14:32:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Later on, a lot of laziness was added to Drools, but even more importantly (in my opinion) â€œbatchedâ€ propagations of facts and it mostly solved the common issues around performance that came up.
#2017-09-01Â 14:32:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara has â€œbatchedâ€ propagation of facts, which seems to typically work out well. The engine basically â€œgathersâ€ up collections of facts at a time that are matching conditions before propagating down the network. This results in typically less churn/rework as the data flows.
#2017-09-01Â 14:33:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Just pointing that out if the question of salience was more about performance than ordering semantics

#2017-09-01Â 20:05:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For one, there is some eval going on, which means it is running the clj compiler and I often see that time dominate for larger rulebaseâ€™s
#2017-09-01Â 20:06:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (terminology things: the â€œrulebaseâ€ term just means the underlying â€œstatessâ€ Rete-based graph that is wired together with working memory within the â€œsessionâ€)
#2017-09-01Â 20:06:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ To answer your next question, you have to build the r/mk-session with all rules/queries involved at once

#2017-09-07Â 13:42:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair I donâ€™t see how it should be different. Do you have a more complete rule example?
#2017-09-07Â 13:42:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Just to be sure you donâ€™t have any extra constructs in play?
#2017-09-07Â 14:53:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dadair @U0LK1552A I wouldnâ€™t expect that kind of ordering to make a difference for non-accumulator rule conditions normally. If you are using manual retractions in rule RHSâ€™s (right-hand-sides) you might be able to get yourself into some odd situations with undefined behavior that could be impacted. A more concrete reproducing example would be helpful to see if thereâ€™s a bug. For accumulators, it isnâ€™t the easiest edge case to hit, but https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/218 is outstanding.
#2017-09-07Â 14:54:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Also, regarding your example 
`[A (= ?x x)] [B (= ?y y)]
` I wouldnâ€™t actually expect whether x or y is nil to impact whether the rule fires at least based on those conditions alone
#2017-09-07Â 14:56:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ those arenâ€™t result bindings, having a field value of a fact be nil (but the fact itself being nil) is a reasonable possibility and Clara will handle that
#2017-09-07Â 15:03:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yep, thatâ€™s the reason was asking for more details to be sure there arenâ€™t things like accumulators in play. Things get more complicated then.
#2017-09-07Â 16:20:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ There seemed to be an issue with using a pre-cached rule session. I was looping through some known mk-session configurations and swapping them into an atom so I could avoid the first performance hit. Then later I'd pull the specific session out of the atom and would insert some facts and fire rules. For some reason this was causing really weird rule activation problems
#2017-09-07Â 16:21:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ So for now I've inlined the mk-session and am taking the performance hit until I can figure out what was going on
#2017-09-07Â 14:03:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Could someone please explain the rhs please - I have put a print and an insert! following on from each other on the rhs and the print always happens even if the rule fails?
#2017-09-07Â 14:12:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mmer The most typical way to structure rules is in a way that they logically express their constraints, but do not necessarily have a guaranteed order the RHS may fire in. insert! inserts facts that are subject to the â€œtruth maintenance systemâ€ (aka the TMS) of the rules engine. If a rule fires at some point due to a, potentially transient, match of some facts, but later some of those facts are retracted, the engine will automatically retract the facts that relied on that match being present.
#2017-09-07Â 14:12:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ When you do a side-effect like a print, there is no way to â€œretractâ€ the side effect
#2017-09-07Â 14:14:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are ways to structure rules that would prevent them from being able to ever fire their RHS â€œearlyâ€. This can be done with setting up the rule to not be able to fire due to some â€œblockingâ€ or â€œguardingâ€ criteria in the LHS that you know will not change itâ€™s truthiness later. Also, you can sometimes do some tricks with :salience. However, in many cases, the best idea may be to just avoid the side-effects in the RHS and perhaps do them outside of the rules based on the facts that are found via queries after performing a fire-rules cycle.
#2017-09-07Â 14:15:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There is some documentation on the TMS @ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/
#2017-09-07Â 14:25:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ That helps. I thought I was going mad!
#2017-09-07Â 14:36:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mmer yeah, it can be a tricky detail
#2017-09-07Â 14:38:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ The docs say you can nest the boolean operators [:not, :or] etc. I have tried to do something like [:not [:or [] []] without much success. Is this just plain wrong on my part?
#2017-09-07Â 14:56:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mmer things can get a little tricky with that
#2017-09-07Â 14:57:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So it is good to note that :or is sort of â€œsyntactic sugarâ€ in rules
#2017-09-07Â 14:57:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It can almost be thought of as just splitting the rule into 2 (or more depending on logic in use) rules
#2017-09-07Â 14:59:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ e.g. 
(r/defrule with-or
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:or
   [B (= ?id id)]
   [C (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))
Is similar to just writing 
(r/defrule side-one
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))

(r/defrule side-two
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [C (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))
#2017-09-07Â 14:59:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The point in that case is that there isnâ€™t something like â€œshort-circuitingâ€
#2017-09-07Â 15:00:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and the :or has certain variable visibility issues due to how that works out
#2017-09-07Â 15:00:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ When it comes to :not + :or and/or nested :and, it may also be good to note that the engine will convert to DNF (disjunctive normal form)
#2017-09-07Â 15:00:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There may be some variable visibility issues in that transition in certain complex cases
#2017-09-07Â 15:13:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mmer but if you have an example that demonstrates an issue you are seeing, itâ€™d be probably clearer to just look at that one and explain what is going on
#2017-09-07Â 15:14:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ I have eventually just split the rules in two so I do not need the not
#2017-09-07Â 15:21:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ sometimes it is clearer to split things up from an comprehension perspective anyways
#2017-09-07Â 15:24:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Probably the most details on this subject can be found in the lengthy old issue comments @ https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/149
#2017-09-07Â 15:24:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ as far as some of the transformations that happen
#2017-09-07Â 15:25:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Only if you were interesting in details though. ðŸ˜› Probably not super easy to read through.
#2017-09-07Â 15:44:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Thanks
#2017-09-07Â 16:04:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ To be more precise - when I load up the rules/queries into the session I get :
#2017-09-07Â 16:04:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ ExceptionInfo Value does not match schema: {:constraints [(not ("s-expression" ?composition)) (not ("s-expression" a-clojure.lang.Symbol))]} schema.core/validator/fn--1296 (core.clj:155)
