#2017-09-07Â 16:58:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s hard to decipher without the actual rule DSL that was written (probably could be improved in Clara to try to capture that better) There is probably some missing [ ] if not just having syntax out of order
#2017-09-12Â 14:11:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ I have a singleton fact that I insert for referencing that contains a large map (hundreds of KB), and is a part of the LHS of most of my rules, so that the RHS can use the map when inserting more rules. Are there any performance issues to consider here? Or ways to exploit the fact that it is a singleton and will never need to be compared between multiple instances? I know with persistent structures it isn't inefficient to have the large map in multiple places, but was wondering last night if perhaps there was a better way to reference it. The LHS query for it is dead simple: [Tree (= ?root root)] in all cases
#2017-09-12Â 16:49:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair I donâ€™t know of anything particularly harmful in the big fact like that
#2017-09-12Â 16:50:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s probably best to make sure it has a â€œtypeâ€ that is distinct from anything else
#2017-09-12Â 16:50:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ beyond that, assuming it is immutable (as facts should be), a cached hashcode may become important
#2017-09-12Â 16:51:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clojure persistent maps cache hashcode
#2017-09-12Â 16:52:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You could also consider wrapping the big map in a custom type that optimizes equality checking and hashing too if you had noticeable perf issues come up
#2017-09-12Â 16:54:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Youâ€™re example does look like you have a type on it called Tree though, so I am not sure what implications that type has
#2017-09-12Â 16:56:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ Tree is just a record wrapper around a map so it works with the default Fact type identification
#2017-09-12Â 16:58:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For clarity: There are basically 2 situations that come to mind in this scenario: 1) How often is this big fact going to be compared to other different facts? 2) This big fact will be part of a token that is stored in memory. This token is sometimes used as a hash map sort of key. If this is hashed too often, the hash code may become a bottleneck. For (1) If the fact has a unique type that no other facts have, it should only ever be compared to maybe itself. The equals check should be fast tehre since most equals implâ€™s will short-circuit on the identical? (or Java == case) For (2) Clojure maps default to caching hash codes. Clojure records do not, prior to what looks like 1.9 (not yet fully released at least (see https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-1224))
#2017-09-12Â 16:59:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So if anything, if your Tree wrapper is made via defrecord, you may be able to see some time spent recalculating the hash code when if this fact ends up being involved in a lot of rules LHS â€œtokensâ€
#2017-09-12Â 16:59:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Tokens contain a sequence of all the facts that matched for a particular successful invocation of the rule
#2017-09-12Â 17:00:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Then again, I may not get worked up about this situation unless you can see measurable issues with perf
#2017-09-12Â 17:02:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ Thanks for the advice, I'm just trying to keep some performance considerations in my back pocket in case I need to improve performance. This Tree is somewhat like a database, so it will continue to grow over time. I'm already seeing processing times approach >= 100ms for the rule engine and I generally want things to be below ~50ms for some soft real-time constraints we have
#2017-09-12Â 17:04:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ hmm
#2017-09-12Â 17:04:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I typically use VisualVM
#2017-09-12Â 17:04:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ start the â€œsampling CPUâ€ profiler
#2017-09-12Â 17:04:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ to clarify: the tree does not change within a rule session, only between rule sessions
#2017-09-12Â 17:04:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ then run whatever takes the tiem Iâ€™m interested in
#2017-09-12Â 17:05:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ then you take a â€œsnapshotâ€, view the snapshot by drilling down through a fairly large callstack
#2017-09-12Â 17:05:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it has visuals to show how much time is being spent where in the callstacks
#2017-09-12Â 17:06:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For this particular concern I had above, Iâ€™d just try to get to the â€œbottomâ€ of the larger time callstacks and see if I can find references to, in this example, the Tree object getting equiv or hash sort of calls on it
#2017-09-12Â 17:07:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ great I'll give that a try, thanks
#2017-09-12Â 17:10:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ no problem. Iâ€™m always willing to take a look at a profiler snapshot, a portion of it, or just say â€œI see lots of time in Clara function X, any ideas?â€ too if you find those parts to be hard to sort through. Iâ€™m not sure how easy it may be to read profiler snapshots sometimes if not familiar with the codebase and/or the way clj compiles out java class names
#2017-09-13Â 00:06:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I'm experimenting to see if I can rewrite my webapp form logic using Clara rules.
#2017-09-13Â 00:08:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ The existing code does multiple passes: Field definitions and values used to generate cleaned field data and errors Field data and errors used by logic which might (1) show/hide fields, (2) disable/enable fields, (3) change field values, (4) manage relationships between fields... (lots of stuff). I borrowed the approach Django uses for form and field validation, they document it well here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/forms/validation/
#2017-09-13Â 00:08:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ The current approach has functions which take the form (field definitions, values...) and return a modified version
#2017-09-13Â 00:09:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Iteratively manipulating the data
#2017-09-13Â 00:09:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I don't think Clara would work in this way
#2017-09-13Â 00:11:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ My guess is I need each phase to have it's own facts so that each phase of the form processing can use previous phase's facts as inputs.
#2017-09-13Â 00:11:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Not sure if I'm explaining that well
#2017-09-13Â 00:13:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Specific question: Am I correct that it's a bad idea to try and reproduce the "modify data" approach I'm currently using.
#2017-09-13Â 00:25:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ @olivergeorge correct, mutating data in Clara is discouraged (though not impossible). I am doing something similar actually with form field- and form-level validation. I don't do multi-pass internally in the rule engine, but rather the rule engine is called multiple times from (essentially) a reduce, which collects the final modifications to perform at the end
#2017-09-13Â 00:26:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ so the rule engine doesn't actually modify the forms, rather it returns what operations to perform in order to modify it
#2017-09-13Â 00:26:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ then the reduce can take those, perform them, and send the modified form back to the rule engine, and it goes until it stabilizes
#2017-09-13Â 00:40:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Gotcha, thanks @dadair that makes sense
#2017-09-13Â 01:37:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ @dadair how do you check for stability? data comparison or does clara provide a "no new facts" test
#2017-09-13Â 01:39:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ stability from the rules side of things would be it returning from fire-rules, otherwise it wouldn keep going. "stability" in terms of your domain is different. For example, in that external reduce you would query the session for operations, if the query returns nothing, you could know that "the form is stable"
#2017-09-13Â 01:40:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ it all depends on how you set up your system

[A (false? x)]

#2017-09-13Â 20:03:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ For constraints that can be determined to be true or false without any reference to other facts Clara will evaluate them upfront without trying to join them with anything and if they are false Clara wonâ€™t retain a reference to them
#2017-09-13Â 20:03:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So for example, in the latter case, Iâ€™d expect Clara to retain a hard reference to every A inserted
#2017-09-13Â 20:04:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ while in the former case, it wouldnâ€™t retain a reference to an A without a value of false in field x
#2017-09-13Â 20:05:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ In cases where you do joins it can also be more efficient to have Clara do as much filtering as it can on each fact in isolation - apart from evaluating your join criteria, there is some (highly optimized) overhead to keeping track of joins
#2017-09-13Â 20:08:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ ok great thanks
#2017-09-13Â 20:00:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ other than if you want to use ?x later in the RHS

#2017-09-13Â 21:19:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it just is more opaque to the engine and could mean youâ€™re skipping out on optimizations

#2017-09-13Â 21:33:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ As far as the actual effects of the example you give here, I donâ€™t know there is a big difference. There is definitely a â€œlittleâ€ more overhead to adding the :test node, but Iâ€™m not sure you lose any particular optimizations in this particular case. Iâ€™d have to mess with it more to be sure though. However, still, Iâ€™d just go with my general rule here. ðŸ™‚
#2017-09-13Â 21:35:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ absolutely, thanks for the help!
#2017-09-13Â 22:48:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I'm trying to encode some form logic which disables dependent fields (e.g. can't pick building if site isn't set, can't pick floor if building isn't set...)
#2017-09-13Â 22:48:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ My rules don't terminate
#2017-09-13Â 22:49:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ 
(ns spike-rules.core
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Operation [field-key field-state])

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?ops <- (acc/all :field-state) :from [Operation (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (println :update-fieldstate ?field-key)
  (insert! (->FieldState ?field-key (reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops))))

(defrule rule2
  "Insert field disable operation if a field depends on a field which is not set"
  [FieldState (= ?nil-field-key field-key) (= (nil? (:value field-state)))]
  [FieldState (= ?disable-field-key field-key) (contains? (:depends-on field-state) ?nil-field-key)]
  =>
  (println :disable-dependent ?disable-field-key)
  (insert! (->Operation ?disable-field-key {:disabled true})))

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil})
      (->Field :bl {:value nil :depends-on #{:site}})
      (->Field :fl {:value nil :depends-on #{:bl}}))
    (rules/fire-rules))
#2017-09-13Â 22:50:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Perhaps rule1 is bad practice. I'm using it to combine the original field state with any operations which modify it. (in this case adding a :disable flag)
#2017-09-13Â 22:51:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ @dadair I was trying to avoid having to do the "merge field with ops" manually and refiring rules. That's the approach you were describing, correct?
#2017-09-13Â 22:58:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ We actually do it slightly differently. In our case, the rule engine inserts the current state of the form, and the operation the user is trying to perform. Then there are rules that check if that operation is valid given the current state of the form. If it's valid, it returns a transformation of the input action that can actually be performed/persisted by an external state management service. If it's invalid, it transforms the input action to an action that will invalidate the field (or reject the action out-right), which is then again carried out by the external state management service
#2017-09-13Â 22:59:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â defndainesÂ Might add in a 
(println "?ops " ?ops)
as part of rule1.
#2017-09-13Â 23:11:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ @defndaines that shows that rule1 is firing repeatedly for the empty ops case. 
Loading src/spike_rules/round1.clj... 
:update-fieldstate :site []
:update-fieldstate :fl []
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:disable-dependent :fl
:disable-dependent :bl
:update-fieldstate :fl []
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:disable-dependent :bl
:disable-dependent :fl
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:update-fieldstate :fl []
Hmm, that makes me think it's not doing what I expect. It should have an operation for disabling that field.

#2017-09-13Â 23:26:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ @defndaines I don't think that would work. I want field -> fieldstate even if ops is empty. That way rule2 has a full list of field-state facts to consider.
#2017-09-13Â 23:27:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Problem is that acc/all doesn't seem to ever return the inserted Operations facts
#2017-09-13Â 23:29:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ There's a feedback loop which seems a possible problem: * rule 1 inserts FieldState (before any Operations are inserted) * rule 2 fires because it sees a FieldState which should be disabled * rule 1 sees a new Operation and does truth maintenance to update the field's FieldState
#2017-09-13Â 23:30:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Odd thing is that I don't ever see the Operation in Rule 1 via acc/all (the third step described)
#2017-09-13Â 23:30:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I'm new to this, likely user error or bad assumptions on how things should work
#2017-09-13Â 23:43:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @olivergeorge acc/all returns an empty collection when no matches.
#2017-09-13Â 23:43:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m not sure that youâ€™ve already realized that, so pointing it out
#2017-09-13Â 23:44:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule foo
 [?xs <- (acc/all) :from [X]]
 [:test (seq ?xs)]
 =>
 (prn :foo))
Something like that would ensure that the rule wasnâ€™t activated with no matches
#2017-09-13Â 23:45:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Looks like the acc/all docs could be a bit clearer on that
#2017-09-13Â 23:45:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Believe it or not, it actually can be useful for it to match with the empty collection in other use-cases.
#2017-09-13Â 23:49:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ @mikerod Thanks Mike. The curious thing is that an inserted Operation is never returned from (all). I'll take a step back to understand truth maintenance better.
#2017-09-13Â 23:52:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Simpler example 
(ns spike-rules.round1
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Operation [field-key field-state])

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?ops <- (acc/all) :from [Operation (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (println :rule1.ops ?ops)
  (println :rule1.insert! `(->FieldState ~?field-key ~(reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops)))
  (insert! (->FieldState ?field-key (reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops))))

(defrule rule2
  "disable if read-only"
  [FieldState (= ?field-key field-key) (:read-only field-state)]
  =>
  (println :rule2.insert! `(->Operation ~?field-key {:disabled true}))
  (insert! (->Operation ?field-key {:disabled true})))

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil :read-only true}))
    (rules/fire-rules))
Returns 
Loading src/spike_rules/round1.clj... 
:rule1.ops []
:rule1.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->FieldState :site {:value nil, :read-only true})
:rule2.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->Operation :site {:disabled true})
:rule1.ops []
:rule1.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->FieldState :site {:value nil, :read-only true})
:rule2.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->Operation :site {:disabled true})
...
#2017-09-13Â 23:52:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ You could write a query to return all operations, if that query returns anything, then your memory does have operations inserted and it's your LHS of rule 1 that is incorrect
#2017-09-13Â 23:53:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Okay, thanks will do.
#2017-09-13Â 23:55:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Actually, not sure how to do a query when it won't terminate.
#2017-09-13Â 23:55:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I appreciate all the help
#2017-09-13Â 23:55:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I'll take some time to learn more and try again.
#2017-09-14Â 00:02:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ oh right it isn't terminating
#2017-09-14Â 00:02:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ in that case I'd write a rule that should match on ANY Operation, and have a println on the RHS
#2017-09-14Â 00:02:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ that way it should activate if an Operation is ever inserted
#2017-09-14Â 00:03:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @olivergeorge This is rough, but hopefully correct (thought about it quickly) So I think the loop goes like this (only including relevant fields): 1) insert Field{:field-key :site :read-only true} 2) activate rule1 3) fire rule1 - insert FieldState{:field-key :site :read-only true} 4) activate rule2 5) fire rule2 - insert Operation{:field-key :site} 6) retract previous rule1 results since (acc/all) changed 7) retract previous rule2 results since rule1 retracted the matching fact changed ;; due to (6) 8) retract previous rule1 results since (acc/all) changed ;; due to (7) - no actual retraction needed here, just updates the accumulator again (6) already retracted 9) (re-)activate rule1 ;; due to (8) 10) insert Field{:field-key :site :read-only true} ;; no Op1 anymore 11) repeat (4) and (5) 12) repeat (6) (7) ( 8 ) (9) 13) keep repeating (11) (12)
#2017-09-14Â 00:06:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Ah! right. That makes sense. Thank you.
#2017-09-14Â 00:06:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I missed the op retraction.
#2017-09-14Â 00:06:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so you have to do something to avoid the cycle that starts there
#2017-09-14Â 00:06:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ perhaps checking some field that would stop the â€œfeedback loopâ€
#2017-09-14Â 00:06:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but itâ€™d be domain dependent I think to know the answer in that particular case
#2017-09-14Â 00:08:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I wondered about having a fire-rules loop and doing (field+ops => field-state) aggregation between iterations.
#2017-09-14Â 00:09:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ I can see other possibilities.
#2017-09-14Â 00:09:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Thanks for putting me on track
#2017-09-14Â 00:10:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ @mikerod do you know of any solid references for designing forward inference rule systems? Or some common design patterns, etc?
#2017-09-14Â 00:39:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair good question. Iâ€™m donâ€™t really think I know a lot off the top of my head. Which is unfortunate
#2017-09-14Â 00:39:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™ll have to think about that one
#2017-09-14Â 01:52:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Is there a simple way to extract all facts from a session?
#2017-09-14Â 01:53:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ My best guess is query with an expression whose fact type is an ancestor of all records which seems to work just fine for records using [?ret <- Object].
#2017-09-14Â 02:38:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ @dadairI was going to suggest that perhaps the Doorenbos paper might be worth checking for references but it's 150 pages long.
#2017-09-14Â 04:12:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ One technique which might have resolved my problem is using insert-unconditional! for Operations as that would ensure they aren't retracted (no feedback loop).
#2017-09-14Â 04:13:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Not sure if using insert-unconditional! is considered a code smell / something to be avoided rather than common usage.
#2017-09-14Â 04:27:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ 
(ns spike-rules.round1
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! insert-unconditional! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Disabled [field-key])

(defn exists
  ([]
   (acc/accum
     {:initial-value     false
      :reduce-fn         (constantly true)})))

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?disabled <- (exists) :from [Disabled (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (insert!
    (cond-> (->FieldState ?field-key (:field-state ?field))
      ?disabled (assoc :disabled true))))

(defrule rule2
  "disable if read-only"
  [FieldState (= ?field-key field-key) (:read-only field-state)]
  [:not [Disabled (= ?field-key field-key)]]
  =>
  (insert-unconditional! (->Disabled ?field-key)))

(defquery export-facts [] [?ret <- Object])

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2 export-facts])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil :read-only true}))
    (rules/fire-rules)
    (rules/query export-facts))
#2017-09-14Â 16:09:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > I was going to suggest that perhaps the Doorenbos paper might be worth checking for references but itâ€™s 150 pages long. @olivergeorge I do think that this paper is a great explanation of Rete (skipping some of the out-dated about some of the â€œtestbedâ€ system parts). Iâ€™m not sure it has a lot on â€œhow to structure and design rules in practiceâ€ though.
#2017-09-14Â 16:11:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ When looking for that sort of guidance I think Iâ€™ve sort of just hunted around the internet searching for like â€œrules engines best practicesâ€

#2017-09-14Â 16:12:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @olivergeorge Iâ€™d be careful using insert-unconditional!
#2017-09-14Â 16:12:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You start to get into an order dependent situation with your rules
#2017-09-14Â 16:13:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if an â€œupstreamâ€ fact from a different rule is logically inserted and later retracted, but a downstream insert-unconditional! has already happened, it wonâ€™t be retracted and youâ€™ll get into an inconsistent state
#2017-09-14Â 16:13:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So then you end up having to do things like add :salience to try to force the rule to fire later than another and this ends up just becoming increasingly brittle
#2017-09-14Â 16:14:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, loses the â€œdeclarativeâ€ sort of property that you get with rules all being under control of the truth maintenance system
#2017-09-14Â 16:59:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Organizing rules sets - My rule set has become reasonably large within a short time. I keep getting issues with Exceptions against the schema. These are really difficult to resolve. I wonder if this is because I am running in a repl rather than outside? However, I thought I would divide my project into 4 namespaces - rules (for those I know work) worker (for any functions that help with processing my data into the working memory) queries . This then leave me with an issue about what to do with the record definitions that need to be available in all of these and in the core where I am creating the session. I either get cyclical dependencies if I put the record defs in any of these files - so I move them out into another records namespace and each of the above and the core require and refer this namespace. However when I run the mk->session if fails to find the record defs. Any ideas?
#2017-09-14Â 18:32:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ â€œHowever when I run the mk->session if fails to find the record defs. â€ It sounds like the namespace defining the records wasnâ€™t compiled then. In case you donâ€™t know, Clojure wonâ€™t actually compile a namespace until something requires it. It can be weird in that if you have a fully qualified reference, it will resolve even if the namespace in question doesnâ€™t require the namespace, but only if something required the namespace already. I personally think of Clojureâ€™s compiler as a â€œproceduralâ€ one that takes in code and alters the state of the runtime environment accordingly.
#2017-09-14Â 17:01:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ I have a shared namespace for shared records, then I build sessions like so: (r/mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x 'rules.y)
#2017-09-14Â 17:02:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ you need to make sure you are requiring the namespace too before making the session, I've run into that before
#2017-09-14Â 17:03:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ so either put rules.shared into the (ns .. (:require ..)) or do an explicit (require 'rules.shared)

#2017-09-14Â 21:02:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Thanks for the reply, BTW?
#2017-09-14Â 22:00:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ shared functions can live in the shared namespace
#2017-09-14Â 22:00:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ then in rules.x you can require rules.shared so you can use the functions
#2017-09-14Â 22:01:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ I only call (mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x ..) in a "core" namespace
#2017-09-14Â 22:02:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ so for example, rules.x, rules.y, and rules.z can require and use records/functions from rules.shared, and then in some other namespace rules.engine, you can require all the namespaces and call the mk-session function: (r/mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x ..)
#2017-09-14Â 22:02:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ that's how I've avoided circular dependencies

#2017-09-17Â 22:16:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mmer when defining types via defrecord (and similarly, deftype), a :refer from a :require does not import the class name to be used shorthand. So you need to refer to the class either by itâ€™s fully qualified name, or add something like 
(:import [rules.shared Thing])
to your rules namespaces using the class
#2017-09-18Â 15:12:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7143406/what-are-the-differences-among-require-import-and-use has an (IMO) nice concise summary of the differences @mmer. One other potential gotcha - if you define a record with hyphens in the namespace path, the Java class created will have underscores in the corresponding class name, and import needs the Java class name

#2017-09-22Â 00:56:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ Do facts inserted by rules with accumulators in the LHS observe truth maintenance retractions if the accumulator changes? i.e., if I have a max accumulator, and 5 facts are inserted, will the RHS facts be retracted for the four facts that aren't the max?

#2017-09-25Â 16:45:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ I have this clause in an LHS:

          (= ?test-id test-id)]]
Because the initial value of the max accumulator is nil, it never fires when there are no test-result facts. Am I missing some idiomatic way to have it fire in that case? Do I need to write my own accumulator with a different initial value? Can I do this with :or?

#2017-09-25Â 21:16:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickowsyÂ Is there a way to use accumulate with multiple fact_contraints? For example, if I have the facts 
{:e 2, :a :type, :v :dog}
{:e 2, :a :age, :v  12}
{:e 3, :a :type, :v :cat}
{:e 3, :a :age, :v 2}
{:e 4, :a :type, :v :dog}
{:e 4, :a :age, :v 10}
I would like to acc/all :type facts, matching :type is :dog and :age > 4. The :fact-type-fn is :a.
#2017-09-25Â 21:33:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
[:type
 (= (:v this) :dog)
 (= ?id (:e this))]

[?all <- (acc/all)
 :from [:age
        (= ?id (:e this))
        (> (:v this) 4)]
@nickowsy perhaps?
#2017-09-25Â 21:33:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So an accumulator that does a join with another fact

#2017-09-29Â 15:12:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In Drools (popular Java-based rules engine that I often reference since it was used a lot in the industry) there was a â€œfire until haltâ€ sort of method I believe it was called. This allowed to have a sort of â€œtimeoutâ€ feature that the rules would stop if they reached a certain threshold of time, steps, # rule firings, etc. So something like that is feasible to implement, but not in Clara right now.
#2017-09-29Â 15:13:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I do tend to try to avoid using something like :no-loop too and instead setup the rules in a way where they logically wonâ€™t loop. :no-loop starts to go against the logical truth maintenance in some cases.
#2017-09-29Â 15:14:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Understandably, there are cases where it is sort of hard to think about how you can make the rule logic you want not form a logical loop.
#2017-09-29Â 15:59:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ There is work logged for Clara to assume by default that after a certain number of iterations of looping that the rules were written incorrectly and throw an exception: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/275
#2017-09-29Â 16:01:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I agree with @mikerod â€˜s comments - perhaps another way of thinking about it is that if you just write a normal infinitely recursive function, Clojure or any other programming language can throw a StackOverflowException but canâ€™t automatically recover from it - the language would have to guess what the programmer actually wanted to do in order to accomplish that
#2017-09-29Â 16:02:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I see Claraâ€™s handling of infinitely looping rules as similar - thereâ€™s no way for Clara to guess what the user actually wanted to do

#2017-09-30Â 01:00:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ Does "query" is a slow operation? For lage sets, witch shoud be optimal? - One big query with "all"(possible) facts, with some "garbage" and use just what I really need - Many little query, with just what I really need,
#2017-10-01Â 04:54:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Queries are really just rules without a RHS, at least in the current implementation. There are some optimizations that could be done on queries that arenâ€™t valid for rules; for my part none of my use-cases have yet had enough of a problem to warrant spending the time implementing them. Note that the results are calculated during fire-rules, and calling â€œqueryâ€ is really just a map get operation. Filters that can be expressed as values of bindings can end up being expressed as just map gets if the query parameters are set appropriately. Otherwise, to be honest its hard to say much about perf without knowing more specifics. My personal bias would be to express as much as possible in declarative logic e.g. â€œlittle queriesâ€ and then address any concrete perf problems that come up, but obviously the optimal strategy depends a lot on your use-case.
#2017-10-01Â 02:56:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Thanks @mikerod & @wparker. No great surprise. I did wonder if keeping track of inputs for truth maintenance provided a mechanism to detect a loop. e.g. If one of my inputs is based on my output then raise exception.
#2017-10-01Â 03:40:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah Iâ€™m not sure. There may be some possibility for the truth maintenance to detect a cycle in the automatic retraction stuff. Havenâ€™t thought that one through before.

#2017-10-05Â 19:03:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ I have a clause like this: 
[:not
   [:and
    (x (= ?foo foo))
    (y (= ?foo bar))]]
When it fires, I get this error: > Using variable that is not previously boundâ€¦. Note that variables used in negations are not bound for subsequent rules since the negation can never match. To my thinking, the y clause is not a subsequent rule since itâ€™s part of the same :and. I want the clause to match cases where this combination of x and y facts doesnâ€™t exist, though an individual x or y fact may exist. How can I express this?
#2017-10-05Â 19:47:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dg looks like you took care of that with https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/346 ?
#2017-10-05Â 19:48:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dgÂ yeah
#2017-10-05Â 19:53:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @enn So Clara (similar to some other rete-based engines) convert the logical structures to DNF (disjunctive normal form). This is typically done to simplify the Rete tree construction and data flow.
#2017-10-05Â 19:53:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So in this case, itâ€™d be NOT (X AND Y) converted to NOT X OR NOT Y and the OR divides the two clauses into distinct chunks. To deal with this, there is typical special handling for â€œnegated conjunctionsâ€.
#2017-10-05Â 19:53:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I wouldnâ€™t expect this behavior since Clara has some special handling of a negated conjunction like this.
#2017-10-05Â 19:53:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Is your rule more complex than just what you posted here?
#2017-10-05Â 20:04:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ @mikerod yes, a bit more complex--hereâ€™s a more accurate version of that clause, and there are also other clauses in the rule: 
[:not
   [:and
    (x
     (= ?foo foo))
    (y
     ((set (map :id ?foo)) foo_id)
     (= ?previously_bound_lvar other_id))]]
#2017-10-05Â 20:04:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ I wonder if the set membership check was messing things up?
#2017-10-05Â 20:04:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ I ended up working around it by getting all values of x.foo in an accumulator, then doing a :not clause checking those values (if any) against y.foo_id
#2017-10-05Â 20:05:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > I wonder if the set membership check was messing things up? I donâ€™t think it should

#2017-10-05Â 20:17:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:not
                     [:and
                      [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]]])])
#2017-10-05Â 20:17:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
ExceptionInfo Using variable that is not previously bound. This can happen when an expression uses a previously unbound variable, or if a variable is referenced in a nested part of a parent expression, such as (or (= ?my-expression my-field) ...). 
Note that variables used in negations are not bound for subsequent
                                    rules since the negation can never match.
Production: 
{:lhs [[:not [:and {:type :x, :constraints [(= ?z (:z this))]}]]], :params #{}}
Unbound variables: #{?z}  clojure.core/ex-info (core.clj:4593)
#2017-10-05Â 20:18:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ That is pretty minimal
#2017-10-05Â 20:33:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @enn I think the issue is that Clara it not allowing a condition within a negation to introduce a new bound variable
#2017-10-05Â 20:35:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This gets even more minimal: 
(mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:not [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]])])
fails due to Unbound variables: #{?z} yet this is ok: 
(mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:y ( = ?z (:z this))]
                    [:not [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]])])
#2017-10-05Â 20:35:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The case of a single condition making a bound variable within a negation doesnâ€™t make sense. However, in negated conjunction like in your previous example it does. I think this may be an edge case that Clara isnâ€™t appropriately handling.

#2017-10-05Â 21:58:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ I am new to Clojure/Clara, and what I am trying to achieve is to make query find-all-shapes to return rectangles as well as squares: 
(ns dsl.test
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]
    ))

(defrecord Shape [center])
(defrecord Rectangle [center width height])
(defrecord Square [center width])


(defquery find-all-shapes
  []
  [?result <- Shape]
  )

(println (-> (mk-session 'dsl.test)
           (insert
             (->Rectangle [1 1] 2 3)
             (->Square [3 3] 5))
           (fire-rules)
           (query find-all-shapes)))
#2017-10-05Â 21:59:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ From clara documentation I guess I have to make Shape an ancestor of Rectangle and Square, but not sure how to do this and wether it is right direction at all.
#2017-10-05Â 22:00:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @alex.furmanov Claraâ€™s defaults are to use the type and ancestors fnâ€™s from Clojure
#2017-10-05Â 22:01:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So you can work it into those in several different ways
#2017-10-05Â 22:01:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m not sure if you are using clj or cljs
#2017-10-05Â 22:01:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ clj
#2017-10-05Â 22:02:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you are using clj and like defrecord to define your types you could just make a marker interface and use the standard Java type hierarchy 
(definterface Shape)
(defrecord Rectangle [center width height] Shape)
<etc>
#2017-10-05Â 22:02:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You could also utilize Clojureâ€™s derive
#2017-10-05Â 22:03:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ From your example it isnâ€™t completely clear, but I donâ€™t think you actually have facts that are actually the type Shape e.g. (->Shape [1 1]) right?
#2017-10-05Â 22:04:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ No, the real case is different: facts are indications of some sort of progress.
#2017-10-05Â 22:06:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Some could be as simple as counter, others are pairs [invites, money], other type of progress possible
#2017-10-05Â 22:07:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Thanks, @mikerod! The (definterface ...) works!
#2017-10-05Â 22:11:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ No problem. Technical note: for Clojure I would choose definterface as the way to mark the record hierarchy just because using defprotocol for itâ€™s underlying generated interface is a bit of a gray area. You could get away with defprotocol as well though. It has edge cases though and it may be better to avoid.
#2017-10-05Â 22:14:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you are still interested, what I mean is, e.g. 
(defprotocol Shape)

(extend-type String Shape)
Doesnâ€™t mean that Stringâ€™s are now considered to be Shapeâ€™s by the built-in Clojure type hierarchy. Also, the protocol will leave a var by the name of Shape that will clash with the classname produced in your ns and that is confusing as well.
#2017-10-05Â 22:25:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ I did not know that, thanks for explanations!
#2017-10-05Â 23:41:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ How to call interface method in LHS constraint? 
(definterface IProgress
  (^int counter [])
  (^int customer [])
  )

(defrecord SpecialIProgress [counter_ customer_ details] IProgress
  (counter [this] (+ counter_ 1))
  (customer [this] 1)
  )

(defquery find-all-i-progresses
  []
;;  [?result <- IProgress (= 1 .customer)] ;; DOES NOT WORK
  [?result <- IProgress]
  )

(println (-> (mk-session 'dsl.test)
  (insert
    (->SpecialIProgress 2 1 "2 out of 3"))
  (fire-rules)
  (query find-all-i-progresses)))
#2017-10-05Â 23:42:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ If I uncomment [?result <- IProgress (= 1 .customer)] line I am getting an error: "Unable to resolve symbol: .customer in this context"
#2017-10-05Â 23:44:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Cannot use customer in constraint either, same type of error

20  F   S   1.8131  2.1821  1.9299  1.4490  1.7000  0.8900  2.2692  1.0944  2.0646

#2017-10-06Â 17:53:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â huwigsÂ now, in the rules engine we have facts that can provide (k1, k2, k3) values and want to know what a v1 value for that combination is

#2017-10-06Â 18:04:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it splits at that point and all the data flow goes down both â€œbranchesâ€ of logic
#2017-10-06Â 18:05:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the only reason Iâ€™d use :or in a case like this is something like
#2017-10-06Â 18:06:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule tester
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  [:or
   <your P,E and P,F joins here using the result from A,B above>]
=>
<etc>)
#2017-10-06Â 18:06:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Meaning if you had some more conditions needed by both joins
#2017-10-06Â 18:07:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Using :or above makes it so the network will share the work done in the prior conditions in the rule before the :or. So â€œnode sharingâ€, as it is called in Rete terminology.
#2017-10-06Â 18:07:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you do it in separate rules, there still may be node sharing though. Clara tries to detect duplicate conditions.
#2017-10-06Â 18:07:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â huwigsÂ OK
#2017-10-06Â 18:07:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â huwigsÂ It probably reads better as multiple rules almost always?
#2017-10-06Â 18:07:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Just pointing out times when :or may be nice. It also lets you not write stuff twice.

#2017-10-06Â 18:10:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and Iâ€™d still probably try it and profile/ take note of the runtime degradation before trying a non-fact based approach
#2017-10-06Â 18:12:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, itâ€™s good to be aware of your â€œhot spotsâ€. A rule like 
(r/defrule joining
  [P (= ?age age)]
  [F (< ?age (:threshold this))]
=>
<etc>)
Is going to evaluate (< ?age (:threshold this)) (number of P) X (number of F) times
#2017-10-06Â 18:12:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so if that is a big number, then it becomes a hot spot and you may end up just being able to improve whatever test is done tehre
#2017-10-06Â 18:12:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â huwigsÂ OK. So if many of these facts would be reused from case to case, is the right thing to do to load the standard facts (from the tables above), keep around a binding to the initial session, and then for each subsequent set of queries, reuse the initial session?
#2017-10-06Â 18:12:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Or eliminate P facts that you know wonâ€™t match F (because they match something else with eq already perhaps).
#2017-10-06Â 18:12:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â huwigsÂ assuming that works on account of persistent data structures etc., just donâ€™t want to load stuff from files many times
#2017-10-06Â 18:13:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think what you said makes sense

#2017-10-06Â 18:13:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can reuse an â€œinitially loadedâ€ working memory state for those rules for different runs of new facts
#2017-10-06Â 18:13:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ definitely a big win of Claraâ€™s persistent, immutable working memory approach

#2017-10-06Â 21:01:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @souenzzo if youâ€™re using queries, you could put an accumulator or an :exists on your query conditions to remove duplication in your results
#2017-10-06Â 21:06:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ It's not about query... It's about session Duplicated facts are fire'ing rules in a loop..
#2017-10-06Â 21:10:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @souenzzo one approach Iâ€™ve done
#2017-10-06Â 21:10:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ introduce an â€œintermediate factâ€
#2017-10-06Â 21:10:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ that can be duplicated
#2017-10-06Â 21:11:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ then have a rule that uses an accumulator acc/all on those possible duplicates
#2017-10-06Â 21:11:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and inserts only one in the presence of any number of them
#2017-10-06Â 21:12:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ Got it. I will try;
#2017-10-06Â 21:13:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Assuming you want to go from X facts to B facts, but do not want duplicates of B â€œdownstreamâ€: 
(r/defrule a-rule
  [X (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Intermediate ?v)))

(r/defrule aggregate-rule
  [?all <- (acc/all) :from [Intermediate]]
  [:test (seq ?all)]
  =>
  ;; Assume everything in `?all` is `=` otherwise do some merge, etc
  (r/insert! (map->B (first ?all))))

(r/defrule b-rule
  [B]
  =>
  <etc>)
#2017-10-09Â 12:59:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ This method is not working because I need acc both Intermediate and 'B`, to ensure that there are no repeated elements
#2017-10-06Â 21:15:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™d use better naming though ðŸ˜›
#2017-10-09Â 14:35:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ why. no amount of intermediates can insert more than one B under this pattern. If you are saying you want to insert B only if there is only distinct Intermediates, you will need to use a smarter accumulator.

#2017-10-13Â 12:43:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Another question - is it possible to reference the name of a rule in a rule?
#2017-10-13Â 15:23:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ as for the first question, you would want to retract the original and insert the newer one. This will require some logic outside of the rules network. Clara assumes immutability in its facts im pretty sure.
#2017-10-13Â 15:25:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ second one: What are you wanting to do with a rule reference? You should be relying on the consequences of the right hand side of said rule on the state of the facts in the session to infer things. Maybe if you had a more specific case of what you are trying to do i can provide more specific advice there.
#2017-10-13Â 15:51:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > as for the first question, you would want to retract the original and insert the newer one. This will require some logic outside of the rules network. Clara assumes immutability in its facts im pretty sure. Yeah, I think that is common. If you arenâ€™t concerned with a constantly growing working memory, i.e. append-only, you can get by with doing it all in rules
#2017-10-13Â 15:51:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It seems to me that Clara should offer something to better support the â€œupdateâ€ pattern
#2017-10-13Â 15:53:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Something like: 
(r/defrule update-fact
  [?current <- FactType (= ?id id)]
  [?update <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [UpdateFact (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/retract! ?current) ;; or if you wanted to remove updates altogether - with no accumulator on LHS `(apply r/retract! [?current ?update])`
  (r/insert! (do-update ?current ?update)))
To me seems like a pretty natural thing to do, but it violates truth maintenance since the supporting facts ?current and ?update are retracted that logically supported the r/insert!
#2017-10-13Â 15:54:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, r/retract! is a bit at odds with Truth maintenance since it is â€œorder-dependentâ€
#2017-10-13Â 15:54:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you r/retract! something, but later the rule is found to be invalidated by some other retractions, youâ€™d expect the r/retract! operation to be rolled back
#2017-10-13Â 16:02:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you do append-only style, I think something like this works though: 
(defrecord UpdateFact [id timestamp stuff])
(defrecord FactType [id timestamp x y])
(defrecord FactTypeSnapshot [id timestamp x y])

(r/defrule current-fact
  [?current <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [FactTypeSnapshot (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (map->FactType ?current)))

(r/defrule update-fact-type

  [?update <- (acc/all) :from [UpdateFact (= ?id id) (= ?ts timestamp)]]
  [?current <- FactType (= ?id id) (< timestamp ?ts)]
  =>

  ;; Inserts a `FactTypeSnapshot w/ updates applied and `:timestamp` = `?ts`
  (r/insert! (do-update ?current ?update ?ts)))

(r/defrule using-fact-type
  [FactType (= ?id id) (= ?x x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (prn ?x))
#2017-10-13Â 16:11:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The key is to have way to represent snapshots of a fact over time - the FactTypeSnapshot, a way to select the one you want to use in rules - the FactType, a way to apply updates - via UpdateFact to those facts in a way that doesnâ€™t cause a logical loop. Didnâ€™t test this specifically, but I believe the idea plays out alright (for append-only working memory). Externally may tend to be smoother, as @zylox said, so often Iâ€™d go with that. I wonder if Clara could provide some sort of helpers for that though 
;;; Add a query to your ruleset to fetch facts you want to update 
(r/defquery find-fact [find-id]
  [?fact <- FactType (= id find-id)])

;;; Example external update fn
(defn do-update [session update]

  ;; Assumes :id uniquely identifies facts here
  (let [old (first (mapv :?fact (r/query sesssion find-fact :id (:id update))))]
    (-> session
        (r/retract old)
        (r/insert (update-fact old update))
        r/fire-rules)))
#2017-10-14Â 14:22:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ @zylox Thanks for the reply.
#2017-10-14Â 15:20:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mmerÂ Sorry another simple question - do all facts have to be records?
#2017-10-14Â 18:21:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mmer no. Clara allows for you to provide your own :fact-type-fn, for arbitrary â€œtype dispatchâ€, as well as :ancestors-fn for setting up â€œtype hierarchiesâ€. This is all in much the same was as Clojureâ€™s ad hoc hierarchies work via derive and isa? etc
#2017-10-14Â 18:21:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ By default, Clara uses clojure.core/type as to map a fact to type
#2017-10-14Â 18:21:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and clojure.core/ancestors to determine the isa? style relationships
#2017-10-14Â 18:21:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So changing nothing, you can use plain maps with :type metadata
#2017-10-14Â 18:23:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule my-rule
 [:my-fact-type (= (:x this) ?x)]
 =>
 (println "hello"))

(-> (r/mk-session [my-rule])
     (r/insert (with-meta {:x 10} {:type :my-fact-type}))
    r/fire-rules)
#2017-10-14Â 18:24:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Here are some docs on it http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/

#2017-10-21Â 20:12:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @wadi.chemkhi By default Clara caches rule sessions for efficiency, but this' isn't great for a REPL-based workflow. I like to set :cache false when working from the REPL to avoid this. The page is a bit old, but there's an example here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Using-Clara-from-the-REPL

#2017-10-25Â 14:20:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @souenzzo using MIN_VALUE would work, it just wouldnâ€™t necessarily be the last thing if you accidentally added another rule with the same salience value. If the rulesets are small and/or youâ€™re the only one working on them that might not be a problem. For our large rulesets with lots of people working on them we find it convenient to have salience with domain-specific categories defined in a single location. If you do need other functionality the salience function is user-configurable, although it defaults to a simple numeric comparison.
#2017-11-01Â 20:49:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara-rules release 0.16.1 is now available on Clojars. This contains several bugfixes and other minor improvements relative to 0.16.0. #2017-11-06Â 20:27:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If the problem is a function in your rules (RHS, accumulator function, etc.) thatâ€™s taking a lot of time then something like VisualVM would likely be helpful. Thatâ€™s where Iâ€™d start. If the problem is that the rules are firing in a bad/suboptimal way then Claraâ€™s tracing could provide some info, but that is harder to use. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.cljc, the discussion on https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/344 around potential tracing enhancements could give some insight into how it works as well
#2017-11-06Â 22:16:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ @wparker I made a macro that wrap rhs inside a time-like macro, that time RHS and store it's time on a global atom (just for use on repl). It allow's me to see how many times each rule is fired, how many time each "burn" takes, avg, "total time" from each rule. Simple and usefull ðŸ˜„
#2017-11-06Â 22:16:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ (now I'm using my-ns/defrule in place of clara.rules/defrule)
#2017-11-06Â 22:37:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Glad youâ€™ve found a working solution @souenzzo FYI, there are some cases where Clara could repeatedly add a rule to the queue of things waiting to be fired, remove it, add it again, etc. without ever actually firing it (and thus avoiding that macro) but my guess is those cases are a small though nontrivial minority of perf problems

#2017-11-13Â 16:43:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ Hi ! I have troubles understanding how destructuring works in clara. If I understand the documentation correctly, I would expect this rule to match any record of type Foo and bind the symbol foo to the record itself, so I can use it afterward. 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [foo]]
  =>
  (do-something-with  foo))
I always get an Unable to resolve symbol: foo in this context, where context is the RHS. Am I missing something ?
#2017-11-13Â 17:07:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @ggaillard the destructured bound symbols are scoped locally to the expressions of the single condition doing the destructuring bind
#2017-11-13Â 17:08:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You have to bind a variable to use throughout other conditions or the rule and/or the RHS
#2017-11-13Â 17:08:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [foo] (= ?foo foo)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?foo))
#2017-11-13Â 17:11:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In this case, it isnâ€™t too useful
#2017-11-13Â 17:11:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This would make more sense 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [?foo <- Foo]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?foo))
#2017-11-13Â 17:12:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ Oh I get it ! Thank you !
#2017-11-13Â 17:12:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ times like: 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [{:keys [x y]}] (< 10 x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?y))
are where it may be more useful
#2017-11-13Â 17:14:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also note that when using Clojure records (i.e. defrecord classes) and/or, on the JVM side, Java POJOs adhering to the Java bean spec, Clara automatically makes the field names visible in the local scope of a conditionâ€™s experssions 
(defrecord Foo [x y])

(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo (< 10 x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?y))
Would work without the explicit destructuring syntax
#2017-11-13Â 17:24:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ I was using your last example until now to extract my records' fields, and since I missed the <- part of facts expressions it quickly became inconvenient when I needed to work with every fields â€¦ Thanks for this clarification ðŸ™‚

#2017-11-13Â 19:00:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule lost-game
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Loser)))
#2017-11-13Â 19:00:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ worksaround it

#2017-11-13Â 19:02:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @mikerod Thanks. I had several puzzling cases like this, will try the work-around when I get home

#2017-11-13Â 19:02:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you have more examples of different shapes, thatâ€™d be interesting too
#2017-11-13Â 19:07:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ Is the test node making a binding somehow instead?....thatd be weird
#2017-11-13Â 19:10:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @zylox I think it is misintepreting it somehow along those lines
#2017-11-13Â 19:10:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ no good
#2017-11-13Â 19:10:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I looked a a bit in clara.rules.compiler but I donâ€™t see the issue yet
#2017-11-13Â 19:11:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you look at the rulebase for the network without the do (the problem case), the TestNode is a beta root with no parents
#2017-11-13Â 19:12:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ And itâ€™s children are the accumulate nodes
#2017-11-13Â 19:12:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This made me suspicious of the function clara.rules.compiler/sort-conditions which does a topological type of sort of accumulators that rearranges some conditions
#2017-11-13Â 19:12:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The topo sort is supposed ensure that any used variable binding is pushed below itâ€™s creation unification binding condition
#2017-11-13Â 19:15:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Adding the do in the :test node pushes it down as a child of the accumulate nodes in the network and then it works
#2017-11-13Â 19:22:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It may be completely a problem with the sort, as the below demonstrates 
(ns test.ns
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
            [clara.rules.compiler :as com]))

(defrecord Ship [])
(defrecord Destroyed [])
(defrecord Loser [])

(r/defrule lost-game-fixed
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]                           ;; Notice the `do` surrounding form is important for the sort
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Loser)))

(r/defrule lost-game-broken
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (= ?ships ?destroyed)]                                  ;; Condition with problem, doesn't work without surrounding form (`do` above)
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Loser)))


(com/sort-conditions (-> lost-game-fixed :lhs))
(comment
  ({:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Ship, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?ships}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Destroyed, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?destroyed}
   {:constraints [(do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]}))

(com/sort-conditions (-> lost-game-broken :lhs))
(comment
  ({:constraints [(= ?ships ?destroyed)]}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Ship, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?ships}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Destroyed, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?destroyed}))
#2017-11-13Â 19:22:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Unless Iâ€™m missing something else prior to this
#2017-11-13Â 19:30:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ juxt
#2017-11-13Â 19:48:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ seems to be that classify-variables considers it an equality-expression?, resulting in them being considered "bound", but "unbound" in the workaround case
#2017-11-13Â 20:17:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ and when they are bound, this fn https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L790 will consider it satisfied because #{} is a subset of #{?ships ?destroyed}, meaning newly-satisfied will contain the test constraint (https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L797) and be put in the front of the order in the into at the end https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L828
#2017-11-13Â 20:19:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ im not sure of a good way to fix this. i can see why it thinks its a bound variable.
#2017-11-13Â 20:28:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ That fixed it, as well as the other cases, which were essentially the same, with an equality check inside of [:test].
#2017-11-13Â 20:33:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The compilation of this rule does seem to be wrong. When I inspect the rule network the :test condition seems to completely not exist in the network. Gist with the pretty-printed network: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/a3adaa3db730229bc01586009bb7178a
#2017-11-13Â 20:35:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ However, if I use join-filter-equals it is there: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/347ba6ca3f7e0afc2c9f183e0731111e
#2017-11-13Â 20:35:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Join-filter-equals just dispatches to =:
#2017-11-13Â 20:36:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ 
(defn join-filter-equals
  "Intended to be a test function that is the same as equals, but is not visible to Clara as such
  and thus forces usage of join filters instead of hash joins"
  [& args]
  (apply = args))
it is a helper function for Claraâ€™s tests
#2017-11-13Â 20:36:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Same idea really as wrapping in a do like @mikerod did
#2017-11-13Â 20:38:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara has special cases around constraints having = as the first symbol in order to create variable bindings, but when the first symbol is something else if becomes a â€œnormalâ€ call to clojure.core/=. @zylox is probably on the right track here with looking at different paths depending on whether equality-expression? returns true
#2017-11-13Â 20:40:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Iâ€™ll need to look more closely at it to have an informed opinion on the exact cause and what to do about it but this does look like a bug to me @dave.dixon You should be able to avoid it for the moment with strategies that prevent = from being the first symbol in a :test constraint for the moment though

#2017-11-13Â 22:15:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @wparker thanks for making it

#2017-11-14Â 18:45:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ 
(clara.rules/defquery ship-destroyed-at?
          [:?point]
          [?destroyed <- Destroyed (= ?ship ship)]
          [?placement <- ValidPlacement 
           (= ?ship ship)
           ((spaces this) ?point)])
for the record this doesnt seem to work either so its not the test node

#2017-11-14Â 18:45:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, @zylox has found that that is still a problem

#2017-11-14Â 18:47:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ its the whole unbound vs bound thing again
#2017-11-14Â 18:48:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ so its at least partially related to the thing from yesterday
#2017-11-14Â 18:51:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The above queries won't work because ?point is not bound, although we could be more clear in our error messaging here.
#2017-11-14Â 18:52:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ The :?point is a query parameter, which just does a lookup. A query parameter is not "bound" when the rule engine is processing...it is simple used to look up bound values.
#2017-11-14Â 18:52:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Since ?point is never bound in the query itself, we get that error message.
#2017-11-14Â 18:54:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ These semantics are a bit confusing in this case because we're conflating query parameters (which do not bind a variable) with variables that must be bound with an (= ?my-variable ...) or similar expression.
#2017-11-14Â 18:58:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Woops, that makes sense to me. I blanked about how they were supposed to work here.
#2017-11-14Â 19:00:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ So presumably the way to attack this is to make a new fact using those conditions, rather than trying to just query?
#2017-11-14Â 19:06:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ Clearly I need to brush up on queries
#2017-11-14Â 19:06:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ ...pun not intended
#2017-11-14Â 19:38:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ @dave.dixon Separating this out into another fact makes sense. I'm not quite sure what your objective for these rules is, but any approach that explicitly binds ?point in the query logic (not just the parameter) should work.
#2017-11-14Â 23:03:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ That worked great, thanks.
#2017-11-19Â 22:29:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Sorry if this is documented somewhere, but I didn't catch it. Is there some best practice around handling fact identity for updates? For example, if have (defrecord Person [name address]), and I want to update the address, or perhaps even insert the same Person (by value) twice. Is there some way to tell clara to use name to identify the Person and change the replace the existing fact, or do I have to explicitly retract the existing instance? Or am I totally missing something for modeling this situation?
#2017-11-19Â 23:30:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > do I have to explicitly retract the existing instance? Yes, the idea is to do this sort of change explicitly
#2017-11-19Â 23:31:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and there is no concept of mutating a fact â€œin placeâ€
#2017-11-19Â 23:31:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are several ways to approach the problem
#2017-11-19Â 23:34:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.dixon one idea is if you donâ€™t actually care about deleting old data (perhaps you want to have it for historical rules etc), you could put an intermediary between external â€œperson data at a point in timeâ€ vs the â€œcurrent personâ€ being processed: 
(r/defrule current-person
  [?latest <- latest-person-acc :from [PersonSnapshot (= ?name name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Person ?latest)))
#2017-11-19Â 23:34:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This is if you made some sort of latest-person-acc that chose the latest by some criteria of yours (like a PersonSnapshot timestamp)
#2017-11-19Â 23:34:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You could use the clara.rules.accumulators/max for this
#2017-11-19Â 23:35:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule current-person
  [?latest <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [PersonSnapshot (= ?name name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Person ?latest)))
#2017-11-19Â 23:36:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You may not want to leave facts in though due to a concern, like memory use or something. Then a common way to deal with the update is somewhat external to the rules processing themselves
#2017-11-19Â 23:48:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrecord Person [name x])

(r/defquery person-with-name [:?name]
  [?p <- Person (= ?name name)])

(def init
  (-> (r/mk-session [person-with-name])
      (r/insert (->Person "joe" 10)
                (->Person "mary" 20))
      r/fire-rules))

(defn find-person-by-name [session pname]
  ;; Assumes name is unique (you could do something different)
  (-> session
      (r/query person-with-name :?name pname)
      first
      :?p))

(defn update-person [session new-person]
  (let [existing (find-person-by-name session (:name new-person))]
    (-> session
        (r/retract existing)
        (r/insert new-person)
        r/fire-rules)))

(def updated
  (update-person init (->Person "joe" 50)))



;; Then try:

(find-person-by-name init "joe")
(find-person-by-name updated "joe")
#2017-11-19Â 23:49:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ That sort of pattern would allow you take rm and old version of the person and insert an update
#2017-11-19Â 23:49:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and it avoids getting into situations within the engine where you have to deal with logical loops in the truth maintenance system and/or unconditional inserts, RHS retracts, etc
#2017-11-19Â 23:50:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You could impl the update-person differently where you just make a change to the existing fact to get some data structural sharing too though instead of a brand new fact like I had
#2017-11-19Â 23:52:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ e.g. 
(defn update-person [session new-person-data]
  (let [existing (find-person-by-name session (:name new-person-data))
        up (merge existing new-person-data)]
    (-> session
        (r/retract existing)
        (r/insert up)
        r/fire-rules)))

;; e.g.
(update-person init {:name "joe" :x 50})
#2017-11-20Â 00:31:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @mikerod Thanks for the excellent and detailed answer!
#2017-11-23Â 17:33:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I think I found the problem. The call to resolve-vars at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/macros.clj#L183 only binds the Clojure namespace. At this point in compilation, the CLJS namespace is not correct. Adding this to the binding fixes the issue: cljs.analyzer/*cljs-ns* (:ns-name production)
#2017-12-02Â 13:51:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s on Twitter, but I thought it was cool enough to share here too: Clara on the ThoughtWorks Technology Radar https://www.thoughtworks.com/es/radar/languages-and-frameworks/clara-rules

I donâ€™t think the rules network could be effectively statically analyzed but perhaps something could be created that looked at what rules were interacted with; that information is available via Claraâ€™s tracing

#2017-12-14Â 20:20:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ perhaps magic
#2017-12-19Â 20:04:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @amarjeet you cut it off I think
#2017-12-19Â 20:07:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It only shows about 5 lines
#2017-12-19Â 21:27:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @mikerod I can see a larger snippet after I expand it in my OS X Slack client. @amarjeet Iâ€™d have to see lines creating sessions and inserting facts to fully understand what youâ€™re doing, but it sounds like you may believe that a fact {:some :value} will match a condition like [{:some :value}]. This is not the case; Clara uses the fact type, not the fact itself, to match on conditions. So for example {:some :value} would match [java.util.Map] by default, though you can customize the function used for this dispatch. This is documented at http://clara-rules.org; I canâ€™t hit the site right now but the pageâ€™s markdown source is https://github.com/cerner/clara-site/blob/gh-pages/_docs/fact_type_customization.md
#2017-12-19Â 21:28:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @wparker I can see it on the side bar (same client as you), not sure why it wonâ€™t expand otherwise. Anyways, irrelevant than woops.
#2017-12-20Â 05:50:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ @wparker
#2017-12-20Â 14:50:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @amarjeet thatnks for sharing more there
#2017-12-20Â 14:50:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So the first level of discrimination in the rules network is going always â€œfact typeâ€
#2017-12-20Â 14:51:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, the combination of :fact-type-fn and :ancestors-fn give you flexibility into what that means
#2017-12-20Â 14:52:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The default :fact-type-fn is Clojureâ€™s clojure.core/type, which is just (or (get (meta x) :type) (class x))
#2017-12-20Â 14:52:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The default :ancestors-fn is clojure.core/ancestors which respects the â€œglobal hierarchyâ€ in Clj which can be altered via things like derive
#2017-12-20Â 14:53:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ :ancestors-fn is just for making the supertype subtype relationships that factor into the fact type dispatch
#2017-12-20Â 14:53:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You donâ€™t necessarily have to have a â€œfact typeâ€ if you really donâ€™t want, or you can make it something that is based on the data of the map entities you have
#2017-12-20Â 14:54:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (def session-one (mk-session 'modelxt.absmodel :fact-type :name)) for example, although that isnâ€™t very suitable for the rule add-entity that you have

#2017-12-22Â 02:02:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ Is Claraâ€™s fact destructuring as described here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ the same as Clojureâ€™s destructuring?
#2017-12-22Â 02:17:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @cfleming the part of the syntax shown there uses Clojure destructuring. It basically ends up being a clojure function arglist that takes a single object.
#2017-12-22Â 02:18:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But yes. It just â€œflows throughâ€ to standard destructuring.

(r/defrule demo
  {:no-loop true}
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (r/insert! (update ?a :some-val inc)))

#2017-12-23Â 16:29:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Drools 5 vs 6 added a lot of things at once. It makes it hard to know which ones are paying off the most. At least from what is public. I think the most important optimization was just the batched fact propagation across the network. That is done in Drools 6 phreak via a â€œlazyâ€ sort of evaluation of rules.
#2017-12-23Â 16:30:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara could potentially do a bit better with lazy propagation. However just having the batched propagation seems to work pretty well already.
#2017-12-23Â 16:31:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ I thought Phreak was more eager
#2017-12-23Â 16:33:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Overall Iâ€™m under the impression Clara was written with distributed computing in mindâ€¦I donâ€™t know if other rule engines compete with that, and to me it seems like a ridiculously powerful feature
#2017-12-23Â 16:40:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Hmm. It should be more lazy. Hah. There are lots of blogs on it by Drools people. Good blogs really. They put out some good content that is helpful more generally

#2017-12-23Â 18:07:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ryanbrushÂ Yeah, Storm support was just an experiment for a need that never really materialized so we didn't pursue it further. When the user first selects â€œshow historyâ€, I want to provide a default (e.g. the first rule firing). After that I want the user to be able to switch through the selected history. Iâ€™d like to have one â€œselected historyâ€ fact. If it doesnâ€™t exist because the user hasnâ€™t set it, it should be derived from other facts. If the user sets it though, then â€œselected historyâ€ should be whatever the user says.
#2017-12-24Â 16:33:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ That sounds like you could encode that as 2 separate rules that both insert the selected history fact

[:not [SelectHistoryEvent]]
=>
(insert! (->SelectedHistory 0))

#2017-12-24Â 02:27:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Brain bubble: clara and onyx might be a great match for distributed processing.
#2017-12-24Â 22:32:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ After reading this (https://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/clara/2015-12-11.html) and @mikerod's article (http://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html), I think there may be something there. Onyx has fault tolerance for stateful tasks, and has taken a pretty good beating from jepsen.
#2017-12-25Â 21:15:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Thanks for the links. Read both and very helpful. This was the inspiration for me: https://www.confluent.io/blog/turning-the-database-inside-out-with-apache-samza/

Thereâ€™s ksql and kafka-streams to deal with joins between topics, but neither seem as good a solution as a rules engine
#2017-12-30Â 00:26:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Agreed. I think Kafka is suitable as a source of facts, but the rules engine gives you both logic and materialized views for "complex event processing". If we could implement the distributed working menu in Onyx and feed the whole thing with Kafka, it seems pretty cool.
