#2017-12-27Â 17:10:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @amarjeet it seems the purpose of the key :fact->explanations is to explain derived facts within working memory
#2017-12-27Â 17:10:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ not facts explicitly given via an external insert or insert-all
#2017-12-27Â 17:10:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ okay, that makes sense then
#2017-12-27Â 17:11:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can dig out that info in some sense
#2017-12-27Â 17:11:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ yeah
#2017-12-27Â 17:11:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Take for example: 
:fact->explanations
{#clara.test_rules.B{}
[{:rule {:ns-name clara.test-rules, :lhs [{:type clara.test_rules.A, :constraints []}], :rhs (do (insert! (->B))), :name "clara.test-rules/test-a"},
:explanation #clara.tools.inspect.Explanation{:matches ({:fact #clara.test_rules.A{}, :condition {:type clara.test_rules.A, :constraints []}}), :bindings {}}}]}
#2017-12-27Â 17:11:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ clara.test_rules.B is the derived fact
#2017-12-27Â 17:12:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the value under it is a list of rules deriving it. Thereâ€™d be more than one if multiple of these facts were = in working memory.
#2017-12-27Â 17:13:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ yes, I did got that when I checked with fire-rules
#2017-12-27Â 17:13:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ understood it now
#2017-12-27Â 17:14:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(into []
      (comp cat
            (map :explanation)
            (mapcat :matches)
            (map :fact))
      (vals (:fact->explanations inspect-results)))
combined with (keys (:fact->explanations inspect-results)) sort of gets you there
#2017-12-27Â 17:15:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, an important consideration is that Clara doesnâ€™t hold references to any inserted facts that cannot contribute to any rule
#2017-12-27Â 17:15:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So those effectively are not in working memory at all anymore
#2017-12-27Â 17:15:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ hmm, yeah, got it
#2017-12-27Â 17:16:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ makes sense now
#2017-12-27Â 17:16:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrecord A [])

(defrule not-using-a
  [:not-a]
  =>
  (insert! {:not-a true}))

(-> (mk-session [not-using-a])
    (insert (->A))
    fire-rules)
#2017-12-27Â 17:16:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ youâ€™d find no references to A fact instance in working memory at all
#2017-12-27Â 17:16:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @alex-dixon has done some more interesting things with session inspection I believe. He may have thoughts on this though.
#2017-12-27Â 17:17:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ On the topic of analyzing all facts inserted or that sort of thing. Then again, for dev only, if you are using the typical type hierarchy you could just do 
(defquery find-any-fact []
   [?f <- Object])
#2017-12-27Â 17:20:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â amarjeetÂ yeah, this testing trick works, I tried testing with different types of queries.
#2017-12-27Â 17:23:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/master/src/cljc/precept/listeners.cljc
#2017-12-27Â 17:24:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Example of abusing clara.listeners ðŸ˜Š
#2017-12-27Â 17:29:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Itâ€™s a tremendously well designed interface. This is just one implementation. We set up a core async pipeline to process insertions from outside the session (see in precept.core if interested). Each time thereâ€™s an insert we add and remove a listener and divide the listener ops into additions and removals
#2017-12-27Â 17:31:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ From there we apply the ops to an atom that represents â€œcurrent stateâ€
#2017-12-27Â 17:34:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Part of motivation over a query is that queries become part of the rete network so having one that matches on everything wasnâ€™t performant

#2018-01-02Â 21:25:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Reasoning is: 1) RHS retract is clunky right now and even worse has some fairly broken behavior with truth maintenance/batched logical insertion etc. 2) Optimizations similar to your â€œupdate factsâ€ optimizations posted above here may also be applicable.
#2018-01-02Â 21:26:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Drools does have some optimization to the path of modifying a fact in place - via some of the property reactive hooks. #2018-01-02Â 21:27:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In our case, weâ€™d not do any in-place mutation of course (structural sharing is good though). #2018-01-02Â 21:28:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think the update! scenario is one of prominent use-cases for retract! on the RHS. Although I think there are other reasons to retract, such as â€œno longer relevant eventâ€ scenarios perhaps, so retract! isnâ€™t completely useless still (and needs to get fixed to behave sanely with batched inserts and truth maintenance).
#2018-01-02Â 21:37:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Yeah, I realize thereâ€™s some other stuff being discussed. Iâ€™ll have to read up on those features in Drools. Re updates and truth maintenance - it isnâ€™t clear to me what sorts of semantics would make sense to manually mess with a logically inserted fact. My intuition there is that manual modification to something that is logically derived doesnâ€™t make sense, since if A implies B, then A should continue to imply B until/unless A changes.
#2018-01-02Â 21:38:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I realize that isnâ€™t the current implementation though - Iâ€™ve toyed with changing things so that a RHS retract of a logically inserted fact simply wouldnâ€™t happen in the same way that an external retract of a fact not in the session doesnâ€™t do anything. The fact that it does do something now always seemed like a leaky impl detail/bug to me actually
#2018-01-02Â 21:44:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think there is a lot of value to be had in the ability to â€œupdate a factâ€

#2018-01-02Â 21:45:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and with truth maintenance and all logical inserts (something I think is very valuable), it gets near impossible to actually retract something because you immediately invalidate it against the truth maintenance
#2018-01-02Â 21:46:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think something liek this: 
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc)))
#2018-01-02Â 21:46:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The truth maintenance should not have an issue with this. and it should propagate and participate in the truth maintenance downstream as expected
#2018-01-02Â 21:47:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ more interesting even

(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A (= value 10)]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc)))
Here the update! actually contradicts the LHS condition - I still think that should be ok
#2018-01-02Â 21:47:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It should participate in a well-defined way with the truth maintenance is the point.

(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A (= value 10)]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc))
  (insert! (->B)))
#2018-01-02Â 21:49:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Here you have a new fact that relies on truth maintenance and this rule as itâ€™s â€œlogical supportâ€. #2018-01-02Â 21:52:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I might agree that retraction of a logically derived fact doesnâ€™t make sense. #2018-01-02Â 21:52:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This one is unrelated a bit to our other thread concerning update!.
#2018-01-02Â 21:53:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It shouldnâ€™t be too difficult to have Clara do something like â€œunlinkingâ€ conditions from evaluation when required prior conditions havenâ€™t been satisfied yet.
#2018-01-02Â 21:54:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ A good example of the problem is something like: 
(defrule do-things
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id) (expensive-constraint x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C)))
Clara will currently do the (expensive-constraint x) when Bs are inserted, with no A in working memory at all, even if this condition is only used in this rule
#2018-01-02Â 21:56:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can write rules to avoid it like: 
(defrule find-things
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [?b <- B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (insert! (->ReadyB ?b)))

(defrule do-things
  [ReadyB (expensive-constraint x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C)))
#2018-01-02Â 21:56:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, that is not super obvious and also may not always be so straightforward to correctly split

#2018-01-04Â 13:25:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ Are there suggested patterns for rules that can require potentially-expensive lookups? If I have a rule that depends on content that could be retrieved from an API call / database hit / etc., is there a way to trigger that retrieval (and insert any facts it results in) only when the rule's other conditions are satisfied?
#2018-01-04Â 13:32:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @tcarls thatâ€™s funny you bring that up since this topic came up fairly recently here
#2018-01-04Â 13:32:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In short: I think in the future Clara could do better to avoid doing work when required previous conditions arenâ€™t yet satisfied.
#2018-01-04Â 13:32:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, there is a workaround pattern:
#2018-01-04Â 13:34:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
;; Say you have this:
(defrule original
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id) (do-expensive-thing x)]
  =>
  (insert (->C)))


It can be transformed to this:
(defrule part-1
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [?b <- B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (insert (->MatchedB ?b)))

(defrule part-2
  [MatchedB (do-expensive-thing x)]
  =>
  (insert (->C)))
#2018-01-04Â 13:38:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you are in a situation where there may be some thrash of insert/retracts of A and B (from example) due to the truth maintenance of the network, then you can also consider adding either :salience or setup â€œactivation groupsâ€ for rules like part-2. However, Iâ€™d only do that if there is actually a situation where it could be an issue.
#2018-01-04Â 13:50:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ Thank you -- that's useful advice.
#2018-01-04Â 13:55:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Some details on salience and activations groups is written here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/ If you end up needing it. However, like I said, avoid it if unnecessary. It is additional complexity to deal with.
#2018-01-04Â 22:22:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Is there a way to establish a conditional relationship between facts outside of a rule RHS? The case I'm thinking of is something like an article app, where articles have comments. Selecting an article makes it "active", and also triggers a request to fetch comments from the server. When the async request completes, comments will be inserted. It would be slick if retracting the active article fact also automagically retracted the inserted comments, but since the response handler for the comments request executes outside of a rule context, I don't see an obvious way to enforce that logical connection.
#2018-01-04Â 22:48:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ You could write something fairly easily to "deactivate" them (by joining the comment fact to the article and inserting an ActiveComment or something) but that wouldnt retract the base comment fact which could lead to build up over time. I don't know of any way to do what you are talking about without an external handler atm
#2018-01-04Â 22:50:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ they would have to come in on the same data object into the session which doesnt match the timeline you describe

I think it doesnâ€™t typically come up. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/321 I mention both in http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html

#2018-01-05Â 15:15:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ ::handle-cancelled-response is arguably just "nice to have", catches the case of ActiveArticle changing before the response to the comments request is received.                    [Fact2 (= e ?e) (= b ?b]]]
#2018-01-06Â 17:06:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @alex-dixon I am not sure if @wparker has an issue logged on this subject but odd things can happen sometime in rule compilation due to how Clara compiler converts these Boolean conditions to disjunctive normal form. DNF
#2018-01-06Â 17:07:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So the conditions in the :and are being split by an :or.

#2018-01-06Â 22:01:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Ok. Let me unwind my attempts that arenâ€™t working and attempt that
#2018-01-06Â 22:02:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule r1
  
   [Fact1 (= e ?e) (= a ?a)]
   [Fact2 (= e ?e) (= b ?b)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Fact3 ?e ?a ?b)))


(defrule r2
  [SomeFact (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]
  [:not [Fact3 (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]]
  =>
  (prn {:a ?a
        :b ?b
        :e ?e}))
#2018-01-06Â 22:02:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I believe that is the extraction
#2018-01-06Â 22:03:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ That would pair all Fact1 and Fact2 facts together in the r1 join to make the Fact3 facts
#2018-01-06Â 22:03:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Then r2 would be looking for the non-existence of any of those join results to match the same a and b of a SomeFact fact

#2018-01-08Â 15:51:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @mikerod I havenâ€™t gotten around to doing a comprehensive writeup, but basically I was looking at how to address https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/343 and ran into what I think are some issues with to-dnf. Basically since the :or operation is actually more of a union in the set theory sense, I think the to-dnf transforms can end up messing with cardinality. For example, [:not [:and A B]] is equivalent to [:or [:not A] [:not B]] in a boolean sense, but the second can match twice and the first canâ€™t in the context of Clara.
#2018-01-08Â 16:12:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @wparker thanks. I remember the topic better now.

#2018-01-12Â 19:54:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I have a way of handling session. But what I really want is to be able to do the final insert such that the fact is a logical consequence of the rule lhs. Not sure if that actually is meaningful given how rete works.
#2018-01-13Â 19:02:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Iâ€™m not sure whether using Claraâ€™s truth maintenance directly allows that, but you should be able to simulate it using unconditional inserts/retracts, other rules, and facts that represent the async event cycle. A poor attempt: 
(defrule make-request-when
  [?task <- AsyncTask]
  =>
  (retract! ?task)
  (insert-unconditional (->AsyncRequest ?task))
 (async-side-effect! my-session ?task)

(defn async-side-effect! [session fact] (request! fact (fn [err res] 
(if err (insert session (->AsyncTaskError err fact)
(insert session (->AsyncTaskSuccess res fact))

(defrule on-async-task-success
  [?success <- AsyncTaskSuccess ?res ?fact]
  [?request <- AsyncTaskRequest ?fact]
=>
(retract! ?success ?request)
(insert-unconditional! (->SomeFactRepresentingResponseFromThisKindOfRequest ?res)
 
  ;; similarly with error
#2018-01-13Â 19:26:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I have something similar, and it works nicely. But it would be nice if I could avoid the manual truth maintenance.
#2018-01-12Â 21:16:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t think anything built-in would allow you to reliable have an actual â€œhandleâ€ on the mutable session state during fire rules for an insert! to go off later yet, still correctly be tracked with TMS
#2018-01-12Â 21:16:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ thereâ€™d be quite a bit of complications for the engine to try to support that even I think
#2018-01-12Â 21:16:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not to mention the fire-rules wouldnâ€™t be able to be â€œdoneâ€ until all async actions were done
#2018-01-12Â 21:17:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and itâ€™d have concurrency issues in a multi-threaded environment
#2018-01-12Â 21:59:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Agreed. Maybe the right(ish) answer is to model facts as something like a promise. The semantics and behavior would have to be constrained, so it isn't just mutating facts behind your back without properly updating the session. But the basic concept seems like a way forward, because conditionally inserting a promise as a fact means it and whatever value it returns will get retracted when TMS requires it.
#2018-01-12Â 22:02:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ The thing I'm trying to avoid is having to manually perform truth management for facts inserted as the result of async effects. In the big picture, those facts are logical consequents of whatever condition triggered the async effect.
#2018-01-12Â 22:46:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah,I think the case is interesting
#2018-01-13Â 16:02:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I took a shot at forcing conditional inserts in the async handler, if only as an exercise to understand the code better. I got as far as actually getting the insert to occur, basically grabbing the *rule-context* and making it available to the handler, and adding an overload of fire-rules that would accept that as an extra parameter. The rule context was modified so it only contained non-empty :batched-logical-insertions with the facts being inserted as a logical consequence of the rule triggering the async effect. clara.rules.engine/*fire-rules* then also had an extra arity to deal with externally supplied rule context. At this point, I guessed that this approach probably wouldn't work in general, because it looks to me like the :token in the rule context contains the fact bindings which are the logical antecedent. If any of those facts had been retracted in the session between the request and response of the async effect, I assume that clara.rules.memory/add-insertions! would be unhappy, as the token would be inconsistent with the state of working memory. Is that correct?
#2018-01-13Â 16:52:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah. I donâ€™t think thatâ€™d be very tractable.
#2018-01-13Â 16:52:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also working memory is in a mutable state. I think things could easily become inconsistent.
#2018-01-13Â 18:13:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Makes sense.
#2018-01-13Â 18:14:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Is there a way to force a rule to fire, even if the fact values don't change? I'm playing around with using an atom to solve this case, but of course the atom reference doesn't change when the atom is reset, only the wrapped value changes, so the rule won't fire after the first time.
#2018-01-13Â 19:06:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @dave.dixon > Is there a way to force a rule to fire, even if the fact values donâ€™t change? No offense intended at all but that seems off to a bad start even to meâ€¦. ðŸ˜„ What are you trying to do?
#2018-01-13Â 19:24:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Yeah, it sounds bad. I'm trying to get the rhs to evaluate when a fact refers to an atom and the atom value changes.

#2018-01-13Â 20:36:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ 
(ns abc.other)

(defrecord SupportRequest [client level])

(defrecord ClientRepresentative [name client])

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(ns abc.core
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]
            [abc.other :as other]))

(defrule is-important
  "Find important support requests."
  [abc.other.SupportRequest (= :high level)] ;; full path here works; change to other/SupportRequest and an exception is thrown
  =>
  (println "High support requested!"))

(defrule notify-client-rep
  "Find the client representative and request support."
  [abc.other.SupportRequest (= ?client client)]
  [abc.other.ClientRepresentative (= ?client client) (= ?name name)]
  =>
  (println "Notify" ?name "that"
          ?client "has a new support request!"))

(-> (mk-session 'abc.core)
    (insert (other/->ClientRepresentative "Alice" "Acme")
            (other/->SupportRequest "Acme" :high))
    (fire-rules))
#2018-01-13Â 20:37:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ the above example reproduces the problem

#2018-01-13Â 20:39:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You have to use import for those.

#2018-01-13Â 23:24:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @alex-dixon I haven't tried multiple time facts. I think it should work correctly with upsert, though. Retracting existing fact would lead to retraction of the generated Tag facts, and the subsequent insert would generate an updated set.
#2018-01-13Â 23:27:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I was hoping to get away from having auxiliary unconditional facts like Time. The other version of async is structurally similar, but there the external fact is Response, which is correlated via a rule with the original Request. There's an additional rule that forces retract of Response when the corresponding Request no longer exists.
#2018-01-13Â 23:29:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Given that both approaches require unconditional inserts, the Request/`Response` pattern is arguably cleaner, as the atom approach requires some extra coordination outside of the rulebase to correctly update the session when the atom value changes.
#2018-01-13Â 23:37:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Iâ€™ll definitely keep this in mind as I try to do similar things. Wish I could be more help but it gets hard for me to reason about and I find my thinking tending toward more immutable approaches which seems like the opposite of the overall approach (fewer intermediate facts/garbage). Iâ€™ll try to experiment next time Iâ€™m at a laptop
#2018-01-13Â 23:38:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Curious, did you try a callback in the rhs and logical insert? Seem to recall that being your first approach. If so what happened? Loss of session context?
#2018-01-14Â 00:29:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I have it working with a callback and unconditional insert. I don't think there's a way to do a logical insert in the context of the callback. The session has already moved forward, could have been modified further by the time the callback is called, etc.
#2018-01-14Â 14:43:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ I havenâ€™t played around with it much. Typically I do the same as you I thinkâ€¦.wait to handle it on the next fire-rules iteration, but that can be problematic in certain cases. So Iâ€™m kind of curious about being able to park/block within the RHS but I havenâ€™t thought about it much. It might be convenient for Javascript but in a parallel or multiple thread environmentâ€¦I dunno. I forget the case I ran into where I really did want to stop the world / rule activations until I could get a result, but I feel like thatâ€™s more an error in my thinking than a feature I need to figure out how to support. Donâ€™t know though
#2018-01-14Â 00:42:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Part of what I was finding was that beyond the simple request/response case there was a proliferation of auxiliary fact types to deal with requests from the UI. For example, if the user toggled the "Favorite" button on an article, I would insert a FavoritedArticle fact, which in turn triggered Request to be inserted, along with a rule to handle the response to that Request. I also had to add clean up rules to get rid of these FavoritedArticle facts when the page changed, as well as properly manage upsertion vs. insertion, etc. It was all starting to feel a bit fiddly. But I think you could actually do this with the same Request/`Response` pattern, just replacing making an HTTP request with rendering the UI which will generate the Response.
#2018-01-14Â 14:34:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ So for precept I implemented something like the following. Below is somewhat similar to Redux in Javascript which also reifies this and request/response/fail for api calls for front-end state management. 
(defrecord Action [type payload])

(defrule actions-only-survive-one-call-to-fire-rules
{:salience -100}
 [?fact <- Action]
=>
(retract! Action)

(defrule on-article-favorited
{:salience 100}
[Action (= ?type :article-favorited) (= ?payload payload)]
=>
;; Still have the async dance but Action facts are automatically cleaned up at the end
(do)
#2018-01-14Â 15:36:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Right. I'm trying to do this without salience, just to see where it takes me in terms of design, possible changes to clara, etc. One thing that has fallen out is that I think the fact-based immutable history approach of precept is probably the way to go, as opposed to using whole entities as facts and trying to update "in place".
#2018-01-14Â 17:39:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Would you consider agenda groups? (rule when-no-user-selected-article
 [:not SelectedArticleId]
  [?most-recent <- (acc/min :time :returns-fact true) :from [Article]]
=>
(insert! (->SelectedArticleId (:id ?most-recent)))

If it did as something like (SelectedArticleId :unset) then you could match on (= id :unset) and (modify! ?selected-article :id (:id ?most-recent))

#2018-01-15Â 18:29:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ What do the vars end up being named? e.g. (defquery ::some-alias/my-spec ..) => #â€™rule-ns/ â€¦ ?
#2018-01-15Â 18:38:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ There are no vars. I'm not defining the queries as ns-level defs. They're grouped inside of a named object, and that symbol winds up holding the collection of productions that is provided to defsession.
#2018-01-15Â 20:21:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Like most of your suggestions and changes I like that. Using defs/the ns as a kind of data structure is something I like sometimes and not others

#2018-01-15Â 21:28:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I'm putting together my own DSL that has those characteristics, not proposing to alter the existing rules DSL packaged with clara. I handle reloading in the implementation of my DSL. Since rules are just grouped in vars, it's pretty straightforward, don't have to deal with the subtleties of CLJS namespace reloading etc.
#2018-01-16Â 03:43:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ is there a way to compose accumulators outside of writing a custom reducer? e.g., I want to get the latest timestamp of all facts, so some combination of (acc/all) and (acc/max :tx)
#2018-01-16Â 06:33:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair there isnâ€™t anything directly for that. On a case by case you may able to get the behavior you want from an accumulator like the max above.
#2018-01-16Â 06:35:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you had a unique ID on all facts for example, you could just do ?l <- (acc/max :tx) :from [A (= id? ?id)]
#2018-01-16Â 06:36:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m not sure that makes much sense though. acc/max is intended to find the max among all facts. Accumulators are mostly for reasoning about aggregates. I may have misunderstood your usage you were looking for.
#2018-01-16Â 06:54:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ The rule engine I work on takes the general from (state, action) -> actions, where action and actions are actions to perform (in aggregate) to transition state to a new state (basically the RE is a reduce, but instead of reducing to a new state, it returns â€œdiffâ€ operations through querying the resulting state that external service(s) can use to transition the state). A difficulty that Iâ€™ve had in general with this pattern is that I need to track changes to state as rules propagate, and then insert output actions based on those changes. So for example, given an initial entity A {:id 1, :x true}, there may be cascading changes over the (short) life of the session that cause it to transition to any number of {true,false} values. I always want the stable result, so I have added tx values to track â€œtimeâ€. Given that, I may have a rule that â€œsubscribesâ€ to a number of those facts (e.g., all :ids), but I want the max :tx of each of those entities.
#2018-01-16Â 06:55:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ In summary: [?entities <- (acc/all) :from [TimestampedEntity]] ;; ?entities => [{:id 1, :x true, :tx 1} {:id 1, :x false, :tx 2} {:id 2, :x true, :tx 3}] but I only want the latest :tx for each unique entity, so desired: ?entities => [{:id 1, :x false, :tx 2} {:id 2, :x true, :tx 3}]
#2018-01-16Â 07:00:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ e.g., to calculate a ratio of true entities over all entities (but only for their final states)
#2018-01-16Â 16:02:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dadair if you use a variable binding bound to the :id field then the accumulator will give you the latest :tx per :id
#2018-01-16Â 16:04:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
[?latest <- (acc/max :tx) :from [TsEntity (= ?id id)]]
#2018-01-16Â 16:05:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thatâ€™s the â€œlatest :tx â€œ of each fact group where they are grouped by :id
#2018-01-17Â 02:15:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â cflemingÂ What is the logic by which class members from fact types are used to create local variables for the constraints?

#2018-01-19Â 15:04:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.dixon I mostly never would recommend many patterns that make pervasive use of insert-unconditional!

Other than that, I think itâ€™s best to avoid. Even then, there are several RHS retract related issues outstanding that can be seen in the GitHub
#2018-01-19Â 15:05:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m looking at your example to see if I see anything you could do

#2018-01-19Â 15:58:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @mikerod Interesting. Let me ponder that.
#2018-01-19Â 15:59:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I am missing a part still. Trying to get that done. The concept I think can work though in terms of marking a timestamp at each stage. However, the above fails because it is letting TMS remove the intermediary collections from previous runs
#2018-01-19Â 16:00:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think you have to signal each â€œstageâ€ as an explicit fact though. Without something like that, the network never knows what each conceptual step is to you. It doesnâ€™t distinguish one fire-rules from another really
#2018-01-19Â 16:00:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So usually when that sort of info is missing, you end up adding it as a fact to represent the idea
#2018-01-19Â 16:52:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.dixon I updated it now
#2018-01-19Â 16:53:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It is hard to say that it exactly captures what you want. If you look at :before-retract though, you get the multiple accumulated groups idea that you were wanting
#2018-01-19Â 16:53:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Just requires each fact to be externally stamped with the same â€œtimestampâ€ as the â€œfire eventâ€ that they were inserted with
#2018-01-19Â 16:53:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I couldnâ€™t work out a way for rules to express that stamping due to logical TMS.
#2018-01-19Â 16:53:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Retracting is slightly harder, since you need to retract all matching facts across all timestamps (at least from your sort of example)
#2018-01-19Â 16:54:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This retraction results in all prior groups being updated as well to remove the fact that is gone. That isnâ€™t exactly what you wanted I dontâ€™ think, but it conveys somewhat similar information.
#2018-01-19Â 16:57:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The accumulation for Nums could tag it with the FireEvent ts it went with. Then that could be used to do a duplicate removal and/or â€œnewestâ€ result lookup on the :before-retract vs :after-retract
#2018-01-19Â 18:57:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dave.dixon Perhaps a model like the following might work if youâ€™re OK with accumulating some â€œgarbageâ€ over time. 
- Logically insert a "Request" fact.
- Have a query like [Request (= ?id id)] [:not [RequestResponse (= ?id id)]].
- The client would externally insert a RequestResponse fact when it wanted to "close" a request.
- A todo could be done like [Request (= ?id id)] [:not [RequestResponse (= ?id id)]] => (insert! (->ToDo ?id)).
Then further logic downstream could dispatch on the TODOs as required, say if too many were outstanding.
If you need to clean up garbage, it almost sounds like youâ€™re asking about retracting a fact without removing downstream insertions due to it.. is that on target at all?
#2018-01-19Â 19:28:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @wparker I think in your 4th bullet you would remove the :not. But otherwise, that's basically it. The "garbage" is okay, I'm experimenting with rulesets that enforce logical consistency over time, e.g. of some process of interacting with the user and an external server. So the "garbage" is really the history. What I'm finding is that you generally have some "anchor" facts from which the rest of the process logic flows, so when you change the anchor the "garbage" gets collected. For example, in the conduit example, an anchor fact is the filter which retrieves a set of articles from the server, So articles wind up inserted with conditional dependence on the filter fact. Then the user can do a number of things, like change the favorite status of an article, edit if they are the author, etc. So all of that history gets accumulated, but when you change the filter it's all retracted.
#2018-01-19Â 19:32:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @wparker It wasn't specifically that I was looking to retract a fact without removing downstream insertions, rather modify the set of facts that went into an accumulator without retracting downstream insertions created by previous activations of the accumulator rule. It makes sense from a purely logical standpoint (I think), but the semantics of accumulators in the rule network are slightly different - not wrong, just making a different logical assertion, and one that is feasible within rule network architecture.
#2018-01-29Â 01:18:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ If I have records having a field used for ordering -- like a timestamp -- and want to make rules that reason about or refer to "the immediately preceding X", or "the most recent X to have attribute Y", is Clara well-suited to the purpose?
#2018-01-29Â 01:18:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ ("immediately preceding" relative to another record, that is, as opposed to, say, an accumulator reflecting the globally most recent insert/assertion).
#2018-01-29Â 02:54:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ It can be, Iâ€™m currently using it to reason about entities that change over time. I have to admit though that I donâ€™t find it that easy to model (although I could be doing things horribly wrong).
#2018-01-29Â 02:56:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ e.g., I have entities of type A that can change over time (tracked through a timestamp), and other entities of type B that can change over time in response to the changes to type A (that is, there is a relation B = f(A)), and other entities of type C = f(B) that also change over time in response to changes in B
#2018-01-29Â 02:57:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ I find the rules Iâ€™m writing to be quite.. cumbersome, and I find myself inserting special facts just to facilitate rule propagation, to prevent e.g., infinite activations
#2018-01-29Â 02:59:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ however, the challenges I face come from the /fact/ that changes are inserted as a consequence of rules, if all history was known prior to rule activation, and I wasnâ€™t inserting new facts from rules (that is, growing/extending time within a given sessionâ€™s fire-rules), and I was simply querying certain states throughout a known and unchanging history, that would be perfectly suitable
#2018-01-29Â 15:20:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @tcarls I think that @dadair has some good things to think about in terms of what you are trying to accomplish. Some of it varies according to the situation. Here is an example that I think meets at least one part of your question though 
(defrule immediately-preceding
  [A (= timestamp ?ts)]
  [?preceding <- (acc/max :timestamp :returns-fact true) :from [B (< timestamp ?ts)]]
  =>
  <etc>)
#2018-01-29Â 15:21:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can use an accumulator that constrains the facts that it accumulates over. By doing this, you can match things more specific/localized/â€œparameterizedâ€, rather than â€œglobalâ€ accumulations.
#2018-01-29Â 16:03:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ @mikerod, that's extremely helpful; thank you.
#2018-01-30Â 16:05:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Hello, I have question about acc/all behavior, the following snippet of code: 
(ns rules-acc-all
  (require [clara.rules :as rules]
           [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
           [clojure.pprint :refer [pprint]]))

(defrecord Customer [id])
(defrecord Reward [id])
(defrecord CustomerReward [id customer-id reward-id])

(rules/defrule quals
  [Customer (= ?C id)]
  [Reward (= ?R id) (= id "bonus-1")]
  ;;[?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= id ?I) (= ?C customer-id)]]
  [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= ?C customer-id)]]
  =>
  (pprint {"?items" ?items}))


(let [session (-> (rules/mk-session 'rules-acc-all)
                  (rules/insert (->Customer "customer-1")
                                (->Reward "bonus-1")
                                (->Reward "offer-1")
                                (->Reward "offer-2")
                                (->CustomerReward "cr-1" "customer-1" "offer-1")
                                (->CustomerReward "cr-2" "customer-1" "offer-2")))
      fired (rules/fire-rules session)]
  )
#2018-01-30Â 16:05:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Prints 
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-1", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-1"}
  {:id "cr-2", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-2"}]}
#2018-01-30Â 16:06:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ i.e. ?items contain two elements.
#2018-01-30Â 16:07:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ However if condition [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= ?C customer-id)]] is replaced with [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= id ?I) (= ?C customer-id)]] (pretty much same with unification added for CustomerReward (= id ?I) the the output would be:
#2018-01-30Â 16:07:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ 
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-1", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-1"}]}
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-2", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-2"}]}
#2018-01-30Â 16:07:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ I.e. ?items contain single element, but rule gets triggered twice.
#2018-01-30Â 16:09:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ I am trying to wrap my mind around this, but cannot - those two rules set look pretty much same to me
#2018-01-30Â 17:01:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I believe it's because when you specify (= id ?I) in the accumulator, clara will now make a unique binding for each unique value of id, so the rule fires once for each id of CustomerReward rather than accumulating over all CustomerReward's with different id's.
#2018-01-30Â 17:12:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Thanks @dave.dixon - that kind of explains it. I guess my confusion was due thinking that binding (= id ?I) is kind of "local" to accumulator, in other words it works as sub-select in SQL, however it appears such binding makes ?I "available" to "outer scope", i.e. I could refer it for unification in clauses which are siblings of accumulator.
#2018-01-30Â 17:13:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Correct. Or you could refer to ?I in the RHS of the rule, where it would have to be unique.
#2018-01-30Â 17:13:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Yep, then it makes sense
#2018-01-31Â 02:07:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ I'm seeing rules no longer firing after I reloaded the namespace that contains them in the REPL, even if I create an entirely new session with (mk-session :cache false). What am I missing?

#2018-01-31Â 22:41:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™ve had quite a few of those before. So if you â€œremoved the duplicatesâ€ youâ€™d fail to meet the needs of someone who wanted to count things
#2018-01-31Â 22:41:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For whatever purpose
#2018-01-31Â 22:42:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In Drools (popular Java-based rules engine), they went with â€œlogical insertsâ€ never are duplicated, but â€œunconditional insertsâ€ are duplicated if they are not identical?
#2018-01-31Â 22:42:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It was nice, when you really just didnâ€™t want duplicates, but difficult to work with when you did
#2018-01-31Â 22:42:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In Clara, if you need some â€œsingle countâ€ fact in the end, you can just use an aggregation sort of rule

#2018-01-31Â 23:18:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ headscratch
#2018-01-31Â 23:24:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ

#2018-01-31Â 23:33:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dadairÂ @tcarls where is the mk-session youâ€™re using (e.g., same ns as the rule? other ns?), and what does the function call look like?

#2018-02-01Â 00:30:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ @dadair, same ns, called from the -main function with :cache false. The get-warnings rule is basically as simple as the above implies -- it just retrieves every single record we have of type Warning with no filters/joins/etc: (r/defquery get-warnings [] [?warning <- Warning])
#2018-02-01Â 00:48:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tcarlsÂ Hmm. Unrelated issue, but I have a theory on why I'm getting more fact insertions than I expected. Looking through the explain output... 
{:ns-name pdfsort.core,
   :lhs
   [{:type pdfsort.types.Document,
     :constraints [(= ?type (or name-type header-type))],
     :fact-binding :?doc}],
   :rhs (do (r/insert! (->DocumentType ?doc ?type))),
   :name "pdfsort.core/use-document-type"}
I expected the (or name-type header-type) to mean that we bind the first non-falsey item of name-type or header-type to ?type, but it looks like it actually results in both paths being followed. Changing it to (if name-type name-type header-type) results in the initially-expected behavior, of performing one DocumentType insertion per Document.
#2018-02-01Â 15:50:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @U2V9F98N8 Iâ€™d expect the or in the above rule to be short-circuiting i.e. just clojure.core/or. Something like this is a Clara-specific non-short-circuiting or: 
[:or [DocumentType1] [DocumentType2]]
but that doesnâ€™t apply to the case you describe; note the keyword :or not the function invocation of â€œorâ€. If you can create a reproducing case it would be helpful if you could log a GitHub issue - tbh I suspect something else is going on, but you never know
#2018-02-02Â 21:16:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mjmeintjesÂ What's the best way to ensure that a fact doesn't get inserted twice. Is there a way to ensure that duplicate facts don't get inserted into the same session?
#2018-02-02Â 21:30:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mjmeintjes I talked about this in a few posts above if you can see them?
#2018-02-02Â 21:30:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I discussed â€œcardinalityâ€ of equal facts in clara and ways to work with it
#2018-02-02Â 21:30:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and tradeoffs etc
#2018-02-02Â 21:40:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mjmeintjesÂ Thanks for the information. I was thinking more about how to efficiently update the session - for example, I have a list of rows from the database. Before firing the rules I need to make sure that all the db rows are included in the session. However, I do not want all the rules to be inserted each time (which causes lots of duplicates), and I also don't want the session to be recreated each time. What I've done now is create a query to retrieve the already inserted rules from the session, and then I'm comparing that against the db rows, and then I only insert the new ones. I was just wondering whether that is the best solution.
#2018-02-02Â 21:45:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mjmeintjes I think that is a fine way to do it. I think there may be a potential enhancement to clara to do something like an â€œupdateâ€ of facts and/or a â€œmodeâ€ that had the working memory act in a set-based way there werenâ€™t duplicates. For now though, the external query idea is good if it can work for you
#2018-02-02Â 21:48:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mjmeintjesÂ Yeah, being able to efficiently update the session would be great, as each time I've used Clara that's something that I've run up against. The only problem with the query approach is that queries are only updated once fire-rules has run, which means you can still get duplicates if you aren't careful to run fire-rules before inserting any new data.
#2018-02-02Â 21:52:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mjmeintjes Yeah, you should never query prior to fire-rules. Iâ€™d call that an â€œundefinedâ€ state
#2018-02-02Â 21:52:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara does some â€œlazyâ€ sort of batching that isnâ€™t forced until fire-rules. It can do some good optimizations with this and could even get more â€œlazyâ€ in the future Iâ€™d think.
#2018-02-02Â 21:53:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think it can be difficult to do â€œlogical updatesâ€ to facts with what Clara currently offers
#2018-02-02Â 21:54:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it relies basically entirely on the caller to query facts and figure out what inserts/retracts to make externally. That is if the rules are going to be written in a way that can smoothly work with the truth maintenance system and logical inserts (ie not insert-unconditional! and right-hand-side based retract!).
#2018-02-02Â 21:54:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ These sort of discussions have came up quite a bit here lately.

#2018-02-06Â 15:12:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dave.dixon I donâ€™t see any docs on it based on a search for â€œexistsâ€ in the clara-site repo. Having doc would be desirable. In the meantime it is really a pretty form of syntax sugar - you can just mentally make the substitution the compiler does at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L618 if youâ€™re trying to understand the behavior

I was having some issues and thought this may be the culprit, but it was other things (which had nothing to do with clara per se). #2018-02-06Â 21:46:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ It looks like the current behavior of parameterized queries is to just return an empty seq if all of the arguments are not bound in the call to query. It would be useful sometimes if leaving out a parameter just treated it as unbound, though I think you could only get away with this when the parameters are used in simple equality constraints, e.g. [?:foo] [Foo (= ?foo foo)]. I can get this behavior by wrapping query, but was wondering if there was a way to achieve it directly in clara.
#2018-02-07Â 16:55:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dave.dixon the query params are defined at query creation time and then used to key the results for the query in a map. This results in the actual call to â€œqueryâ€ basically just being a map lookup. If arbitrary keys could be missing, I donâ€™t think you could look things up that way without creating a lookup table for every possible permutation of absent and present bindings during fire-rules time, which could become costly. Looking at the code it seems perhaps we could add logic allowing the user to either pass all present params or none, providing all results regardless of bindings in the later case. Relevant code sections: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1959 for the query implementation in the engine, note the mem/get-tokens call. In QueryNode note the memory calls as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L431 with the join-bindings coming from the param-keys via this: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L149 Then see get-tokens and get-tokens-all: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/memory.cljc#L451 ; get-tokens-all would ignore the bindings
#2018-02-07Â 18:05:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ @wparker Thanks, good insight on working memory. It looks like the inspect function illustrates how to get at the bindings via get-tokens-all.

#2018-02-12Â 16:16:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â yyonchoÂ Here is simplified example of what I am trying to accomplish: I have fact FnHolder which contains how the Temperature facts will be compared/processed. I want to have a rule which produces another fact from the FnHolder and the Temperature but it doesn't trigger the depending rules when a new Temperature which doesn't change the produced value(thus I cannot do the accumulation in the body). This behavior is similar to acc/max which does not trigger if a non-maximal Temperature is inserted. Ideally I would have been able to write the following code but it doesn't run since ?fn is not visible in the custom-accum block. Can you advice? code (defrecord Temperature [location temperature]) (defrecord FnHolder [location other-params]) (defrule chaning [?fn <- FnHolder (= location ?loc)] [?t <- (custom-accum ?fn) :from [Temperature]] => ;; insert facts... ) code
#2018-02-12Â 17:53:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @yyoncho I donâ€™t have an immediate complete answer to that question, but perhaps you could accomplish what you are wanting with a :test condition after the accumulation. Accumulate with something that doesnâ€™t need to be â€œparameterizedâ€.
#2018-02-12Â 17:54:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Another possibility is to use a sort of joined fact. Iâ€™m not sure how appropriate it will be for you, but it would look like:
#2018-02-12Â 17:55:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrecord Temperature [location temperature])
(defrecord FnHolder [location other-params])
(defrecord TempWithFn [temp fn-holder])

(defrule combine
  [?fn <- FnHolder  (= location ?loc)]
  [?t <- Temperature]
  =>
  (insert (->TempWithFn ?t ?fn)))

(defrule chaning
  [?t <- (custom-accum :fn-holder) :from [TempWithFn]]
  =>
  ;; insert facts...
)
#2018-02-12Â 17:56:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think the custom-accum doesnâ€™t really need the :fn-holder key anymore though. it has the whole fact with all that info on it.
#2018-02-13Â 07:15:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â yyonchoÂ @mikerod if I do that I will be able to process the Temperature facts one by one in FnHolder which won't work since FnHolder is stateful processing over the whole collection of Temperature facts, e. g. find the max Temperature for particular day of the week.

#2018-02-20Â 15:39:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @souenzzo what do you mean by â€œstrange exceptionsâ€? In terms of number of facts, the only real limit in Clara should be the memory available.. but of course if you have problematic rules (not necessarily incorrectly written, just poorly performing) you can run into problems. If you can find a reproducing case that seems like it performs more poorly than it should feel free to log an issue. Weâ€™ve mostly optimized Clara against the examples we have at Cerner but representative benchmarks of other workloads could be interesting/useful.

#2018-02-28Â 14:58:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ I haven't found a good way to do detailed profiling / tracing yet, so all suggestions are welcome ðŸ™‚
#2018-02-28Â 14:58:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Well, retracts can happen due to logical inserts (normal insert! in Clara). Also, accumulators may be updated and have to retract previous results. There are quite a few reasons to have â€œimplicitâ€ retracts happening in working memory
#2018-02-28Â 14:59:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ make sense
#2018-02-28Â 14:59:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ I am using an all accumulator in the rule
#2018-02-28Â 14:59:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ VisualVM is free. Iâ€™ve used it mostly just since it was good enough for seeing many things like this.
#2018-02-28Â 14:59:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ but the funny thing is that it works just fine when doing 2 million in bulk on an empty session
#2018-02-28Â 15:00:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ I'll give that a spin
#2018-02-28Â 15:00:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ That isnâ€™t entirely surprising to me - if youâ€™ve found a bad retraction sort of scenario
#2018-02-28Â 15:00:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In bulk, Clara does a lot of work in batches
#2018-02-28Â 15:00:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Which has one benefit of avoiding â€œreworkâ€ - aka retractions/insertions to update â€œincorrectâ€ earlier working memory states
#2018-02-28Â 15:01:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ I'm comparing 2 million in 1 go, vs 2 batches of 1 million
#2018-02-28Â 15:01:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ (I was expecting memory usage to be a bottleneck, but it's doing pretty fine on that front)
#2018-02-28Â 15:01:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ anyway, visualvm it is ðŸ™‚
#2018-02-28Â 15:01:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So running with the VisualVM idea. 1) Download it, 2) open it, 3) find your JVM process (it has a list on in the UI) running the bad performance case with
#2018-02-28Â 15:02:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (4) click â€œSamplerâ€ tab (5) click â€œCPUâ€ (6) start running whatever is taking a long time
#2018-02-28Â 15:03:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (7) let it run for a bit, perhaps like a minute or so, then click â€œsnapshotâ€
#2018-02-28Â 15:03:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ :+1:
#2018-02-28Â 15:05:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Once you have a snapshot, you can dig around the callstack to see where the time is. If you want help with that, you can perhaps explain what is taking such a long time in the Clara functions of the callstack and perhaps I (or someone) will know enough by that. Or you can you can â€œexport toâ€ via an icon in the UI and itâ€™ll give you an nps file to share. If you have proprietary stuff (I donâ€™t think much proprietary info shows up in these though, but still.) you donâ€™t want to show, you could try to just find good screenshots that cut the callstack down to just the Clara functions parts.
#2018-02-28Â 15:05:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ I have to run now, but I'll do the test later today and post back with the results
#2018-02-28Â 15:05:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ thanks a lot already!
#2018-02-28Â 15:05:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s probably not a bad idea to get some familiarity with digging through some cpu sampling snapshot results though. Can definitely be useful for finding bottlenecks quickly
#2018-02-28Â 15:05:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ No problem
#2018-02-28Â 16:21:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @wdullaer are you inserting the facts like this: 
(-> session (insert first-fact) .... (insert millionth-fact))
or like this: 
(insert session [first-fact .. millionth-fact]
It seems odd to me that simply breaking a single batch into two would have such a huge performance impact - OTOH smaller batching could do it. Arguably Clara should try to batch the first case together anyway, but it doesnâ€™t. See how facts are added into the â€œpending-operationsâ€ on insertion at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1818 and removed from the queue in fire-rules at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1870
#2018-02-28Â 16:26:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If a simple division into two batches really does increase runtime like that Iâ€™d be curious to see a reproducing case and if there is some performance optimization we could do - at first glance it doesnâ€™t seem like it should happen, but as always it is hard to say without a concrete case. On profiling, seconding mikerodâ€™s suggestion of VisualVM. Another possible route would be to look at the trace of the rule execution for a smaller number of facts - manual examination wouldnâ€™t be practical for millions of facts, but a batch of 2 facts vs 2 batches of 1 fact each might show insights. Iâ€™d probably start with VisualVM though especially since traces generally require some understanding of Claraâ€™s internals to yield much insight. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.cljc

    (insert-all (generate-consents 1000000 test-purposes test-attributes))
    (fire-rules)
    (insert-all (generate-consents 1000000 test-purposes test-attributes))
    (fire-rules))

#2018-03-01Â 16:25:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It seems like these collections created via acc/distinct would be fairly large. Also, there are many of them after the first 1mil facts. Thereâ€™d be a big acc/distinct collection associated with each personId + purpose grouped Consent facts. When the next 1mil facts come in, I believe they will contribute to many (or perhaps even all) of those same big collections.
#2018-03-01Â 16:26:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The work from the first 1 mil facts is stored in working memory. Clara builds the new collections on the 2nd wave of inserts. It then must remove the old accumulated work it did from working memory - in order to replace it with the updates.
#2018-03-01Â 16:26:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think the fact that there are many of these large collections in working memory is making it get really expensive to remove them all from working memory. Clara tries to be efficient in finding and removing things in memory. I think huge collections may be a pitfall.
#2018-03-01Â 16:28:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™d like to look a little deeper at it, but havenâ€™t been able to yet. Iâ€™m not sure what a reasonable workaround may be, other than inserting everything in one batch (as youâ€™ve found).

#2018-03-02Â 19:37:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ @wdullaer for a workaround in your use case, would it make sense to first filter the consents? Your example shows 1/10th as many persons as events. Shrinking the search space by explicitly filtering the duplicates may speed things up.

#2018-03-02Â 19:46:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ cool
#2018-03-02Â 19:58:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ another thought (possibly in addition to the previous one) was to explode the Processor facts into something like DesiredConsent [processorId purpose attribute], use a rule to match them to a Consent and dump into another intermediate fact ApprovedDesiredConsent [processorId personId purpose attribute]. Then accumulate and match your ApprovedDesiredConsent to the Processor. I havenâ€™t tested it, so I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s more performant, but the idea/hope is that youâ€™d accumulate less when creating the AllowedProcessor
#2018-03-02Â 20:29:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ Iâ€™ll experiment with some of these on Monday
#2018-03-02Â 20:29:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wdullaerÂ the easiest I think is to just ensure that no duplicate consents are asserted, which I think I can do out of band (the consent will intially be put on a log)
#2018-03-03Â 06:13:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ Newbie question... I'm struggling to write a rule which boils down to "This or that".
#2018-03-03Â 06:13:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ 
(defrecord This [x])
  (defrecord That [y])
  (defrule this-or-that
    "Print This if fact exists, else print That."
    [:or [?x <- This] [?x <- That]]
    =>
    (println :this-or-that ?x))

  (-> (mk-session 'labs-costs-clara.core)
      (insert
        (->This 1)
        (->That 2))
      (fire-rules))
#2018-03-03Â 06:13:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ This will print twice which isn't what I'm after.
#2018-03-03Â 06:14:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â olivergeorgeÂ (my real example is patching data... if X exists use it else use some other facts to fill in the gap)

#2018-03-03Â 06:20:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ gotcha. id suggest something like 
(defrule with-summary
  ""
  [Summary (= ?data data)]
  =>
  (println ?data))

(defrule without-summary
  ""
  [:not [Summary]]
  [?others <- (acc/all) :from [SecondaryFacts]]
  
  =>
  (println ?others))
then

#2018-03-14Â 18:20:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ Why this code 
(ns experiments.a
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules]

            [clojure.pprint :refer [pprint]]))

(defrecord A [id])

(rules/defrule create-a-if-not-exists
  ""
  [:not [A]]
  =>
  (println "creating A")
  (rules/insert! (->A "a")))

(-> (rules/mk-session)
    (rules/fire-rules))
#2018-03-14Â 18:20:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â afurmanovÂ creates infinite recursion?
#2018-03-14Â 18:27:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The initial state of the session makes the LHS of your rule evaluate as true thus it inserts an A, which then makes your rule's LHS evaluate as false causing the truth maintenance of clara to logically retract the A that was insert. repeat
#2018-03-14Â 18:27:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ forever
#2018-03-14Â 18:28:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @alex.furmanov
#2018-03-14Â 18:28:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ "ok i'll insert a if there is no A. Inserting. Ok now lets look at the state of things. Oh there is an A. Retract That thing i inserted. Ok now lets look at the state of things. Oh there is no A. Time to insert A...." ~ Internal monologue of the session repeat ad infinitum
#2018-03-14Â 18:30:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ truth maintenance is the name of the game

#2018-03-21Â 16:07:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You could probably do what you ask though: 
(r/defquery []
  [?o <- Object]
  [:test (not (isa? (type ?o) ExcludedType))])

#2018-03-28Â 19:53:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ can you give an example?

#2018-03-28Â 19:56:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I can probably do a shorter one in a min
#2018-03-28Â 19:57:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ yeah this example is in response to my colleague
#2018-03-28Â 19:57:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ weâ€™re working on the same problem
#2018-03-28Â 19:58:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ just seems kinda hackish
#2018-03-28Â 19:58:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ also you need to know about the other rules
#2018-03-28Â 19:58:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule short-circuit
  [X] ;; whatever here
  =>
  (r/insert! <your fact here>
             :rule-marker/short-circuit))

(defrule fallback
  [:not [:rule-marker/short-circuit]]
  [Y]
  =>
  (r/insert! <your fact here>))
#2018-03-28Â 19:58:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I see

#2018-03-28Â 19:59:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ (defrule premium-video [Video (= ?id id)] [:or [PremiumChannels (= id ?id)] [LessThanTwoHours (= id ?id)] [PremiumTopics (= id ?id)]] => (insert! (create-rule-result ->MarketplacePremiumVideoContent ?id (->Rule 1 â€œPremium Videoâ€ :points 6)))))

#2018-03-28Â 20:00:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ another thing you can do
#2018-03-28Â 20:00:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Is let the :or fire as much as it can
#2018-03-28Â 20:00:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ then reconcile in a separate rule to â€œchoose the bestâ€
#2018-03-28Â 20:00:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ there is no best per se
#2018-03-28Â 20:00:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ they are all equal importance
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so what is the reason to want short-circuit
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Do you just not want multiple facts inserted?
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ `
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ 
(defrule premium-video
  [Video (= ?id id)]
  [:not [MarketplacePremiumVideoContent (= id ?id)]]
  [:or
    [PremiumChannels (= id ?id)]
    [LessThanTwoHours (= id ?id)]
    [PremiumTopics (= id ?id)]]
  =>
  (insert! (create-rule-result ->MarketplacePremiumVideoContent ?id (->Rule 1 "Premium Video" :points 6)))))
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ I tried this
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ but it went to an infinite loop
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ not sure why
#2018-03-28Â 20:01:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ yeah I just want one fact to be inserted
#2018-03-28Â 20:02:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule rule-with-or
  [:or
   [A]
   [B]
   [C]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->FoundIt)))

(r/defrule aggregate-found
  [?found <- (acc/all) :from [FoundIt]]
 [:test (seq ?found)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (do-aggregation ?found)))
#2018-03-28Â 20:02:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Insert a middle-fact
#2018-03-28Â 20:02:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ that you aggregate to a single fact
#2018-03-28Â 20:02:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ for â€œdownstreamâ€ rules to only see 1 fact
#2018-03-28Â 20:02:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ this can be either a merge or just pick one if they are all the same, etc
#2018-03-28Â 20:03:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(r/defrule aggregate-found
  [?found <- (acc/all) :from [FoundIt]]
 [:test (seq ?found)]
  =>
;; They are all the same, so I dont' care
  (r/insert! (first ?found)))
#2018-03-28Â 20:03:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I should add a non-empty check to just avoid useless fires
#2018-03-28Â 20:05:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > but it went to an infinite loop I believe your rule is invalidating itself
#2018-03-28Â 20:05:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ logically
#2018-03-28Â 20:05:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ however, I donâ€™t know for sure not knowing what create-rule-result does

#2018-03-28Â 20:05:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if somehow the RHS (or later rule) leads to a MarketplacePremiumVideoContent to be inserted with that ?id then youâ€™d get a loop
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ because itâ€™d get inserted, which would make the :not become false
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so itâ€™d be retracted
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but then :not would be true again, so itâ€™d get reinserted, but then :not would be false again, so itâ€™d be retracted - and repeat
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ I see
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ yeah, a bit of a mind bender
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â talgiatÂ ðŸ™‚
#2018-03-28Â 20:06:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s best to try to think of the rules as declarative and order-independent
#2018-03-28Â 20:07:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ where possible

#2018-04-02Â 21:51:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ I have some business processes that end up reading/saving data from and to a relational database. Some of my logic is pure, and some of it need this shared mutable state. Is there an idiomatic or clean way to handle side effects in clara ? It would be great if I could, for example, rollback a transaction in my database when the fact that caused the corresponding side effect is retracted â€¦ don't know if it's a sane way to tackle the problem thoughtâ€¦
#2018-04-03Â 02:38:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @ggaillard when you perform the side-effect, you can insert a fact that indicates that the side effect was performed
#2018-04-03Â 02:38:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can then have a rule that uses that to â€œretractâ€ the side effects
#2018-04-03Â 02:39:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you likely need to make these effects â€œidempotentâ€ so they can be replaced multiple times without causing issues
#2018-04-03Â 02:42:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ maybe something like 
(r/defrule do-thing
  [A (= v :something) (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (do-side-effect ?a)
  (r/insert! (->DidSideEffectFor ?id)))

(r/defrule undo-thing
  [?effect-data <- DidSideEffectFor (= ?id id)]
  [:not [A (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (retract-side-effect ?effect-data))
Assumes you have a way to link facts up, like an ID. This doesnâ€™t attempt to remove the DidSideEffectFor facts. So if this is a long running process, this may start to add up as too much data in memory
#2018-04-03Â 02:42:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If thatâ€™s the case, you may just want to handle the side-effects externally and clean up the DidSideEffectFor as well
#2018-04-03Â 02:47:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ My post on ways to update facts may be somewhat related to, if you are interested http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html
#2018-04-03Â 09:26:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ Awesome answer! Thank you!
#2018-04-04Â 19:19:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara-rules 0.18.0 is released. The release includes performance optimizations, a bugfix in error handling code, and new APIs targeted at ClojureScript library/platform developers consuming Clara. The release adds a new listening method that anyone creating a custom listener will need to implement, but the implementation can just be an empty body so it is an easy uplift. Additionally, the :rule-matches key in session inspection will now only have rules that led to logical insertions, with a new :unfiltered-rule-matches key now optionally available with a superset of the data previously in the :rule-matches. For a discussion of the rationale behind this change see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/386
#2018-04-05Â 20:54:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Fellow clarians (?): linked is a draft of an article of describing some of the fun I've been having using clara for UX. Any feedback greatly appreciated. https://sparkofreason.gitbooks.io/maali/content/

#2018-04-10Â 18:57:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @whilo Iâ€™m not completely up-to-speed on all of the various references you posted here. I can at least (for now) add a bit of light on the â€œdurabilityâ€ side of things. Clara does currently have some (fairly raw) support for session and working memory durability. More on that can be read about first @ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/durability/
#2018-04-10Â 18:57:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Much of the working memory side of the durability implementation is up to your particular use-case
#2018-04-10Â 18:58:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara does provide a Fressian backed impl of durability for the Clara infrastructure part of the rule sessions themselves

#2018-04-10Â 19:02:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In that case, the durability alone wonâ€™t be enough. In Claraâ€™s early days, Ryan Brush (the creator of Clara) had a demo project that prototyped how Claraâ€™s working memory could be realized over a distribution cluster using Apache Storm

#2018-05-07Â 16:23:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t think it is a trivial problem to solve and is going to end up being domain dependent. #2018-05-09Â 16:28:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jimbobÂ great point!
#2018-05-09Â 16:31:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ So that should be the matches on constraints that donâ€™t depend on joins - if you do [Fact (and (= field 1) (< field2 ?binding-from-ancestor))] youâ€™re forcing those constraints together in Claraâ€™s view, where [Fact (= field 1) (< field2 ?binding-from-ancestor)] keeps them separate
#2018-05-09Â 16:31:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The latter is also better for perf reasons, Clara can optimize it more
#2018-05-09Â 16:32:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Also note that :condition-matches doesnâ€™t work for accumulator conditions yet: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/293

#2018-05-13Â 22:22:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @devn Would the fact-graph functionality help? https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/fact_graph.cljc I know I never got around to building graphical tools on top of it and frankly probably wonâ€™t at this point, but even in a REPL or with text-based visualization maybe it could be useful. The main ways youâ€™d get at that sort of info would be session inspection (which the fact graph functionality uses internally) or listeners such as tracing - since the resulting data is just Clojure data you could process it as appropriate to make it more easily understood in your use case. To be honest though, my first thought is that if you need to go from the actual rule firing patterns backwards to the logical order, something is probably suboptimal about the organization of the codebase in question. Code organization is a tricky thing to get right and IMO highly domain-dependent but FWIW the rulebases Iâ€™ve worked with tended to either be DAGs or have broad groupings of rules that could be sketched out with their relationships to each other on a single piece of paper (with each of those groupings potentially containing other groupings and so forth)

#2018-05-17Â 12:41:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ I did the type customisation for a tuple, it's working out okay, however my rules are full of a lot of destructuring sugar: 
(defrule app-asg-min-size
  [:box/type [[e a v]] (= v :server) (= ?app e)]
  [?tup <- :min-size [[e a v]] (= e ?app)]
  =>
  (let [[e a v] ?tup]
    (insert!
      [(str e "-asg") :min-size v])))

  [[?e :todo/done false]]
  =>
  (println "The todo with this entity id is visible: " ?e)

#2018-05-17Â 14:35:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ The devtools were conceived in isolation, so before Iâ€™d work on porting some of it to Clara Iâ€™d really want to know what would be useful for people. As it stands, you can view the history of a rule, history of a fact, â€œevent logâ€ (all inserts and retractions in order), see explanations for all of those (the rule conditions that were defined, the facts they matched on, the bindings of the variables, what was inserted or retracted), whether something was inserted or removed unconditionally, logically, or the result of schema enforcement, if it was schema enforcement which existing fact triggered the schema enforcement and the relevant schema rule, added and removed facts for a particular rule firing (i.e. diff), and the total set of facts that exist in the session at the end of any rule firing
#2018-05-17Â 14:36:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Itâ€™s implemented as a client and serverâ€¦the client for visualization, the server for receiving messages from the inspected session/app over socket

#2018-05-18Â 13:16:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You canâ€™t refer to bare symbols that â€œrepresentâ€ lookup keys in a rule condition if you are asking that though with regard to â€œreferring to e. Clara currently only offers special syntactic access directly to record or â€œJava beanâ€ field/accessors. If you are using generic types it doesnâ€™t attempt to resolve like the symbol e to (:e this) This may be what youâ€™re asking
