#2018-05-18Â 15:07:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ 
(ns roll-alt
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]
    [clara.tools.fact-graph :as fg]
    [clara.rules.accumulators :as accum]
    [rhizome.viz :as rhizome]))

(defrecord D [e a v])

(defrule todos-done-invisible
  ;; [:todo/title (= ?e e)]
  [:todo/done (= (:v this) false) (= ?e (:e this))]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->D ?e :todo/visible true)))

(comment
  (-> (mk-session
        :fact-type-fn :a
        :ancestors-fn (constantly [:all]))
      (insert
        (->D "foo" :todo/title "FOO!")
        (->D "foo" :todo/title "FOOBAR!")
        (->D "foo" :todo/done true)
        (->D "blah" :todo/done false))
      (fire-rules)
      (query visible-datoms)))
@mikerod the first line in the defrule doesn't work.
#2018-05-18Â 15:16:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dominicm that seems related to the explanation I at least attempted to give above about when you can refer to â€œfield nameâ€ symbols directly in a rule
#2018-05-18Â 15:16:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara compiler cannot statically/compile time know what those symbols mean since the rule condition has a custom type that canâ€™t be introspected
#2018-05-18Â 15:17:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™d be interesting if Clara added support for you to explicitly state â€œfieldsâ€ that go with custom fact types. But nothing like that right now. Youâ€™d have to do (:e this) instead of e or use destructuring as you have in the past
#2018-05-18Â 15:20:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ When rules have records or other types of classes directly in the rule condition Clara compiler will reflect on the class to determine its available field names. When it can do that, you can refer to field names directly as their name symbol.
#2018-05-18Â 15:29:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ > Clara compiler cannot statically/compile time know what those symbols mean since the rule condition has a custom type that canâ€™t be introspected That explains it to me, that's entirely what I was missing. It obviously worked when I wrote the form this way: 
(defrule todos-done-invisible
  [?d <- D (= a :todo/title)]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->D (:e ?d) :todo/visible true)))
Which has a trade-off.

#2018-05-18Â 15:46:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™ll add that you probably donâ€™t want to write all your rules against a single type like D, so that isnâ€™t a pattern Iâ€™d advocate
#2018-05-18Â 15:46:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™d lead to a lot of thrash in the rules since every insert/retract would potentially affect every rule

I donâ€™t have a good enough understand of what your data might be looking like and the sorts of things you want to do with it.

I'm guessing this is suggesting that ?for is unbound, which is weird, but does explain what I am seeing.

#2018-05-19Â 20:48:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ 
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?dbi <- AWSDBInstance]
  [?dbox <- DatabaseBox]
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->AWSDBInstanceEngine ?dbi ?v)))
This inserts 2 AWSDBInstanceEngine rules, I think I understand why, it's due to how the dataset is being queried. Do rule engines / Does clara provide anything around stopping the insertion of facts twice here? I'm quite happy to "defend" on the LHS, rather than attempt to deduplicate on the RHS. I'm somewhat trying to avoid having to figure out conflict resolution in my final state.
#2018-05-19Â 21:17:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dominicm I havenâ€™t been able to look at anything today. I can quickly answe your last question though: Clara doesnâ€™t try to prevent duplicates. Thatâ€™s up to your logical structuring. You can often do something like an accumulate all sort of rule to â€œde dupe â€œ or aggregate your duplicate facts and choose how to merge it. So youâ€™d let some â€œintermediate typeâ€ be duplicated but have some downstream aggregate/merged type result from them and then be used in subsequent rules
#2018-05-19Â 21:18:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™d be interesting to have a mode for Clara to prevent duplicates. However there are practical use cases for actually wanting duplicates too. So the default I feel is sane. Think something about logic that cares about cardinality of matches etc. Also removing duplicates tends to be performance overhead.
#2018-05-19Â 21:21:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ @mikerod yeah, I actually want the many cardinality in some cases. I was hoping there might be a way to structure the rule such that there was no duplicates in the query.
#2018-05-19Â 21:24:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I could give good example if not on phone. Hah
#2018-05-19Â 21:24:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ 
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?dbi <- AWSDBInstance]
  [?dbox <- DatabaseBox]
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
[:not AWSDBInstanceEngine ?dbi ?v]
Maybe something like this? Sry on phone also
#2018-05-19Â 21:24:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I tend to just let the rules insert duplicates. But make it a intermediate fact type. Then have a single rule that aggregates it.
#2018-05-19Â 21:25:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are negation patterns too. Like @alex-dixon just said. You just have to watch out for making a logical infinite loop
#2018-05-19Â 21:28:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
Defrule example

Lhs Logic

=>

Insert IntermediateThing data from rule

Defrule aggregate-dups 

?all <- acc/all :from IntermediateThing (= ?id is)

=>

Insert RealThing (merge-somehow ?all)
#2018-05-19Â 21:29:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Pseudo code
#2018-05-19Â 21:36:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ Appreciate the help here. I'll take a shot at this tomorrow
#2018-05-19Â 21:38:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Nb I think my example above would loop with insert logical, not if you were to use insert unconditional
#2018-05-19Â 22:09:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ I'm worried about unconditional insert, because I don't want ordering to become a problem. The intermediate facts also feel "icky", I think because they expose a part of the LHS which isn't able to match the user's view of the world. It feels more incidental, and less domain.
#2018-05-19Â 22:41:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I like to be able to avoid unconditional inserts. But there are reasons where it canâ€™t be easily avoided currently. Those are mostly around expressing removing old facts etc. I typically donâ€™t use it though.
#2018-05-19Â 22:41:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t see intermediate facts as a bad thing. I think it is really common.
#2018-05-19Â 22:41:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Often have to express intermediate concepts to connect rules for more complex logical conditions. At least in my experience with the rules Iâ€™ve needed to write.
#2018-05-20Â 08:40:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ I seem to have identified a big misunderstanding on my part: 
(ns bugB
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]))

(defrecord DatabaseBox [id])
(defrecord AWSDBInstance [id])

(defrecord DatabaseBoxEngine [e v])
(defrecord AWSDBInstanceEngine [e v])
(defrecord RollCreatedFor [e v])

(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi) (= v ?dbox)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (println ?dbi ?dbox ?v))

(comment
  (clear-ns-productions!)
  (let [foo (->DatabaseBox "foo")
        foo-db (->AWSDBInstance "foo")
        foo-db-backup (->AWSDBInstance "foo-backup")]
    (-> (mk-session)
        (insert
          foo
          (->DatabaseBoxEngine foo :postgres)
          foo-db
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db foo)
          foo-db-backup
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db-backup foo-db)
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db-backup foo))
        (fire-rules))))
I cannot understand why this prints #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres (among the 2 other results, I expect of AWSDBInstace with a DatabaseBox). I particularly don't understand how it finds a DatabaseBoxEngine where e is an AWSDBInstance?
#2018-05-20Â 08:41:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ The total output: 
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres
#2018-05-20Â 17:32:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Looks like the only a database box engine has an e of foo record and if thatâ€™s your only rule thereâ€™s no way it should match on two different fact types when the fact type function is type

#2018-05-20Â 18:16:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ 
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?a <- RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi) (= v ?dbox)]
  [?b <- DatabaseBoxEngine (= ?dbox e) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (prn ?a ?b))

=>

; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}, :v #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo-backup"}, :v #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo-backup"}, :v #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
#2018-05-20Â 18:21:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Ok so the fact types are right I was mistaken on that
#2018-05-20Â 18:52:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ I suppose that in [?b <- DatabaseBoxEngine (= ?dbox e) (= ?v v)] The (= ?dbox e) is being ignored.
#2018-05-20Â 22:11:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ 
(= (->DatabaseBox "foo")
     (->AWSDBInstance "foo")) ;; => false
  (.equals (->DatabaseBox "foo")
           (->AWSDBInstance "foo")) ;; => true
So there is probably some confusion in some of the java collections used within clara
#2018-05-20Â 23:06:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ @dominicm the problem is here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/platform.cljc#L11 Replace the group-by-seq with 
(seq (group-by f coll))
and it works properly again
#2018-05-20Â 23:07:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ 
(platform/group-by-seq vector
                         [(->DatabaseBox "foo")
                          (->AWSDBInstance "foo")])
  ;; =>   [[[#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"} #clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}]]]

  (defn group-by-seq [f coll]
    (seq (group-by f coll)))
  (group-by-seq vector
                [(->DatabaseBox "foo")
                 (->AWSDBInstance "foo")])
  ;; => ([[#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}]] [[#clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}]])
#2018-05-21Â 05:29:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ That equality is crazy! Thanks!
#2018-05-21Â 05:39:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-867
#2018-05-21Â 05:59:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ http://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/defrecord > and will defined Java .hashCode and .equals consistent with the contract for java.util.Map. Looks like this is intentional
#2018-05-21Â 07:56:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ 
(definterface Foo
  (getB []))

(deftype C [a]
  Foo
  (getB [this] a))

(deftype B [a]
  Foo
  (getB [this] a))
Onto java beans I go!

#2018-05-21Â 11:52:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dominicm thatâ€™s interesting. I donâ€™t know how you were encountering the use of platform/group-by-seq though. It does sound to me like there could be potential edge cases around platform/group-by-seq though on the jvm-impl since it does make use of Java collections to (a) preserve consistent order (b) do the grouping and order preservation efficiently.
#2018-05-21Â 12:02:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ @mikerod if the promise is that clojure = is used, than @dominicmâ€™s example shows a bug
#2018-05-21Â 12:05:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ 
(defrecord ClauseOne [b])
(defrecord ClauseTwo [b])

(defrule rule-one
  [ClauseOne (= ?b b)]
  [ClauseTwo (= ?b b)]
 =>
  (println "Match found:" ?b )
  )

(defrecord WrapAlice [num])
(defrecord WrapBob [num])

(comment
  (clear-ns-productions!)
  (let [alice (->WrapAlice 1)
        bob (->WrapBob 1)]
    (println "(= alice bob)" (= alice bob))
    (println "(.equals alice bob)" (.equals alice bob))
    (-> (mk-session)
        (insert
         (->ClauseOne alice)
         ;; Line below is important, without it the wrong behavior does not surface
         (->ClauseTwo alice)
         (->ClauseTwo bob)
         )
        (fire-rules)
        ))
  ;;(= alice bob) false
  ;;(.equals alice bob) true
  ;; Match found: #clara_bug.core.WrapAlice{:num 1}
  ;; Match found: #clara_bug.core.WrapBob{:num 1} ;; <- should not happen
  )
#2018-05-21Â 12:47:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @thegeez I think this actually is a bug
#2018-05-21Â 12:47:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I had suspicion of it being one as soon as I saw this discussion above regarding platform/group-by-seq
#2018-05-21Â 12:49:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ platform/group-by-seq was added on the JVM-Clara to make the operation of grouping more efficient, as well as to have deterministic ordering of the seq it returns on each run to avoid variance in rule performance. The use of Java collections for this can cause subtle problems when the bindings of fact fields are record types that are Object.equals() from Java, but not clojure.core/=. This is the case with Clj record since their Java-interop form uses Java map equality instead of incorporating the type.
#2018-05-21Â 12:55:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ @mikerod this might be of use: https://github.com/ztellman/bizarro-collections to get a speedy group-by-seq with the semantics of clojure =
#2018-05-21Â 12:55:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I believe the issue is fairly isolated to the platform/group-by-seq. I think the solution would be to stop using a Java-based equality hashmap impl. A clj based one would be needed instead. It may be slightly tricky to do to keep similar performance characteristics. (itâ€™s a hot spot in the rule engine).
#2018-05-21Â 12:56:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @thegeez maybe, but we need a â€œlinked hash mapâ€
#2018-05-21Â 12:56:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the deterministic â€œorder preservationâ€ is an important characteristic
#2018-05-21Â 12:57:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I believe the bizarro only has hash map (unordered)
#2018-05-21Â 12:58:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ a java.util.LinkedHashMap is used to do the grouping by operations, then it is seqâ€™ed in platform/group-by-seq. The order the seq comes out, we want to be the same given the same input, independently from one process/machine to another (really, the Java runtime execution)
#2018-05-21Â 12:59:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If we didnâ€™t need the order preservation part, we could just use a clj transient map and likely not have a problem with performance
#2018-05-21Â 13:00:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ One solution would just be to write some sort of collection in Clara to fit this goal. That maybe the smoothest path forward.
#2018-05-21Â 13:03:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ https://github.com/amalloy/ordered supports transients.
#2018-05-21Â 13:03:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ I don't know of one of the shelve
#2018-05-21Â 13:04:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ But when does the case occur that the order is different between process? And when do these two different orderings meet?
#2018-05-21Â 13:19:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dominicm @thegeez I logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/393 - fixed link
#2018-05-21Â 13:19:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it has quite a bit of detail on this
#2018-05-21Â 13:20:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ determinism from one JVM instance to another is pretty important in some production scenarios
#2018-05-21Â 13:20:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ platform/group-by-seq is hit in a hot spot in the engine - it has a fairly large effect on performance
#2018-05-21Â 13:21:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the order of its results can play a large role in the activity that takes place within the engines evaluation of the network facts
#2018-05-21Â 13:21:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If the order changes from run to run, then the performance characteristics change too. This can make it hard to track down a bottleneck that comes up only on occasion
#2018-05-21Â 13:22:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, different orders of evaluation could potentially even lead to things like exceptions thrown in defects in written rules. However, may only sometimes these defects would manifest themselves - aka hard to reproduce problems
#2018-05-21Â 13:22:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ A while back, all known places within Claraâ€™s engine evaluation and compiler were made deterministic run-over-run to alleviate these issues
#2018-05-21Â 13:27:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ This is quickly going beyond what I know of rules systems, which is very little. I'm only surprised to see the "order changes from run to run", I would expect the ordering to be arbitrary, but the same from run to run with the same input data
#2018-05-21Â 13:44:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @thegeez the ordering guarantees are arbitrary from a user-level semantics
#2018-05-21Â 13:44:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and the outputs are produced in a deterministic way from that level
#2018-05-21Â 13:44:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m talking on more of a low-level evaluation within the engine
#2018-05-21Â 13:44:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It is basically opaque to the user-level semantics
#2018-05-21Â 13:45:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ however, it has real world implications, (a) deterministic performance characteristics (b) deterministic order things actually are evaluated (mostly useful to reproduce error cases)
#2018-05-21Â 13:46:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Things get more involved if you consider using the truth maintenance system within Clara, ie performing a typical clara.rules/insert! on a rule right-hand side (RHS).
#2018-05-21Â 13:46:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The engine works to put the system into a consistent logical state
#2018-05-21Â 13:46:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The â€œworksâ€ part, is where time is spent
#2018-05-21Â 13:47:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are different orders/paths to take to reach the same consistent logical state, depending on how rules are chosen for evaluation, how facts are propagated from node to node in the internal network etc
#2018-05-21Â 13:47:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The determinism Iâ€™m talking about is in being deterministic in those inner choices taken
#2018-05-21Â 13:55:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â thegeezÂ If "defsomething A, defsomething B, execute" should do the same as "defsomething B, defsomething A, execute" I would expect the usage of a HashMap instead of a LinkedHashMap, with its insertion-order preserving. That part is still fuzzy in my thinking
#2018-05-21Â 14:09:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @thegeez I guess Iâ€™m not able to explain it correctly
#2018-05-21Â 14:09:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yes, they can do the same thing, however, the way they accomplish it may be different depending on the order
#2018-05-21Â 14:10:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ hash map can arbitrarily change the order
#2018-05-21Â 14:10:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and it does
#2018-05-21Â 14:10:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For example, we had correct rules running in a production case before. However, about 1 in 10 times, it performed about 100x worse
#2018-05-21Â 14:10:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ that 1 in 10 time, was when the hash map ordered 2 groups in a flipped way
#2018-05-21Â 14:11:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the engine then went on to do extra work, it hit a performance bottleneck case
#2018-05-21Â 14:11:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it still was functionally correct, it just went down a â€œbad pathâ€ performance-wise
#2018-05-21Â 14:11:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ fixing the determinism allowed the case to be pinpointed and recreated in a consistent way, the bottleneck was then fixed
#2018-05-21Â 14:12:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are many places within the engine evaluation where the â€œorder things are doneâ€ can make measurable performance differences. Even if the outcome is always the same no matter the order.
#2018-05-21Â 14:13:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It is hard to explain most of these, since they are detailed things about the engine/network/fact propagation
#2018-05-21Â 14:14:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, truth maintenance can evaluate a rule, evaluated its RHS actions, like insert!, but then later, realize that that rule isnâ€™t satisfied anymore due to some other rule that evaluated. The engine can â€œretractâ€ the work done by the rule in that case.
#2018-05-21Â 14:14:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are cases (many) where itâ€™d be better to never have evaluated that rule at all, it wasted time
#2018-05-21Â 14:15:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The situation is really that the engine can at times â€œspeculativelyâ€ evaluate a rule that is later found to be invalidated by other rules. There are ways for user-level directed rule orderings, and also there are engine-level â€œheuristicsâ€ or similar that attempt to avoid premature evaluation
#2018-05-21Â 14:15:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So a rule could have a RHS that says (throw (Exception.))
#2018-05-21Â 14:16:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This rule may never be true after fire-rules, however, during the truth maintenance cycle, it could actually be evaluated
#2018-05-21Â 14:16:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So if you have non-determinism in that cycle, you may only sometimes hit the exception side-effect
#2018-05-21Â 14:17:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It doesnâ€™t (and likely wouldnâ€™t) be something trivial like that. It could be something less obvious like (insert! (call-my-fn-that-has-a-defect-for-some-args ?x))
#2018-05-21Â 14:17:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If that rule sometimes evaluated, but needs to retract later by the truth maintenance, and this only happens 1 in 10 times, you may have a 1 in 10 times sort of scenario you are trying to recreate to debug your defect in your rules
#2018-05-21Â 14:18:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This will manifest itself in cases like, our tests fail arbitrarily at times when run on our build servers, but when we rerun the build/retest the error is gone
#2018-05-21Â 14:19:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The determinism of ordering used within these areas of Clara help both of these scenarios, the performance situations, and the finding failures scenarios situation

	(with-tracing)
	(insert ...)
	(fire-rules))

#2018-05-23Â 19:24:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ defquery more or less sets up an endpoint in your rules network, it needs to be known before hand
#2018-05-23Â 19:25:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ query goes and grabs the list it generates at when things are fired, it doesnt go calculate it then (to my knowlege)
#2018-05-23Â 19:37:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ you can, and i would not reccomend this outside of development, create a defquery for Object that just grabs everything in the session and then filter that as you see fit.
#2018-05-23Â 20:35:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.tenny Iâ€™ve only partially read your example so far, but one immediate piece of feedback, donâ€™t query until after fire-rules
#2018-05-23Â 20:35:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ think of query the same as with-tracing earlier, you have to only do it on â€œconsistentâ€ states of a session
#2018-05-23Â 20:36:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara does some delayed evaluation for performance reasons. Any inserts/retracts that occur prior to a fire-rule cannot be relied upon and Iâ€™d consider the session to be in an â€œundefinedâ€ state
#2018-05-23Â 20:37:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™d actually prefer Clara to change for query to either (a) throw exception if called prior to a fire-rules or return something that indicates it is not ready yet.
#2018-05-23Â 20:38:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara takes advantaged of batched insertion and also potentially a few other things, so it does not eagerly perform things like insert or retract. The evaluation is typically pushed to batch up the facts propagating through the network. This can play a major role in performance.
#2018-05-23Â 20:39:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You mentioned OPS5, which you likely wouldnâ€™t have seen behavior like this long ago. It is more common now. Drools is a popular JVM-based rules engine and it similarly has delayed evaluation of things prior to rule firing due to similar concerns.
#2018-05-23Â 20:40:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This issue seems to somewhat often trip people up though. So I donâ€™t think it is clear enough.
#2018-05-23Â 20:41:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For your second question > ;why are my counters still there, I retracted them? I think it is because (query % counters) doesnâ€™t return what you are thinking it does
#2018-05-23Â 20:41:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It doesnâ€™t return the bare counter fact, instead it returns a bindings map from the query, so it returns something like: 
{:?counter <the counter fact>}
#2018-05-23Â 20:42:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so youâ€™d probably have to do something like 
(#(apply retract % (map :?counter (query % counters))))
#2018-05-23Â 20:42:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ Oh sorry, forgot to include the output

#2018-05-30Â 17:11:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @jdt The Clara count accumulator should fire with an initial value of 0. Do you have an example where it does not? Also keep in mind that you can create your own accumulators with arbitrary domain-specific logic. So say "choose the top two at most" could be done. My instinct here is that it sounds like the problems you describe might be addressable with accumulators without any insert-unconditional logic, although as always hard to say without knowing the problem space. It sounds like @mikerod was suggesting that as well.
#2018-05-30Â 17:13:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ See the writing accumulators section at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/
#2018-05-30Â 17:14:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Also regarding the cost of joins, that varies depending on the type of join, I'd suggest reading http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/hash_joins/ if you're working with millions of facts
#2018-05-30Â 17:59:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ I thought the behavior I observed with the acc/count condition not firing seemed consistent with the documented behavior on this page: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/, however I suspect I read it wrong and they were talking about other accumulators not firing when there weren't facts matching the condition, instead of acc/count. #2018-05-30Â 18:38:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.tenny if an accumulator has a â€œtruthyâ€ :initial-value, itâ€™s condition in a rule will be considered satisfied even if no facts exists to match the accumulators fact match criteria
#2018-05-30Â 18:39:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ default :initial-value is nil, so the default would not be true, however acc/count initializes to 0, so a condition that uses it will be satisfied when no facts match the condition.
#2018-05-30Â 18:40:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ e.g. [?count <- (acc/count) :from [NoMatchEver]] would bind ?count to 0 and the condition would be satisfied.

#2018-05-31Â 13:06:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @dave.tenny perhaps your example created new bindings, in that case Claraâ€™s accumulators wonâ€™t fire without facts even given an initial value. i.e. for [?result <- (acc/all) :from [Fact (= ?a a)]] if ?a isnâ€™t created elsewhere you need facts to give ?a a meaning so the accumulator wonâ€™t fire without them. This is in the accumulator docs pages I posted before IIRC, I think there are some examples in the clara-examples project too
#2018-05-31Â 13:09:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @wparker I forgot that that was ever changed. I thought they still fire always even without a binding

#2018-06-01Â 16:17:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the rules donâ€™t assume what a â€œduplicateâ€ means to you or what you want to do with them. You need an extra rule to configure that yourself.
#2018-06-01Â 16:17:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Example, Maybe you wanted to know how many duplicates you had
#2018-06-01Â 16:17:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you could then have (defrecord Derived [ftype matches-count])
#2018-06-01Â 16:18:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Then 
(defrule merge-derived
  [?all <- (acc/all) :from [::derived-intermediate (= ?ftype (-> this :derived :ftype))]]
  =>
;; Merging to one, but include the count of the "duplicates" for whatever reason
  (insert! (-> ?all first :derived (assoc :matches-count (count ?all))))
#2018-06-01Â 16:18:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ ok, digesting this, back to drawing board

[WorkerViableJob

#2018-06-01Â 22:05:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Clojure in general I find it helps to just give up on making lines short
#2018-06-01Â 22:08:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Most rules Iâ€™ve written have positional syntax so everything on one line works wellâ€¦joins typically line up nicely. In Clara Iâ€™d probably do the same for the same reasonâ€¦try to group things vertically by joins
#2018-06-02Â 14:05:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @mikerod Regarding datalog syntax for Clara: Would you want it to be schema based? The implementation I have only enforces a datomic schemaâ€™s cardinality and uniqueness â€¦ nothing related to types. It enables upsert behavior, which may or may not be desirable for Clara users. Cardinality and uniqueness indices are checked and updated before inserting or retracting facts (within the insert/retract functions), and if anything should be upserted then the appropriate retracts and inserts are made. Only one to one facts are indexed at this time, since thereâ€™s no uniqueness or cardinality enforcement that applies to one to many. Overall I tried to follow Datomicâ€™s semantics on this: https://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/schema.html#operational-schema-attributes, https://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/schema.html#required-schema-attributes. If a fact is not mentioned in a schema it defaults to one to one cardinality. I think that could be changed easily if you wantedâ€¦the idea there was facts are typically one to one for UI and we didnâ€™t want to force users type out cardinality for every fact.
#2018-06-02Â 14:13:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ This would affect the implementation at the session-ish level. None of this has to be part of a LocalSession and I donâ€™t think it should be, but Iâ€™m toying with a LocalDatalogSession that takes a LocalSession and â€œindexesâ€ argument so the indexes can travel with a session. It should be possible to use with insert/retract per the normal api (`(-> session (insert facts) (fire-rules))`) though the insert/retract functions would need be datalog specific (`(clara.rules.datalog/insert)`) if enforcing a schema the way I described
#2018-06-04Â 13:10:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @alex-dixon thatâ€™s interesting. When Iâ€™ve mentioned support for the datalog syntax before, I was only thinking of it at a syntactic level - like an alternative DSL. The one thing I wasnâ€™t sure of in that was how the fact-type-fn would work (what would it be?). It sounds like youâ€™re considering an approach that is a bit more integrated with the semantics of these structures. That may be a reasonable thing to do. I havenâ€™t worked with this sort of thing enough to have any big insight. What you describe above seems like something that may be useful and reasonable to me.
#2018-06-04Â 14:45:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @mikerod > The one thing I wasnâ€™t sure of in that was how the fact-type-fn would work (what would it be?) Precept uses :a with a Tuple record [e a v t] (t is an incremented fact id). We use the clojureâ€™s (derive) to associate cardinality and uniqueness with :a keywords. Clara receives the hierarchy via the :ancestors-fn option in order to be able to match on :all attributes. Every :a descends from :all so you can write conditions that will obtain across attributes (e.g. [?e :all 42]). The ancestry is also used outside Clara for maintaining e-a-v and a-v-e indexes. When facts are inserted or retracted it lets us determine their cardinality and uniqueness constraints. Based on that and the current indexes we determine whether inserts and retracts should be performed so that the schema can be adhered to, or whether an error should be thrown. Over the weekend I worked on a design that doesnâ€™t use global vars for the indexes and ancestors hierarchy. I havenâ€™t figured it out yet. insert! seems like the real challenge. Itâ€™s not part of the ISession protocol and only takes facts as arguments. My best guess is that we should bind a sessionâ€™s indexes and ancestry to a dynamic var (like session-context) when fire rules is called on it. Then we could read from it from within an insert! implementation and update the indexes there. I think thatâ€™d require something like a LocalDatalogSession that could take these extra arguments in its constructor.
#2018-06-04Â 15:11:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @alex-dixon this makes sense to me.
#2018-06-04Â 15:11:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I was thinking that the :a may be the best fact type too, wasnâ€™t sure. And good point on deriving from :all

#2018-06-05Â 13:10:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.tenny should be possible to use Clara tracing to take a look at something like that. Although itâ€™s exploratory to find what you want given the data structures it returns. You could get something like count of times things were evaluated that way.
#2018-06-05Â 13:10:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™d be nice if Clara had more supporting functions for this purpose though.
#2018-06-05Â 13:13:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ There are some minimum number of queries in addition to the above rules.
#2018-06-05Â 13:16:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ Between each fire-rules the dispatcher will select one job per job type (so 15 in this numbers case), dispatch it, update the ActiveUserJobCount, WorkerResource, facts, and retract the dispatched JobRequest facts.
#2018-06-05Â 13:17:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ So I'm averaging about 1-3 seconds per job dispatch, and whacking the hell out of my CPU. (Memory footprint is good however... surprise!)
#2018-06-05Â 13:23:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ I had originally hoped to do the fact maintenance for active user job counts (used for round robin eligibility consideration), and worker resource stats (to track remaining worker capacity), in the RHS of rules. But I gave that up early in the process because it was a side-effect oriented process with a bunch of [:not A] => A scenarios, which might have been doable, but it was really the timing of the rule LHS evaluations that killed it, since LHS evaluations are perceptually "in parallel" and not sequential with respect to cause and effect for a given rule.
#2018-06-05Â 13:24:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ So I compute some eligible things, then do the dispatching and accounting between calls to fire-rules, then do it all over again (always saving and continuing from the updated session).
#2018-06-05Â 13:44:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > but it was really the timing of the rule LHS evaluations that killed it, since LHS evaluations are perceptually â€œin parallelâ€ and not sequential with respect to cause and effect for a given rule. Only the case for insert-unconditional! (and possibly even a defect), but yeah. if you have to extract these facts after they are â€œdoneâ€ it may make most sense to be an external thing anyways.

#2018-06-05Â 13:47:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ well, time will obviously go to the instrumentation/tracing you do

#2018-06-05Â 13:54:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
[:not [JobRequest (< job-id ?job-id) 
                    (= ?job-type job-type)
                    (= ?user-id user-id)
                    (<= threads ?threads)
                    (<= memory ?memory)]]
#2018-06-05Â 13:54:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ The memory and thread tests are to test only for jobs that can actually execute on the worker resources, i.e. for which enough resources exist.

#2018-06-05Â 14:11:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > Any advice for a beginner on how to effectively use the tracing API here? The one time I tried it there was too much data to process, and that was on the simplest most minimal amount of facts. I havenâ€™t used it as much as Iâ€™d expect. I was used to rolling my own stuff prior to when tracing stuff was introduced. However, for counting, I believe you can do something like: 
(let [traced (-> (clara.rules/mk-session <your rules>)
                 (clara.tools.tracing/with-tracing)
                 (insert <your facts>)
                 fire-rules
                 clara.tools.tracing/get-trace)]
  (frequencies (map :node-id traced)))
#2018-06-05Â 14:12:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ or perhaps better sorted: 
(let [tr (-> (clara.rules/mk-session [temp-rule])
                                       (t/with-tracing)
                                       (insert (->Temperature 10 "MCI")
                                               (->Temperature 20 "MCI"))
                                       (fire-rules)
                                       (t/get-trace )
                                       )]
                            (->>  (map :node-id tr)
                                  frequencies
                                  (sort-by val)
                                  reverse))
#2018-06-05Â 14:13:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ once you know the highest count :node-ids you can look those up in the rulebase associated with the session
#2018-06-05Â 14:13:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jdtÂ excellent, thanks
#2018-06-05Â 14:16:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(let [session (-> (clara.rules/mk-session <your rules>)
                  (t/with-tracing)
                  (insert <your facts>)
                  (fire-rules))

      trace (t/get-trace session)
      node-id <whatever node id in question from `trace`>


      {:keys [rulebase]} (clara.rules.engine/components session)
      {:keys [id-to-node]} rulebase]
  (get id-to-node node-id) )
This is how you could look up the node-id to try to find what node in the engine it is
#2018-06-05Â 14:16:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ a node will be a defrecord of stuff, not all that readable to you, but you should be able to recognize aspects of it and align it back to your rules typically

#2018-06-15Â 02:25:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hiredmanÂ I've just started exploring with Clara, and don't have a ton of experience with rules systems, and I've run into a surprise. When I have a rule something like [Foo (= x 1)] (not [Foo (= x 2)]) => (insert! (->Foo 2)) it goes in to an infinite loop
#2018-06-15Â 03:21:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @hiredman insert! Is a conditional insert. These inserts are monitored by a â€œtruth maintenance systemâ€ (aka TMS). The goal of the TMS is to keep all of the rules and their consequences in a logically consistent state
#2018-06-15Â 03:21:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So the rule you put above is a logical contradiction.
#2018-06-15Â 03:21:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are workarounds. Depending on what it is you are trying to achieve.
#2018-06-15Â 03:23:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also the TMS is useful to be able to express large numbers of rules in a declarative/non order dependent way. You donâ€™t have to worry about â€œwhen something was insertedâ€ to be careful to not check for it â€œbefore it was insertedâ€ and that sort of thing. It leads to a less brittle system.
#2018-06-15Â 03:23:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The concept of a TMS has been around in many of the more modern rule systems.
#2018-06-15Â 18:15:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hiredmanÂ @mikerod thanks, makes sense, I hadn't connected those dots
#2018-06-15Â 18:24:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @hiredman I will say that the engine going into an infinite loop without trying to help isnâ€™t really user-friendly. The action a rule does on the right-hand side (aka RHS) of the => is arbitrary from the rules engine perspective, so it cannot â€œknow it is in an infinite loopâ€. However, something could reasonably be added to allow a configurable upper limit on the times youâ€™d allow what may â€œlook like a loopâ€ to be allowed until the engine halted and reported a possible error. For now though, it could be documented as a FAQ or something as well.
#2018-06-15Â 18:24:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ eg â€œIf the engine seems to be in an infinite loop, this is commonly the causeâ€¦â€
#2018-06-15Â 18:29:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are cases that you may think it is hard to see how to not need a rule like you have above. Some of those can actually be tricky to express, but in many cases that Iâ€™ve seen, accumulators can be used to achieve the semantics desired, or a new fact type that is used for the derived fact that is different from what is deriving it eg instead of 
[:not [Foo (= x 2)]] => (insert! (->Foo 2))
Something like 
[:not [Foo (= x 2)]] => (insert! (->DerivedFoo 2))

#2018-06-25Â 18:32:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ although it doesnâ€™t provide an ideal solution
#2018-06-25Â 18:33:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can use things like insert-unconditional! and also :no-loop properties on a defrule to attempt to do things like you are describing. However, I try to avoid those since they become more imperative/order-dependent etc in nature. Also, they can have interactions at odds with the rest of the truth maintenance system.
#2018-06-25Â 18:33:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In the post linked above, I mention â€œApproach 1: Append only updatesâ€

#2018-06-25Â 19:03:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â tony.kayÂ I agree it would be nice to reason about things in isolation
#2018-06-25Â 19:04:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule udpate-it
  [?old-one <- A (= ?e e) (= ?a a)]
  [?new-one <- NewA (= ?e e) (= ?a a)]
  =>
  (retract! ?old-one)
  (insert-unconditional! (map->A ?new-one)))
#2018-06-25Â 19:05:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™d worry a bit about pervasive use of unconditional inserts
#2018-06-25Â 19:05:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it misses out on one fairly large advantage of the rules engine - which is a declarative logical truth maintenance system.

#2018-06-26Â 13:45:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @baptiste-from-paris there is some support for this. Itâ€™s referred to as durability in the Clara codebase. You do have to implement a protocol though to serialize the working memory facts that are specific to your domain of use
#2018-06-26Â 13:46:43Â Â Â Â Â baptiste-from-parisÂ nice ðŸ™‚
#2018-06-26Â 13:46:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, the durability is currently targeted at being fast for serialization, but especially for deserialization. It doesnâ€™t attempt to be able to deal with evolution to the stored data structures. If you have a change of rules, or a change of Clara version, sometime you may have to rerun rules and re-serialize.
#2018-06-26Â 13:47:14Â Â Â Â Â baptiste-from-parisÂ ok, got it
#2018-06-26Â 13:47:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Well to clarify, any change in rules requires a new run. A change in Clara version may or may not. It just depends on what changes.

#2018-06-26Â 15:22:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ How might I accumulate facts of the same type to test if they are: all contain the same value and any contain a certain value?
#2018-06-26Â 15:34:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @jeremy642 Sounds like 2 separate things, if so
#2018-06-26Â 15:34:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
;; ?all contain the same value for :val
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?val val)]]


;; ?all has at least one containing :some-val for :val
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A]]
[:test (some #(= :some-val (:val %))
             ?all)]
#2018-06-26Â 15:34:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ Yes ðŸ˜›
#2018-06-26Â 15:34:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, the 2nd accumulator is weird, not sure why you want to accumulate like that
#2018-06-26Â 15:34:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but perhaps
#2018-06-26Â 15:35:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ â€œany contain a certain valueâ€ sounds like a typical rule match
#2018-06-26Â 15:35:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ [?all <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?val val)]] and this will group each A where they have the same value for val
#2018-06-26Â 15:35:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ Yes it is.
#2018-06-26Â 15:36:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™ll match and propagate for each grouping possible
#2018-06-26Â 15:36:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ Yeah, I think any would be a typical rule match.

#2018-07-16Â 02:03:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ Stupid question time: Is it possible to use Rete with disk storage only for working sets that canâ€™t fit into memory? Would there be any advantage to using it as part of a database implementation?
#2018-07-16Â 08:34:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @alex-dixon There isn't any reason in principle why you can't use disk storage in a Clara memory implementation. It would obviously be less performant than in memory storage; if every Rete operation resulted in a random disk seek it could be pretty poor at a guess. I've toyed with the idea of a memory implementation dumping overflow to disk before though with some kind of heuristics for what to keep in memory. There could be complications to work through if you're trying to basically serialize random objects too.
#2018-07-16Â 18:17:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ > Iâ€™ve toyed with the idea of a memory implementation dumping overflow to disk before though with some kind of heuristics for what to keep in memory Heh, I was thinking about the same thing yesterday ðŸ™‚ I havenâ€™t been able to find any papers or mention of Rete being used with a persistence layer. Do you know of any?
#2018-07-16Â 19:09:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @alex-dixon No, I donâ€™t know of any offhand. My (completely untested ðŸ™‚ ) guess would be that avoiding internal retractions from truth maintenance would be a big part of it. Maybe if the data were appropriately structured you could use a local database to back the memory - is that what you were getting at with â€œWould there be any advantage to using it as part of a database implementation?â€
#2018-07-16Â 20:40:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hiredmanÂ there is presentation from, uh, maybe it was at a clojurewest, the presenter discusses implementing a rules system on top of a database, it does away with, maybe just alpha nodes, in rete because it expects database indices to do basically the same thing
#2018-07-16Â 20:42:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hiredmanÂ https://github.com/threatgrid/naga
#2018-07-18Â 17:15:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â alex-dixonÂ @hiredman thanks! The readme says in memory only but plans for persistence with an rdf triple store or graph database. Iâ€™ll look into it more

#2018-08-08Â 21:28:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ennÂ I have a Clara rulebase that, for comprehensibility reasons, Iâ€™d like to split into â€œphases.â€ So, phase 1 gets a bunch of facts, the rules fire, and new facts are generated. Somehow, this becomes the input to phase 2, which fires a new set of rules, generating new facts. Etc. Iâ€™m not sure what the best way is to pass the output of one phase into the next. Originally I was thinking Iâ€™d just take the session from phase 1 and use that as the starting point for phase 2. But unless Iâ€™m missing something, itâ€™s not possible to load new rules into an extant session. So I guess what I need to do is to just grab all the â€œoutputâ€ facts out of phase 1 and insert them into a new session for phase 2. Is there a simpler way to do this than by writing (and then executing) a query for each and every fact type?
#2018-08-08Â 21:30:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @enn > So I guess what I need to do is to just grab all the â€œoutputâ€ facts out of phase 1 and insert them into a new session for phase 2. I think this is likely a smoother approach (there is an alternative I can mention in a min) As far as worrying about querying for too many types, maybe you can make a â€œparentâ€ type for the output types you care about and just have a query on that parent type.

#2018-08-08Â 21:45:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule find-java-things
  [JavaThing (= x ?x)]
  =>
  (insert! {:fact-type :thing
            :x ?x}))
#2018-08-08Â 21:45:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but if you need the JavaThing in the end, for the query consumer

#2018-08-08Â 21:45:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ I was thinking about keeping the rules in a seperate jar. #2018-08-08Â 21:45:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
(defrule find-java-things
  [?j <- JavaThing (= x ?x)]
  =>
  (insert! (with-meta {:fact-type :thing
                       :x ?x}
             {:source ?j})))
#2018-08-08Â 21:46:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If itâ€™s a classpath issue, where you wonâ€™t know the types ahead of time youâ€™ll have to be more tricky

#2018-08-09Â 16:47:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @jeremy642 @mikerod this might be useful in combination with Mikeâ€™s suggestion of using Java objects as facts that you could translate into Clojure objects if desired: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/java/ Basically Clara has a wrapper that you can use instead of needing to do the interop glue work yourself. In case you werenâ€™t already aware.
#2018-08-09Â 16:49:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Also FYI Clara will use the bean properties on Java objects to allow field use by name in the DSL, that isnâ€™t just for records

#2018-08-09Â 16:51:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ 
(defrule new-return
  "The service is a new return."
  [:approval-status (= (:value this) :new-return)]
  =>
  (insert! {:type :rule/result
            :id :new-return
            :priority 2}))
#2018-08-09Â 16:52:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ 
(r/insert {:type :approval-status :value :new-return})
is how I would insert using clojure.
#2018-08-09Â 16:53:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ Without changing the rules to beans or defining the facts with defrecords. The big ?? was how to allow Java to create maps with the keyword format that matched the rules properly.

#2018-08-09Â 17:02:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Note that Clojure maps also implement Javaâ€™s map, so youâ€™d need to guard against an infinite loop there (i.e. require that it a Java Map but not a Clojure map)
#2018-08-09Â 17:14:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ Thanks
#2018-08-09Â 17:15:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jeremyÂ I noticed that clara-rules is on the tech radar by thoughtworks. https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/languages-and-frameworks
#2018-08-09Â 22:57:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Saw this one back when it was new on there. Pretty cool though!
#2018-08-10Â 06:30:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â henrikÂ Iâ€™m working on an ingestion pipeline for scholarly material. It takes XML files and adds them to a (Datomic) database. Thereâ€™s a ton of little decisions to be made along the way. Depending on the publisher, the type of material, the presence of related material already in the database, the subject matter, the presence or absence of a myriad of little attributes in the file itself, and so on, the ingestion process behaves differently. This means tons and tons of conditionals all over the place, and it quickly gets hard to get an overview. Iâ€™ve been contemplating ways to extract this decision making process into its own place. Would Clara be a suitable tool for this?
#2018-08-10Â 10:21:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @U06B8J0AJ that sounds like a plausible use-case. Much depends on how much involved the logic is - IMO a rules engine has some upfront cost to bring in especially if the team hasnâ€™t used one before, but at a certain complexity of business logic it helps a lot. Clara does what it can to help by â€œplaying nicelyâ€ with the rest of the Clojure ecosystem e.g. by being simple Clojure code rather than an entirely separate framework with its own IDEs etc., but it still is a different way of thinking and is a nontrivial component to introduce to a system. FWIW the analysis in the ThoughtWorks radar linked above seems on-target to me. My guess would be that something like you describe would work best with a rules engine if large chunks of logic can be computed before needing to return to the stateful pipeline, but as always it is hard to say since so often it is the details that are most important.
#2018-08-10Â 17:50:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ howdy folks

{:type :foo
 :desc "'Foo' node"
 :parent :D}

{:type :D
 :desc "'D' node"
 :parent :C}

{:type :C
 :desc "'C' node"
 :parent :B}

{:type :B
 :desc "'B' node"
 :parent :A}

{:type :A
 :desc "'A' node"}
#2018-10-23Â 14:09:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dhruv1Â here is what i would like the output of the query to look like:

'(:?node {:type :foo
          :desc "'Foo' node"
          :parent :D}
         
       :?parents [{:type :D
                      :desc "'D' node"
                     :parent :C}

                    {:type :C
                     :desc "'C' node"
                     :parent :B}

                    {:type :B
                     :desc "'B' node"
                     :parent :A}

                    {:type :A
                     :desc "'A' node"}])
#2018-10-23Â 14:11:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dhruv1Â is this possible with a clara query?
#2018-10-23Â 15:47:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Not with just a query, you'll need to introduce some facts.
#2018-10-23Â 15:51:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ So you'd have one rule that's (heavily abbreviating the code): [:test (no-children? ?node)] => (insert! (->TreeRep ?node ?node))). And one that's [:test (children? ?node)] ?children <- (acc/all) :from [Node (= parent ?node)] => (insert! (->TreeRep ?node (add-children ?node ?children))).
#2018-10-23Â 15:52:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Assuming your graph is acyclic. If it isn't, this will be bad.
#2018-10-23Â 15:53:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ It might be doable with one rule, actually. But the point is, AFAICT, there's no way to recurse without inserting facts.
#2018-10-23Â 16:01:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dhruv1Â Ah understood.
#2018-10-23Â 16:02:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dhruv1Â Will give that a go. Thank you!
#2018-10-23Â 16:12:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Oh, you want to (acc/all) :from [TreeRep ...], probably.
#2018-10-23Â 16:13:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ You could also do this with a custom accumulator, but that would be much harder, I'm guessing.

#2018-10-24Â 14:03:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It is comparing to the traditional rete used in the OPS5 and perhaps a few others at the time
#2018-10-24Â 14:03:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ things were quite a bit different in those I believe
#2018-10-24Â 14:03:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara takes advantage of batch-oriented fact propagation
#2018-10-24Â 14:03:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I am of the opinion that that is the biggest perf win
#2018-10-24Â 14:04:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ over any sort of laziness. However, Drools (popular JVM/Java based rules engine) went to a custom algo they decided was sufficiently different enough to get a new name
#2018-10-24Â 14:04:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ â€œPHREAKâ€
#2018-10-24Â 14:04:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ in Drools 6, they wrote some good stuff on it
#2018-10-24Â 14:04:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but it was meant to be lazier and to do things like cut parts of the rete tree off when they arenâ€™t needed
#2018-10-24Â 14:05:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the unfortunate part of that upgrade was that Drools went from eager and single fact propagation to this lazier and batched propagation
#2018-10-24Â 14:05:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and I think the batching is the bigger win
#2018-10-24Â 14:05:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So the topic of being lazier in Clara has came up before
#2018-10-24Â 14:06:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but hasnâ€™t been done since it isnâ€™t clear how much you really gain from that over the batched propagations.
#2018-10-24Â 14:06:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ that is assuming you have queries that you intend to use
#2018-10-24Â 14:06:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you had like 10 queries and were only going to want to perform 1 of them a lot of the time or something like that, then there may be a bigger win to delaying things
#2018-10-24Â 14:06:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I'm only a little way in, and I haven't seen the laziness part yet (even though it's claimed in the abstract). It so far has claimed that the biggest win is not needing to materialize facts in memory. I don't understand it yet.
#2018-10-24Â 14:07:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ also, keep in mind, these older papers
#2018-10-24Â 14:07:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ they have some good material for sure, but have to be aware of the environments there were dealing with
#2018-10-24Â 14:07:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ e.g. sometimes they are really emphasizing using minimal memory (was more constrained then), or higher allocation costs etc
#2018-10-24Â 14:08:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s just something to be aware of, still good material out there and most of it is pretty old
#2018-10-24Â 14:08:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ also, sometimes things are explaining a situation that is most helpful when dealing with a large number of rules, other times its for dealing with a large number of facts, and occasionally perhaps a large number of both is discussed
#2018-10-24Â 14:09:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ yup. But I read things like this as a hobby, honestly.
#2018-10-24Â 14:09:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I'm not suddenly suggesting that we must implement this ðŸ˜„
#2018-10-24Â 14:09:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ no, itâ€™s good to discuss and to think about
#2018-10-24Â 14:09:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ In fact, it would be neat if there was a bibliography for Clara Rules.
#2018-10-24Â 14:10:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ quite a bit of perf-related work has been done in Clara already
#2018-10-24Â 14:10:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ some of that was just impl details and other things were tweaks to propagation or often accumulators
#2018-10-24Â 14:11:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Neat... I got that impression. It performs super well for us.
#2018-10-25Â 16:55:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @eraserhd Agreed with @U0LK1552Aâ€™s previous comments - Another interesting way that this played out (both myself and Mike spent a while doing perf optimizations on Clara) is that in practice, it turned out that even for large cases (hundreds of thousands of facts/tens of thousands of rules) the constant factors seemed to be most important. Hashing turned out to be a large percentage of work performed for example. A lot of these optimizations (on the Clojure side) are in the memory.cljc namespace with lots of Java interop etc. That said, this was in use-cases where we didnâ€™t really have lots of data that we were just going to end up discarding, and thereâ€™s definitely cases where more laziness could be useful.
#2018-10-24Â 14:12:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara make some small mention to background here https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Introduction#the-rules-engine
#2018-10-24Â 14:12:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The paper referenced there is http://reports-archive.adm.cs.cmu.edu/anon/1995/CMU-CS-95-113.pdf
#2018-10-24Â 14:12:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It is concerned with the ops system I think. Itâ€™s long and not all that relevant to current stuff, but there are some nice fundamental chapters in it
#2018-10-24Â 14:13:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Starts with a very basic description of a simple rete impl, and then discusses some interesting ways to improve it, such as left and right unlinking
#2018-10-24Â 14:14:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and Drools has a lot of extra stuff going on that is left out of Clara, but they do have some good docs on approaches https://docs.jboss.org/drools/release/6.2.0.CR2/drools-docs/html/HybridReasoningChapter.html#ReteOO
#2018-10-24Â 14:16:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thatâ€™s their newer one. Not the same as Clara, but there are some commonalities in some the ideas. It also may explain some of the deficiencies in the overly simple approach traditionally taken.

#2018-10-24Â 14:38:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ sure, sorry it isnâ€™t super organized - reference dump
#2018-10-24Â 22:15:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ I'm trying out Clara, but I'm hitting an issue, perhaps I'm using it wrong, here's the simplest snippet that shows my issue: 
(defrecord Request [resource])

(defn condition
  [x y]
  (= x y))

(defrule some-rule
  [Request (condition ?resource resource)]
  =>
  (println ?resource))

(mk-session)
I'm getting an error about ?resource not being bound, however if I replace condition with = this works. I didn't see anything in the Boolean Expressions documentation about not being able to use other functions, however if that's the case, how does one go about doing this?
#2018-10-24Â 22:21:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ 
[Request (= ?resource resource)]
[:test (condition? ?resource)]
=>
(prn ?resource)
#2018-10-25Â 13:25:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ Probably not relevant and more of an FYI, but if the condition? is simply equality it could be done with a third argument to =. 
(r/defrule some-rule
  [Request (= ?resource resource "GET")]
  =>
  (println ?resource))
#2018-10-25Â 13:42:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ 
[Request (= resource "GET")]
=>
(prn "GET")
Onde it will only match if resource is GET ðŸ˜…
#2018-10-25Â 13:43:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ you can also do 
[?request <- Request (= resource "GET")]
=>
(prn ?request)
Will print the "full record"
#2018-10-25Â 13:59:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ Thanks @U3KC48GHW ! This is actually something that I did need (for a different rule)

#2018-10-24Â 22:39:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ (= ?resource resource) it not a function call. it just a DSL to bind the value of resource (form record) to ?resorce (symbol)
#2018-10-24Â 22:47:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ Ah gotcha, thank you! This points me in the right direction, I'll continue to play with Clara ðŸ˜ƒ

#2018-10-25Â 13:57:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ As a newcomer itâ€™s not super clear which functions are built-in. This is definitely an advanced user library :)
#2018-10-25Â 14:22:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I'm believe that the only functions that Clara handles specially are the equality expressions: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L213-L223
#2018-10-25Â 14:36:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah, = is the only special thing
#2018-10-25Â 14:37:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It still means = too, but it can also be used for unification purposes/binding variables
#2018-10-25Â 14:37:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ nothing is special about contains? (or anything else)
#2018-10-25Â 14:54:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Agreed with other comments that it is just = that is special when used as a top-level value in the constraint to create/join on bindings (starting with ?)
#2018-10-25Â 14:54:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ that has perf benefits in that those joins are done by hashing
#2018-10-25Â 14:55:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ otherwise you can use arbitrary functions and they should behave the same as elsewhere
#2018-10-25Â 14:55:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ While reading the docs, it goes from straightforward to advanced very quickly. In http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/, I fully understand the free-lunch-with-gizmo because there's no ? binding, you're matching that an item is :gizmo, but then in the sophisticated example: 
(defrule grant-discount-months  
  [Purchase (= ?month (get-month date))]
  [DiscountMonth (= ?month month)]
  =>
  (insert! (->GrantDiscount :for-month ?month)))
The = doesn't have the same meaning (in the Purchase condition) as the straightforward example, but it does in the DiscountMonth condition?
#2018-10-25Â 14:57:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ it has the same meaning in that it requires equality, but clojure.core/= wonâ€™t be called
#2018-10-25Â 14:57:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Not quite.
#2018-10-25Â 14:58:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ = is unification. So, it requires the expression to be true. If there are variables in it that do not yet have a value, the variables are "assigned" such to make it true. If the variables are already assigned, it works like clojure.core/=
#2018-10-25Â 14:58:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thatâ€™s a reasonable way to think about it
#2018-10-25Â 14:58:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but Clara may optimize on it
#2018-10-25Â 14:58:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ when unifying on a ? binding
#2018-10-25Â 14:58:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it uses it to build the rete graph
#2018-10-25Â 14:59:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ > = is unification This distinction is makes sense!
#2018-10-25Â 14:59:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ makes a hash-based match for nodes known to be doing = based bindings
#2018-10-25Â 14:59:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but = is also just = when equating to constant values etc
#2018-10-25Â 14:59:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ If there are many possible values for a variable, it can assign each value consecutively.
#2018-10-25Â 14:59:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can do [Purchase (= ?month month "JAN")] for example
#2018-10-25Â 14:59:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ (*and what @mikerod is saying is true, I'm only describing the semantics, it doesn't actually work like that.)
#2018-10-25Â 15:00:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ yeah, semantics are most important
#2018-10-25Â 15:00:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ just making sure someone may not get carried away and try to print within clojure.core/= or something and wonder why it isnâ€™t always called hah
#2018-10-25Â 15:00:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ unlikely
#2018-10-25Â 15:01:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ [Purchase (= ?month month "JAN")] binds the value of the field month to ?month, when (= month "JAN") (via clojure.core/=)
#2018-10-25Â 15:01:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Of course in this case, ?month would just be â€œJANâ€

#2018-10-25Â 15:04:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ Woah secret docs
#2018-10-25Â 15:06:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ â€œ`=` is unificationâ€ => correct. Note that this is for top-level constraints though, when nested inside a constraint that isnâ€™t the case i.e. [A (= ?b c)] vs [A (stuff (= ?b c))]
#2018-10-25Â 15:06:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Hah not secret, just nested inside the â€œperformance optimizationâ€ page

(defquery get-by-last-name

#2018-10-25Â 22:19:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jvtriguerosÂ I'm only able to create defquerys that have ?:

#2018-10-26Â 15:52:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @jvtrigueros that is correct, the parameter of the query should be :?last-name, and would work similar to a filter on the ?last-name binding in the lhs of the query. Where did you find that example, it should probably be updated?
#2018-10-26Â 16:02:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ nvm, i found it: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L51

#2018-10-26Â 18:03:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yep @zylox has a good point on the issues around the complexities.
#2018-10-26Â 18:05:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In general negated conjunctions and rete have complexities due to the structure of the network
#2018-10-26Â 18:07:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Most of the times if things get weird in a rule doing this stuff I think you can typically just break the logic up across more rules to keep the structures simpler
#2018-10-26Â 18:52:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ How cheap are intermediate facts? I mean, clojure records themselves are cheap, but is memory used by facts interesting? They are alpha-pruned, I assume.
#2018-10-26Â 18:53:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ The idea of a NegatedCondition, for example, is that going to be more memory. (Also, Iâ€™m not sure how that could work, because it would need to join on a variable number of bindings.)
#2018-10-26Â 19:13:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @eraserhd they arenâ€™t much overhead beyond the fact object itself
#2018-10-26Â 19:14:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can make a rule that does the conjunction and inserts a fact if it is true. Then a rule with a negation on that fact. Clara actually sometimes automatically does something similar to that.
#2018-10-26Â 19:15:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Intermediate facts in memory are about the same as just making a new record of whatever is what I meant. Cpu timewise just depends on what it interacts with. The actual working memory insert and retract operations are pretty fast (optimized it quite a bit)
#2018-10-26Â 19:15:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not sure if that addresses all your questions there
#2018-10-26Â 19:15:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I think so.
#2018-10-26Â 19:32:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ When writing rules I typically go pretty heavy on intermediate facts
#2018-10-26Â 19:33:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ With preference on making simple rules that models smaller concepts at a time and then compose them together for main outcome models for query. If that makes any sense.
#2018-10-26Â 19:36:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â zyloxÂ same here
#2018-10-26Â 20:06:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â jimbobÂ what if i have three rules that act on type A and they all output type B while â€œmutatingâ€ some state in the fact. will the final fact be type B with all the â€œmutationsâ€?

#2018-10-31Â 19:13:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it is a prio queue since you can have precedence on which rules should be staged ahead of one another - e.g. :salience

#2018-11-01Â 14:40:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ yeah, defrecord in clj is often considered more of a perf optimization for a common group of fields you access, they work as regular maps in many cases, and having any number of keys is one of them. the keys not defined on the record are just accessed slower on the impl side
#2018-11-01Â 14:40:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and you canâ€™t reflect for them etc

#2018-11-01Â 14:41:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you donâ€™t provide one, Clara will default to rebuilding things minus the facts retracted
#2018-11-01Â 14:41:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ :retract-fn is meant for when you know how to more efficiently remove a retracted fact from your reduced structure

#2018-11-01Â 14:44:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ We have the ability to do more efficient retraction and combining, so we're writing a custom accumulator to get around the thrashing from yesterday. It also allows us to get rid of some intermediate facts that are frequently retracted.
#2018-11-01Â 14:47:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ when you use the accumulator
