#2018-11-01Â 14:49:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Are you using some joining conditions there like [X (test-something ?y z)], or just [X], or equality based join, like [X (= ?y z)]?
#2018-11-01Â 14:49:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The point is there are 2 variants of accumulate nodes in the rules engine, one for the simpler join cases using = or no joining at all
#2018-11-01Â 14:49:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ that one is optimized for those cases because they can be done better
#2018-11-01Â 14:50:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the other variant handles the rest, which are arbitrary other joining criteria
#2018-11-01Â 14:51:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ At this point, if I recall all the impl details correctly, providing your own :retract-fn is only a potential perf optimization. If you use the optimized, easier variant of an accumulator, it will be used, otherwise, it is ignored because it canâ€™t be used from within the more generalized case
#2018-11-01Â 14:51:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ or really, it canâ€™t be used to help in the more general case, it would only be slower
#2018-11-01Â 15:10:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ Does the accumulator maintain the reduced value before being passed to the :convert-return-fn for the purposes of handing it to the :retract-fn?
#2018-11-01Â 15:10:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ (assuming both are defined)
#2018-11-01Â 15:12:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ To rephrase, should the :retract-fn expect the output of the :reduce-fn or the :convert-return-fn?
#2018-11-01Â 15:18:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @jody > To rephrase, should the :retract-fn expect the output of the :reduce-fn or the :convert-return-fn? It should expect the output of :reduce-fn
#2018-11-01Â 15:19:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s part of the â€œreducing phaseâ€, :convert-return-fn is only done after everything else
#2018-11-01Â 15:19:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Under the current implementation (would have to double check), I donâ€™t think working memory for the accumulate node ever maintains the :convert-return-fn value actually, just the :reduce-fn/`:retract-fn` returned value state
#2018-11-01Â 15:20:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the reason is that the :convert-return-fn value is not considered useful to use for any subsequent changes
#2018-11-01Â 15:20:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the reducing state is
#2018-11-01Â 19:31:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Is it possible for an accumulator to get a net negative, e.g. more retractions than insertions. I'm wondering because maybe this is implied by the "combine" function?
#2018-11-01Â 20:03:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ProbablyJodyÂ I believe the combine function is just a performance optimizer for the reduce phase. Iâ€™d expect a net-negative to represent a bug in truth maintenance. I might be mis-understanding the question though.
#2018-11-01Â 20:48:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I mean, obviously, if you combine all batches, you can't have more retractions than insertions. But depending on how you are batching, you could have one batch with, say three insertions and another batch with two retractions. That would mean that two retractions were applied to the initial value in that case.
#2018-11-01Â 20:50:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Alternately, you could say that Clara enforces that retractions occur in the same batch as insertions. I'm not sure how it could, though I don't understand how this is being called.
#2018-11-01Â 20:56:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I guess one possibility is that Clara only uses this for joins where each reduced value is a selection of attributes, such that insertions and retractions are always sorted into the same batch. That actually makes the most sense.
#2018-11-01Â 21:39:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @eraserhd when retracting facts, with respect to an accumulator, the accumulator is only re-ran on facts that were retracted and were found to have previous matches
#2018-11-01Â 21:40:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so the facts retracted and processed by an accumulator, should only be facts that were processed by the same accumulator before, when they were inserted
#2018-11-01Â 21:41:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you batched up retracts of facts that were not inserted yet, the accumulator wouldnâ€™t need to retract anything
#2018-11-01Â 21:41:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and it wouldnâ€™t try
#2018-11-01Â 21:41:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ facts are considered the â€œsameâ€ via =
#2018-11-01Â 21:42:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but respecting cardinality of them
#2018-11-01Â 21:42:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ ie insert 2 = objects, retract 1, you still have 1 left
#2018-11-01Â 21:42:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if the retracted is identical? to 1 of = instances, thatâ€™d like be the one removed - but I think thatâ€™s more due to perf optimizations than anything
#2018-11-01Â 22:12:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ @mikerod OK, that makes sense. Thanks!
#2018-11-02Â 11:56:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @eraserhd Agreed with @mikerod that the only facts which will be retracted are those that were provided before. Regarding the inefficiencies of accumulation with non-hash join conditions, I think thatâ€™s a more general problem than the :retract-fn actually. For example, I believe when a new fact matching the accumulation condition is added the previous facts will have the accumulator rerun on them in their entirety, whereas the simple case with no joins or only-hash based joins will store the previous result and add onto it. Contrast the following in AccumulateNode, the simple case: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1156 with the equivalent in AccumulateWithJoinFilterNode, the more complex case: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1525
#2018-11-02Â 11:58:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The tricky thing is that Claraâ€™s memory is set up to store the elements (facts coming into the current condition) and tokens (facts from ancestor conditions) separately, but in the case of these complex accumulator joins youâ€™d really want to store them together for maximum efficiency. I donâ€™t think there is any fundamental reason why this couldnâ€™t be done though, it
#2018-11-02Â 11:58:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ would just be the work to do it and get it right/performant, plus durability changes probably if the memory structure changed
#2018-11-02Â 12:00:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara does avoid downstream thrash from the complex accumulators still when the result didnâ€™t actually change - see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/182 and the changes made there - but the internal calculation has some room for improvement perf-wise
#2018-11-02Â 12:03:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ If you want to understand how the accumulator logic works, some basic terms:
#2018-11-02Â 12:03:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ -right-activate: new facts matching the condition at hand
#2018-11-02Â 12:03:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ -right-retract: removal of facts matching the condition at hand
#2018-11-02Â 12:04:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ -left-activate: facts were added to ancestor conditions and need to be passed down the network
#2018-11-02Â 12:04:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ left-retract: facts were removed from ancestor conditions and need to be passed down the network
#2018-11-02Â 12:05:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ AccumulateNode - simple no-condition or hash-join-only accumulation conditions
#2018-11-02Â 12:05:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ AccumulateWithjoinFilterNode - accumulation condition with arbitrary filter logic taking facts from ancestor conditions as input
#2018-11-02Â 12:09:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ probably the best source of truth there is the code, fortunately it is a well commented area imo though iâ€™m biased as i wrote many of those comments
#2018-11-02Â 12:10:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ to be clear: when I say to understand how it works, i mean the algorithms at play - the docs should be sufficient for the behavior and if theyâ€™re not they should be improved
#2018-11-02Â 12:10:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ hopefully this helps
#2018-11-02Â 12:11:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ if youâ€™re trying to get a case with complex accumulator joins to perform better, frankly my first reaction would be to use salience most likely
#2018-11-02Â 12:12:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ if youâ€™re using truth maintenance without side effects, the salience shouldnâ€™t impact actual behavior so it doesnâ€™t make the code harder to read/understand in that respect
#2018-11-02Â 13:44:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ @wparker thanks! This is all good info.
#2018-11-02Â 13:48:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I'm guessing, in [Foo (= ?a a)] [?acc <- (acc/whatever) [Bar (= ?a a)]], Foo would be left and Bar would be right?
#2018-11-02Â 15:46:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @eraserhd basically yes
#2018-11-02Â 15:46:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ left is the matched-token-so-far in a rule LHS
#2018-11-02Â 15:47:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ tokens consist of all facts involved in a match
#2018-11-02Â 15:48:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In a LHS [A] [B] [C] if we were looking at the network node for the [C] condition, incoming C facts would be right-activate, left-activate to this node would be matched up A+`B`s - represented as a â€œtokenâ€
#2018-11-02Â 17:24:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ And for the [B] condition, incoming B facts would be right-activate, left-activate would be tokens passed down from the [A] condition. For the [A] condition the right-activate would be incoming A facts, the left-activate would basically be a dummy placeholder. Does that make sense?
#2018-11-06Â 21:22:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ queries are prioritized last (in terms of salience), I hope, right?
#2018-11-06Â 22:06:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @eraserhd Iâ€™m canâ€™t think of a reason where itâ€™d matter how queries are â€œprioritizedâ€
#2018-11-06Â 22:06:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ they just receive matches from facts that are currently in working memory
#2018-11-06Â 22:07:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ priority with :salience is about ordering when a rule is eligible to be fired
#2018-11-06Â 22:07:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ aka perform the action specified on its RHS, so this concept does not apply to queries
#2018-11-06Â 22:08:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ hmm, so if I have rules that insert and retract things that are queried, the query results aren't updated by the firing of a pseudo-rule?
#2018-11-06Â 22:11:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ (bad sentence, but hopefully the question is clear)
#2018-11-06Â 22:29:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ OK, I see. They are their own thing.
#2018-11-06Â 23:07:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not sure I understand that question. But in general always fire rules before query. Not sure if that helps. Hah
#2018-11-07Â 14:06:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @eraserhd Not sure I understand the question either, but the API with queries is that if you call the query function on a rules session after firing rules, the query results will reflect all insertions/retractions prior to the fire-rules call. Under the hood, queries are basically a rule LHS and the results are computed as part of fire-rules - the query function in clara.rules really is more of a â€œretrieve query resultsâ€ function than a â€œrun queryâ€ in that way. If your concern was performance, there are optimizations that could be made around deferring some query matching work to later in the fire-rules, thus avoiding the need to retract query matches that are invalidated, but that hasnâ€™t been implemented. Iâ€™ve found it isnâ€™t often an issue and in the few cases where it was it was fairly easy to work around.
#2018-11-14Â 13:40:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nlessaÂ Hi, I am having performance problems in my set of rules. Probably some of the rules are performing bad. Is there any way to profile the time spent by each rule when firing-rules in a session? I couldn't find any obvious way to get this info using the inspect api.
#2018-11-14Â 14:17:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The inspect api is targeted at understanding the end result of the rules, not performance. For performance problems youâ€™ll probably want a profiler or perhaps tracing. Tracing shows all the internal steps of the rules engine, and can produce a lot of data that is probably best sorted through with the REPL rather than manual inspection, but if a single rule is constantly re-firing it can make that clear. Iâ€™d probably start with a profiler though. Another approach could be to take separate parts of your use-case and see if you can find a simple subset with the perf problem, particularly one you can share that would be easier for someone else to look at.
#2018-11-14Â 14:17:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Are you on Clojure or ClojureScript?
#2018-11-14Â 14:20:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nlessaÂ Thanks, @wparker! Clojure.
#2018-11-14Â 16:40:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @nlessa and feel free to share profiler sample results with me (or anyone interested) (with anything propriety removes). Sometimes just seeing the Clara internals in a profiling snapshot can help point someone in the right direction. Not always though.

#2018-11-19Â 20:08:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ It seems like this is a bunch more thought that applies to how to build an alpha network than I've seen mentioned before.
#2018-11-19Â 20:16:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @eraserhd not familiar with this one.
#2018-11-19Â 20:17:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ looks like itâ€™d take a bit to parse through it to see how the ideas relate to other rete things that are out there
#2018-11-19Â 20:23:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I have yet to see anything about optimizing the order of alpha tests, except for specific things like hashing 8 ways to find an alpha memory when using triplets.
#2018-11-19Â 20:24:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ AFAICT, there's no cases of filtering with user tests before storing in an alpha memory, even, and I presume that's because it's hard to know when you can do that and not duplicate memories?
#2018-11-19Â 20:29:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Claraâ€™s alpha network partitions on how facts match the â€œtypeâ€ criteria first
#2018-11-19Â 20:30:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you have alpha-side only constraints like [A (< x 5)]
#2018-11-19Â 20:30:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ those will be filtered as they come in and will not be stored in alpha mem if they donâ€™t match
#2018-11-19Â 20:31:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and if you have variable bindings (via the overloaded = semantics), eg. [A (= ?x x)], facts in the alpha memory will be stored in a hash lookup keyed by that variable binding
#2018-11-19Â 20:31:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ those are the main alpha-side network details I can think of
#2018-11-20Â 17:02:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ Case A 
[:test (my-pred?)]
[MyFact [a] (= a ?a)]
=>
....
Case B 
[MyFact [a] (= a ?a)]
[:test (my-pred?)]
=>
....
With A, clara will call my-pred? at mk-session With B, clara will call my-pred? at fire-rules There is docs about this behavior?
#2018-11-20Â 17:45:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I'm not sure there is any document referencing that behavior. It would be an odd scenario to have a test node that is independent of the other nodes in a production. A typical scenario would make that test node dependent on some upstream fact, thus making the test node evaluate some time during fire-rules
#2018-11-20Â 18:09:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ @ethanc can I disable it?
#2018-11-20Â 18:12:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I'm not sure what you mean by disable it. From your example above i am assuming that my-pred? is some sort of stateful check, and if that is true then i would recommend against imbedding that sort of logic in the network itself, maybe moving it to the RHS of the rule.
#2018-11-20Â 18:13:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ It's not statefull. it access a *dynamic* env var ðŸ™‚
#2018-11-20Â 18:43:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The use of a dynamic var would likely be considered stateful, as the state of the var would impact the result from the predicate. Clara makes some pretty big assumptions on statelessness, as in it will not reevaluate conditions that it "doesn't have to". Air quoting doesn't have to because clara determines what must be reevaluated by direct or indirect actions(Truth Maintenance) on the session, ie insertion or retraction of facts. That being said, if there is statefulness in a session's rules and for some reason that state changes then all bets are off when it comes to the validity of the outcome of said rules.
#2018-11-20Â 18:45:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Perhaps you could instead insert facts that represent the same thing that this dynamic var encapsulates
#2018-11-20Â 18:45:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ however, evaluating anything at â€œcompile timeâ€ of mk-session seems weird to me. Iâ€™d have to see it reproduced probably to understand what may be happening there
#2018-11-20Â 20:23:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ https://gist.github.com/souenzzo/e38e600d486532308084c2bba0a9b3e9 @mikerod
#2018-11-20Â 20:25:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ #tools-deps is awesme to report bugs â¤ï¸
#2018-11-20Â 21:36:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @souenzzo, I was looking at your example, it seems that the side effect that you mention is due to: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L2050 which is used during the creation of the session as you described: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L264 The left activate in that snippet seems to be aimed at rules that have no LHS, ex: 
(r/defrule insert-sentinel 
  =>
  (r/insert! (->SomeFact)))
the token being passed is empty. This "bootstrapping" operation is likely done because these productions wouldn't have an alpha-root for them to be triggered later. In your scenario: 
(defrule rule1
  [:test (my-pred? :rule1)]
  [Fact (= a ?a)]
  =>
  (prn ["rule1" ?a]))
the first node in the beta-roots would be the test-node, as mentioned before this is not a normal pattern as test nodes are usually dependent on prior facts. When the conditions are reversed the test node would not be evaluated as it would be a child node of a join node.
#2018-11-20Â 21:44:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â souenzzoÂ PROPOSAL: If is possible to reach LHS, then run the RHS. If there is no how to reach LHS, then do not run anything in RHS. Is it possible? Is it reasonable? Should I open a issue? I think that I can try a PR.
#2018-11-20Â 22:54:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @souenzzo I'm not sure i fully understand the intent of your proposal. The determination of RHS evaluation is done currently by percolating facts down the nodes until they ideally enter a ProductionNode, assuming all conditions are met. To do this we would still have to evaluate the truthiness of the LHS.
#2018-11-26Â 21:07:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Hey, whereâ€™s the source for the Clara Rules site? I donâ€™t see it on gh-pages or master in the clara-rules repo.

#2018-12-05Â 16:54:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ that sounds right
#2018-12-05Â 16:55:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ i would think that we surfaced it in the dsl proper
#2018-12-05Â 16:57:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ *wouldn't

#2018-12-05Â 17:20:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ thatâ€™s what I thought :condition was
#2018-12-06Â 13:29:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hjrnunesÂ Hello! I'm trying to get some explanations for my rules, but clara.tools.inspect/explain-activations doesn't print anything at all. With clara.tools.inspect/inspect I get a map but :fact->explanations is nil: 
{:rule-matches
 {{:ns-name validator.typing,
   :lhs
            [[:not {:type validator.typing.LowCardinality, :constraints []}]],
   :rhs     (do (c/insert! (->ColType :t))),
   :props   {:salience -100},
   :name    "validator.typing/text",
   :doc     "The column is textual when cardinality is not low"}
  (),
  ...
  :query-matches ...
  :condition-matches
  {{:type validator.typing.ColInfo, :constraints [(= 1 non-num-vals)]}
                                                                   (),
   {:type validator.typing.LowCardinality, :constraints []}        (),
   ...
  :insertions
  {{:ns-name validator.typing,
    :lhs
             [[:not {:type validator.typing.LowCardinality, :constraints []}]],
    :rhs     (do (c/insert! (->ColType :t))),
    :props   {:salience -100},
    :name    "validator.typing/text",
    :doc     "The column is textual when cardinality is not low"}
   (),
   ...},
  :fact->explanations nil}
#2018-12-06Â 13:30:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hjrnunesÂ Is this a problem with my rules?
#2018-12-06Â 13:30:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hjrnunesÂ Also, how do I interpret this data?
#2018-12-06Â 13:37:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hjrnunesÂ OK, I re-read the docs, and I can't understand what is meant by 'logical insertions". Isn't this inserting a fact on the RHS of a rule? The one above is inserted in the RHS of a rule, but there's no explanation for it...
#2018-12-06Â 15:07:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @hjrnunes logical insertion is the default c/insert! in the RHS of the rules
#2018-12-06Â 15:08:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it is referring to insertions that are managed by the truth maintenance system (TMS) of the engine. If the rule is found to later become unsatisfied in its LHS, the logically inserted fact will be automatically retracted.
#2018-12-06Â 15:08:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t think that is your main question though, you are wondering why :fact->explanations is nil above
#2018-12-06Â 15:12:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ What you have above, if you look at :insertions, it is saying that the rule :name validator.typing/text had no facts inserted as a result of it.
#2018-12-06Â 15:12:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, :rule-matches says similar, there were not matches for the rule
#2018-12-06Â 15:13:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So the result of this is that you have no facts that were inserted from a rule, so there are no :fact->explanations to show

#2018-12-10Â 20:47:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I'm definitely simplifying. We're working on making a small reproduction. Maybe it'll go away, or we'll figure out we're doing something boneheaded. :D
#2018-12-10Â 20:57:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Could do 2 not conditions for that one right
#2018-12-10Â 20:57:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But in general Clara compiler will try to convert things into disjunctive normal form.
#2018-12-10Â 20:58:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Sometimes there may be issues with doing this when variable bindings are used across clauses that are moving around.
#2018-12-10Â 20:58:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ It may or may not relate to your issue. I just think there were perhaps still a few edge cases pointed out in some gh issues outstanding
#2018-12-10Â 20:59:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I often will just advocate for breaking more complex expressions into separate rules that have intermediate facts between them to recreate the logic you are looking for
#2018-12-10Â 21:00:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Generally will lead to less confusion and more transparency in introspection since you can look at the intermediate facts.
#2018-12-10Â 21:00:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Often perf is fine or better that way too, but that can depend.
#2018-12-13Â 17:34:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ So, I should follow up. Clara was working correctly. We had an extra rule spelled weirdly enough to defy grep.

#2019-01-08Â 20:11:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Had some discussions about performance for our use cases, and I made a bunch of assumptions. 1) In terms of inserts/retracts and fire-rules, Clara is single-threaded and does not take advantage of parallelziation. 2) Working set size and memory bandwidth dominate CPU speed.
#2019-01-08Â 20:12:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Do those sound accurate?
#2019-01-08Â 20:28:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @eraserhd (1) seems accurate enough; I think (2) isnâ€™t clear enough to me to say yes/no
#2019-01-08Â 20:30:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The CPU is typically dominated by the number of constraints being evaluated against the working set of facts. So yes to that part I believe. What do you mean by memory bandwidth?
#2019-01-09Â 05:44:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â devnÂ I think they are saying what I might assume to be true. Large numbers of facts coupled with large numbers of rules are likely to create memory pressure as they scale in number. But, Iâ€™ll go on record as saying I doubt physical limits are a bottleneck when it comes to performance in Clara. Mechanical sympathists in the audience?
#2019-01-09Â 15:07:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Agreed with (1), with the proviso that one could create multiple sessions and get parallelization that way. Regarding (2), in part I'd have to give the annoying-but-true answer that much depends on the structure and size of your rule/fact set. For many use cases, particularly on clj since it has gotten most of the perf optimization, perf likely is good enough to be a non-issue. CPU can be a concern, especially for rulesets with lots of truth maintenance work. When you say memory bandwidth, do you just mean memory use or the actual speed of retrieval of data from RAM/the CPU cache? It isn't clear to me how you'd optimize the latter effectively running on top of the JVM, but TBH I haven't thought about that level of optimization in the context of Clara. I suspect there's still much lower hanging fruit to work on in term of perf improvements.
#2019-01-09Â 15:09:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ @mikerod by memory bandwidth, I mean memory bus speed. If the working set is larger than cache, I assume the speed constraint is loading the data to the CPU, not number crunching.
#2019-01-09Â 15:10:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ And the way to optimize it is to choose a different AWS instance type :D
#2019-01-09Â 15:25:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I see. Thanks for clarifying
#2019-01-09Â 15:26:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah. All of this can contribute. The underlying hardware solution would likely be a last resort time. But if you are seeing a perf issue and can get profiler sampling data that could be useful.
#2019-01-09Â 15:30:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are also some ways to look at tracing output to get a sense of count of times parts of the network were evaluated. Sometimes you can look for outliers there
#2019-01-09Â 15:53:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Keep in mind that the CPU cache will hold more than just what you think of as the data e.g. routines of the JVM itself, methods from the Clojure runtime, Clara itself, etc. If you were trying to make the cache efficient that might dominate the actual â€œdataâ€ youâ€™re working with. Iâ€™m a bit skeptical that thatâ€™s your dominating performance factor though - agreed with Mike that a profiler snapshot showing whatâ€™s taking time in Clara would be helpful.

#2019-01-10Â 18:53:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mauricio.szaboÂ @U0LK1552A I'm running the code in the following way: 
(let [session (-> (mk-session 'events-reports.reports.deferred
                              'events-reports.reports.normalize-data
                              :fact-type-fn :fact))
      res (jdbc/query db "SELECT * FROM my_table WHERE ...")
      location-ids (map :id res)]

  (doseq [id location-ids]
    (async/go
     (println "Emitting for" id)
     (jdbc/with-db-connection [db @smart/db]
        (let [facts (search-facts db id)
              rows (-> session
                       (insert-all facts)
                       (fire-rules)
                       (query detailed-anual-report)
                       (->> (map make-detailed-anual-row)))]
         (println "Saving for" id)
         (save-rows rows))))))

#2019-01-10Â 17:08:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ To my original comment, the scenario i was remembering was something like: 
(defrule simple-rule
 [A (= ?f f)]
 [?bs <- (acc/all) :from [B (= f ?f)]] 
 =>
(insert! (->C)))
This does cause an retract on the production node, but thats due to new facts being add. So not as i remembered.
#2019-01-10Â 16:52:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ 
#2019-01-10Â 16:55:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @U0ECYL0ET Itâ€™s a bit cutoff and always a challenge to really know. From this, it seems to suggest that you have a rule with a negation - :not that is initially true due to no matches at some point in fire-rules. Later, it gets matches so becomes false. Due to order of rule firing, when it is becomes false, there was already staged activations of the rule from when it was true that need to be discarded now that that is no longer the case - via the truth maintenance
#2019-01-10Â 16:55:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The activations being discarded may have large tokens as one possibility - perhaps there is a large data gathered via an accumulator in this rule?
#2019-01-10Â 16:56:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Alternatively, I may have to see more stack to know (or canâ€™t really know), the rule had a lot of combinations of matches resulting in many activations that now all have to be discarded
#2019-01-10Â 16:57:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ OK, my reading also. We're going to try to isolate which rule(s) cause it.
#2019-01-10Â 16:58:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Maybe you can find one of that structure. The negation May be your actual last condition of the role, although that isnâ€™t strictly true in all cases I believe.
#2019-01-10Â 16:59:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ May be able to do some listener tracing to find more details too. Iâ€™d have to play around to come up with a useful example of how to use it in this sort of case.
#2019-01-10Â 17:39:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Regarding tracing - I wrote some helpers at one point for this that I really need to clean up some and push to master - but basically you get an entry in a list for every interaction in the rules engine, most of which have a node ID attached. You can then use that ID to look up the node in the session and see what rules/queries it corresponds to. So if you see an ID come up a lot those rules are doing a lot of work. Since it is ordered, you can investigate in more complex ways, but often a â€œlots of stuff is happening in this ruleâ€ can be enough to narrow things down enough
#2019-01-10Â 17:45:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ would be good to get some doc examples of this sort of thing
#2019-01-13Â 13:19:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â frickeÂ Hi all, (in the google-group the title is Infinite Loop when using :not-guard in a rule) I tried to do something that is really easy to do in e.g. Datalog, like having given a node->parent relationship, I try to get hold of all the parents that are around (no duplicates). This snippet show the data-model with the rule: 
(defrecord Node2Parent [node parent])
(defrecord Node [node])
(r/defrule insert-all-parents
  [Node2Parent (= ?parent parent)]
  [:not [Node (= node ?parent)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Node ?parent))
  )
The way I read this is that we add a new Node-fact for each occurring parent, that has not been added already. And here's how I call it: 
(defn s [] (-> (r/mk-session 'engine.core) (r/insert (->Node2Parent :inner1 :root)
                                                     (->Node2Parent :leaf1 :root)
                                                 (->Node2Parent :leaf2 :inner1)
                                                 (->Node2Parent :leaf3 :inner1))
           (r/fire-rules)))

(r/defquery all-nodes "all nodes"
  []
  [Node (= ?node node)])
(r/query (s) all-nodes)
It goes into a infinite loop and never comes back. Adding a print-statement to the rule tell you that it keeps adding :root nodes to the fact-base. I guess that I miss something the way the unification in the LHS-conditions play out. thanks and regards markus
#2019-01-13Â 16:04:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ @markus.frick the issue here is that Clara performs "truth maintenance". The better way to interpret the Node2Parent rule is, "Every Node which does not have a parent, should have a parent."
#2019-01-13Â 16:05:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ In this case, it confuses Clara. Clara sees a node with no parent and decides it should have one. Then it sees that the node has a parent, and therefore shouldn't have one, and therefore retracts it.
#2019-01-13Â 16:06:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ If there's no other way for Node to be created, just remove the :not. If there is, you'll likely have to restructure it.
#2019-01-13Â 16:17:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ You could also use an unconditional insert, as this would remove the fact from truth maintenance.
#2019-01-13Â 19:37:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â frickeÂ oh thanks a lot; I totally missed the "truth maintenance" aspect (coming from a Datalog world where rule-evaluation is monotonous). I guess it's just easier to understand and implement, if I add the Node-facts by hand and add them to the session before I execute the rules. More so, since I won't get rid of the duplicate facts anyway. With unconditional inserts I get 
({:?node :root} {:?node :inner1} {:?node :inner1} {:?node :root})
I guess set semantics are just really difficult to have in a world where you just see the fixed number of facts from the LHS. thanks, markus
#2019-01-15Â 21:29:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @markus.frick late to this answer, but you can eliminate duplicates via â€œintermediary factsâ€ and accumulators
#2019-01-15Â 21:32:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ

#2019-02-02Â 11:31:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â david_clojurianÂ Hello everyone, I have a problem with clara rules and I hope you can help me. To resolve components that are productive I create facts of dependencies and mark components that are used by productive components as productive as well. Right when I have a loop in the dependency chain, clara rules ends up in a endless loop while firing rules. Here is the code: 
(ns clara.error
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]))

(defrecord DependsOn [element dep])
(defrecord Productive [element])

(defrule productive
  ""
  [DependsOn (= ?element1 element) (= ?element2 dep)]
  [Productive (= ?element1 element)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Productive ?element2)))

; Works
(as-> (mk-session 'clara.error) $
      (apply insert $ [(->Productive "A")])
      (apply insert $ [(->DependsOn "A" "B")
                       (->DependsOn "B" "C")
                       (->DependsOn "C" "D")])
      (fire-rules $))

; ends in a loop
(as-> (mk-session 'clara.error) $
      (apply insert $ [(->Productive "A")])
      (apply insert $ [(->DependsOn "A" "B")
                       (->DependsOn "B" "C")
                       (->DependsOn "C" "A")])
      (fire-rules $))
The approach of clara rules is awesome. That's why I hope we can find the problem so I can continue using clara rules. Thanks in advance.
#2019-02-03Â 09:40:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ Hey David! I've been using for some time so I hope I'll be able to help. Based on the graph you are building, if I understand correctly, it seems normal that Clara ends up looping. You have Productive -[DependsOn]-> Productive. And you insert A -> B -> C -> A, but A DependsOn B, so clara run again A -> B -> C -> A -> B -> C -> A -> B â€¦. You have a loop in your graph. It might be a problem with identity. You create a new Productive instance every time, but do clara knows that (->Productive "A") is identical by value to (->Productive "A") (new instance) ?
#2019-02-03Â 09:43:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â david_clojurianÂ Hello @ggaillard. I filed an issue on github and I get 2 answers. I'm evaluating these answers now, but as far as I can see, it seems to resolve my issue. Here is the link: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/418
#2019-02-03Â 09:43:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ggaillardÂ Ah nice, will look into it!
#2019-02-19Â 22:04:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Over the next week or so, we're going to be working on a library to translate pull expressions into Clara rules productions. Any thoughts on that now could shape how this works.
#2019-02-19Â 22:33:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ Why do you need this? I'm missing something I think
#2019-02-19Â 23:00:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ The primary system I work on models tasks and data dependencies. Inputs and output for a task are described as pull expressions, and this allows us to compute task dependencies. We couldn't do this with raw Clara queries, since they model general computation so halting problem yada yada.
#2019-02-19Â 23:01:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Pull expressions are a really nice, natural way to describe the shape of data wanted, IMHO.
#2019-02-19Â 23:03:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ We are moving to Clara handling more of the computation, because its truth maintenance property solves a lot of problem for us, and one of the new things we want to know is when a tasks inputs have changed, in order to retrigger our task.
#2019-02-19Â 23:04:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ So we're building this library to have Clara compute the inputs for a task in real time and update them as new data arrives.
#2019-02-20Â 03:48:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â adamfeldmanÂ @U0ECYL0ET sounds like an interesting project. Do the task inputs and outputs change frequently, preventing the use of a simple dependency graph? Can you say more about the business domain? If you havenâ€™t seen this, you may find it useful for working with pull expressions: https://github.com/edn-query-language/eql
#2019-02-20Â 06:34:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ This sounds quite similar to something I've been working on in my spare time!

#2019-02-20Â 13:57:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ eql looks really neat, definitely something to investigate

#2019-02-20Â 14:07:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Our thing's tasks are like, "we need a marketing site". That integration might use terraform.
#2019-02-20Â 14:08:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ There's some similarities, except that we really lean on forward-chaining rules. We need to have things built as early as possible, and we incrementally discover the information we need to do things.

#2019-02-20Â 14:33:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ Is it possible to create rules with parameters? And be explicit about passing them in?
#2019-02-20Â 14:42:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dominicm It isnâ€™t clear to me how that would work in general
#2019-02-20Â 14:42:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ However, queries take parameters if thatâ€™s more what youâ€™re looking for
#2019-02-20Â 14:42:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For rules, instead of taking a parameter, model the param as a fact inserted by a rule perhaps
#2019-02-20Â 14:44:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Instead of 
(defrule param-rule
  [A (= <my-param-here> x)]
  =>
  <do things>)
Do 
(defrule find-param
  [?i <- InputFact]
  =>
  (insert! (map->Param (extract-data ?i))))

(defrule param-rule
  [?p <- Param]
  [A (= (:x ?p) x)]
  =>
  <do things>)
#2019-02-20Â 14:45:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â dominicmÂ @mikerod hmm, maybe I haven't thought it through. But I want to write rules like "for every X insert 5", where I might have multiple of these inserted.

#2019-02-26Â 15:45:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bmaddyÂ Does anyone know if Clara supports recursion in queries? I couldn't find a mention of it on the website.
#2019-02-26Â 16:01:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @bmaddy could you elaborate on "recursion in queries"
#2019-02-26Â 16:07:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bmaddyÂ Sure, be advised that I'm really new to Clara and rules engines in general. Basically, I have a tree of data (nested associatives). I want to convert that into facts to query over it. If you're familiar with Datomic, it would be like asserting an entity {:a 1 :b {:c {:d 5}}} into datoms. I then want to do a query that finds a result if :d is 5 and any ancestor has an :a with the value 1. And because I said ancestor there, I think I'll need a recursive query.
#2019-02-26Â 17:28:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ Sorry for the delay You could probably brute force it in a query(iterate over the nested maps), but i would think that the idiomatic way would be to deconstruct the parent and insert the children with reference to there parent or root. for example: 
(ns some.namespace
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]))

(r/defrule expansion-rule
  [?e <- :entity (some map? (vals this))]
  =>
  (doseq [v (vals ?e)
          :when (map? v)
          [k v] v]
    (r/insert! (with-meta
                 ;; wrapping ?e in a vector to prevent
                 ;; v from having a child with that is a map
                 ;; (infinite loop)
                {:key k :val v :root (or (:root ?e) [?e])}
                {:type :entity}))))

(r/defquery get-root
  [:?val :?key]
  [:entity
   (= ?key (:key this))
   (= ?val (:val this))
   (= ?root (or (first (:root this)) this))])


(-> (r/mk-session)
     (r/insert (with-meta {:a 1 :b {:c {:d 5}}} {:type :entity}))
     r/fire-rules
     (r/query get-root :?val 5 :?key :d))
#2019-02-26Â 17:31:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ Using clara's fact-type here as i was being lazy and didn't want to construct a wrapper fact. By default clara uses clojure.core/type to determine rules to activate, thus i made the maps of type :entity
#2019-02-26Â 17:44:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The when in the doseq would be wrong and could be removed
#2019-02-26Â 17:46:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ and would be replaced with logic to expand all the keys rather than just maps
#2019-02-26Â 18:12:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The ancestors questions would then have to be post query, either that or you could insert some sort of fact representing what you are trying to join logically. Queries are aimed more at field equivalence
#2019-02-26Â 19:11:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ As an example of what i mean by inserting a fact to represent what you logically want to join, 
(ns some.namespace
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]))

(r/defrule expansion-rule
  [?e <- :entity (some map? (vals this))]
  =>
  (doseq [v (vals ?e)
          :when (map? v)]
    (r/insert! (with-meta
                 (assoc v :ancestors (conj (or (:ancestors ?e) []) (dissoc ?e :ancestors)))
                 {:type :entity}))))

(r/defrule query-rule
  [:query
   (= ?aq (:ancestor-question this))
   (= ?eq (:entity-question this))
   (= ?t (:query-id this))]
  [?e <- :entity]
  [:test (and (?eq ?e)
              (some ?aq (:ancestors ?e)))]
  =>
  (r/insert!
    (with-meta
      {:res ?e :query-id ?t}
      {:type :result})))

(r/defquery result-query
  [:?query-id]
  [:result
   (= ?query-id (:query-id this))
   (= ?result (:res this))])

(-> (r/mk-session)
    (r/insert (with-meta {:a 1 :b {:c {:d 5}}} {:type :entity}))
    (r/insert (with-meta {:query-id :d-5_a-1
                          :entity-question #(= (:d %) 5)
                          :ancestor-question #(= (:a %) 1)}
                         {:type :query}))
    r/fire-rules
    (r/query result-query :?query-id :d-5_a-1))
=>
({:?query-id :d-5_a-1, :?result {:d 5, :ancestors [{:a 1, :b {:c {:d 5}}} {:c {:d 5}}]}})
#2019-02-26Â 20:21:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bmaddyÂ Wow, thanks for all the explanation. I must admit, I'm rather stunned. I thought rules engines would let you do datalog-like queries across data to get notified as it changes, but now it seems like you need to build data up every step of the way in order to answer your question. I was thinking about using that to help with a ton of validations on nested data I have, but that sounds like I might be better off with something like datascript. So what's the killer app for rules engines? Right now my understanding of it makes me basically think it's like calling iterate on a set of data until it doesn't change anymore (applying rules) and then filtering it (the queries). (If you don't have the time to explain, I totally understand--you're generously volunteering your time after all! Thank you!)
#2019-02-26Â 20:45:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @bmaddy I believe the distinction may be more around the forward-chaining vs backward-chaining strengths and weaknesses
#2019-02-26Â 20:46:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clara being oriented around the forward-chaining style rules
#2019-02-26Â 20:47:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and logic programming systems like prolog (core.logic too?; datascript too?) more around a backward-chaining design
#2019-02-26Â 21:01:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bmaddyÂ Yeah, I've heard that. I could certainly stand to do some research to get a better grasp on that.
#2019-02-26Â 21:49:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @bmaddy I think itâ€™s difficult to explain well and there are probably good write-ups out there on the differences
#2019-02-26Â 21:50:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Claraâ€™s forward-chaining approach is good for a type of problem where you have a set of known facts and you have a complex chain of logical inference that can be done based on those facts to arrive at some - typically pre-enumerated set of outcomes
#2019-02-26Â 21:51:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can parameterize the queries in Clara to an extent that does allow you to look for different sorts of matches, but I donâ€™t think the concept extends well to asking arbitrary questions about the state of the system
#2019-02-26Â 21:51:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Like, I can say â€œGive me the outcomes that have an x value between 30-50â€
#2019-02-26Â 21:52:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but it is harder to say, â€œTell me what facts Iâ€™d need to get an outcome with x value between 30-50â€
#2019-02-26Â 21:53:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So Ethan had good examples above of how you can use forward-chaining to explicitly model relationships - so that you can query on those relationships-as-facts later
#2019-02-26Â 21:53:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think backwards-chaining may have more built-in approaches when thatâ€™s teh type of problem you are solving
#2019-02-26Â 21:54:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Forward-chaining is nice when you are doing waht I said above, and it comes with a good mechanism of chaining along a â€œpathâ€ that supports arriving at your various outcomes. I donâ€™t think anyone tends to say which is better, forward/backwards, I think itâ€™s just that each is better at a certain class of problem.
#2019-02-26Â 21:54:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But not sure why I typed all that. Probably much better explanations available online. ðŸ˜›
#2019-02-26Â 22:44:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bmaddyÂ Yeah, I'm a little familiar with what you're describing. I certainly have an entity (nested associative structure) that regularly changes slightly (in one case this is part of a state for a UI) and I want to run the same set of validations on it after every little change. That's what makes me think a rules engine is the way to go (i.e. my queries don't change, my data does). I just thought the querying would have something like datalog rules. #2019-02-28Â 16:13:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I donâ€™t have much to add to the above - as the examples shows, Clara doesnâ€™t try to query further into facts, it just treats them as top level entities to be joined, inserted, etc. 
Right now my understanding of it makes me basically think it's like calling `iterate` on a set of data until it doesn't change anymore (applying rules) and then filtering it (the queries).
That sounds on target. One thing a rules engine such as Clara is good at is efficiently applying small changes onto a complex ruleset - the intermediate states of the rule engine internals are kept to facilitate this. The â€œtruth maintenanceâ€ page on the webpage is a good one to read if you havenâ€™t yet. @bmaddy
#2019-02-28Â 19:21:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bmaddyÂ Thanks, it's nice to know my mental model is in the right ballpark. ðŸ™‚ Yeah, I've read that page before--it's very clear and well written. I haven't been able to find much on joins though. I actually didn't even realize that was possible until I was looking at Precept.

#2019-04-10Â 21:13:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @eraserhd Clara uses atoms in engine.cljc in some places to store pending operations, conceivably you could get there from data being put in those atoms. It would be fairly hard though. But then the performant version of your rules sessions taking 25 minutes is striking. ðŸ˜± Obviously it could be unavoidable if youâ€™re just processing massive amounts of data, but Iâ€™d be curious to see any kind of reproducing example of inordinate resource use, smaller examples obviously being easier to diagnose. I suspect youâ€™ve uncovered some kind of bad pattern in the way the rule network fires rather than this (poor) level of performance being inevitable. Most of Claraâ€™s optimization to date has been done against Cernerâ€™s use cases; having a broader sample of benchmarks would be useful.
#2019-04-10Â 22:04:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ AlphaNodes are also generated with an atom for the bindings that the node will propagate in the event that its satisfied, however they would be scoped to the function that determined the satisfaction of the node. The atom is probably unnecessary and could be probably be replaced with shadowing within the functionâ€¦ I doubt that this is the growth that you are seeing though. Might be a performance gain by not having to swap! that atom thoughâ€¦.
#2019-04-10Â 22:29:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @U3KC48GHW interesting on the use of an atom there. Iâ€™ll have to check that out again. However, overall, I wouldnâ€™t expect to see an â€œAtomâ€ itself taking memory up. Itâ€™s a pointer to something that may be large, but it itself shouldnâ€™t show up as taking that memory (thatâ€™s not what I expect in heap dumps at least I think?)

#2019-04-19Â 06:26:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ What sorts of introspection did you have in mind? If you mean introspection on what the rules engine did and why, there's a good amount of that, you can take a look at the inspect namespace and if you wanted something lower level the tracing namespace. If you mean introspection on the rules network, possibly yes if you write things yourself, but since the rules can contain arbitrary code (that the user writes) you have the usual problems with inspecting arbitrary code.
#2019-04-19Â 06:28:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Regarding dynamic modification, if you want to change the rules you have to build a new session and rerun the rules.

#2019-04-19Â 13:59:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ The second part, probably thinking about the wrong way, but for parts of the rules that have variables, I'd kind of like to see the rules served up with the variables replaced with actual values, so that it's easier to understand for user (developer). Basically I'll be serving up the rules from a server, and the server will also know what some of the vars should be in the rules, if server could basically inject that info, my thinking it's easier than having to reason about than having to look-up the values by hand. These variables change infrequently. Maybe server could inject them not necessarily inline so at least easy to see in one place. Hope that makes sense.
#2019-04-22Â 14:58:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @UH13Y2FSA The way to model what you are saying in the â€œsecond partâ€ above, would be to make your variables expressed as facts instead.
#2019-04-22Â 14:59:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thatâ€™s the typical way itâ€™d be done and the most straightforward with the way the forward-chaining data flow of the rules engine works.
#2019-04-22Â 14:59:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > if server could basically inject that info The â€œinjectionâ€ would be to just insert these facts.
#2019-04-22Â 15:00:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You base logic on them. If you need to derive things from them for other rules - derive â€œintermediate factsâ€, ie facts meant to just build up higher-level concepts to relay to other rules.
#2019-04-22Â 15:01:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Remember, the working memory â€œsessionâ€ state is immutable. So if you donâ€™t want to continually put in these infrequently changed facts, you could potentially create a session, insert these facts only, then use that as your base session for other later independent memory states with the more frequently changing facts.
#2019-04-24Â 08:52:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ This will work and is probably easiest, but if you really want to have the values be determined statically note that Clara can build sessions from rule data structures that you pass it; rules/queries don't have to be created with the defrule/defquery macros. So you can have arbitrary generation logic. You can look at the schemas namespace and the data under rule/query vars for examples. It might be best to become familiar with code generation e.g. macros in Clojure if you go down this route though.
#2019-04-22Â 03:43:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ (dir clararules.core) will give me a list of the rules in that ns, but how can i tell rules from other items in the namespace?
#2019-04-22Â 05:15:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ how do i see which rules are/were fired? I don't see an example.
#2019-04-22Â 12:46:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @joel380, Im not sure if this is an implementation detail or not, but clara uses a protocol and metadata to determine productions in a given namespace. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.19.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L270-L305 To your second question, i believe the way you would determine if rules have or have not fired would be to use the tracing listener. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/listeners/ Either that or the end state of the session could be used via queries and facts returned from those queries.
#2019-04-23Â 04:45:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ thanks... that second question. I was able to look at the session and see a fired rule, so that seems workable. The link you sent looks good, it looks like it uses something called "meta" to determine (query or rule), but doesn't seem to work for me.
#2019-04-23Â 04:50:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ actually no, this works: (meta (resolve 'has-email))
#2019-04-23Â 05:32:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ @ethanc --- is there any examples around activation-group-fn. Maybe the documentation is good enough, but being a clojure newbie, I'm really not understanding what that function should be receiving (a map that always represents rules only? or the metadata?) Also the it's sort sibling is fuzzy to me.
#2019-04-23Â 12:50:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @joel380, This is a test demonstrating the usage of the activation-group-fn: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.19.1/src/test/clojurescript/clara/test_salience.cljs#L76-L99 Please note that the manipulation of salience is typically reserved for tuning poor preforming rules. By poor performing, I mean rule scenarios where a pattern can be established where the execution order of rules will drastically impact the time that subsequent rules will take to execute and maintain truth.
#2019-04-24Â 02:05:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ another good link, that makes it understandable.
#2019-04-24Â 02:09:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ it looks like a "one-to-one" port of existing drools rules is problematic. Drools has a way for you to veto a rule firing, it also can allow us to skip rule groups. It looks like the equivalent involves just ensuring proper behavior by writing appropriate when clauses. I do like how using a defrecord to predicate on is simple.
#2019-04-24Â 02:41:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ i suppose the "clara way" to control groups would be to modify the productions --- add predicate(s)
#2019-04-24Â 04:36:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ i'm getting infinite loops: (defrule has-email "allow rule" [User (= "<mailto:/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection|/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection>" email)] [:not [Decision (contains? #{:allow} type)]] => (insert! (->Decision :allow)) (println "allowed")) (defrule has-email-deny "deny if not allowed" [:not [Decision (contains? #{:allow :deny} type)]] => (insert! (->Decision :deny)) (println "denied")) trying to make "allow" take precedence over "deny" decisions, but either my "contains" or universal non-existence seems to not be working.

#2019-04-25Â 04:09:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ It actually works as expected if I add the fact when making the session.
#2019-04-25Â 04:45:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ changing salience fixes this!?
#2019-04-24Â 08:44:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Regarding looking at fired rules, the idiomatic way to get output from the session would usually be to have facts that represent that output and query on those facts. The tracing listener will tell you what rules fired, but it will also include rules that were later retracted. The API guarantees are generally around the final state of the session, not what rules are fired on the way there. It's possible to design rules in a way that constrains this, but this has to be done carefully and wouldn't be my first approach to solving a given problem. The tracing listener is primarily intended for debugging and performance problem diagnosis.
#2019-04-25Â 17:48:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ thanks @wparker. I opened clara ticket and that has been insightful as well.
#2019-04-26Â 04:21:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ is it possible to refer to the doc string on the RHS?

(defrule a-rule
  "hello"
  [A (> x 3)]
  =>
  (println (:doc (meta #'a-rule))))

(-> (mk-session)
    (insert (->A 4))
    fire-rules)
hello

#2019-04-27Â 17:08:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So if you did defquery, youâ€™d just do: 
(mk-session [my-query])
#2019-04-27Â 17:08:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There is more you can do too if you mark a var metadata with :production-seq that allows you to store sequences of rule/query structures under a single var when a ns is searched for rules/queries.

#2019-04-28Â 09:54:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ I'm not sure what you're trying to do, could you elaborate?
#2019-04-28Â 17:31:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ I was trying to strip out the rule :docs that had matches. It wasn't clear to me that there were rules listed that weren't fired. This did the trick: (defn matched-rule-docs [session] (let [rule-match-map (:rule-matches (inspect session)) matched-rules (filter #(seq (get rule-match-map %)) (keys rule-match-map))] (map :doc matched-rules)))
#2019-04-28Â 18:57:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ Can this be done w/o using :test?: ''' [?registry <- ListRegistry] [:test (.isMember ?registry "userguidwl" "whitelist" "userguid")] '''

#2019-04-30Â 00:22:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ How can I apply the working memory from one session to another? Or fire one group of rules, and then apply it's WM to another set of rules?
#2019-04-30Â 01:33:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @joel380 if needing to go from one group or rules to another, you could just make query for the facts you want out of the first group, then insert those query results into the next group.

#2019-04-30Â 13:27:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah a query for all types is typically rough on performance.
#2019-04-30Â 13:28:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ For all facts in working memory I donâ€™t think there is a direct hook. I think maybe @ethanc would remember how we did â€œall factsâ€ before.
#2019-04-30Â 13:29:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Also, keep in mind that the engine wonâ€™t hold onto facts that it knows will never match. So for example, if you insert a fact A but no rule will ever be able to match it, it doesnâ€™t stay in working memory. So you wouldnâ€™t get it back with some â€œall factsâ€ request.
#2019-04-30Â 14:00:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @joel380, Perhaps creating a marker protocol for the types of facts that you are interested in, and then leveraging a single query on that protocol. Something like: 
(require '[clara.rules :refer :all])
(require '[clara.rules.accumulators :as acc])

(defprotocol ImportantFacts)

(defrecord A [x])
(defrecord B [y])

(defrecord C [z]
  ImportantFacts)

(defrecord D [a]
  ImportantFacts)

(defrecord E [b]
  ImportantFacts)


(defrule a-rule 
  [A (= ?x x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C (+ ?x 10))))


(defrule b-rule
  [B (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (insert! (->D (+ ?y 50))))

(defrule ab-rule
  [A (= ?x x)]
  [B (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (insert! (->E (+ ?y ?x))))

(defquery important-query
  []
  [?all-important <- (acc/all) :from [user.ImportantFacts]])


(-> (mk-session)
    (insert (->A 12))
    (insert (->B 1))
    fire-rules
    (query important-query))
There is something goofy about the clara.rules.dsl namespace, with respect to how it resolves â€œtypesâ€, specifically protocols so i had to fully qualify the ImportantFacts symbol.
#2019-04-30Â 14:09:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ 
=> ({:?all-important [#user.C{:z 22} #user.D{:a 51} #user.E{:b 13}]})
#2019-04-30Â 15:03:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @joel380 @ethanc discussed on the side w/Ethan, but the defprotocol pattern for type hierarchies is sort of pedantically â€œwrongâ€ Iâ€™d say. I think the host-type associated w/a defprotocol is meant to be more of an â€œimpl detailsâ€ (although it isnâ€™t going to change), that is concerned with performance optimizations. So Iâ€™d probably go w/ definterface when all you want is the type marker. That said, Clara has supported defprotocol types being used in rules when the symbol is in reference to the the class type, not the protocol metadata var. Ethan is likely going to log a Clara issues concerning the 2nd case and how this can get weird.
#2019-05-01Â 01:13:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ I appreciate all the help here so far! FWIW, I'm looking into something that might work better than Drools for us. On that side we currently leverage rule-groups, and the order of groups is controlled. I think we can probably break away from that pattern, but just in case, the reason for my question is to see if that behavior could be had as a "fallback" in Clara. I think though if facts get "kicked out" of WM, then managing that could be kind of ugly. It sounds like the "one true way" in Clara is to put guards in as appropriate, and that's the approach I'll take for now rather than trying skip rule-groups or some such by segregating the rules.
#2019-05-01Â 01:14:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ I'm curious if anyone changes their rules dynamically in a production environment, and any issues that may come up as a result.
#2019-05-01Â 14:36:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @joel380 Clara does have support for activation group like behavior. But it doesnâ€™t completely disable rules. It prioritizes a firing order. Itâ€™s much like salience, but on a group of rule level. And salience works within a group.
#2019-05-01Â 14:36:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I just tend to think you can write more robust rules when you donâ€™t write them in order dependent ways. Clara defaults to logical inserts that self-maintain the logical consistency to eliminate a large need for ordering.
#2019-05-01Â 14:37:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Drools provides a truth maintenance system too, but it isnâ€™t the default in drools to insert â€œlogicalâ€, you have to call a separate fn for that in Drools.
#2019-05-01Â 14:37:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In Clara the reverse is true.
#2019-05-01Â 14:37:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Part 2: what do you mean changing rules dynamically in production?
#2019-05-01Â 14:38:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Youâ€™d have to create a new session+rulebase for new rules. Clara doesnâ€™t support dynamic addition and removal of rules in an already constructed network.
#2019-05-01Â 14:39:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Drools does. And the semantics are to distribute working memory state to the new rules as they are added I believe. Clara has some mice optimization properties due to it not allowing this.
#2019-05-01Â 14:40:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s possible it could be a future â€œmodeâ€ supported, but thatâ€™s require someone quite motivated to do it. I tend to think you can often just make a new session and re-run from scratch, or only put new rules in separate session and propagate facts from one to the next as needed. Cases vary though.
#2019-05-02Â 03:06:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ dynamic loading --- i mean doing load-string on a clojure file containing the rules/defsession, at runtime as rules are occasionally dynamically updated.
#2019-05-02Â 03:10:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ in drools we short-circuit to the last group if a previous group makes a decision basically. I think for Clara we just put guards in all the following rules.
#2019-05-03Â 14:21:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ Couple of questions 1) I see there is no "update!" --- is retract! followed by insert! considered non-idiomatic?
#2019-05-03Â 14:37:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ In general, updating a fact would make truth maintenance really hard, if not impossible. If you find yourself retracting and inserting a fact on a right-hand-side, you are probably also going to run afoul of truth maintenance, likely by creating an infinite loop.
#2019-05-03Â 14:38:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Logically, if a fact is no longer true because of a new piece of data, you should have an additional condition on the left-hand-side of the original rule.
#2019-05-03Â 14:38:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Which allows truth maintenance to clear it up.
#2019-05-03Â 14:39:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ 2) I have a case where I take measurements of events something like {"eventX" [ (:limit 5 :prior (5 hrs)) (:limit 10 :prior (1 day)) ]} also I need to +1 those measures if they just now happened based on rule. (I don't have a list of events over that time, just the prior totals) I'm guessing the short answer is I need to "normalize the list" into individual facts and leverage insert-all! as well as use an accumulator (prior total + 1?), but then I need to accumulate and match against the limit, and how to do this with a flexible list is the part I'm not currently seeing. Particularly totaling over each period to compare against limit.
#2019-05-03Â 14:43:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I would absolutely break down the measurements into independent facts.
#2019-05-03Â 14:44:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ I'm not sure how you are saying :prior works. Do you want a rule to fire a rule if you get an event more than :limit in the last :prior?
#2019-05-03Â 14:45:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ so there's the existing count (from DB) if that count + (just now happened) > limit fire rule.
#2019-05-03Â 14:47:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ You've inserted multiple facts that has the database count of events of a particular type?
#2019-05-03Â 14:48:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ i can do that... currently the logic is the LHS side fetches the info (uses cache)

#2019-05-03Â 14:49:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ the final piece is maybe something like [ EventCount (?name name)(?limit limit)(?period period) (>= ?limit ( accumulate total for ?period ?name)) ; pseudocode

#2019-05-03Â 14:50:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Assuming you aren't using an immutable, global database, you will likely have trouble with consistency if you put database calls on the left-hand-side.
#2019-05-03Â 14:51:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ (the cache fixes that part, only refetches for another session)

#2019-05-03Â 14:52:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ (in a rule at all, in fact?)
#2019-05-03Â 14:52:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ no... its a java bean inserted into WM
#2019-05-03Â 14:53:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ what's a WM?
#2019-05-03Â 14:53:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ but a new one for each ... sorry firing. (working memory : clara currently drools ðŸ™‚ )
#2019-05-03Â 14:54:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ basically the bean is inserted before fire rules.
#2019-05-03Â 14:54:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ ah, right. But this will have the consistency issue I'm talking about. If the count changes in the database, it will not refire a rule.
#2019-05-03Â 14:54:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ not an issue.
#2019-05-03Â 14:54:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ it caches the call and keeps it for rest of that firing.
#2019-05-03Â 14:54:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ and that's acceptable.
#2019-05-03Â 14:54:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Ahhh, I see.

#2019-05-06Â 10:17:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @joel380 not sure if this will impact you, but note that facts should be immutable, including as regards their equals and hash methods. If, say, a hashcode changed while rules were firing you could get strange (undefined) behavior.
#2019-05-09Â 03:25:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â JoelÂ I'm thinking I may like to express a part of my system as a list (of maps) that gets turned into rules dynamically. #2019-05-10Â 13:05:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The API constraint is that mk-session needs to receive unevaluated code in the same format that the defrule and defmacro macros construct. Iâ€™ve worked on cases where the rules were generated from a DSL that had quite a bit of processing into Clara rule forms, so what youâ€™re suggesting sounds plausible.
#2019-05-15Â 16:34:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â drewverleeÂ Apologies for asking wide sweeping and possible horrible inaccurate questions: 1. clara (and rules engines in general) has no story for how to persist data correct? 2. datatomic and clara would seem to overlap in that they both use declarative joins to query data. 3. clara has reactive in memory updates to rules, while nothing in the dataomic ecosystem offers this (that i know of, which isn't saying much). It seems like reactive datalog, would bridge many of these gaps (but at what costs!). However, i also assume maybe trying to bridge these differences at the library/database level has large implications for how your system has to be setup (databases, etc...). especially in order to be fast enough to be interesting.
#2019-05-15Â 20:43:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @drewverlee > 1. clara (and rules engines in general) has no story for how to persist data correct? Yeah, for the most part it doesnâ€™t do that. There is some foundations for â€œdurabilityâ€ supported, but subject to change, but itâ€™s nothing like datomic or something to that extent. > 2. datatomic and clara would seem to overlap in that they both use declarative joins to query data. There is some overlap in how you query data out perhaps. However, itâ€™s done much differently. Datomic assumes much more of an ecosystem around it. Clara is a lightweight lib you can drop in the middle of your app and it just is a way to express conditional logic that is perhaps hard to express well with your own if-then logic. It also gives you the ability to be more declarative in describing your logic by using a truth maintenance system and a modern variant of the classic rete algorithm for perf benefits. > 3. clara has reactive in memory updates to rules, while nothing in the dataomic ecosystem offers this (that i know of, which isnâ€™t saying much). I canâ€™t say exactly that datomic is lacking this. I think youâ€™d have to put a system over it indeed. You allude then to datalog, which is probably similar to Clara in nature, but I believe it is based on backwards-chaining logic, so then you have to consider forward vs backwards chaining for your application area. Hopefully this sheds some insight for you.
#2019-05-15Â 20:47:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â drewverleeÂ This is hugely helpful, thank you. I was only recent aware of forwards chaining logic and to find out there is a (potentially) a relationship with datalog through a similar model, backwards chaining logic, is very interesting.
#2019-05-15Â 20:49:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ No problem. Yeah, exploring forwards vs backwards chaining and when one may be better suited or not is always a topic of interest to me.
#2019-05-15Â 20:50:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think more or less, you can do similar things in both, but one may be more optimal for certain usages than the other
#2019-05-15Â 20:53:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ And in Claraâ€™s case specifically, queries are expressed in a pre-defined way that is built directly into the rules network - via something such as defquery. So they are â€œpre-cannedâ€ and actually participate in the forward-chaining logic just like any other rule does. Something like datalog, I believe you just specify arbitrary queries on demand. These then form backwards chaining execution paths. More like a relational db query or something to that extent.
#2019-05-15Â 21:30:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â drewverleeÂ I think your right mike, that very much gels with what i understand in principle about both. I think my next step is some papers and hammock time. Thanks a ton!
#2019-05-16Â 14:32:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Just so you know, we use Datomic with Clara, and bolting them together has hit a sweet spot where we solved several problems at once.
#2019-05-16Â 14:33:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Before, we had custom data validation code, and custom code to create "synthetics" - computed values that appear in our GraphQL queries that don't exist in the database.
