#2019-05-16Â 15:12:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think the idea was to smoothly use EAV style tuples as facts. I havenâ€™t used it or anything though. I just think it relates to datomic datoms.
#2019-05-19Â 02:08:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â drewverleeÂ Whats the difference from a query and a rule in rules engines in general. As i understand it. a rule is propositional logic "if X then Y" / X :- Y. But is query something else or is it just a rule where X is some direct match lookup?
#2019-05-19Â 02:08:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â drewverleeÂ It seems in clara that rules can have arguments, is that right?
#2019-05-19Â 02:36:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @drewverlee queries gives you an external hook to pull data from the session. It has no RHS. When you â€œcallâ€ the query you get the matches as a result. The matchâ€™s have all the variable bindings of the rule bound by those keys for you to access.
#2019-05-19Â 02:36:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can parameterize a query. When you call it, you bind those parameters.
#2019-05-19Â 02:37:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Normal rules canâ€™t be parameterized like this because you donâ€™t â€œcallâ€ into rules directly.
#2019-06-26Â 19:00:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ why do rules have to have fact-type? e.g. Person here: 
[?person <- Person (= first-name "Alice") (= ?last-name last-name)]
;; or here
[Person (= ?name1 name) (= ?age1 age)]
#2019-06-26Â 19:05:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ how does engine implementation leverages that? it seems like having datomic-like datalog api would be somewhat more uniform or convenient, or ...?
#2019-06-26Â 20:07:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ @misha in essence Clara, given facts, finds the types that match that fact and looks up the rules with conditions on that type. Note that â€œmatching the typeâ€ includes conditions matching on an ancestor of the factâ€™s type.
#2019-06-26Â 20:09:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ This improves performance when there are lots of rules - a fact doesnâ€™t have to be evaluated against rules that itsâ€™ type wonâ€™t allow it to match
#2019-06-26Â 20:10:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Thereâ€™s some tangentially related discussion of this at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_fn_perf/
#2019-06-26Â 20:36:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @misha also, there are alternatives to how you could structure a DSL over this - Clara just has this one as the default. It isnâ€™t necessarily trivial to extend things, but there are examples of at least datom-like datom support with https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav
#2019-06-27Â 11:50:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ Thanks, Mike and W. Reading into both clara and eav sources now. However I still have strong feeling, something clever can be figured out on top of â€œvanillaâ€ datalog (or very tightly coupled with). Eav seems to wrap clara, and only pretend to be datomic-like, in dsl layer. Iâ€™ll dig deeper into how attribute in conjunction with :aevt index can be used to pre-narrow down query space, as clara does with records-as-ruletypes
#2019-06-27Â 14:33:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @misha Clara implements a forward-chaining, Rete based, engine. Datalog I believe is backward-chaining and maybe based on something like miniKanren or something? Either way, they arenâ€™t the same. So thatâ€™s a correct observation.
#2019-06-27Â 14:33:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ And typically on this path, youâ€™ll have to consider the trade offs of the different styles of engine.
#2019-06-27Â 14:34:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I wasnâ€™t suggesting changing a DSL will change the fundamentals of the underlying engine for you there. It was just if you had EAV style data to represent as facts, and wanted to use them with a forward chaining engine.
#2019-06-27Â 14:47:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ does forward-chaining give any speed, or other guarantees/properties, which clara relies on explicitly (comparing to backward-chaining)?
#2019-06-27Â 15:56:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @misha I think thatâ€™s a more difficult question to answer succinctly. There are some papers out there that do discuss this exact topic (which I think we should work to link to in some Clara reference docs sometime soon). It looks like this paper https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/54af/b81b814acea73450430b4dabd0fc5c13732a.pdf and (a paper the above references) http://iips.icci.edu.iq/images/exam/artificial-intelligence-structures-and-strategies-for--complex-problem-solving.pdf section on â€œ3.2.1 Data-Driven and Goal-Driven Searchâ€ have some guidelines and more overview on the topic. I think there is a lot more out there than this though. The key concept being, â€¢ forward-chaining emphasizes the â€œdata-drivenâ€ approach - use available facts to see what all possible â€œend statesâ€/â€œgoalsâ€ can be reached â€¢ backward-chaining emphasizes the â€œgoal-drivenâ€ approach - see if there are available facts to support some desired â€œend stateâ€/â€œgoalâ€
#2019-06-27Â 15:57:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Since they emphasize a different desired solution finding paradigm, they tend to optimize better for that purpose
#2019-06-27Â 15:58:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Meaning, * forward-chaining is likely more performant, and also more natural, when you want the â€œdata-drivenâ€ approach. * backward-chaining is more performant, and also more natural, when you want the â€œgoal-drivenâ€ approach.
#2019-06-27Â 16:00:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are engines that do a blend of each at times too. Clara doesnâ€™t currently. An example of how where this could apply, is that a Clara style query (typically defined via defquery) could be utilized in a way where you perhaps could say (query session :?x 5) and the engine could potentially use a backward-chaining approach to arrive at that goal. Perhaps to reduce the search space/work done. Nothing like this exists right now. I think that in the later version of Drools (popular, Java-centric (currently)) Rete-style, forward-chaining rules engine, there was actually limited support of a somewhat backward-chaining approach to deriving query results.
#2019-06-27Â 16:01:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ however, if your main target is â€œgoal-driveâ€, itâ€™d likely still be best to use something centered around a full backward-chaining engine.
#2019-06-28Â 07:47:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ first paper link is $$$, thank you, Mike
#2019-06-28Â 07:54:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ (2nd link is probably golden too, but, man, 800pages kappa)
#2019-06-28Â 09:23:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Another point to consider is that since forward-chaining computes results upfront, applying diffs e.g. new facts can be quite fast once an initial "batch" has been completed.
#2019-06-28Â 09:50:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ I wonder if datomic's datalog is still implemented with backward chaining, given team recommends to put the most specific query clause first

#2019-06-28Â 10:09:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ so what I am actually trying to achieve/figure out, â€“ is how to sneak rule-based parasite system onto datomic/datascript, without any changes to user api, e.g.: there are d/q, d/transact, d/transact!, and I'd like the defrule to be just a composition of those from user point of view (with some cleverness under the hood, like extra working memory or knowledge base). For example, clara-eav seems to have lots of internals leaking out into user api, making it less and less looking like datomic/datascript, which people already are used to "dev-flow"-wise. One seemingly minor, but I think very important from usability/adoption point ov view â€“ is it is still dsl with custom tokens, which will be highlighted all over the ns as undefined in Cursive and probably some other IDE, on top of being yet another DSL you need to remember semantics of.
#2019-06-28Â 10:11:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ re dsl, from https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav#fact-dsl 
;; Clara fact syntax
[?eav <- :todo/text (= (:e this) :new)]
[?eav <- (a/all) :from [:eav/all (= (:e this) :new)]]

;; ClaraEAV fact syntax
[?eav <- [:new :todo/text]]
[?eav <- (a/all) :from [[:new]]]
#2019-06-28Â 10:15:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mishaÂ why this, if everyone is familiar with let-style bindings, and many libraries manage to represent domain-specific bindings with their custom let forms, eg: let for monads: https://github.com/funcool/cats/blob/master/src/cats/core.cljc#L233-L255 let for generators: https://github.com/clojure/test.check/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clojure/test/check/generators.cljc#L1590-L1630
#2019-07-01Â 16:13:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1561715419047500 I donâ€™t know the specifics here at all. But probably could still be backwards chaining and have something like this apply.
#2019-07-01Â 16:16:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1561716926057800 The syntax can be altered if you want an alternative dsl. The rules have a well defined data model. Itâ€™s not â€œjust letâ€ syntax since that would be awkward to make semantically work for more complex rules. Rules are about unification bindings etc. datalog isnâ€™t let-binding syntax either. Also Clara is aligning its default DSL syntax closer to the world of forward chaining rules engines that have existed for a long time.
#2019-07-01Â 16:17:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But your problem seems interesting @misha I donâ€™t have necessarily any easy answers there. First I would make sure the rules can express your problems that you try to solve. Then maybe worry more about blending it with a datalog syntax if thatâ€™s youâ€™re goal.
#2019-07-13Â 22:48:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â drewverleeÂ so rules engines model if then relationships and in the "then" part its easy to insert new facts or take abitrary actions on those facts. #2019-07-14Â 15:25:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @drewverlee similar to recent posts in this channel, I think you may be running up against the pros/cons of forward chaining rules (clara) and backwards chaining â€œparadigmâ€ in terms of what is best for what sort of situation.

#2019-08-04Â 14:53:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â hadilsÂ Hi! I am new to Clara. I am very excited to be using it, but I am having difficulty with debugging a rule: 
(defrule processed-transactions-rule
  [?account <- Account (= type :bank)]
  [TransactionSettings (= ?db db)]
  =>
  (insert-all! (get-processed-txs ?db ?account)))
The error I get is:

#2019-08-07Â 21:22:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.dixon in current version of Clara (and several before) the rule will not continue to propagate if the accumulated value hasnâ€™t changed according to = See lines like https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1200
#2019-08-07Â 21:24:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So specifically if the accumulators result from the :convert-return-fn is = to what it was in the previous round of accumulating fact matches, propagation stops - which would imply no RHS action being triggered/activated

#2019-08-08Â 00:26:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Think I hit another issue trying to update in place. I thought I could get away with it for unconditional facts, but it appears that when I have multiple LHS bindings on a rule that does a retract! followed by an insert-unconditional!, the RHS fires for all bindings, so the retracts all occur before other rules fire that would potentially invalidate the LHS on the first rule after a subset of firings, based on those retractions.
#2019-08-08Â 01:50:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @dave.dixon if you get into the business of doing unconditional things, youâ€™ll have to control rule order more. This can be done with salience and possibly â€œblockerâ€ fact patterns.
#2019-08-08Â 15:19:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ It seems like avoiding this sort of thing can be a guiding principle for data modeling. For example, the existence of an entity might be unconditional, but the facts describing that entity may have more detailed logical relationships. Trying to group those facts as attributes under a single entity fact map or record leads to the headaches I'm encountering. But maybe if I separate them so that they can be separately inserted/retracted, things will be cleaner. Giving clara-eav a try for this purpose.
#2019-08-28Â 13:10:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â griersonÂ Should I run side effectful things (database/email) in the RHS of a rule. Or should I insert a new fact, query the session, and do side effectfs based on the query result?
#2019-08-28Â 13:45:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The latter is recommended, Clara makes no promises on the number of times that the RHS will be executed before reaching steady state.

#2019-09-10Â 14:19:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ â€¢ clara is based around the rete algo which is a forward-chaining (ie data-driven) approach Good references for further reading: 1) https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/54af/b81b814acea73450430b4dabd0fc5c13732a.pdf 2) http://iips.icci.edu.iq/images/exam/artificial-intelligence-structures-and-strategies-for--complex-problem-solving.pdf (section 8.2 Rule-Based Expert Systems)
#2019-09-10Â 14:20:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can make some progress of course with inspection - you can see what did happen, and subtract that from all the rules you know exists to find which were left out
#2019-09-10Â 14:21:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you can also make more rules in some cases, perhaps even systematically (and programmatically) that try to capture the â€œnegativeâ€ cases
#2019-09-10Â 14:21:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ eg. if I have a rule rule a => insert b, then also make a rule rule not(a) => insert z
#2019-09-10Â 14:22:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ of course it can be more difficult than that with mult-condition joins, negation, and accumulators involved

#2019-11-05Â 20:41:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Object query is straightforward. Itâ€™s slow because it always is activated by all working memory changes
#2019-11-05Â 20:41:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ And remember to fire rules always before running query
#2019-11-05Â 20:41:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ They (can) do some batching/lazy stuff they may delay until fire rules.
#2019-11-05Â 20:43:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sashtonÂ Thanks!
#2019-11-05Â 22:04:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ On the subject of the query performance, something that may be counterintuitive is that the cost comes from the presence of the query in the rules session, not the query call itself. In essence when fire-rules is called the query results are computed. Agreed that a query on Object is the simplest way to get all facts in the session if the perf hit doesn't matter e.g. in testing.
#2019-11-05Â 22:05:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Assuming we're talking about JVM clojure, not sure offhand what the cljs equivalent would be.
#2019-11-13Â 13:51:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sashtonÂ Iâ€™m trying to figure out if there is a way to accumulate some joined data. I havenâ€™t been able to come up with a single rule which will fire with my desired output. In the following example, I am trying to answer the question, what is the sum of quantities for each name: 
(defrecord A [id name])
(defrecord B [id quantity])

(defrule merge-things
  ???
  =>
  (println ?name ?total-quanity))

(-> (mk-session)
    (insert (->A 1 "car"))
    (insert (->A 2 "truck"))
    (insert (->A 3 "car"))
    (insert (->B 1 2))
    (insert (->B 2 3))
    (insert (->B 3 5))
    (fire-rules))
I am trying to have that rule print out: 
car 7
truck 3
#2019-11-13Â 13:52:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sashtonÂ I havenâ€™t been able to come up with a ??? for that rule which works.
#2019-11-13Â 14:00:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sashtonÂ Well, duckie to the rescue. While typing this up, I found one way I hadnâ€™t tried. So now my question is, are there any problems with the following rule definition? (memory,performance,other,â€¦) It is different that other rules Iâ€™ve used. Not sure if using the accumulator and re-creating the set of ids â€” (set (map :id ?a)) â€” in the rule expression would cause any unexpected problems. 
(defrule merge-things
  [?a <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?name name)]]
  [?total-quantity <- (acc/sum :quantity) :from [B (get (set (map :id ?a)) id)]]
  =>
  (println ?name ?total-quantity))
#2019-11-14Â 18:36:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @sashton, Sorry for the delay. From my experience accumulators are relatively cheap with respect to memory/performance in scenarios where the state of the session that they are accumulating is relatively stable. Performance can degrade in the event that there are massive amounts of logical retractions due to truth maintenance, but it would be directly linked to the data in the session and other rules that may feed into this rule. To the second half, > Not sure if using the accumulator and re-creating the set of ids â€” (set (map :id ?a)) â€” in the rule expression would cause any unexpected problems. I believe that would require each B in the session to generate the set again, perhaps using the distinct accumulator instead might be â€˜betterâ€™. Any updates to A would also require this work to be redone. Something like: 
(defrule merge-things
  [?ids <- (acc/distinct :id) :from [A (= ?name name)]]
  [?total-quantity <- (acc/sum :quantity) :from [B (contains? ?ids id)]]
  =>
  (println ?name ?total-quantity))
In theory this would only have to recalculate the set when a new A was seen and then only if that return value changed then re evaluation of the B logic would have to occur. Then again all of this needs to be taken with a grain of salt as data scenarios can change the behavior of performance while executing rules.
#2019-11-14Â 18:44:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ insteresting error, I am using a private function inside the namespace of the rules and clara gave me the follow stacktrace 
#error {
 :cause var: #'secland.securities.contract-rules/now-in-inst is not public
 :via
 [{:type clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo
   :message Failed compiling alpha node...
#2019-11-14Â 18:44:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ I would like to understand more why
#2019-11-14Â 18:48:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @iagwanderson, Was the function was used inside the LHS of a rule?
#2019-11-14Â 18:50:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ nvm, i missed Failed compiling alpha node. So the answer to my question would be yes.
#2019-11-14Â 18:58:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The reason that this would occur would be due to how clara evaluates LHS/RHS. The LHS is assumed to be namespace agnostic, as nodes that make up the LHS(AlphaNodes, JoinNodes, ect.) could be shared across namespaces and rules in those namespaces, whereas the RHS(ProductionNodes) canâ€™t be shared and can be seen as Namespace bound. This means that Clara evaluates LHS nodes outside of the original namespace that they are defined within, and production nodes are evaluated within the namespace that they are defined. So, by having a private function within the LHS of a rule clara will cause an exception to be thrown due to illegal access. Iâ€™m not sure if that is documented anywhere, but it probably should beâ€¦ I will see if i can find any.
#2019-11-14Â 19:30:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ @ethanc thanks so much for the clear explanation, didn't find any explanation around it when I searched
#2019-11-14Â 19:32:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ I have a more general question about code organization
#2019-11-14Â 19:33:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ I have some rules that need to be run for specific clients and products, there is a recommended approach about how to organize the rules and the sessions for each situation?
#2019-11-14Â 19:33:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ I would like to enable some users to enable/disable a rule, so probably having a reference to it in a database
#2019-11-14Â 22:33:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I guess it would depend on your use-case, i think the way i would handle them would be treating a namespace as a â€œfeature packageâ€. Then a given client could enable features(sets of rules) by namespace, of course through some abstraction(wouldnâ€™t want consumers directly loading namespaces). That way when it comes to session creation you would only have to worry about loading a set of namespaces containing rules, ex 
(defn load-session 
  []
  (let [client-namespaces (get-namespaces-by-client)]
    <require namespaces if not already done>
    (com/mk-session client-namespaces)))
per rule filtering would probably be more tricky.
#2019-11-26Â 20:23:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ hi, @ethanc thanks for the answer

#2019-11-26Â 20:39:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s the underlying fn - just have to deal with some boilerplate with quotes etc
#2019-11-26Â 20:39:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s signature is slightly different
#2019-11-26Â 20:40:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ takes sequence of sources-and-options
#2019-11-26Â 20:40:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ sources expected to come first
#2019-11-26Â 20:40:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ then keyword options
#2019-11-26Â 20:40:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ example ['my.ns.name :my-option :foo]

Is that correct ? I think that makes sense, for changes outside of the session, you would have to manually update the fact inside the session via an external retract followed by insertion of the fact.

#2020-12-31Â 20:05:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Thank you, I'll check out.
#2020-12-31Â 20:09:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Sorry, thought this was related to my question...
#2020-12-31Â 20:54:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @U0516053R, I donâ€™t typically use the defsession macro, but it seems to me that it is building the call to mk-session differently. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L368 
(mk-session [:fact-type-fn :type])
vs 
(mk-session :fact-type-fn :type)
so the session in this case is empty(no productions) due to defsession not appending the current namespace.
#2020-12-31Â 20:57:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ To get this to work, 
(defsession session `app.mv.clara2 :fact-type-fn :type)
the namespace would have to be provided
#2020-01-01Â 01:38:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â geraldodevÂ @U3KC48GHW Thank you!. I've started with (def session (mk-session . Later I've switched to defsession. Also I was trying to infer changes on the sql table based on the primary key. The plan was to baby sit the session like an atom. I've stumbled across a issue that shows that clara ignores facts that are not touched by rules and queries. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/48 . I was intending to use it wrong. It looks like reading the table, insert the facts and collect the results and let the session go way is a more correct approach..
#2020-01-06Â 19:55:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Eduardo MataÂ I am applying a basic rule saying

[?event <- Event (nil? flower-id) (= ?id _id)]

#2020-01-06Â 19:56:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Eduardo MataÂ for some reason, I have a Record with flower-id and it clara still telling me the flower-id is missing
#2020-01-06Â 20:18:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @contact904 do you have more than one Event? #2020-01-07Â 14:32:01Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ Hi all, I want to serialize/deserialize the working-memory separately so I started off by using a simple implementation for IWorkingMemorySerializer that serializes to an atom (as per Clara's docs) and deserializing from the atom by derefing it. That works perfectly fine, in that I am able to run queries and get the same results from both the original and deserialized session. However, if I add the extra step to write to fressian and read fressian to the ser/deserializer of the IWorkingMemorySerializer , all queries in the deserialized version of the session return with nil: eg. ({:?crn nil}) while the same query on the original is returning ({:?crn {:fact-type :client-representative-notification, :name "Alice", :client "Acme", :level :high}}) . I should note that I am fairly new to clara rules. Has anyone come across something like this before?
#2020-01-07Â 15:09:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @konstantinos562, Do you have a small snippet, it would help me reproduce it locally?
#2020-01-07Â 15:12:24Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ Hi @ethanc do you need the rules as well?
#2020-01-07Â 15:13:08Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ 
(defrecord WorkingMemoryAtomSerializer [input output]
  d/IWorkingMemorySerializer
  (serialize-facts [_ facts]
    (reset! state (write-fressian facts)))
  (deserialize-facts [this]
    (-> @state io/input-stream read-fressian)))
#2020-01-07Â 15:14:12Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ with (def state (atom nil)) in the namespace
#2020-01-07Â 15:14:36Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ and the read and write fressian as follows
#2020-01-07Â 15:14:40Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ 
(defn write-fressian [obj]
  (let [baos (ByteArrayOutputStream.)
        wr   (frz/create-writer baos)]
    (frz/write-object wr obj)
    (.toByteArray baos)))

(defn read-fressian [b]
  (-> b frz/create-reader frz/read-object))
#2020-01-07Â 15:14:47Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ sorry for the long posting all
#2020-01-07Â 15:15:50Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ NB: I have replaced fressian with nippy/freeze and nippy/thaw and it works perfectly fine now. I am not sure what the issue was (most probably I am doing something wrong there)
#2020-01-07Â 15:16:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @konstantinos562 not sure what frz ns is referring to
#2020-01-07Â 15:16:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You may just not have setup good read/write handlers for your facts

#2020-01-07Â 15:16:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ or they will cause many clj data structures to become Java structures - or not the same as before

#2020-01-07Â 15:17:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ however, there really is no compelling reason to not just use nippy if you have it set up
#2020-01-07Â 15:18:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I wouldnâ€™t have used Fressian to impl Claraâ€™s session serialization if I were to do it again today. it is difficult to work with in what it provides by default and I donâ€™t think it is any better than something like nippy or perhaps a few others. It is also not documented super well and at the â€œprimitiveâ€ level makes some unavoidable Java collections that are awkward to convert from (and also wasting perf time)

#2020-01-10Â 11:25:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ I was thinking in this API: 
(defrecord Values [id])

  (defrule testing->include
    [?value <- Values [v] (= ?id (:id v))]
    =>
    (println "INCLUDING!!! " ?value))

  (defrule testing->exclude
    [?value <- Values [v] (= ?id (:id v))]
    =>
    (println "EXCLUDING!!! " ?value))

  
  (def session-without (rl/mk-session 'clara.rules.compiler/testing->include
                                      'clara.rules.compiler/testing->exclude
                                      :blacklist ['clara.rules.compiler/testing->exclude]))

#2020-01-10Â 09:30:41Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ Hi all, I'm back ðŸ™‚ . Sorry for the several questions and thank you very much for all your prompt and very helpful responses; it's been very enjoyable working with Clara. I am progressing very well in building up the ruling system in Clara however I am getting some OOMs when I surpass a certain number of facts in my application. My application has around 15 rules, some of which are fired by others, and the facts may well range between 300k - 2m, but when I go closer to the upper end I get OOMs. So, I thought that it may be reasonable to run a few benchmark tests (and maybe start profiling?). I tried the clara-benchmark repository and experimented a bit with the AccumInsert test; in this I've played with the number of Customers, setting it from 250k to 10m. I noticed that on my machine, Clara threw an OOM above 5m facts. I was wondering whether you have a direction to suggest on methods to cut down such costs? In my application the first try was to chop the initial facts only to the absolutely necessary fields required (I am using clojure maps as extracted from a DB) but without luck. Thank you all in advance!
#2020-01-10Â 13:49:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @konstantinos562 2m facts themself would be quite a memory burden in the jvm I think. If itâ€™s just memory issues is the heap space youâ€™re giving enough?
#2020-01-10Â 13:50:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can use a profiler to look more at the memory layout but Clara will certainly take more space than those 2m facts since it has working memory structure it uses on top of what they already take alone. And if you have rules inserting facts based on them.
#2020-01-10Â 13:51:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The benchmark stuff would be more aimed at execution time. Which isnâ€™t too useful if youâ€™re running out of memory. If itâ€™s slow itâ€™s probably due to GC thrashing before OOM
#2020-01-10Â 13:52:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Or at least thatâ€™d hide any other perf issues.

#2020-01-10Â 13:55:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But the diagnosing the issue will also come down to what youâ€™re rules are doing. #2020-01-10Â 13:55:36Â Konstantinos TzanidakisÂ but will note this with VisualVM

#2020-01-10Â 14:01:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah to not have them all in memory at once I think youâ€™d have to be a bit careful.
#2020-01-10Â 14:02:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not sure something like insert-all would be careful enough within Clara. Would probably have to like near N number at a time, then fire rules. Then repeat the next batch
#2020-01-10Â 14:03:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But if they are mostly matching or even â€œpartial matchingâ€ rules they will be held in memory. So it can be brittle
#2020-01-10Â 14:03:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ A fact is held in memory if it can even â€œpotentiallyâ€ be used to satisfy a rule later. Thatâ€™s the â€œpartial matchâ€

#2020-01-10Â 22:04:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ Uhmm... Ok. I will make this change.
#2020-01-13Â 13:08:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ For some background, in Clojure Clara can create sessions on the fly using eval, while in ClojureScript sessions have to be defined at compilation time typically using a call to defsession at the top level. The dynamic session building in Clojure ultimately uses eval, which is why it doesn't work in ClojureScript. Defsession-test essentially makes the static session building in ClojureScript tests look more dynamic without needing to create tons of top-level defs etc.
#2020-01-13Â 23:33:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ interesting!! #2020-01-13Â 13:33:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Is there something in particular that looks strange to you?
#2020-01-13Â 22:21:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ the default indentation looks like this:
#2020-01-13Â 22:21:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ 
(defrule rule->legacy-contract?
  "Add a Legacy fact into the session if the contract was sent with this status."
  [?contract <- Contract [ct] (= ?principal-external-id (:contract/principal-external-id ct))
   (= :legacy (:contract/status ct))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Legacy ?principal-external-id)))
#2020-01-13Â 22:22:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ and I have to manually change it to: 
(defrule rule->legacy-contract?
  "Add a Legacy fact into the session if the contract was sent with this status."
  [?contract <- Contract [ct] (= ?principal-external-id (:contract/principal-external-id ct))
                              (= :legacy (:contract/status ct))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Legacy ?principal-external-id)))
#2020-01-13Â 23:34:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bartukaÂ sometimes I need to use M-x align-regexp (= to align the conditions
#2020-01-15Â 12:23:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mbraggÂ Hi. Im evaluating potentially using Clara for one of our use cases. Can you imagine a sensible way to be able to determine the start-time and end-time of a given rule execution? Say I have a rule that has some expensive operationâ€¦ Iâ€™d like to be able to record when it started and ended, ideally without adding the required code to the rule itself and adding the values to the emitted fact (as it would be great if all rules exposed this information implicitly). Iâ€™ve started looked into: â€¢ The inspect + trace tools dont seem to provide it â€¢ Creating a new Listener, but this may be a bad idea given it would no longer be immutable if its calling out for the current time? â€¢ Creating a macro and extend the parsing logic to wrap the rule execution somehow Any thoughts / suggestions appreciated. Many thanks
#2020-01-15Â 17:10:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mbragg I donâ€™t think itâ€™s as straightforward as perhaps it seems. Rules arenâ€™t the same as something like a fn body that you can time
#2020-01-15Â 17:10:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The rules are structures that are used to create a rete based data flow tree (forest really)
#2020-01-15Â 17:12:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Some examples of the complexity: (1) In some cases LHS conditions from separate rules may end up being shared as one common node in this tree. (2) rule conditions are nodes on the tree. They have varying degrees of eager vs lazy behavior. In most cases, the engine tries to batch facts up prior to evaluation of conditions
#2020-01-15Â 17:13:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ (3) before fire-rules happens a certain degree of evaluation takes place. Once fire-rules happens more work is done but always oriented towards batched fact propagation.
#2020-01-15Â 17:14:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The inspection/trace stuff can be useful to get a sense of how many times a condition is being evaluated/matched. This tends to just give a relative â€œcountâ€ to compare and often find the outliers.
#2020-01-15Â 17:16:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But overall. The rules are more like â€œsql query structuresâ€ where they are then compiled to a network, like the â€œdb eval planâ€
#2020-01-15Â 17:16:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So the concerns tend to be things like how many times is this â€œjoin conditionâ€ being evaluated given some facts.
#2020-01-15Â 17:19:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ With profiling you can find actually hot spot functions which sometimes end up being a fn used in a condition that is being evaluated a large number of times: 
[MyFact (my-fn ...)]
If that condition has a large number of matches you may profile and see my-fn is a hot spot and looking to be a perf issue.
#2020-01-15Â 17:46:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mbraggÂ Thanks @mikerod for the explanation, makes sense. I guess I was specifically meaning everything in the RHS do block for a given rule. But I can see it may not be that straight forward... especially if thereâ€™s batching involved.
#2020-01-15Â 22:42:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ In case a concrete demonstration helps for clarity, the rule RHS calls like insert! add things to a cache that will be processed later (the details of that probably arenâ€™t super important here), the default implementation of which is in this file: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/update_cache/core.cljc Itâ€™s certainly possible to have a poorly-performing function called in a rule, for which profiling with something like VisualVM can be useful, but a simple timer isnâ€™t necessarily much help with diagnosing poorly performing rules networks as Mike has elaborated on.
#2020-01-16Â 16:08:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mbraggÂ Thanks @U0KRSVDHR
#2020-01-15Â 17:49:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mbragg the RHS is easier to time at least
#2020-01-15Â 17:49:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I mean you can wrap that fairly easily - but still the time it takes to do the insert! sort of functions is where the batching happens
#2020-01-15Â 17:49:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so you if youâ€™re RHS is: 
(insert! (->Something ?x))
timing it wonâ€™t necessarily tell you much
#2020-01-15Â 17:50:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ that same RHS may end up being activated N times - so it evaluates N times, and you have N insert! calls all batched, so no fact is actually inserted right away until a later cycle
#2020-01-15Â 17:51:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the batching is very useful from a perf standpoint too - but does complicate timing things
#2020-01-15Â 18:42:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mbraggÂ @mikerod ok understood. It think Iâ€™m going to suggest that this â€œrule timingâ€ requirement is something we drop if we go with Clara, as it sounds like it doesnâ€™t really make sense... in the way they are imagining rules being executed anyway. Thanks for all your help

(defrule my-rule
=>
(insert! (->MyFact `my-rule))

#2020-01-15Â 19:05:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ however, you can always opt to make your own macro
#2020-01-15Â 19:06:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ defrule itself is just a macro and rules and queries in Clara are all modeled in a data-oriented data structure underneath that alternative DSLâ€™s can be written to produce (via macros typically)
#2020-01-15Â 19:06:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ OK. A macro implementation might be in line for me too.

#2020-01-15Â 19:08:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ an old (and probably no longer able to run examples) post, that did give a good overview of alterantive DSLâ€™s http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ just for reference if that concept is something you find further interest in - you donâ€™t really need it for this small case
#2020-01-15Â 19:11:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t see anything built-in as of now

#2020-01-16Â 04:33:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @matthew.pettis you can pass a collection of rules and queries
#2020-01-16Â 04:33:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So a vector yes
#2020-01-16Â 04:34:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you pass an ns name itâ€™ll be automatically expanded to a collection of all rules sources within it
#2020-01-16Â 04:34:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Rule sources are defined by a protocol
#2020-01-16Â 04:35:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are a few more built in impls but those are the main 2
#2020-01-16Â 04:36:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ And â€œruleâ€ is a bit overloaded here unfortunately since it includes queries. Clara typically calls them â€œproductionsâ€ when referring generally to both.
#2020-01-21Â 03:09:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Are there any examples out there that show how to define a session in the namespace project.a, define facts in namespace project.b , rules in project.c , and how to import b and c into a to fire rules on them? #2020-01-21Â 03:11:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ My two files which fails (I"m looking only at importing rules for this examples, not yet facts):
#2020-01-21Â 03:11:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ The session namespace...
#2020-01-21Â 03:12:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ The rule namespace I want to import from...
#2020-01-21Â 03:21:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ The error I get:
#2020-01-21Â 03:29:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @matthew.pettis I believe you would want to import the fact into the namespace where the rule is using it: 
(ns clara-lein.ex06rulesns
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all] 
            [clara-lein.ex06 :as ex06])
  (:import [clara-lein.ex06 Myfact]))
;; Rules namespace for rules for ex06.
;; Define rules
(defrule rule-1
  "Rule-1 in rulesns"
  [Myfact (= ?size size)]
  [:test (> 1 ?size)]
  =>
  (insert! (ex06/->Rulefail "rule-1" ?size)))
Though this might lead to issues with cyclical dependencies, with the session ns and rules ns. It might be practical to pull the fact definitions out into a separate ns so that they can be pulled by both ns without the possibility of a cycle.
#2020-01-21Â 03:35:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Thank you! If I copy and pasted this correctly, when i run (require 'clara-lein.ex06rulesns) in clara-lein.ex06 , I get an error that No namespace: clara-lein.ex06rulesns found. I'll keep poking, but that's my current error...
#2020-01-21Â 03:35:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ ... and that's when I run the final let that creates the session...
#2020-01-21Â 03:37:21Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ oops, I take that back. When I run that require statement, I get a ClassNotFound exception for clara-lein.ex06.Myfact.
#2020-01-21Â 16:20:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ So, I was able to make this work if I included all of the defrecords, rules, queries, and facts in a different namespace, referred that namespace, and then made a session with mk-session 'source.namespace) . However, I am struggling to modularize this, so that I can make a session where facts come from one namespace, rules from another namespace, and queries from yet another namespace. I'm not sure if it is the namespace inclusion-ing that I am messing up, or that I don't know the proper syntax on mk-session or insert to build up a session that has facts, rules, and queries from these sources in it. An pointing to examples of rules that has that would be appreciated. I am doing this as an exercise to show that you can make a modular rules system and that clara-rules can support that modularity. Which is why I'm making a toy example that is doing this... thanks in advance...
#2020-01-21Â 16:59:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @matthew.pettis there are no special evaluation rules being done by Clara. You have to appropriately require all nsâ€™s you depend on in the order they depend on each other via standard clj :require
#2020-01-21Â 17:00:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You can have things in as many nsâ€™s as you want.
#2020-01-21Â 17:00:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ If you show your example I maybe can help. Iâ€™m confused what you are using to get into a situation you are describing at this point.
#2020-01-21Â 17:26:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ @mikerod Thanks for the help! I pushed a repo here of example code that doesn't quite work, but has the rules, facts, and queries in separate namespaces. The part is at the end of the core.clj file, where I assemble a session out of the facts, rules, and queries, to be able to query the session. https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex
#2020-01-21Â 19:42:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ First just style Notes: In clara-ns-ex.core, typically all :require are in one spec, but I guess what you have can work? I havenâ€™t actually tested in recent clj: 
(ns clara-ns-ex.core
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]
            [clara-ns-ex.facts :refer :all]
            [clara-ns-ex.rules :refer :all]
            [clara-ns-ex.queries :refer :all]))
Instead of 
fact-sess (apply insert query-sess facts)
use insert-all 
fact-sess (insert-all query-sess facts)
just since there is API to make you not need to use apply with varargs.
#2020-01-21Â 19:43:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Second (most important): You donâ€™t insert rules and queries. These are needed upfront at mk-session time. Clara actually does not support dynamically adding or removing rules/queries at all right now. It may be a future potential to add, but there are perf benefits to not doing so. Even if it did allow that later though, you wouldnâ€™t â€œinsert rulesâ€. insert is meant for facts, not rules.
#2020-01-21Â 19:43:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ what youâ€™d need to do for your example is: 
init-sess (mk-session 'clara-ns-ex.core 'clara-ns-ex.rules 'clara-ns-ex.queries)
if you just wanted to automatically include all rules/queries defined in those namespaces.
#2020-01-21Â 21:00:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ OK, this is super-helpful, thank you so much! I will try these changes as soon as possible.
#2020-01-21Â 21:04:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ I was not aware that rules and queries could not be dynamically added. It is nice to see an example of mk-session with multiple namepaces put in there. I wasn't sure if it was as a varargs or as a vector of namespaces, etc.

#2020-01-22Â 02:29:12Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So you require the ns that defines the records - to ensure it is compiled.

#2020-01-22Â 04:21:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ I have the import statements, I tested that it worked. #2020-01-22Â 04:39:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ OK, I got it to work by playing with what did and did not need namespace qualified names, and where. I don't fully understand the rules of when I should and should not yet, but I have a working example to go off of, so thanks for all of your help! #2020-01-22Â 09:41:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Looks like you've got it figured out mostly. :). You don't need the fact class imports in your core namespace, but rather just in the rule/query namespaces that use them. Clara rule and query defs use the same evaluation semantics as normal Clojure code, that is something used, be it a function, class, etc. needs to be resolvable in the namespace where the rule/query is being defined. Also it's somewhat a matter of personal preference, but I find it more clear where things are coming from when I use :as aliases rather than :refer :all, that might help reduce confusion.
#2020-01-22Â 09:43:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Admittedly there's a fair amount of code in Clara dealing with that evaluation, but the end result is to have the same user-facing semantics.
#2020-01-22Â 12:54:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Awesome! I'll take out the require and import statements in core and use :as aliases in the rest and push a cleaner example. Thanks for the help.
#2020-01-22Â 13:48:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I also advocate for :as aliases too. It helps to make it clear where symbols are coming from. ClojureScript doesnâ€™t even have :refer :all support! Hah
#2020-01-22Â 14:06:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ I just discovered 'how to ns' by Sierra, reading that to guide me on that: https://stuartsierra.com/2016/clojure-how-to-ns.html

#2020-01-22Â 14:32:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ OK, just for completeness and posterity... For this question, which was how to use namespaced rules, queries, and facts in making a session, I cleaned up the namespace declaration, using Sierra's "how to ns" style recommendations, and removed most :require :refer :all statements to be more precise (except for clara-rules). Here is the commit that is cleaned up per this comment: https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex/tree/8b78de1442fd8484341cc68d6ac63b7d78cf85e4

#2020-02-07Â 21:14:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Because it occurs to me that rules like this are just like basic syllogisms (which I'm sure others have observed long before me here) I put together a dead-simple example of making the rules engine do modus ponens from basic propositional logic. https://github.com/mpettis/clara-lien/blob/master/src/clara_lein/ex07.clj
#2020-02-07Â 21:36:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I donâ€™t believe that the rhs should be wrapped in a vector, https://github.com/mpettis/clara-lien/blob/master/src/clara_lein/ex07.clj#L28
#2020-02-07Â 21:43:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ my reasoning with this nit is, that the clara wraps the rhs inside a fn and executes it when the lhs is satisfied. basically something like: 
(fn [bindings] 
  <original form>)
The inserts! would be considered stateful as the operate on the active session, thus the example still works its just the vector is superfluous. I am just being nit picky though
#2020-02-07Â 21:44:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ this is good... i was getting some wierd nested results when I ran (but still had right answers). I'll remove and see if that does what's expected; i didn't notice I had wrapped that...
#2020-02-07Â 22:39:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ ... guess i'm a little surprised it worked in the original, now that I see it...
#2020-02-07Â 23:21:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I should add that clara also wraps the RHS form in a do when you use defrule. 
(fn [bindings] 
  (do 
     <form>))
Since clara doesnâ€™t use the returned value from this function, it doesnâ€™t really make a difference, clojure will gladly return a vector with whatever insert! returns. Which is promptly ignored by clara ðŸ™‚
#2020-02-08Â 18:26:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ fixed and pushed.

#2020-02-10Â 00:18:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Documentation question: from this page (http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/), in the defrule structure flow has an optional props token. I can't find anywhere in the documentation that talks about what that actually is. Can anyone point me to what that is?
#2020-02-10Â 16:16:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ The primary property used currently is salience, which allows users to control the order in which rules fire. Usually it shouldnâ€™t be necessary, but sometimes is useful either for performance optimization or when rules opt out of truth maintenance (by using unconditional insertions and/or RHS retractions). The latter tends to make things more complicated in my experience, but sometimes can be useful/necessary
#2020-02-10Â 16:41:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ OK, thank you, this is nice to know.

#2020-04-02Â 11:40:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ BTW I think that I have a very interesting use case for Clara rules, once done ill share it but I'm very excited about it
#2020-04-02Â 14:19:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Hi Clara team, is there an option to run a query that matches any fact? for example: 
(defquery get-failures [] 
    (?f <- [_ true]))
Assuming that the first value in the vector is not important we only care for the second true value
#2020-04-02Â 14:20:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Or alternatively: 
(defquery get-failures [] 
    (?f <- _ (= ?failure true)))
#2020-04-02Â 14:22:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ (looks like ancestors-fn might be useful in such a case?)
#2020-04-02Â 14:26:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ A rule/query that has a fact type of Object would find all facts
#2020-04-02Â 14:36:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ In my case I'm using a keyword as the fact type, if I understand this correctly (ancestors :foo) is nil so Object dosent capture this?
#2020-04-02Â 14:36:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ 
(defquery get-failures [] 
    (?f <- Object (= ?failure true)))
#2020-04-02Â 14:37:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Sounds like I need to use an actual clojure keys hierarchy?
#2020-04-02Â 14:46:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ ah when using a custom fact-type-fn i think the only reliable way to achieve this would be to also provide a matching custom ancestors-fn
#2020-04-02Â 14:47:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Makes sense, ill continue to fiddle with it

#2020-04-04Â 23:45:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â rainbow_bambooÂ Hi :) I've been working on a website to cite data about the pandemic, http://coronavirus-charts.org . Underneath it uses clara rules to generate HTML charts... (A full writeup on the project https://devpost.com/software/coronavirus-charts-org and the source code https://github.com/rainbow-bamboo/coronavirus-charts/ ) any help, advice or feedback is welcome :)
#2020-04-05Â 22:39:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @ada this looks interesting! Cool to see clara being used some underneath this.
#2020-04-16Â 15:42:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Hi Clara team just wanted to share my use which is using Clara rules for provisioning https://github.com/re-ops/re-core/blob/re-flow/src/re_flow/core.clj, the ability to combine different flows easily while getting the computation graph for free is amazing, trying to implement this with procedural if/else or state machines would have resulted with much less composeable and brittle code. To be able to just query and see why a flow has failed is just the icing on the cake ;) Thank you for the hard work!

#2020-05-02Â 22:11:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ I'm new to Clara Rules. I have been trying to write a rule for a board game, but I haven't been able to do it. The rule in English is: During a player's turn, at the stage of the turn called :into-city, the player will move into the city if either there are no other players in the city, or if there is just one player in the city and the total number of players is more than four. I have these fact types: 
(defrecord Player [id name health score energy])
(defrecord Turn [id stage])
(defrecord InCity [id])
InCity just means that a player is in the city. Turn keeps track of whose turn it is and at what stage the player is in his turn. Player just represents a player. I tried this: 
(cr/defrule into-city
  [?turn <- Turn (= ?id id) (= :into-city stage)]
  [?players <- (acc/count) :from [Player]]
  [?in-city <- (acc/count) :from [InCity]]
  ;; (or (zero? ?in-city
  ;;            (and (= 1 ?in-city)
  ;;                 (> ?players 4))))
  =>
  (cr/retract! ?turn)
  (cr/insert! (->Turn ?id (next-stage :into-city)))
  (cr/insert! (->InCity ?id)))
But of course that part of the condition with "if either there are no other players in the city, or if there is just one player in the city and the total number of players is more than 4" is missing. I have commented out an expression that I tried to put in there somehow. But I'm not sure where to put that. As far as I have seen, conditions apply to individual facts, and I'm not sure if I can put in another condition line with just boolean logic. Can I? Also, since, as you can see, I'm retracting the Turn fact that led to the new facts being inserted, because now the stage of the turn is the next stage, and so the inserted facts will be instantly retracted, right? So how should I think about it? I'm finding it harder than I anticipated to write a program with rules.
#2020-05-03Â 17:18:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ To: > As far as I have seen, conditions apply to > individual facts, and I'm not sure if I can put in another > condition line with just boolean logic. Can I? yes, clara represents this as an underlying join of the two facts. You could also do this in a "test" condition: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ For: > Also, since, as you can see, I'm retracting the Turn fact > that led to the new facts being inserted, because now the > stage of the turn is the next stage, and so the inserted > facts will be instantly retracted, right? So how should I > think about it? As you alluded to, truth maintenance(http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/) would kick in when retracting the fact, meaning that this rule would likely cause a loop to occur. I've never really thought about modeling game state management in clara, but i would wonder if the retract is necessary.
#2020-05-03Â 19:56:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ I discovered that there is insert-unconditional too, maybe I can use that
#2020-05-03Â 19:56:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ Thanks
#2020-05-04Â 01:17:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @oskarkv maybe related http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html
#2020-05-07Â 16:38:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ Thanks!
#2020-05-07Â 16:46:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ 
(cr/defquery my-query
  [:?x :?y]
  [?p <- (acc/all) :from [Player]])

(defn oktest []
  (-> (cr/mk-session)
    (cr/insert (->Player 0 0 0))
    (cr/insert (->Player 1 2 3))
    cr/fire-rules
    (cr/query my-query :?x 0 :?y 0)))
This does not produce any results. But if I use ?x and ?y in the query, e.g. (= ?x x) and same for y then it does produce results. This is kind of surprising since in normal functions one doesn't have to use the args. Is there any particular reason for this? Same if I remove the arguments :?x and :?y from the query but keep them in the call to cr/query, then the query doesn't produce any results. Also a bit confusing.
#2020-05-07Â 16:57:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ And apparently this doesn't work. I'm confused about queries. 
(cr/defquery my-query
  [:?x :?y]
  [?p <- (acc/all) :from [Player (> x ?x) (> y ?y)]])

(defn oktest []
  (-> (cr/mk-session)
    (cr/insert (->Player 1 1 1))
    (cr/insert (->Player 2 2 2))
    cr/fire-rules
    (cr/query my-query :?x 0 :?y 0)))

#2020-05-07Â 17:31:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ So with (= x ?x) I get results if I pass in the correct arguments. With (> x ?x) I get an error. #2020-05-07Â 17:52:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ

with no ?x or ?y in body

with no argsvector

#2020-05-07Â 19:53:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @oskarkv I will take a look at this in a bit. My gut reaction as to why this isnâ€™t acting as expected is due to the implementation of how queries are executed directly on claraâ€™s internal memory.
#2020-05-07Â 22:04:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™d be interesting if itâ€™s not working for non =.
#2020-05-07Â 22:05:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Perhaps that was its original intent though
#2020-05-07Â 22:43:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I was under the assumption that queries never support heavier logic than equality, as its the job of the rules to do more complex filtering and joining logicâ€¦ Might be a poor assumption on my part but it sure seems like bound variables are the contract
#2020-05-07Â 22:44:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ at least in its current implementation
#2020-05-08Â 00:17:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thatâ€™s probably accurate
#2020-05-08Â 00:24:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ Ok looking at this, I would say that clara.rules/query(https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L47-L57) could use a bit of validation on the args. As the user provides both the query and key/values to query already it should be pretty straight forward to determine if the map of arguments match that of the params on the query itself. similar to how we validate that the query is in rulebase today: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1976 a disjunction between the keys of the params provided and params on the node itself(https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L432) in the event that the user provided more/less the query behaves quite differently as demonstrated in the examples provided. This simply comes down to the implementation of query itself: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1978
#2020-05-08Â 00:25:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ as it uses bindings to retrieve the tokens from memory
#2020-05-08Â 00:26:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ so the assumption i mentioned above is technically true, and has to be true as it would be inforced by the behavior of the memory
#2020-05-08Â 15:50:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I have logged: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/454 for the conversation above. Please feel free to add Comments/Concerns, it seems pretty straight forward and if i get time this weekend i might knock it out
#2020-05-08Â 17:09:42Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ I'm not completely sure I understand everything you said. Can I only use = in query constraints?
#2020-05-08Â 19:37:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ yes
#2020-05-08Â 19:42:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ in the context of the query 
(= ?x x)
is defining a binding of :?x, when querying the memory of a session the bindings of the query denoted by the query parameters are used. meaning a defquery like: 
(defquery some-query
  [:?x]
  [?a <- SomeFact (= ?x x) (= ?y y)])
would use: 
{:?x <val>}
to retrieve the values of the query from the session.
#2020-05-08Â 19:43:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ where value is provided from the clara.rule/query function like: 
(r/query session some-query :?x 42)
#2020-05-08Â 19:48:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ however today clara allows arbitrary values to be provided to the query, like: 
(r/query session some-query :?x 42 :?v 1 :?w 2)
this causes the retrieval from memory to miss tokens as it simply assumes that all values passed are valid bindings.
#2020-05-13Â 10:50:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â oskarkvÂ When using :exists, adding a binding variable changes the behaviour of the rule, making it trigger more times. For example (only difference being ?i <- in more): 
(cr/defrule more
  [?p <- Player (= id ?id)]
  [:exists [?i <- Item (= id ?id)]]
  =>
  (println "more" ?p))

(cr/defrule less
  [?p <- Player (= id ?id)]
  [:exists [Item (= id ?id)]]
  =>
  (println "less" ?p))
prints: 
more #claraz.rules.Player{:id 2, :y 2}
more #claraz.rules.Player{:id 1, :y 1}
more #claraz.rules.Player{:id 2, :y 2}
more #claraz.rules.Player{:id 1, :y 1}
more #claraz.rules.Player{:id 1, :y 1}
less #claraz.rules.Player{:id 2, :y 2}
less #claraz.rules.Player{:id 1, :y 1}
I find that a bit unintuitive. Is it supposed to be this way?
#2020-05-13Â 13:19:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @oskarkv I think itâ€™s invalid to do a â€œfact bindingâ€ on an :exists
#2020-05-13Â 13:19:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Now that I see that syntax, makes me wonder why it works
#2020-05-13Â 13:25:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So basically, I think more is invalid - but I guess it isnâ€™t being checked well
#2020-05-13Â 13:25:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t understand how it could have any semantically meaningful compilation result
#2020-05-13Â 13:25:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ :exists in general does not allow you to access the fact that â€œexistsâ€
#2020-05-13Â 13:25:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ because it isnâ€™t meaningful directly - there could be more than one
#2020-05-13Â 13:26:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you need to have an actual fact - and I suppose any fact will do for you - you should use an accumulator
#2020-05-13Â 13:27:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ 
[?items <- (acc/all) :from [Item ...]]
=>
;; choose one here
... (first ?items) ...
#2020-05-13Â 13:28:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ In your case, you may be thinking that in your domain there is exactly 1 match or no matches. However, the rules do not know this
#2020-05-13Â 13:29:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I do find the situation where the syntax is allowing this fact binding to be put inside the :exists condition to be something to be addressed though
#2020-05-30Â 17:16:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Hi Clara team, iv been trying to use Clara rules within a graalvm native image and iv managed to compile it however its failing during runtime on the use of eval, is there an option iv missed to not use eval? (compile the rules ahead of time) https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L223 
[{:type clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo
   :message Failed compiling alpha node
{:expr (clojure.core/fn [?__fact__ ?__env__] (clojure.core/let [{:keys [?wildcard]} ?__fact__ ?__bindings__ (clojure.core/atom {:?e ?__fact__})] (clojure.core/let [?wildcard true] (clojure.core/swap! ?__bindings__ clojure.core/assoc :?wildcard ?wildcard) (clojure.core/deref ?__bindings__)))), :condition {:type :grant.rules/user-spec, :constraints [(= ?wildcard true)], :args [{:keys [?wildcard]}], :fact-binding :?e}, :env nil}

   :data {:expr (clojure.core/fn [?__fact__ ?__env__] (clojure.core/let [{:keys [?wildcard]} ?__fact__ ?__bindings__ (clojure.core/atom {:?e ?__fact__})] (clojure.core/let [?wildcard true] (clojure.core/swap! ?__bindings__ clojure.core/assoc :?wildcard ?wildcard) (clojure.core/deref ?__bindings__)))), :condition {:type :grant.rules/user-spec, :constraints [(= ?wildcard true)], :args [{:keys [?wildcard]}], :fact-binding :?e}, :env nil}
   :at [clara.rules.compiler$try_eval invokeStatic compiler.clj 238]}
  {:type clojure.lang.Compiler$CompilerException
   :message Syntax error compiling at (grant/rules.clj:15:0).
   :data {:clojure.error/phase :compile-syntax-check, :clojure.error/line 15, :clojure.error/column 0, :clojure.error/source grant/rules.clj}
   :at [clojure.lang.Compiler analyzeSeq Compiler.java 7115]}

   :message clojure.lang.PersistentHashMap
   :at [com.oracle.svm.core.hub.ClassForNameSupport forName ClassForNameSupport.java 60]}]
 :trace
 [[com.oracle.svm.core.hub.ClassForNameSupport forName ClassForNameSupport.java 60]

  [clojure.lang.RT classForName RT.java 2211]

#2020-05-30Â 18:05:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @narkisr Currently there is no such flag to disable eval, that mainly comes down to the fact that we have to evaluate user provided functions(RHS) and generated functions from the LHS of rules on the fly. Otherwise the forms produced by larger sessions would likely exceed some of the constraints of generated code sizes set by java. I am curious as to the use-case, are you AOT compiling the sessions themselves or are you trying to generate the sessions during runtime? I know @mikerod has been trying to untangle eval from rule compilation, but i believe that has been focused on Cljs as clara has been doing that wrong.
#2020-05-30Â 18:15:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Cljs is closer to meeting that sort of requirement. The clj impl would not be easy to make happen. Unless it also went through a macro expansion type cljs like flow. Then again. I donâ€™t even know exactly the constraints weâ€™d have to use graal for this
#2020-05-30Â 18:15:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™m guessing if macros could expand to code that avoided any eval and all fn instantiations were done via the compiler directly from the expanded code itâ€™d work. Which is basically what cljs has to do
#2020-05-30Â 18:16:15Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But only my current side branch of cljs at the moment. And itâ€™s not functional yet.

#2020-06-08Â 13:33:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Pieter SlabbertÂ Hi, We are are going to be using clara rules at work, the example at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_fn_perf/ looks like it will be very useful for part of our system. There are many facts that we will use records for, but there is one kind of fact in particular which we have many different instances of the same fact but each with a different status (there can be quite a few of these statuses) Ideally we don't want to create a new type for each of these statuses. So I would like to be able to create a tuple as shown in the link, but I would also need to be able to write other conditions on it. There is a hint of how to do it on the page right at the bottom, but I can't seem to figure it out. Would anyone be able to provide a fleshed out example with extra conditions?
#2020-06-08Â 14:07:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Felix HolmgrenÂ Hi everyone! ðŸ‘‹ I just (finally) published a podcast interview I did with @ryanbrush two years ago, about Clara. I would think most of it is still as relevant, but if Clara has changed in ways that make what's said in the interview misleading I'd be happy to include pointers in the show notes. In any case, I would of course welcome any feedback/criticism from this community! https://thesearch.space/episodes/2-ryan-brush-on-retaking-rules-for-developers
#2020-06-08Â 16:46:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @blob626 youâ€™ve seen this one too http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ ?
#2020-06-08Â 16:47:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the one you linked was more about performance than the feature use itself
#2020-06-08Â 18:28:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @blob626, If I remember correctly you should be able to apply constraints to a condition even when using a custom fact type. However, the syntactic sugar that clara provides for field accessors would no longer be available. Meaning that you would have to provide custom destructuring for the fact or have the constraints access the fact via this and drill in that way. For example: 
(ns test.rules
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]))


(defrecord SomeFact [id status another-identifier])

(defrecord IncompleteFact [id])

(r/defrule a-rule
  [[SomeFact "id-1"] [{:keys [another-identifier status]}]
    (= ?another-identifier another-identifier)
    (= status "INCOMPLETE")]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->IncompleteFact ?another-identifier)))

(r/defquery get-incomplete-facts
  []
  [?f <- IncompleteFact])

(defn fact-type-fn
  [fact]
  (if (instance? SomeFact fact)
    [`SomeFact (:id fact)]
    (type fact))) 

(defn run-test
  []
  (-> (r/mk-session [a-rule get-incomplete-facts]
                    :fact-type-fn fact-type-fn)
      (r/insert (->SomeFact "id-1" "INCOMPLETE" "external-id"))
      (r/fire-rules)
      (r/query get-incomplete-facts)))
Specifically, 
[{:keys [another-identifier status]}]
#2020-06-08Â 19:56:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â apbleonardÂ Clara Rules has a mention in Rich Hickey's HOPL IV "A History of Clojure" paper! ðŸ™‚ https://clojure.org/about/history

  [SomeRecord  (= ?list-of-ids list-of-ids)]
  =>
  (for [id ?list-of-ids]
    (insert! (->Addition id :some-key "icecream"))))

#2020-06-21Â 16:00:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickÂ Hey all I was wondering if there is a simpler way to rewrite this? 
(defrule calc-total-sum
  [?total1 <- (acc/reduce-to-accum (fn [previous value]
                                     (+ previous (get-amount value)))
                                   0
                                   ) :from [Record1]]
  [?total2 <- (acc/reduce-to-accum (fn [previous value]
                                     (+ previous (get-amount value)))
                                   0
                                   ) :from [Record2]]
  =>
  (insert! (->TotalAmount (+ ?total1 ?total2))))
I have lots of record types like RecordN(in this simplified example) defrecord-s and all of them implement the same protocol(`get-amount` func) I'm trying to get the total amount for all those record types. Ideally this would be just a single reduce-to-accum with :from [Record1 Record2 ...] or :from [[Record1] [Record2] [...]] but it doesn't seem to work.
#2020-06-22Â 13:05:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mbraggÂ Have you seen http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/? This would allow you to match on the ancestor type and just have the single accumulator.
#2020-06-22Â 13:21:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ Another option would be to leverage interfaces and allow the default ancestors function to handle it. Something like: 
(ns test.interfaces
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(definterface Summable
  (^long amount []))


(defrecord RecordOne [x]
  Summable
  (amount [_] x))

(defrecord RecordTwo [y]
  Summable
  (amount [_] y))


(defrecord Sum [z])


(r/defrule sum-rule
  [?s <- (acc/sum #(.amount ^Summable %)) :from [Summable]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Sum ?s)))

(r/defquery sum-query
  []
  [?s <- Sum])

(defn run-test
  []
  (-> (r/mk-session)
      (r/insert (->RecordOne 1)
                (->RecordOne 2)
                (->RecordTwo 3)
                (->RecordTwo 4))
      (r/fire-rules)
      (r/query sum-query)))

;; (run-test)
;; => ({:?s #test.interfaces.Sum{:z 10}})
#2020-06-22Â 13:22:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ this assumes you own the definition of the records in the session. Otherwise, @mbragg solution would likely be easier
#2020-06-22Â 13:53:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ cc. @nfedyashev
#2020-06-22Â 13:56:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â nickÂ @mbragg @ethanc Perfect! Thank you so much

#2020-06-29Â 19:35:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Thatâ€™s your smoothest path forward.
