#2020-06-29Â 19:59:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Thanks @mbragg and @mikerod -- I'll take a look at these things.
#2020-06-29Â 21:23:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Agreed that if you need to pull out facts, targeted queries are probably the way to go. You could write a query that would match all facts e.g. against Object on the JVM, but the performance impact of that could be significant. You might consider whether you actually need multiple sessions though - what is the motivation there as opposed to having the facts youâ€™re extracting trigger those rules in the same session? You could use a design pattern where you have subsets of your system that have â€œprivateâ€ facts that by convention are only used in say a particular namespace, and â€œglueâ€ facts that connect different parts. It is highly domain-dependent but thatâ€™s a pattern Iâ€™ve used before. @matthew.pettis
#2020-06-30Â 13:13:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ @wparker Thanks for this. At this point, I am honestly just exploring, and thinking more about the ability to see the complete state of a session after starting with an initial fact set and seeing what all gets generated by firing the rules. I'm thinking more about a diagnostic to just dump a session and being able to talk through with someone "If you start with these rules and this initial fact set, this is the final set of facts that end up in the session." Starting with that fact set and triggering another set of rules was just a thought experiment, but looking at a given state thoroughly was the main driver. The session use cases I can think of probably won't be all that large in terms of facts, or at least initial facts, but might get a lot of derived facts with the rule set I put into the session. I like the "private" and "glue" facts approach... I was thinking along the lines of "initial" and "derived" facts from rules, and comparing those two sets.
#2020-07-01Â 05:27:39Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â macÂ Is there an idiomatic way to do hierarchical rules in clara? I have a set of rules that all calculate the same property from a fact but I would like the calculation only to be made by the most specific of the rules that match. I have tried inserting a guard fact when a rule (e.g. [:not [:guard (= (:active this) true] and (insert! {:type guard :active true} ) matches and using salience to control firing order, but this results in an endless loop for reasons I cannot figure out.
#2020-07-01Â 10:00:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â macÂ As an example I don't understand why the code below goes into an endless loop. 
(defrule test-rule
    "test guard"
    [:not [:guard (= (:active this) true)]]
    =>
    (do
      (println "Inserting guard!")
      (insert! {:type :guard :active true})))
  (-> (mk-session [test-rule]
                  :fact-type-fn :type)
      (fire-rules))
#2020-07-01Â 11:06:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mac use a different guard type for each tier
#2020-07-01Â 11:06:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Where the rule never inserts itâ€™s own type
#2020-07-01Â 11:12:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mac https://gist.github.com/mrrodriguez/6a6f8373b25d69826b3efe154c928fac this actually has a somewhat similar model as well. For a slightly different goal but notice the guarding not conditions
#2020-07-01Â 11:19:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â macÂ @mikerod Thanks, the gist looks very useful. Do you know why my example would loop?
#2020-07-01Â 11:30:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @mac the rules attempt to find a logical consistency balance
#2020-07-01Â 11:30:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Your rule Left side condition is invalidated when the right side inserts.
#2020-07-01Â 11:31:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ The engine then retracts thatâ€™s fact because it is no longer logically supported.
#2020-07-01Â 11:31:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s called the truth maintenance system
#2020-07-01Â 11:31:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Then it can activate again and re insert. And again it invalidates itself. So itâ€™s logical looping
#2020-07-01Â 11:35:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â macÂ @mikerod OK, so the guard gets removed because the LHS match that caused it to be inserted no longer matches?
#2020-07-01Â 12:39:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yes
#2020-07-01Â 12:39:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Think of rules not like in order. But instead that the rhs facts inserted are supported by the lhs
#2020-07-01Â 14:07:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â macÂ @mikerod Got it, this is much closer to logic programming than I thought, but it makes sense when framed like that.
#2020-07-08Â 21:47:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Regarding fact-type customization, from here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/fact_type_options.clj
#2020-07-08Â 21:49:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Can someone explain how this works to find ancestors?
#2020-07-08Â 21:49:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ (def custom-ancestors-fn {:precise-temperature-reading #{:temperature-reading}})
#2020-07-08Â 21:50:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ I get that a map can work in the function position, and will look up the value for a key given as argument, but I am struggling to see how this def works as a function to look up ancestors.
#2020-07-09Â 14:12:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The def itself isnâ€™t special, its just handed off to the mk-session call. Unless I am miss interpreting your question
#2020-07-09Â 14:16:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @matthew.pettis I think I donâ€™t know exactly what you are asking either, but perhaps you are just trying to understand what the ancestors fn does?
#2020-07-09Â 14:16:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it takes a type, and returns a set of ancestors
#2020-07-09Â 14:16:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ And in rules, a type T matches any rule type that is the same type T or any ancestor in the set of ancestors of T - as returned from ancestors fn
#2020-07-09Â 14:17:36Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the docs http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ here seem to explain this with an example though - so not sure this is where you the confusion is
#2020-07-09Â 14:18:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ > I get that a map can work in the function position, and will look up the value for a key given as argument, but I am struggling to see how this def works as a function to look up ancestors. A map is a fn of 1 argument. It looks no different from the callers perspective. So the clara-rules engine has a fact with type T, it looks up ancestors like: (ancestors-fn T) which returns the ancestor types
#2020-07-09Â 14:19:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ in pure clj with the above example: 
(let [ancestors-fn {:precise-temperature-reading #{:temperature-reading}}]
  (ancestors-fn :precise-temperature-reading))
;;= #{:temperature-reading}}
#2020-07-09Â 14:51:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ @mikerod Thanks, I think that what you said is enough for me. The missing thing for me, which I understand from your code snipped, is that it interacts with the fact-type-function. That is, it seems that first the fact-type-function is used to get a value, and then that value (like :precise-temperature-reading), and then that is the argument to the ancestor-fn, which returns a set of ancestors that the argument belongs to, and then rules that use any of those ancestors are considered. I was trying to figure out how that ancestor-fn could be applied directly to the the fact, instead of the result of the fact-type-function applied to the fact.
#2020-07-09Â 14:52:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ So, in short, I was missing that ancestor-fn operated on the result of fact-type-fn, not on the original fact itself, which I couldn't see how that would work.
#2020-07-09Â 15:05:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ yes exactly!
#2020-07-16Â 21:16:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sekaoÂ is there any way, either with the public API or with private stuff, that i can determine which fact(s) caused a rule to fire? something that i could check in the right hand side of a rule. i tried looking in clara.rules.engine/**rule-context** but the :token inside it seems to contain all matching facts, not just the ones that triggered the rule.
#2020-07-16Â 23:13:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @sekao if you use a fact level binding you have the fact available as a binding on rhs
#2020-07-16Â 23:14:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ [?fact <- Something] =>
#2020-07-16Â 23:44:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sekaoÂ yes but what i'm hoping to figure out is which of the bound facts actually caused the rule to fire. so if i have three facts bound on the lhs, in the rhs i want to know which of the three caused the current execution. i'm guessing this info is not available anywhere?
#2020-07-16Â 23:46:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sekaoÂ during the first execution the answer will be "all three caused it to fire", but if i insert a new fact that matches the first binding, for example, the rule will execute a second time, and i want to know that the first binding was what caused that second execution.
#2020-07-17Â 12:12:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @sekao each time there is a match itâ€™s a new rule firing. The cause is whatever the combination of facts it was to cause the rule to fire.
#2020-07-17Â 12:13:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Seems an odd thing you are trying to distinguish.
#2020-07-17Â 15:48:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sekaoÂ fair enough. the reason i'm interested in this is that it would potentially be a way to make updating facts within rules more ergonomic (avoiding the infinite loop problem). but it may not fit how clara works underneath.
#2020-07-17Â 17:12:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @sekao Iâ€™d encourage you read http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html
#2020-07-17Â 17:12:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I wrote it a while ago but it was an attempt to basically dump as much info I could on the updating facts concept and how it interacts with clara and in general the automatic truth maintenance system model (which is what allows rules to be order independently expressed etc)

#2020-07-18Â 18:29:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @matthewlisp, Clara is pretty flexible with the terminology of fact, clara provides extension points(fact-type-fn & ancestors-fn) to allow users to define their own â€œfactsâ€ or whatever that means to their system. Iâ€™m having trouble visualizing the sort of system that you described with the state map above, perhaps you could provide a small example?
#2020-07-29Â 00:37:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Are there examples of using things like multiple insert! calls, or insert! inside of an if-let on the RHS of a rule? Or reasons why that isn't allowed? I'll try once back at a computer, but I wanted to ask in case there was something obvious I should know.
#2020-07-29Â 13:43:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ The rhs of a rule is inside an implicit let block, so it should allow for multiple inserts: 
(defrule rule-name
  <lhs>
  =>
  (insert! <fact1>)
  (insert! <fact2>))
https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/main/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L454-L456 The RHS can be arbitrary clojure code, so if-lets would be fine. Though as a word of warning, donâ€™t do stateful things in the RHS of a rule as it can lead to weird side effects.
#2020-07-29Â 13:50:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Thanks! Warning taken. I'm trying to put together a framework like the 'sensors' example in the https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples repo. I haven't worked out how I want it structured yet, but I know I want to trigger using a function to compute something based on the presence of facts, and then conditionally insert another fact based on what that function returns. Something like, "if these two facts exist, do this computation on them. If that computation yields a certain result (like a constraint violation) insert a fact that records the constraint violation. Otherwise, don't insert a fact." I'm not sure if good practice is to that computation on the LHS of the rules as a precondition, and then the RHS will trigger if result passes a test, or to do that check totally on the RHS.
#2020-07-29Â 17:59:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ As mike has mentioned(outside of this thread) LHS is probably the ideal place for this sort of logic. We can continue that conversation there. :)

#2020-07-29Â 13:59:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Here's some pseudocode of what I am trying to decide between, not sure if both are even feasible or, as noted here, advisable:
#2020-07-29Â 13:59:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
;; pseudocode for a lhs computation.  I'm not sure how to compute ?c here syntactically, if possible at all.
(defrule lhs-pseudocode
 [?a <- ConditionA]
 [?b <- ConditionB]
 ;; [?c <- compute a function return value (check-function ?a ?b)]
 ;; [:test ?c is truthy]
 =>
 (insert! (->ExceptionFact ?c)))


;; pseudocode for a rhs check
(defrule rhs-pseudocode
 [?a <- ConditionA]
 [?b <- ConditionB]
 =>
 (let [c (check-function ?a ?b)]
  (when (truthy c)
   (insert! (->ExceptionFact c)))))
#2020-07-29Â 14:05:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Iâ€™d add itâ€™s generally not good to do conditional things in RHS. The rules themselves are meant to capture the conditional flows
#2020-07-29Â 14:05:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I generally find it an anti pattern for the RHS to â€œmaybe do some insertâ€
#2020-07-29Â 14:05:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ There are exceptions
#2020-07-29Â 14:06:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ But above , youâ€™d be better off using a :test node on LHS

#2020-07-29Â 14:19:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ The one way I thought to get around that was to not check conditions at all in the rules, but always insert a fact with the results of the computation I want to do, and that record has the result. And then, during a query, I can filter out those new records based on some flag/indicator field of the result. That seems like I potentially put more facts into the session than are necessary.
#2020-07-29Â 14:20:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Another thought I was to follow up what I did above, but then add another rule that prunes facts that don't have a certain value in an indicator field -- like a cleanup rule. #2020-08-06Â 15:39:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So itâ€™s not represented as a var. so :require + :refer wonâ€™t work.
#2020-08-06Â 15:39:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s somewhat unfortunate. In CLJS you actually can refer to them as non-interop style symbols.
#2020-08-06Â 15:41:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So something like. : `(:import [ clara_rules_test.parent_rules_split_ns.rule_records MyFirstRecordOne MyFirstRecordTwo])`
#2020-08-06Â 15:41:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Not also the need for underscores instead of hyphens. Again. Thatâ€™s the java interop part. Cannot have hyphens in class names on JVM so clj converts them (called â€œmunchingâ€) to underscores.

#2020-08-11Â 16:21:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â defndainesÂ We have a hook to turn on explain-activations, but we rarely use it. We accumulate data in each of our facts that helps with all of our debugging. We also capture all of the input to the sessions, so we can reproduce a session for debugging in order to analyze.
#2020-08-11Â 16:22:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ thank you! thatâ€™s super helpful
#2020-08-11Â 19:24:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So a session is immutable.
#2020-08-11Â 19:24:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I would necessarily recommend making a new session when speed is important or it is slower due to many rules

#2020-08-11Â 19:27:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ This is also assuming the rule set is unchanged per use.

#2020-08-12Â 15:12:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Does Clara do better with [Object (= n ?n) (odd? n)] than [Object (= n ?n)] [:test (odd? n)]? (In other words, does it filter before working memory in the previous case?)
#2020-08-12Â 18:30:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I believe that the first example would compile the odd? constraint into the alpha node, where as the second would have test node after the AlphaNode. I donâ€™t believe that either of these nodes add anything to working memory, following nodes might though.
#2020-08-12Â 18:34:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â eraserhdÂ Hmm, I omitted that I expect there to be another hash-join field on Object.
#2020-08-12Â 19:20:30Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ with the hashJoin between the alpha and the test, then i would expect moving the odd? constraint to the alpha node to likely reduce some of the objects being placed into working memory. How much savings it would produce I cannot say.
#2020-08-31Â 13:54:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Pieter SlabbertÂ I have sample code that I'm trying to figure out the best way to fix. 
(defrecord ThingA [id data])
(defrecord ThingB [k])

(defrule broken
  [ThingB
   (= ?k k)]
  [ThingA
   (= ?id id)
   (= ?data data)
   (= ?entry (-> data :items (get ?k)))
   (some? ?entry)]
  =>
  (println "entry" ?entry))

(-> (rules/mk-session)
    (rules/insert (->ThingA 1 {:items {:entry {:a 1 :b 2}}}))
    (rules/insert (->ThingB :entry))
    (rules/fire-rules))
When I run this I get 
Execution error at clara.rules.compiler/try-eval (compiler.clj:233).
Unable to resolve symbol: ?entry in this context
If I hard code the value of ?k it works, but it when I try get it from another fact I get the error. What would be the proper way to extract a field from one fact and use it to look something up in another fact

#2020-09-07Â 13:42:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ What would be the most efficient way to get notified when results of a specific query have changed?
#2020-09-11Â 08:22:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara computes query results upfront; when you call (query session â€¦.) youâ€™re basically just doing map lookups. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/main/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1998 So I donâ€™t think different ways of doing this would have much difference in terms of performance; youâ€™d probably want something that stores the previous state, calls query on the session, and then compares them.
#2020-09-11Â 22:59:38Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ I was thinking more in terms of getting notified per query only when the results changed. I'll look at doing it with a listener.
#2020-09-11Â 08:28:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â wparkerÂ Clara-rules version 0.21.0 has been released and is available on Clojars. This release primarily has improvements to error reporting and inspectability along with a minor bugfix where exceptions could be thrown on certain Java object fact types. Further details at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md#0210
#2020-09-17Â 02:39:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Is there a way to import defrec definitions from another namespace to use in a rules session? I want to modularize my rules, queries, and record definitions into different namespaces, and am having troubles getting the definitons/objects recognized in a rules session. Below is a the most stripped-down example I could make that I cannot figure out...
#2020-09-17Â 02:39:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
user=> (ns a
  #_=>   "Has the record definitions")
nil
a=> (defrecord MyRec [nm])
a.MyRec


a=> (ns b
#_=>     "Has the logic to run the clara rules session"
#_=>     (:require
#_=>         [clara.rules :as r]
#_=>         [a :as nsa])
#_=>     (:import (a MyRec))
#_=> )
nil


b=> (r/defrule therec
#_=>   "Has a MyRec record"
#_=>   [?r <- nsa/MyRec]
#_=>   =>
#_=>   (r/insert! (nsa/->MyRec :output)))
#'b/therec


b=> (r/defquery qrec
#_=>   []
#_=>   [?e <- nsa/MyRec])
#'b/qrec


b=> (def sess (r/mk-session))
Syntax error (ClassNotFoundException) compiling at (form-init1616251358278573848.clj:1:11).
MyRec
#2020-09-17Â 02:47:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @matthew.pettis, i believe that you would want to remove the alias qualifier from the conditions of the query and the rule. nsa/MyRec would instead be MyRec
#2020-09-17Â 02:49:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
user=> (ns a
  #_=>   "Has the record definitions")
nil
a=> (defrecord MyRec [nm])
a.MyRec


a=> (ns b
#_=>     "Has the logic to run the clara rules session"
#_=>     (:require
#_=>         [clara.rules :as r]
#_=>         [a :as nsa])
#_=>     (:import (a MyRec))
#_=> )
nil


b=> (r/defrule therec
#_=>   "Has a MyRec record"
#_=>   [?r <- MyRec]
#_=>   =>
#_=>   (r/insert! (->MyRec :output)))
#'b/therec


b=> (r/defquery qrec
#_=>   []
#_=>   [?e <- MyRec])
#'b/qrec


b=> (def sess (r/mk-session))
Syntax error compiling at (form-init2860030196736207126.clj:1:11).
Unable to resolve symbol: ->MyRec in this context
#2020-09-17Â 02:50:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Different error message though... I keep trying permutations and am having a hard time tracking what each means...
#2020-09-17Â 02:51:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ you would still want to qualify the position based constructor function in the RHS of the rule
#2020-09-17Â 02:54:49Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ ah, right, the difference makes sense. That fixed the error messages, thanks! But I'm getting an empty query result, but I expect to find two facts with the query... any advice there?
#2020-09-17Â 02:54:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
b=> (ns a
#_=>   "Has the record definitions")
nil
a=> (defrecord MyRec [nm])
a.MyRec


a=> (ns b
#_=>     "Has the logic to run the clara rules session"
#_=>     (:require
#_=>         [clara.rules :as r]
#_=>         [a :as nsa])
#_=>     (:import (a MyRec))
#_=> )
nil


b=> (r/defrule therec
#_=>   "Has a MyRec record"
#_=>   [?r <- MyRec]
#_=>   =>
#_=>   (r/insert! (nsa/->MyRec :output)))
#'b/therec


b=> (r/defquery qrec
#_=>   []
#_=>   [?e <- MyRec])
#'b/qrec


b=> (def sess (r/mk-session))
#'b/sess


b=> (let [qsess (-> sess
#_=>                (r/insert-all (nsa/->MyRec :init))
#_=>                r/fire-rules
#_=>                (r/query qrec))]
#_=>   qsess)
()
#2020-09-17Â 02:58:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ (But I see that that is not related to my namespace issue... I'm doing something wrong with just basic rules, I think...)
#2020-09-17Â 02:58:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ insert-all in this case is assuming that you passed a list and is probably breaking the record down into a list of keyvalue pairs
#2020-09-17Â 02:59:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ (r/insert-all [(nsa/->MyRec :init)])
#2020-09-17Â 02:59:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ however this will cause an infinite loop do to therec inserting a fact that then triggers itself
#2020-09-17Â 02:59:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ *due
#2020-09-17Â 03:00:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ ach, yeah, i copied that over from a place where I was inserting a list, thanks for the catch!
#2020-09-17Â 03:08:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ For posterity, here is a working example where I'm importing the defrec from another namespace... And thank you @ethanc for the great help!
#2020-09-17Â 03:08:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
user=> (ns a
  #_=>   "Has the record definitions")
nil
a=> (defrecord MyRec [nm])
a.MyRec


a=> (ns b
#_=>     "Has the logic to run the clara rules session"
#_=>     (:require
#_=>         [clara.rules :as r]
#_=>         [a :as nsa])
#_=>     (:import (a MyRec))
#_=> )
nil


b=> (r/defrule therec
#_=>   "Has a MyRec record"
#_=>   [?r <- MyRec (= :nm :init)]
#_=>   =>
#_=>   (r/insert! (nsa/->MyRec :output)))
#'b/therec


b=> (r/defquery qrec
#_=>   []
#_=>   [?e <- MyRec])
#'b/qrec


b=> (def sess (r/mk-session))
#'b/sess


b=> (let [qsess (-> sess
#_=>                (r/insert-all [(nsa/->MyRec :init)])
#_=>                r/fire-rules
#_=>                (r/query qrec))]
#_=>   qsess)
({:?e #a.MyRec{:nm :init}})
#2020-09-17Â 03:24:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Ok, so I tried splitting defrec, rules, and queries up into their own namespace, and run a session in a namespace separate from those three. With the help above, I was able to not get errors. But in the final query, I expect to see a single Outp record, but the query gives me (). It should be a simple step from what I did above, but I'm not seeing where I went wrong... UPDATE: Below, my rules LHS tried to match the record field as a symbol, not as a symbol. Fixing below, see update further down.
#2020-09-17Â 03:24:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
rules-engine.core=> (ns rules-engine.rec-defs
               #_=>   "Records to use in rules")
nil

rules-engine.rec-defs=> (defrecord Inp [nm])
rules_engine.rec_defs.Inp
rules-engine.rec-defs=> (defrecord Outp [nm])
rules_engine.rec_defs.Outp



rules-engine.rec-defs=> (ns rules-engine.rules
                   #_=>   "Rules to import"
                   #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                   #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd])
                   #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Inp Outp))
                   #_=>   )
nil


rules-engine.rules=> (r/defrule has-inp
                #_=>   "Has a Inp record"
                #_=>   [?r <- Inp (= :nm :init)]
                #_=>   =>
                #_=>   (r/insert! (rd/->Outp :output)))
#'rules-engine.rules/has-inp



rules-engine.rules=> (ns rules-engine.queries
                #_=>   "Queries"
                #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd])
                #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Inp Outp)))
nil

rules-engine.queries=> (r/defquery all-outp
                  #_=>   []
                  #_=>   [?e <- Outp])
#'rules-engine.queries/all-outp



rules-engine.queries=> (ns rules-engine.run-it
                  #_=>   "Main script to run a rules set"
                  #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.rules :as rl]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.queries :as q]
                  #_=>             )
                  #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Inp Outp))
                  #_=>   )
nil


rules-engine.run-it=> (def sess (r/mk-session 'rules-engine.rules 'rules-engine.queries))
#'rules-engine.run-it/sess

rules-engine.run-it=> (let [qsess (-> sess
                 #_=>                (r/insert-all [(rd/->Inp :init)])
                 #_=>                r/fire-rules
                 #_=>                (r/query q/all-outp))]
                 #_=>   qsess)
()
#2020-09-17Â 03:43:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Well, I know it is my logic, not the namespace stuff... this version works, I'll work on the one above...
#2020-09-17Â 03:43:22Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
rules-engine.run-it=> (ns rules-engine.rec-defs
                 #_=>   "Records to use in rules")
nil
rules-engine.rec-defs=>

rules-engine.rec-defs=> (defrecord Myrec [nm])
rules_engine.rec_defs.Myrec



rules-engine.rec-defs=> (ns rules-engine.rules
                   #_=>   "Rules to import"
                   #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                   #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd])
                   #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Myrec)))
nil

rules-engine.rules=> (r/defrule has-inp
                #_=>   "Has a Inp record"
                #_=>   [?r <- Myrec (= :nm :init)]
                #_=>   =>
                #_=>   (r/insert! (rd/->Myrec :output)))
#'rules-engine.rules/has-inp



rules-engine.rules=> (ns rules-engine.queries
                #_=>   "Queries"
                #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd])
                #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Myrec)))
nil

rules-engine.queries=> (r/defquery all-outp
                  #_=>   []
                  #_=>   [?e <- Myrec])
#'rules-engine.queries/all-outp

rules-engine.queries=> (ns rules-engine.run-it
                  #_=>   "Main script to run a rules set"
                  #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.rules :as rl]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.queries :as q]
                  #_=>             )
                  #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Myrec)))
nil

rules-engine.run-it=> (def sess (r/mk-session 'rules-engine.rules 'rules-engine.queries))
#'rules-engine.run-it/sess

rules-engine.run-it=> (let [qsess (-> sess
                 #_=>                (r/insert-all [(rd/->Myrec :init)])
                 #_=>                r/fire-rules
                 #_=>                (r/query q/all-outp))]
                 #_=>   qsess)
({:?e #rules_engine.rec_defs.Myrec{:nm :init}})
#2020-09-17Â 03:56:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ Fixed session from above:
#2020-09-17Â 03:56:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ 
rules-engine.run-it=> (ns rules-engine.rec-defs
                 #_=>   "Records to use in rules")
nil

rules-engine.rec-defs=> (defrecord Inp [nm])
rules_engine.rec_defs.Inp
rules-engine.rec-defs=> (defrecord Outp [nm])
rules_engine.rec_defs.Outp
rules-engine.rec-defs=>



rules-engine.rec-defs=> (ns rules-engine.rules
                   #_=>   "Rules to import"
                   #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                   #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd])
                   #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Inp Outp))
                   #_=>   )
nil

rules-engine.rules=> (r/defrule has-inp
                #_=>   "Has a Inp record"
                #_=>   [?r <- Inp (= nm :init)]
                #_=>   =>
                #_=>   (r/insert! (rd/->Outp :output)))
#'rules-engine.rules/has-inp



rules-engine.rules=> (ns rules-engine.queries
                #_=>   "Queries"
                #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd])
                #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Inp Outp)))
nil

rules-engine.queries=> (r/defquery all-outp
                  #_=>   []
                  #_=>   [?e <- Outp])
#'rules-engine.queries/all-outp

rules-engine.queries=> (r/defquery all-inp
                  #_=>   []
                  #_=>   [?e <- Inp])
#'rules-engine.queries/all-inp



rules-engine.queries=> (ns rules-engine.run-it
                  #_=>   "Main script to run a rules set"
                  #_=>   (:require [clara.rules :as r]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.rec-defs :as rd]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.rules :as rl]
                  #_=>             [rules-engine.queries :as q]
                  #_=>             )
                  #_=>   (:import (rules_engine.rec_defs Inp Outp)))
nil

rules-engine.run-it=> (def sess (r/mk-session 'rules-engine.rules 'rules-engine.queries))
#'rules-engine.run-it/sess

rules-engine.run-it=> (let [qsess (-> sess
                 #_=>                (r/insert-all [(rd/->Inp :init)])
                 #_=>                r/fire-rules
                 #_=>                (r/query q/all-outp))]
                 #_=>   qsess)
({:?e #rules_engine.rec_defs.Outp{:nm :output}})
#2020-09-17Â 17:38:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @matthew.pettis itâ€™s just clj rules here for how you refer to record types
#2020-09-17Â 17:38:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ in cljs you use nsâ€™s and aliases like your stuff above
#2020-09-17Â 17:38:31Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ in clj (unfortunately), you have to use interop
#2020-09-17Â 17:39:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so the actual :import class symbols
#2020-09-17Â 17:39:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ nothing from a :require + :as etc
#2020-09-17Â 17:41:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ @mikerod Thanks. Yep, I hit this problem once before (I think I posted it here too)... The way I am currently thinking about it is: for rules that do matching on the LHS, I need to import the classes with :import. When I want to construct a record I need to insert on the RHS, with ->Myrecord, I need to require the namespace from which I have my defrecord declaration so I have that constructor. Does that seem right?
#2020-09-17Â 17:52:29Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @matthew.pettis I do not like it. I think when writing non-interop clj, things like :import should not be necessary at all
#2020-09-17Â 17:52:41Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I donâ€™t like that Clara basically enforces this needing to be done for records
#2020-09-17Â 17:53:02Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Clj does offer some â€œfactory functionsâ€ it auto-creates with defrecord - which allows you to not have to use interop forms to create records
#2020-09-17Â 17:53:20Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ What clj does not offer, is how to refer to records in a way without interop (eg. :import)
#2020-09-17Â 17:53:34Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ More frustrating to me, is CLJS does allow you to refer to record types via :require + :as
#2020-09-17Â 17:54:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so this causes lots of additional problems with say , making cljc files where you want to use :as aliases, but then records need to be specified different ways for :clj vs :cljs
#2020-09-17Â 17:54:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so thatâ€™s some background. I donâ€™t know what exactly Clara should/could do here to help. However, Claraâ€™s compilation has control over symbol resolution so itâ€™s likely something could be done to allow for no :import to be needed
#2020-09-17Â 17:55:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ I think probably, Clara could attempt to support the cljs style record syntax
#2020-09-17Â 17:55:23Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ like a/MyRec
#2020-09-17Â 17:55:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and just implicitly know to resolve it in clj following some rules like: 1) first see if a/MyRec exists 2) if not, try a.MyRec1
#2020-09-17Â 17:56:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ this could be convenient for Claraâ€™s perspective. it would deviate from the perspective of what clj actually allows
#2020-09-17Â 17:56:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so thereâ€™s a pro vs con
#2020-09-17Â 18:03:14Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ That would be nice to not have the interop require vs. import split, as it seems a typical rules pattern is to have record class referenced in the LHS, and needs to construct and insert a record on the RHS, which needs the constructor via require. It took me a while to suss out the difference, and a post by Alex Miller (which I can't find today) helped me understand it a bit more. I considered going down to the plain maps workflow and not using records, which would take care of this issue, and I assume people who don't use records make code that should mostly run in either CLJ or CLJS.
#2020-09-17Â 18:06:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ But I'll say that Clara still seems to have better semantics and usability than other solutions I've tried. durable_rules from jruizgit at github works, but not for my use case, where I like the concept of queries that can return me the facts in the session, which durable_rules does not in theory (jruiz made a function to do so after a an issue I filed, but it appears to still have some bugs).
#2020-09-17Â 18:06:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Nice that Clara has worked better for you!
#2020-09-17Â 18:06:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and I really wish clj would have supported non-interop ways to refer to records
#2020-09-17Â 18:06:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ itâ€™s much nicer in cljs
#2020-09-17Â 18:07:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you will see in clara-rules test nsâ€™s we have a lot of cljc stuff. And youâ€™ll see a lot of read-conditionals around the difference between having to use :require in cljs for records, vs :import for clj
#2020-09-17Â 18:07:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but yeah, feel free to log a clara-rules github issue if you want to propose allowing the syntactic forms perhaps
#2020-09-17Â 18:08:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ the only thing I donâ€™t like as much as it differs from how clj resolves symbols
#2020-09-17Â 18:08:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ but we do that in other ways throughout forms as well - so maybe not that big of a deal
#2020-09-17Â 18:08:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and records can be quite convenient over maps (although both are supported)
#2020-09-17Â 18:08:50Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ records have another benefit in that clara compiler will â€œunderstand field referencesâ€
#2020-09-17Â 18:09:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so you can do like [MyRec (= ?x x)] where x is a field on MyRec
#2020-09-17Â 18:09:47Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you used a map, youâ€™d have to do [:my-rec (= ?x (;x this))] (assuming your map used the clara default type impl to produce that :my-rec type)
#2020-09-17Â 18:10:25Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ in disclosure, I am not so much a programmer as a data scientist with some ability to code, and I have a some applications I can really see rules engine bridging for me, so I am learning Clojure and Clara mostly at the same time. I say that so when you see crazy recommendations from me, you'll take it with a grain of salt.
#2020-09-17Â 18:10:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and lastly, records can have some efficiency gains where some cases that may matter
#2020-09-17Â 18:12:40Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Matthew PettisÂ yeah, that's why I like the records approach -- it seemed like a much more comprehensible syntax to make rules with. I haven't had to address performance yet, as my rulesets are not that large, and probably won't be for what I am envisioning.
#2020-09-22Â 16:45:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â yendaÂ Is there a way to have async code in the LHS of a rule? It looks like because a go block returns immediately, if one tries to insert! a fact in the go block on the LHS of a rule, the insert throws an error because the context is gone
#2020-09-22Â 18:52:19Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ Pretty sure the answer is "no". Why do you want a go-block in the LHS? Maybe there's another way to accomplish what you need.

#2020-10-16Â 14:50:52Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ this is what it does to scan built-in
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so specifically for vars
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you have meta : :rule, :query, or :production-seq
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:53Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ it is treated as a rule container of some sort
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ :rule and :query are a single rule/query
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ :production-seq is a collection of rules/queries - aka â€œproductionsâ€
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you donâ€™t need macros
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ and you donâ€™t need vars
#2020-10-16Â 14:50:56Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you have a more data-oriented case
#2020-10-16Â 14:51:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ mk-session takes collections of rule/query (aka production) structures

#2020-10-16Â 14:53:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ you see they are almost all just based on passing rule/query maps in a collection to mk-session
#2020-10-16Â 14:53:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ so this is probably all you are really looking for
#2020-10-16Â 14:53:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ vars with metadata are basically just a convenience
#2020-10-16Â 14:53:51Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ for automatic rule/query detection in namespaces
#2020-10-16Â 14:54:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ which works better for cases where you are more statically writing rules via macros/DSL

#2020-10-18Â 14:37:06Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ i.e if I have 
(defrule foo
  [HighCardinality (= foo ?foo)]
  [LowCardinality (= foo ?foo)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Foo ?name)))
does it matter for performance that HighCardinality is before LowCardinality?
#2020-10-18Â 17:41:59Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I don't believe it would impact performance. The cartesian product would be the same size I believe
#2020-10-18Â 19:04:09Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ okay, this one has me completely stumped: 
(defrecord Reachable [nodeType name])
(defrecord Node [nodeType area name])

(defrule area-reachability
  [Reachable (= nodeType :area) (= name ?area)]
  [Node (= area ?area) (= nodeType ?nodeType) (= name ?name)]
  ; [:not [Reachable (= nodeType ?nodeType) (= name ?name)]]
  =>
  (insert! (->Reachable ?nodeType ?name)))

(comment
  (-> (mk-session [area-reachability])
      (insert (->Reachable :area "World"))
      (insert (->Node :room "World" "Foo"))
      fire-rules))
#2020-10-18Â 19:04:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ as written it finishes instantly, if you uncomment the [:not ...] it goes into an infinite loop
#2020-10-18Â 19:11:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ the intent is to not insert the Reachable fact if itâ€™s already in the session
#2020-10-18Â 19:27:32Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Itâ€™s a commmon issue @schmee and you have to rethink the LHS to be in terms of whatâ€™s true about the entire state of the system
#2020-10-18Â 19:27:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ So with the :not above you are expressing a logical contradiction.
#2020-10-18Â 19:38:33Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ I see, could you elaborate a bit?
#2020-10-18Â 19:39:07Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ my mental model is that since the inserted node is not of nodeType :area, it will fail to match the first clause and hence the rule as a whole will not fire
#2020-10-18Â 19:39:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ but that canâ€™t be the case?
#2020-10-18Â 20:59:24Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ What Mkie is alluding to is clara's truth maintenance: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ With the not un-commented, the rule itself becomes a logical contradiction of itself. The rule will only execute and be considered true if the fact in question is not within the session. However, if the rule inserts a fact that itself asserts to be absent, then a loop would be formed. A base state would be a session without the fact in question, ergo the rule must insert the Fact. Then clara must assert that all truth has been maintained, and finds that the Fact is now present. Meaning that the Rule is no no longer true, thus a logical retraction occurs removing the Fact from the session. Then clara must asser that all truth has been maintained, again. However we are back to the base state meaning that there is no Fact within the session and the Rule is true again, thus the cycle repeats and continues forever. The wiki mentions ways to circumvent this mechanic using unconditional inserts, however these can lead to non-logical conclusions if assumptions are made.
#2020-10-18Â 21:09:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ thanks @ethanc, that clears things up quite a bit! Iâ€™ll take some time to ponder that and see if I can write the rule differently
#2020-10-18Â 21:11:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â schmeeÂ Iâ€™m coming into Clara with a Datomic mindset, which will surely trip me up a few times before I understand the â€œrule engine wayâ€
#2020-10-18Â 22:33:03Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â sparkofreasonÂ insert-uncondtional! is your friend here, if you want to have effects in the LHS of your rules. I find it easier to always use insert!, so that my rules are pure logic statements. When I want an effect, instead I insert a request fact, which is executed by some external component. That effect often invalidates the rule, thus causing the request to then be retracted by truth maintenance.
#2020-10-18Â 22:43:16Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Yeah. I avoid unconditional in most cases.
#2020-10-18Â 22:44:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ You typically can phrase the problem in a way that works with TMS. Often intermediate facts and accumulators in an aggregate rule can solve common situations.

#2020-10-20Â 16:20:05Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ @schmee Use an accumulator for the fact you actually want 1 of
#2020-10-20Â 16:20:10Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ if you have rules that may produce multiples
#2020-10-20Â 16:20:17Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ make an intermediate fact type to represent the multiple
#2020-10-20Â 16:20:26Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ then a single acumulator to aggregate it â€œdown to 1â€
#2020-10-20Â 16:20:46Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ this aggregation rule is you explicitly choosing how you want to represent or handle multiple supporting matches

#2020-11-02Â 00:13:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ hi, i get this issue on compiling a rules namespace. could anyone help me understand whatâ€™s wrong with my bindings? 
Malformed variable binding for #{?contract-provider ?claim-provider}. No associated value.
(defrule associated-contracts
  [:contract (= ?contract this)]
  [:contract (= ?contract-provider (:subject ?contract))]
  [:claim (= ?claim this)]
  [:claim (= ?claim-provider (-> ?claim
                                  :billing-provider
                                  :identifier
                                  :value))]
  [:associated? (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
  =>
  (insert! {:resource-type :associated-contract
            :claim ?claim
            :contract ?contract}))
#2020-11-02Â 00:14:28Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ iâ€™m using fact-type functions instead of clojure records but iâ€™m having trouble figuring out what are the right patterns
#2020-11-02Â 00:14:43Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ in this case i want to bind the entire object to either ?claim or ?contract
#2020-11-02Â 00:15:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ and i also want to bind nested variables in that map
#2020-11-02Â 00:20:00Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ I don't have repl open currently, but it looks like this might be because of the multiple conditions with similar fact types. rather than 2 conditions to bind contract and claim, i would assume that you might actually want a single condition for each. Something like: 
(defrule associated-contracts
  [:contract 
(= ?contract this)
(= ?contract-provider (:subject this))]
  [:claim 
 (= ?claim this)
(= ?claim-provider (-> this
                                  :billing-provider
                                  :identifier
                                  :value))]
  [:associated? (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
  =>
  (insert! {:resource-type :associated-contract
            :claim ?claim
            :contract ?contract}))
#2020-11-02Â 00:24:08Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ oh i see â€” thatâ€™s definitely a lot cleaner ðŸ™‚ itâ€™s still giving me that error though
#2020-11-02Â 00:31:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ hmmm, seems clara is incorrectly moving the joined conditional up in front of the binding itself. Specifially, 
[:associated? (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
#2020-11-02Â 00:31:54Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ however this condition seems odd to me, you are looking to a fact in the session but not asserting anything based on this fact
#2020-11-02Â 00:32:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ it almost seems as if that should be a test node: 
[:test (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
#2020-11-02Â 00:33:35Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ or potentially rolled up into the :claim condition itself
#2020-11-02Â 00:34:45Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ something like: 
(r/defrule associated-contracts
  [:contract
   (= ?contract this)
   (= ?contract-provider (:subject this))]
  [:claim
   (= ?claim this)
   (= (-> this
          :billing-provider
          :identifier
          :value)
      ?contract-provider)]
  =>
  (r/insert! {:resource-type :associated-contract
              :claim ?claim
              :contract ?contract}))
#2020-11-02Â 00:37:04Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ oh thatâ€™s totally it â€” iâ€™m trying to set it up to have the simple predicate comparing facts and i didnâ€™t realize that you had to name it :test in order for that to workâ€¦
#2020-11-02Â 00:37:44Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ would the above example give you ones that matched or all combinations of facts?
#2020-11-02Â 00:38:57Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ also how does querying for the fact-type-fn work? i tried the following: 
(defquery get-associated-contracts
  []
  [?associated-contract <- :associated-contract])
#2020-11-02Â 00:39:11Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ in the example above, the RHS should execute and insert a fact for each combination of a Claim and Contract that share the same provider
#2020-11-02Â 00:43:48Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ oh i see
#2020-11-02Â 00:43:55Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ thatâ€™s perfect! thank you so much!!
#2020-11-02Â 00:44:01Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ Queries should work the same way while using/not using an overridden fact-type-fn. For example: 
(defn test-session
  []
  (-> (r/mk-session :fact-type-fn :resource-type)
      (r/insert {:resource-type :contract :subject :Thomas})
      (r/insert {:resource-type :claim :billing-provider {:identifier {:value :Thomas}}})
      (r/fire-rules)
      (r/query get-associated-contracts)))
should net: 
({:?associated-contract {:resource-type :associated-contract,
                         :claim {:resource-type :claim, :billing-provider {:identifier {:value :Thomas}}},
                         :contract {:resource-type :contract, :subject :Thomas}}})
#2020-11-02Â 00:46:27Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â pandaÂ ooh i see â€” thank you! that makes sense

#2020-11-10Â 12:05:18Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ (BTW I don't expect to keep any facts within the session prior to manipulating it, I just want to be able to manipulate the rules prior to usage in some tests)
#2020-11-10Â 15:17:37Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â ethancÂ @narkisr, Clara does not currently support adding or removing productions from a compiled session. I believe that currently the only way to have a session with fewer rules would be to remake the session without providing the rules in question.
#2020-11-11Â 13:50:58Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â narkisrÂ Yeap thats the route iv went with (the session is stored in atom which makes it possible) thanks for help

#2020-11-17Â 22:44:13Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mikerodÂ Canâ€™t look now
